headings: Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act
explanations: Figure II.1 shows the trend of foreign direct investment (FDI) in India from FY96 to FY09. The graph shows that FDI increased significantly after the impetus to investment liberalisation in 2000-2003.

The Golden Quadrilateral project, the largest infrastructure project of independent India, was launched during the period between FY00 to FY03. The project led to enhanced connectivity, improved industrial activity, trade and economic growth.
To address the historic highs of the combined Gross fiscal deficit of the Government, the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) Act was passed during the period between FY00 to FY03.

To support the banking system, which had accumulated bad debts during the period of economic resurgence after the 1991 reforms, interest rates were deregulated during the period between FY00 to FY03. This move promoted competition amongst banks, provided more banking options to depositors, and strengthened monetary policy transmission.

The enactment of the SARFAESI Act 2002 allowed banks and financial institutions to recover their dues by proceeding against the secured assets of the borrower/guarantor without the intervention of the court/tribunals. This reform improved the credit situation in the economy.

Figure II.2 shows the trend of gross fiscal deficit (centre and states combined) from FY88 to FY08. The graph shows that the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) Act helped to address the historic highs of the combined Gross fiscal deficit of the Government.

Figure II.3 shows the growth in non-food credit by scheduled commercial banks from FY97 to FY21. The graph shows improvement in the credit situation in the economy after the deregulation of interest rates and implementation of the SARFAESI Act.
The article discusses India's growth outlook in the medium-term future with optimism despite the one-off shocks that overshadowed the reforms of 1998-2002.

The period between 1998-2002 witnessed a series of domestic and global shocks that subdued investor confidence in India; these included US sanctions, droughts, heightened global uncertainties, and balance sheet repairs of the financial and corporate sectors. Despite these challenges, the government undertook reforms that laid the groundwork for India's participation in the Global boom that followed soon after.

Following India's nuclear test, the US imposed sanctions that resulted in a sharp decline in capital flows to India in the months that followed. Monthly foreign direct investment in India came down in 1998.
The period between 2000 and 2002 witnessed two successive droughts in various parts of India that affected millions of people and caused significant damage.
During the same period, heightened global uncertainties resulted from the end of a tech boom and the 9/11 attacks.

The balance sheets of the Indian financial system and corporate sector were under-repair during the period of reforms, which further subdued investor confidence in India. However, the reforms laid the groundwork for India's participation in the Global boom that followed soon after.

headings: India’s participation in The Global Boom of 2003-08
Reforms for new India-sabka saath sabka Vikaas
Underlying framework for reforms for a new India
Focus on growth-centric aspects of reforms
explanations: During 2003-2008, while the global growth averaged 4.8 per cent, the Indian economy grew at more than 8 per cent on average. The economic growth during the period was supported by strong capital inflows, which indicated favourable domestic and external factors. Some of these included sustained momentum in domestic economic activity, better corporate performance, a conducive investment climate, positive sentiments for India as a preferred investment destination, and encouraging global liquidity conditions/ interest rates.

The reforms undertaken before 2014 primarily catered to product and capital market space. However, the government imparted a new dimension to these reforms in the last eight years. With an underlying emphasis on enhancing the ease of living and doing business and improving economic efficiency, the reforms are well placed to lift the economy’s potential growth. The broad principles behind the reforms were creating public goods, adopting trust-based governance, co-partnering with the private sector for development, and improving agricultural productivity. This approach reflects a paradigm shift in the growth and development strategy of the government, with the emphasis shifted towards building partnerships amongst various stakeholders in the development process, where each contributes to and reaps the development benefits.

The broad principles behind the reforms for a new India were creating public goods, adopting trust-based governance, co-partnering with the private sector for development, and improving agricultural productivity. This approach reflects a paradigm shift in the growth and development strategy of the government, with the emphasis shifted towards building partnerships amongst various stakeholders in the development process, where each contributes to and reaps the development benefits.
While the reforms undertaken in the post-2014 period have multiple socioeconomic benefits for the economy, this chapter focuses on the growth-centric aspects of these reforms.
The content talks about India's medium-term growth outlook and how the recently launched reform framework is contributing towards enhancing the productive potential of the economy and its people.

The first principle of the reform framework is creating public goods to enhance opportunities, efficiencies, and ease of living. The launch of the Golden Quadrilateral project in the 2000s was the beginning of infrastructure-intensive policymaking in India, which continued sedately for another decade. In the last few years, the government has taken a quantum leap in policy commitment and outlay for infrastructure, leading to the government's capital expenditure as a percentage of GDP on the rise. This has helped cushion economic growth when the non-financial corporate sector was unable to invest due to balance sheet troubles, and laid a good platform for crowding in private investments and growth in the coming decade.

The dedicated programs for road connectivity, port infrastructure, electrification, railways upgradation, and operationalizing new airports/airroutes have significantly improved the physical infrastructure in the last few years. With the National Infrastructure Pipeline in 2019 and the National Monetization Pipeline in 2021, a strong baseline for infrastructure creation and development has been put in place, providing a multitude of opportunities for foreign investment and engagement. With its strong forward and backward linkages, physical infrastructure will enhance the economy's productivity in the medium term.

The new reform framework in India is expected to have profound positive implications on India's medium-term growth outlook. The creation of public goods and improvement of physical infrastructure will enhance opportunities, efficiencies, ease of living and ultimately enhance the economy's productivity. With the National Infrastructure Pipeline and the National Monetization Pipeline in place, India provides a multitude of opportunities for foreign investment and engagement.

headings: Government Focus on Public Digital Infrastructure
Financial Inclusion and Access to Credit Through Digital Initiatives
explanations: This section presents an index of critical infrastructure capacity in India, with the first available value set as 100. Key infrastructure developments shown include national highways (in kilometers), railway tracks (running track kilometers), cargo handling capacity of ports (million tonnes per annum), and electricity installed capacity.

The government's push towards developing public digital infrastructure in the last few years has been significant in enhancing India's economic potential for individuals and businesses. A recently published RBI article estimates that India's digital economy has grown 2.4 times faster than overall economic growth between 2014 and 2019. Digitalisation has numerous advantages, including higher financial inclusion, greater formalization, increased efficiencies and opportunities.

India has made significant progress in financial inclusion through the pillars of digital identity Aadhar, linking bank accounts with PM-Jan-Dhan Yojana, and the penetration of mobile phones (JAM Trinity). The country has witnessed significant progress in access to bank accounts, increasing from 53% in 2015-16 to 78% in 2019-21. Many digital public goods such as digital verification (e-KYC), digital signature, digital repositories (Digilocker), and digital payments (UPI) have supported financial inclusion by improving access to formal financial services and reducing transaction costs. Greater financial inclusion and access to credit incentivize higher consumption and investment, resulting in higher economic growth. Several digital initiatives such as the Open Network for Digital Commerce (ONDC) and the Account Aggregator framework will open up further avenues for e-commerce market access and credit availability for smaller businesses and strengthen the expected economic growth in the medium term.

headings: Ease of Governance through Digital Interfaces
Impact of Economic and Structural Reforms
explanations: Digital infrastructure has had a significant impact on formalising the Indian economy. The digital financial architecture, GST system and growth in UPI usage have led to the formalisation of the workforce in India. The creation of digital identities such as Aadhar, eshram portal, SV ANidhi, GSTN, and Udayam portal has included various groups in the formal economy. This formalisation has led to improvements in access to credit and efficiency gains in operations.

Unified digital interfaces that connect various initiatives/portals have simplified governance resulting in a more efficient resource allocation in the economy. The National Single Window System, JanSamarth portal, UMANG app, Eshram portal, and PM Gatishakti have all integrated multiple systems, enabling ease of doing business. Digital technologies are at the forefront of reforms to accelerate India’s economic growth.

Building trust between the government and citizens/businesses has led to efficiency gains through improved investor sentiment, better ease of doing business, and more effective governance. Simplification of regulatory frameworks through reforms such as the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) and the Real Estate(Regulation and Development) Act (RERA) have enhanced ease of doing business.

Gains from economic and structural reforms tend to be more significant when binding constraints of governance have been addressed. Consistent reforms that address governance constraints need to be made to enhance India's economic growth. The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) and Real Estate(Regulation and Development) Act (RERA), for instance, are essential reforms that enhance the ease of doing business.

The greater formalisation of the economy has enhanced the productivity of individuals and businesses through improved access to credit and efficiency gains in their operations. The formalisation of business transactions has been facilitated by digital systems such as GSTN and e-Way Bill system. The increasing number of GST taxpayers indicates the expansion in formal businesses.

More than 93,000 micro-enterprises have grown to become small enterprises, and more than 10,000 small enterprises have become medium enterprises over the last two years. Over 32.7 lakh street vendors have availed of the first loan under the PM SV ANidhi Scheme, and more than 6.9 lakh have availed a second loan. The formalisation of transactions, even for the smallest of amounts, has been possible with the wide usage of the digital payment system of UPI.
Sources used in this content include a report in The Economist (January 2023), PMEAC Report (June 2022), and IMF World Economic Outlook 2019.

headings: Decriminalisation of Offences under the Companies Act, 2013
Snapshot of Decriminalisation of Offences under the Companies Act, 2013
explanations: The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) provides an honourable exit mechanism for honest business failures and enables the release of credit locked into the stressed assets for better resource allocation. This market-driven, transparent resolution mechanism instils confidence in the financial system and attracts many new investors to invest in Indian businesses. A significant achievement of the IBC has been the change brought in the debtor-creditor relationship. Debtors are resolving stress early to avoid being pushed into insolvency. Until 30 September 2022, 23,417 applications for initiating the corporate insolvency resolution process (CIRP) of corporate debtors having underlying defaults of ₹7.3 lakh crore were disposed of before their admission into CIRP.

Real Estate (Regulation and Development) Act (RERA) is creating a culture of transparent transactions in the real estate sector. The Act has transformed the real estate sector by registering real estate brokers and agents with the regulator, establishing mechanisms for the speedy redressal of disputes and enabling a single window clearance for timely approvals to the developers. The Real Estate Regulatory Authorities across the country have disposed off more than 1.06 lakh complaints. With 99262 projects and 71514 agents already registered under RERA, the Act incentivises more investments into the sector.

Another significant reform to enhance doing business has been the decriminalisation of minor economic offences under the Companies Act of 2013. By introducing civil liabilities for dealing with simple defaults that do not involve fraud or where the nature of the lapse is purely procedural, the government has demonstrated its intent to promote ease of doing business for domestic and global investors. Furthermore, a trust-based approach towards compliance builds entrepreneurs’ faith in corporate institutions and motivates them to adopt fairer and more transparent business practices. After the reform, more than 1400 default cases have been decided without resorting to the court. Also, more than 4,00,000 companies have willingly rectified past defaults to avoid penalties under the Companies Act.

Total penal provisions reduced from 134 to 124 after decriminalisation. Compoundable offences reduced from 81 to 31. Non-compoundable offences remained the same at 35. Defaults subject to civil liability through In House Adjudication Mechanism increased from 18 to 58.

The Companies Fresh Start Scheme encourages companies to rectify past defaults to avoid penalties under the Companies Act. The scheme provides an opportunity for companies to make a clean start by filing pending documents, returns, and forms without paying any additional fees. This scheme helps businesses to comply with statutory requirements, boost investor confidence, and enable better resource allocation.

The Indian government has taken steps to improve the taxation ecosystem in the country. This includes adopting a unified GST, reducing corporate tax rates, exempting sovereign wealth funds and pension funds from taxes, and removing the Dividend Distribution tax. These reforms have reduced the tax burden on individuals and businesses, removed distortionary incentives from the economy, and improved the ease of doing business.

The adoption of GST by the Indian government has helped businesses by reducing compliances, ensuring a free flow of goods across states, doing away with the need for businesses to have a separate warehouse for every state, and improving the ease of doing business. The buoyancy of the indirect tax system, replaced by GST, has improved in the post-GST regime, as evidenced by the positive trend of higher tax buoyancy in the economy.

Despite the pandemic, the positive trend of higher tax buoyancy is visible in the economy. The average monthly gross GST collection has increased from ₹0.90 lakh crore in FY18 to ₹1.49 lakh crore in FY23. The notable economist Indira Rajaraman termed GST ‘a revenue success’ in 2019. Corporate tax collections for April to November 2022 have increased by 21.1% YoY compared to a longer-term average YoY growth of 10.3% during the corresponding period from FY13 to FY19.

The positive impact of tax reforms, such as corporate tax cuts, is gradually becoming visible in higher tax collections. Despite the pandemic-led uncertainty and disruptions, corporate tax collections for April to November 2022 have increased by 21.1% on a YoY basis compared to a longer-term average YoY growth of 10.3% during the corresponding period from FY13 to FY19.

headings: Public Sector Enterprise Policy for Aatmanirbhar Bharat
Support for Domestic Industrialisation amidst Foreign Competition
Incentivising Foreign Investments for Domestic Production
explanations: Introduction of technology-based tax governance reforms for simplifying tax processes, enhancing compliance, and improving fraud detection systems has led to higher revenue buoyancy. Faceless assessment and appeal systems no longer require a physical interface between taxpayers and the Income Tax department. Multiple consistency checks possible with integrated digital systems reduce tax evasion. Sharing data and information between CBDT and CBIC on an automatic and regular basis is a promising reform. These reforms augur well for future economic growth and future resource mobilisation in the economy.

The government's policy in the post-2014 period has been the engagement with the private sector as a partner in the development process. The government’s disinvestment policy has been revived in the last eight years with stake sales and the successful listing of PSEs on the stock market. During FY15 to FY23, an amount of about ₹4.07 lakh crore has been realised as proceeds from disinvestment through 154 transactions. Privatisation of Air India re-ignited the privatisation drive which has improved labour productivity and overall efficiency of the PSUs.

The New Public Sector Enterprise Policy has been introduced to minimise the presence of the government in the PSEs to only a few strategic sectors. This policy is aimed to realise higher efficiency gains.

The PLI scheme will significantly boost production, exports and employment in the medium term. Sector-specific Production Linked incentives have been introduced in the aftermath of the pandemic to incentivise domestic and foreign investments and to develop global Champions in the manufacturing industry. Early estimates of the impact of PLI show encouraging trends in some sectors. For instance, the PLI scheme for large-scale electronics manufacturing has attracted an investment of ₹4,784 crore and contributed to a total production of ₹2.04 lakh crore, including exports of ₹80,769 crore (as of September 2022).

The need for a dedicated government policy to support domestic industrialisation amidst foreign competition can be better appreciated from the industrialisation experiences of East Asian countries such as South Korea and Taiwan in 1960-1990. These countries supported their domestic industries during their high growth phase, while also ensuring healthy competition required for the industries to grow.

Production incentives under Aatmanirbhar Bharat also incentivise foreign investments for domestic production. The last eight years have seen further liberalisation of the policy towards foreign investors, with most sectors now open for 100% Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) under the automatic route. This has resulted in a visible structural shift in the gross FDI flows to India.

India’s gross FDI has steadily increased over the last decade, from an average of 2.2% of GDP from FY05-FY14 to 2.6% in FY15-FY22. The country had a record high of USD 84.8 billion in FDI inflows in FY22, which signals its status as a preferred destination for global investors.

India is developing enabling infrastructure to become a cost-effective production hub. The National Logistics Policy (2022) was launched to create a comprehensive logistics ecosystem for improving logistics efficiency and making Indian products more competitive in the global market. The government has also opened strategic sectors like defence, mining and space to the private sector, providing business opportunities and investment incentives to start-ups.

India's industrial policy has focused on supporting MSMEs and addressing their structural challenges in recent years. Measures like the Emergency Credit Line Guarantee Scheme (ECLGS) and revised definition of MSMEs under Aatmanirbhar Bharat have helped MSMEs weather the pandemic crisis. The ECLGS alone has benefited 1.14 crore MSMEs in the last two years, with collateral-free loans amounting to ₹2.38 lakh crore. The introduction of TReDS and non-tax benefits, as well as access to digital platforms for marketing and online payments, have also created a robust support system for MSMEs.
The Account Aggregator Platform will open up avenues for access to credit for MSMEs, enhancing opportunities and productivity of the MSME sector.

The agriculture sector in India has grown at an average annual growth rate of 4.6 per cent during the last six years due to various reforms undertaken by the government to enhance agricultural productivity, such as policies like Soil Health Cards, the Micro irrigation Fund, and organic and natural farming, promoting Farmer Producer Organisations (FPOs), and enabling farmers to get good returns through the National Agriculture Market (e-NAM) extension Platform. Other measures like Agri Infrastructure Fund (AIF) and Kisan Rail are directed towards supporting the growth in agricultural productivity.

Comprehensive and wide-ranging reforms undertaken in the economy during the last eight years would have accelerated India’s growth, but that was not to be. The culprit is India’s balance sheet stress caused by the credit boom in previous years, leading to the non-financial private sector debt to GDP ratio going up from 72.9 per cent in March 2004 to 113.6 per cent by December 2010. Despite limited economic reforms, global capital flows and optimism about BRICS triggered a domestic credit and investment boom that eventually proved unsustainable. The credit supply was severely constrained due to stress in the balance sheets of banks during the second decade.

Enhancing opportunities and productivity of the MSME sector have large-scale implications for a resilient production ecosystem, thus strengthening the growth prospects of the industry and the economy as a whole.

headings: Collapse of IL&FS and Housing Finance Companies
Low Credit Growth and Weaker Capital Formation
explanations: India's medium-term growth outlook is optimistic and hopeful.
The credit to GDP gap has remained negative for most of the 2010s.

The impairment of companies' ability to repay bank loans due to investments going sour set in motion a long period of repair of the financial and non-financial sector balance sheets in the second half of the last decade. The government and the RBI took several policy initiatives to help the financial sector recoup the balance sheet stress during the 2010s.

Policy initiatives such as the amendment to the SARFAESI Act 2002, implementation of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC), launch of ‘Asset Quality Review’ (AQR), introduction of prompt corrective action (PCA) framework, recapitalisation of Public Sector Banks (PSB), and merger of PSBs among others, helped in cleaning up the balance sheets of banks/corporates.

The collapse of the Infrastructure Finance and Leasing Services (IL&FS) in September 2018 had a huge ripple effect on other non-banking financial entities. Few housing finance companies also went under. Hence, housing loan disbursements were disrupted. Usually, non-banking finance companies lend to more borrowers and riskier borrowers than banks. They are refinanced by banks. Their re-financings came down in the wake of the collapse of IL&FS, a big NBFC, followed by the collapse of some housing finance companies.
Low credit growth and hence weaker capital formation impacted economic growth.

The government responded with several measures to stem the fallout of the collapse of IL&FS and housing finance companies, including a corporate tax cut in September 2019. Soon thereafter, the pandemic struck, and the government had to address the emerging health, social and economic consequences of unprecedented nature.
Back-to-back shocks have delayed the impact of such momentous reforms on economic growth. These have been discussed in detail in the previous two economic surveys of 2020-21 and 2021-22.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 draws a parallel between the periods of 1998-2002 and 2014-2022 in terms of transformative reforms being launched but growth being delayed due to one-off shocks, such as nuclear testing and sanctions, balance-sheet stress in the banking and corporate sectors, and unprecedented pandemic shocks.

The periods of 1998-2002 and 2014-2022 saw significant structural reforms in the Indian economy. These included interest rate deregulation, privatisation, asset recovery for banks, infrastructure development such as the Golden Quadrilateral, the FRBM Act, financial inclusion, GST implementation, insolvency and bankruptcy code, tax administration reforms, decriminalisation of offences, and AatmaNirbhar Bharat initiative.

The growth returns from the periods of 1998-2002 and 2014-2022 were delayed by one-off shocks but ultimately paid dividends once they faded away. In the later period, balance sheets in the financial sector were strengthened, the corporate sector deleveraged by about 30 percentage points, and emphasis was placed on macro-economic stability.

External factors such as global shocks from the pandemic and commodity price spikes, as well as domestic factors such as balance sheet stress in the banking and corporate sectors, delayed growth in the periods of 1998-2002 and 2014-2022, highlighting the importance of managing these factors to realize growth potential.

headings: Credible destination for capital diversifying out of other countries
explanations: India is expected to grow at its potential once the one-off shocks recede.

The sound and healthy financial system, digitalisation reforms, productivity-enhancing reforms, skilling initiatives, and evolving geo-political situation are expected to be the growth magnets in this decade.

After the long period of balance sheet repair, the financial cycle is poised to turn upward, and the Indian economy is well placed to grow at its potential. Thanks to India’s digital revolution and formalisation, banks have far more information about their customer’s credit risks than before, contributing to higher growth in the coming years through higher investments and consumption.

The resulting efficiency gains in terms of greater formalisation, higher financial inclusion, and more economic opportunities will be the second most important driver of India’s economic growth in the medium term. IMF highlighted that India’s successful implementation of the wide-ranging reforms could increase India’s medium-term growth potential. These productivity-enhancing reforms along with the Government's Skilling initiatives, will also help unleash the benefits of the demographic dividend in the coming years.

The diversification of global supply chains presents an opportunity for India. Given the global policy uncertainty, multinational firms are gradually exploring strategies to diversify their production bases and supply chains. India presents itself as a credible destination for capital diversifying out of other countries.

With enabling policy frameworks, India presents itself as a credible destination for capital diversifying out of other countries. The PLI scheme has attracted Apple as its iPhone production picks up in India.

headings: Financial and Corporate Sector Balance Sheets
explanations: The Chief Economists Outlook 2023 emphasizes India's opportunity to gain from global trends of supply chain diversification.
The new age reforms undertaken over the last eight years form the foundation of a resilient, partnership-based governance ecosystem and restore the ability of the economy to grow healthily.

Further reforms are needed to ensure that economic growth can both accelerate and be sustained at higher levels to deliver a better quality of life. The deregulation and simplification of compliances should continue to dismantle the licensing, inspection and compliance regime entirely.
State governments have to address power sector issues, and the financial viability concerns of the Discoms have to be addressed.

Impetus must be given to education and skilling to match the requirements of modern industry and technologies, deal with twenty-first-century challenges such as climate change and energy transition, and make the most of India’s demographic dividend.
Initiatives to sensitise the population towards a healthy lifestyle should be continued. Strategies to arrest and reverse the rising obesity levels need to be adopted.
Long-range plans need to be formulated to secure the necessary metals and minerals required for energy transition and diversification.
Determined efforts should be taken to make the public sector asset monetisation scheme successful in realizing wide-ranging efficiency gains from the program.

Reforms to reduce the compliance burden on MSMEs, enhance their access to finance and working capital and equip them with skills, knowledge and attitude to grow their businesses responsibly must continue.

The Indian economy could have grown faster in the absence of the financial and corporate sector balance sheet stress. Even as we were looking forward to the economy being able to reap the benefits of improved and healthier balance sheets in the new decade, it was buffeted by the global pandemic followed by a sharp rise in the prices of food, fuel and fertilizer.

The higher economic efficiency resulting from the public digital infrastructure created over the last 6-7 years will also add 30-50 basis points to the potential GDP growth. The growth effects of the maturation of India’s public digital infrastructure are insufficiently understood. Formalisation and financial inclusion that it has enabled are too evident to be ignored. It is a matter of time before its growth effects become persistent in the data.

It is inevitable that the effects of reforms will now shine through. A restored credit cycle will rejuvenate the Indian private sector capex cycle. That alone is adequate to enable India to grow at least 6 percent per annum in real terms. In addition, if the other reforms explained in the previous paragraph are pursued in the coming years, India’s potential GDP growth can rise to 7-8 percent per annum in the medium term.
The article discusses the Indian Union Government's fiscal policy response amidst uncertain macroeconomic environment and global supply disruption.

The article highlights the buoyancy in revenues from direct taxes and GST despite additional fiscal pressures due to geopolitical conflict and global supply disruptions. The Gross Tax Revenue showed growth of 15.5% YoY from April to November 2022, driven by robust growth in direct taxes and GST. The GST collections increased at 24.8% YoY basis during April - December 2022.

The Union Budget for FY23 was presented amidst uncertain macroeconomic environment and global supply disruptions. The Government implemented a judicious mix of increasing food and fertiliser subsidies while reducing taxes on fuel and certain imported products to counter the additional fiscal pressures. The Centre's Capex steadily increased from a long-term average of 1.7% of GDP (FY09 to FY20) to 2.5% of GDP in FY22 P A.

Despite additional fiscal pressures during the year, the Union Government emphasized on capital expenditure (Capex), and incentivised State Governments to prioritize their spending on Capex. The increase in Capex has large-scale positive implications for medium-term growth, especially on infrastructure-intensive sectors like roads and highways, railways, and housing and urban affairs.  This Capex-led growth strategy will enable India to keep the growth-interest rate differential positive, leading to a sustainable government debt to GDP in the medium run.

With the continuing global risks and uncertainties, the availability of fiscal space with governments has become paramount. It is especially true following the recent incidence of the pandemic when the fiscal policy became an effective macroeconomic stabilisation tool globally. In India, particularly when all economic activities had reached a standstill, fiscal policy was instrumental in providing a safety net to the vulnerable, reviving the economy by boosting demand, and addressing certain domestic supply-side constraints through public investments and sustained structural reforms. The large, frontloaded packages across the countries led to over-stimulation of demand, leading to its much faster recovery. In combination with the still-existing supply disruptions and constraints, the overheating of the economy led to inflationary pressures. The conflict in Europe and the related geopolitical developments aggravated the crisis. The slowing global growth, rising interest rates, persistently high inflation rates and uncertain global environment have thus posed certain pertinent questions for fiscal-policy experts to motivate the overarching fiscal policy strategy. How to evaluate the trade-off between maintaining fiscal support to manage the continuing crisis versus withdrawing fiscal stimulus from the economy to control inflation and regain the lost fiscal space? When to do so and at what pace? While a sudden withdrawal may have costs for medium-term growth, a slow withdrawal may be inflationary and hence put upward pressure on yields, making the debt costly. Moreover, the financial markets may have less tolerance for fiscal unorthodoxy in an era of rising interest rates.

Against this backdrop, the Government of India adopted a calibrated fiscal response to the pandemic and planned to withdraw the fiscal stimulus gradually as it moves along the glide path outlined in the Budget FY22. This chapter discusses the government's fiscal strategy amidst uncertain geopolitical developments. The chapter starts with a discussion of the performance of the Union Government's finances, followed by an overview of the State finances. It concludes with a commentary on India's debt profile.

While India entered the pandemic with a stretched fiscal position, the government's prudent and calibrated fiscal response enabled stable public finances even amidst the present uncertainties. The fiscal deficit of the Union Government, which reached 9.2 per cent of GDP during the pandemic year FY21, has moderated to 6.7 per cent of GDP in FY22 PA and is further budgeted to reach 6.4 per cent of GDP in FY23 (Figure III.1). This gradual decline in the Union government's fiscal deficit as a per cent of GDP, in line with the fiscal glide path envisioned by the government, is a result of careful fiscal management supported by buoyant revenue collection over the last two years.

headings: Types of Taxes and their Growth
explanations: The given content talks about the revenue generated by the Union Government from April to November 2022. The content provides a table (Table III.2) that shows the growth of various types of taxes in percentage and value from 2021 to 2022. It is observed that the revenue generated from Gross Tax Revenue has increased from 15.42 lakh crores to 17.81 lakh crores from April to November 2021 to 2022, respectively. The revenue generated from Direct taxes has also increased from 7.00 lakh crores to 8.67 lakh crores, and indirect taxes have grown from 8.21 lakh crores to 8.91 lakh crores. Overall, the content shows that the economic growth of the country has contributed to the growth in revenue, and government efforts to expand the tax base and enhance compliance have been effective.

The given content talks about the growth in various types of taxes. These include Direct Taxes and Indirect Taxes. Direct taxes have been further divided into Corporation tax and Taxes on Income other than Corporation tax. It has been observed that Direct taxes have registered YoY growth of 26% from April to November 2022. Corporation tax YoY growth is 21.1%, and taxes on Income other than corporation tax YoY growth is 26.7%. Similarly, Indirect taxes have also shown growth, with GST YoY growth of 23.1%. Customs have grown YoY by 12.4%, while Union Excise Duties have declined YoY by -20.9%. The given content provides the numbers for each type of tax, making it easy to understand the growth of various taxes.

The given content talks about factors contributing to the growth of revenue. The first factor is the resilience exhibited by economic growth. The economic growth has led to sustained revenue buoyancy over the years. Another important factor is the effectiveness of efforts taken by the government to expand the tax base and enhance tax compliance. Structural reforms such as the introduction of GST and the digitalisation of economic transactions, among other measures, have led to increased formalisation of the economy and hence expanded the tax net. The content also talks about other tax administration/policy measures, such as the Faceless Assessment and Appeal, simplification of return filing, assistance to taxpayers in getting familiar with the systems, generation of e-way bills under the GST system, and information sharing between government departments, which have all contributed to higher tax compliance through technology and artificial intelligence.

The given content talks about the role of direct taxes in the growth of Gross Tax Revenue. Direct taxes, which broadly constitute half of the Gross Tax Revenue, have registered YoY growth of 26% from April to November 2022, enabled by corporate and personal income tax growth. The growth rates observed in the major direct taxes during the first eight months of FY23 were much higher than their corresponding longer-term averages. The growth in direct taxes has contributed significantly to the overall growth in Gross Tax Revenue.

headings: Stabilisation of Goods and Services Tax
explanations: The tax profile of the Union Government in FY23 BE is represented in Figure III.3. Direct taxes, including Corporation Income Tax (CIT) and Taxes on Income other than Corporation Income Tax (PIT), constitute 52% of the tax revenue, while Goods and Services Tax (GST) and Union Excise Duties (UED) make up 40% and 8% respectively.

Centre's direct taxes have grown higher than their corresponding longer-term averages during April to November 2022 (as shown in Figure III.4). Gross Tax Revenue (GTR), including CIT and PIT, has grown by 15.5% compared to the average growth from FY13 to FY19, which was 13.9%. This demonstrates the effectiveness of direct taxes in safeguarding revenue buoyancy.

Customs and Excise duties have acted as flexible policy tools during the fiscal response to the pandemic. In FY21, when direct and indirect tax collections were adversely impacted due to the pandemic, the government raised the excise duty on petrol and diesel to augment the revenue pool. However, when other taxes recovered and inflationary pressures built up in the economy, the government reduced the excise duty in November 2021 and May 2022 to control the impact of rising global oil prices on consumers. Similarly, customs duties were brought down on several items to control the inflation impact on essential products such as edible oils, pulses, cotton, and steel in FY23.
The budget estimate had factored in a negative growth of 15% on excise collections for FY23. As expected, excise duty collection has declined by 20.9% from April to November 2022 on a YoY basis.

Despite bringing down customs duties on essential products, the customs collection has grown by 12.4% YoY from April to November 2022. This growth is higher than the average growth during the corresponding period from FY13 to FY19. The growth can be attributed to high imports during the current year.

Goods and Services Tax (GST) has evolved and stabilised as a vital revenue source for central and state governments. Gross GST collections, taken together, were ₹13.40 lakh crore from April to December 2022 (as shown in Figure III.5), implying a YoY growth of 24.8%. The improvement in GST collections has been due to the combined effect of the Customs and GST, with an average monthly collection of ₹1.5 lakh crore (Figure III.6).

explanations: The article talks about rapid economic recovery post-pandemic, the nationwide drive against GST evaders and fake bills along with many systemic changes introduced recently, and various rate rationalisation measures undertaken by the GST Council to correct inverted duty structure. Consistent efforts have resulted in a doubling of the GST net, with the number of GST taxpayers increasing from nearly 70 lakh in 2017 to more than 1.4 crore in 2022. Apart from directly supporting government revenues, GST has led to better reporting of income, which in turn has positive externalities for income tax collection and economic activity.

The graph in Figure III.5 shows the high Year-over-Year growth in cumulative Gross GST collections from April to December for the years 2019, 2020, 2021, and 2022. The Department of Revenue is the source of this data.
Figure III.6 displays the continued momentum in monthly Gross GST collections over the years from January 2019 to August 2022. The Department of Revenue is again the source of this data.

Box III.1 discusses the shift to GST and whether it has improved or worsened the buoyancy of India's indirect tax system. The pre-GST period (FY13 to FY17) showed a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 11.53% for the aggregate State and Central taxes subsumed in the GST, and the nominal GDP grew at a CAGR of 11.54% during this period. Since the growth of the subsumed taxes was slightly less than the growth of GDP, the buoyancy was slightly below one and could be taken as one for practical purposes. The post-GST period (FY19 to FY23) faced many headwinds, most notably the exogenous shock of the Covid pandemic. The nominal GDP grew at a slower CAGR of 9.6% in the post-GST years. However, GST collections have grown at a CAGR of 10.9%, implying aggregate GST collections buoyancy of around 1.1.
The article mentions a PMEAC report titled ‘GST-Connecting the remaining dots’, published in June 2022.

headings: Improved Tax Collection Efficiency under GST
Comparison of Performance of Pre and Post GST Period
Buoyancy of Total Subsumed Taxes in GST
explanations: The implementation of Goods and Services Tax (GST) in India aimed to improve the tax collection efficiency of the government's revenue system. According to the Economic Survey 2022-23, the evidence so far suggests that GST has indeed shown a higher buoyancy than the pre-GST system, which augurs well for future resource mobilisation in the economy.

The comparison of the performance of various taxes subsumed in GST, during the pre and post-GST period, has been presented in tables 1a and 1b. Table 1a represents the pre-GST period, which shows the state taxes and central taxes subsumed in GST. The table shows that the total state tax collection on the GST portal increased from 2.86 lakh crore in FY13 to 3.92 lakh crore in FY17, while the total of central taxes subsumed in GST increased from 1.66 lakh crore in FY13 to 3.14 lakh crore in FY17.

Table 1a showcases the pre-GST collection of state taxes and central taxes. The table shows that the collection of state taxes subsumed in GST on the GST portal increased from 2.86 lakh crore in FY13 to 3.92 lakh crore in FY17, while the total of central taxes subsumed in GST increased from 1.66 lakh crore in FY13 to 3.14 lakh crore in FY17. Furthermore, the total taxes subsumed in GST (Centre+States) increased from 4.88 lakh crore in FY13 to 7.55 lakh crore in FY17, showing a CAGR of 11.53%, and the nominal GDP also showed a CAGR of 11.54% during the same period.

Table 1b showcases the post-GST collection of total GST collections (domestic supplies) and total GST collections (including GST on imports). The table shows that total GST collections (domestic supplies) increased from 8.77 lakh crore in FY19 to 12.94 lakh crore in FY23, showing a CAGR of 10.2%. Similarly, total GST collections (including GST on imports) increased from 11.77 lakh crore in FY19 to 17.80 lakh crore in FY23, showing a CAGR of 10.9%. The nominal GDP also showed a CAGR of 9.6% during this period.

The buoyancy of total subsumed taxes in GST during the pre-GST period was found to be 0.9988, indicating that the GST system was better at responding to changes in the nominal GDP. During the post-GST period, the buoyancy of GST collections (domestic supplies) was found to be 1.0603, indicating that the system was even more responsive to changes in nominal GDP than during the pre-GST period. Moreover, the buoyancy of GST collections (including GST on imports) was found to be 1.1299, which shows that the GST system was highly responsive to changes in nominal GDP.

The non-tax revenue collection of the Union Government includes interest receipts on loans to States and Union Territories, dividends and profits from Public Sector Enterprises and the Reserve Bank of India, and external grants and receipts for services provided by the Union Government. The budgeted non-tax revenue receipts for FY23 are lower than FY22, but 73.5% of the budgeted amount has already been collected up to November 2022. The non-tax revenue collection for FY22 is much higher than previous years. The table III.3 shows the trends in non-tax revenue of the Union Government from FY18 to FY23.

Non-debt capital receipts, which comprise recovery of loans and advances, and disinvestment receipts, have become an important part of non-debt receipts for the Union Government. In the past few years, ₹4.07 lakh crore has been collected through disinvestment proceeds in 154 transactions. This includes ₹3.02 lakh crore through minority stake sale and ₹69,412 crore through strategic disinvestment transactions in 10 CPSEs. Despite the pandemic-induced uncertainties and geopolitical conflicts, the government is committed to privatisation and strategic disinvestment of Public Sector Enterprises. Out of the budgeted amount of ₹65,000 crore for FY23, 48% has already been collected as of January 2023.

The Union Government has implemented countercyclical fiscal policy measures to support the economy during a crisis, as seen during FY21. The total expenditure of the Union Government in FY21 increased significantly. Reprioritisation of expenditure has been a pragmatic policy to address changing economic situations.

headings: Increasing Union Government capital expenditure to GDP ratio
Rising share of Capital Expenditure in Total Expenditure of the Union Government
High growth in capital expenditure of the Union Government during the April-november period
explanations: The Economic Survey for the year 2022-23 highlights that the government's expenditure was higher at 17.7% of GDP compared to the previous 5-year average of 12.8% of GDP. The government's focus shifted towards productive domestic capital expenditure after ensuring safety nets for the vulnerable. The Centre's capital expenditure has steadily increased from a long-term average of 1.7% of GDP to 2.5% of GDP in FY22 PA and further budgeted to increase to 2.9% of GDP in FY23.

The Union Government's capital expenditure to GDP ratio has been steadily increasing, from 2.2% in FY14 to 2.9% in FY23. This shows an improvement in the quality of government expenditure over the years.

The share of capital expenditure in total expenditure of the Union Government has been rising steadily, from 12.3% in FY18 to 13.3% in FY19, 12.5% in FY20, 12.1% in FY21, 15.6% in FY22 PA, and is budgeted to increase to 19.0% in FY23.

The capital expenditure of the Union Government has seen high growth during the April-November period, with a share of 29.3% in FY18, 4.0% in FY19, 11.7% in FY20, 12.8% in FY21, 13.5% in FY22, and is expected to see further growth in FY23.

headings: Capex-led growth to bring back animal spirits and manage debt levels
Centre's Capital expenditure focussed on infra-related sectors
explanations: The Government of India has budgeted an unprecedented ₹7.5 lakh crore of Capital Expenditure for FY23, of which more than 59.6 per cent has been spent from April to November 2022. Capital expenditure strengthens aggregate demand and enhances the longer-term supply-side productive capacity. The components of the Centre's revenue expenditure include Interest payments, major subsidies, salaries of Government employees, pensions, defence revenue expenditure, and transfers to States. Reprioritizing expenditure and rationalizing subsidies are essential tools to stimulate aggregate demand and fulfill redistributive imperatives.

The Government's thrust on Capital expenditure, particularly in the infrastructure-intensive sectors like roads and highways, railways, and housing and urban affairs, has longer-term implications for growth. Capital expenditure plays a role in crowding-in private spending in times of risk aversion. The growth in capital expenditure was much higher than the long-term average growth of 13.5 per cent recorded in the corresponding period from FY16 to FY20. Private sector investments have shown early signs of a rebound in recent months. Incentives in the form of long-term interest-free loans and capex-linked additional borrowing provisions were announced to boost states' capital expenditure.

The focus of the Centre's Capital expenditure is on infrastructure-intensive sectors like road transport and highways, railways, housing and urban affairs, defence services, telecommunications, atomic energy, defence (civil), police and space. Capital expenditure in road transport and highways grew by 102.10% YoY while it grew by 76.65% YoY in the railways sector. Capital expenditure in Telecommunications saw a YoY growth of 692.43%. Housing and Urban Affairs registered a negative YoY growth of -32.47%, while Space showed a negative YoY growth of -48.74%.

Improved fiscal transparency and realistic revenue assumptions in the Budget
explanations: The Union Government of India has been able to fulfil its additional expenditure needs for the current year with the help of better-than-anticipated revenue collections. It is expected that the budget estimate for the fiscal deficit during FY23 will be achieved without any concerns. The Union Government will be able to achieve its fiscal policy targets with resilient economic growth, continued revenue buoyancy, and careful expenditure management over the medium run. The Union budget has undergone major reforms in the last few years to enable better fiscal management.

The figure III.10 highlights the high-interest payments as a percentage of receipts that can be lowered through various initiatives for resource mobilization. The interest payment/revenue expenditure percentage has decreased from 36.5% in FY14 to 25.2% in FY19, and the interest payment/non-debt receipts percentage has decreased from 41.2% in FY14 to 29.7% in FY19. The Union Budget documents and the Office of Controller General of Accounts are the sources of this data.

The Union Government has introduced several reforms in the Union Budget over the last few years for better financial management. The government has brought below-the-line expenditures above the line for improved financial transparency and realistic revenue assumptions in its financial statements and accounts. The Union Government has reduced extra-budgetary borrowings from ₹1.48 lakh crore in FY20 and ₹1.21 lakh crore in FY21 to ₹750 crore in FY22 (RE). No Extra Budgetary Resources were estimated for FY23 in the Budget. These changes have resulted in greater efficiency in public spending.

The Union Government has accorded the highest priority to improving transparency in its financial statements and accounts by bringing below-the-line expenditures above the line. The Extra-Budgetary borrowings of the Union Government were brought down from ₹1.48 lakh crore in FY20 and ₹1.21 lakh crore in FY21 to ₹750 crore in FY22 (RE). No Extra Budgetary Resources were estimated for FY23 in the Budget. These changes have resulted in greater efficiency in public spending.

The Guidelines for Public Expenditure Management by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in 1999 provides the framework for budget preparation. The guidelines highlight the importance of transparency, accountability, and prioritization in public spending. The guidelines offer several suggestions on how public expenditures can be better managed, which can be adopted by governments worldwide.

headings: Merger of railway Budget with the Main Budget
Shifting the date of the Budget to 1 February
explanations: Budget 2022 based its revenue projections on realistic assumptions, thus providing a buffer to the government in an uncertain global environment. These measures credibly demonstrate the government's commitment to sound fiscal management and provide an adequate buffer to deal with global challenges.

The Budget FY18 discontinued having Plan and Non-Plan classifications of Government expenditure. The reform gave a greater emphasis to the Revenue and Capital classification of Government expenditure. Over the years, a broad understanding had been that Plan expenditures were good and Non-Plan expenditures were bad, resulting in skewed allocations in the Budget. The reform enabled effective planning and allocation of resources in the Budget.

The railway budget was merged with the Union Budget from FY18. The reform gave a holistic picture of the government's financial position. The initiative envisaged facilitating multimodal transport planning between highways, railways and inland waterways, which has been strengthened in the subsequent years through Gatishakti. The reform has helped to enhance the efficiency of resources for both Railways and the Union Government. While the merger has exempted Railways from paying dividends to the Government Revenues, it allows the Ministry of Finance to have a greater elbow room at the mid-year review for better allocation of resources. It has also enabled the Ministry of Finance to ensure a coherent emphasis on capital expenditure across sectors in recent years.

The date of the Budget was advanced to 1 February from the Budget FY18. The advancement of Budget presentation by a month has paved the way for early completion of the Budget cycle. It has also enabled the Ministries to ensure better planning and execution of schemes from the beginning of the financial year.

State Governments improved their finances in FY22 after being adversely impacted by the pandemic in FY21. The combined Gross Fiscal Deficit (GFD) of the States, which increased to 4.1 per cent of GDP in the pandemic-affected year, was brought down to 2.8 per cent in FY22 PA. Given the geopolitical uncertainties, the consolidated GFD-GDP ratio for States has been budgeted 3.4 per cent in FY23 (Figure III.11). However, the States' monthly fiscal Accounts data released by O/o CAG shows that from April- November 2022, the combined borrowings of the 27 major states have just reached 33.5 per cent of their total budgeted borrowings for the year.

explanations: The figure III.11 in the given content shows the consolidation of states' deficits as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) according to a study by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). The data includes figures for 27 states and is sourced from the RBI Study of State Budgets in January 2023, and the Office of the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG). The figure covers the fiscal years from 2017-18 to 2022-23, with a projected figure for 2023-24. The figure shows that there has been a decline in the Gross Fiscal Deficit and the Revenue Deficit between the fiscal years FY17 to FY22, with a further projected decline in the next fiscal year PAFY23.

The figure III.12 in the provided data shows the lower states' combined fiscal deficit during the months of April to November. The data is based on the Budget Estimates for the fiscal years 2021-22 and 2022-23 and is measured in lakh crore. The figure shows a decrease in the states' combined fiscal deficit during this period.

States faced resource constraints in the past years, so the Central government enhanced the net borrowing ceilings (NBC) for states to ease their financial burden. For instance, the net borrowing ceiling for states had increased to 5% of the Gross State Domestic Product (GSDP) in FY21, 4% in FY22, and 3.5% in FY23. The states had leftover borrowing limits during the previous three years.

As per the Budget Estimates of the State Governments in FY23, the combined tax revenue and non-tax revenue of the states were expected to increase by 17.5% and 25.6%, respectively, from the Revised Estimates (RE) of FY22. The growth rate in the expenditure was envisaged to be 10.4% for revenue expenditure and 16% for capital expenditure, over the FY22 RE. Moreover, the provisionally estimated actual capital outlay expenses of states in FY22 have been higher than estimated capital outlay in Revised Estimates, registering a growth of 31.7%.

The transfer of funds from the Centre to the States in India is based on Union taxes devolved to the States, Finance Commission Grants, Centrally Sponsored Schemes (CSS), and other transfers. The data shows an increase in the total transfers to states between the Budget Estimates of FY19 and FY23.

The table III.6 shows the details of transfers from the Centre to States (other than devolution to States) for the financial years (FY) 19-23. The transfers include Centrally Sponsored Schemes, Finance Commission Grants, and Other Grants/Loans/Transfers. The data shows an increase in transfers over the years with the highest being ₹4.4 lakh crore in FY23. The data is sourced from Union budget documents.

The Finance Commission recommended an allocation of ₹1.92 lakh crore for FY23 in respect of post-devolution revenue deficit grants, grants to local bodies, health sector grants, and disaster management grants under Article 275 of the Constitution. Table III.7 shows the allocation of grants to the State Governments as recommended by the 15th FC along with the amount released for the current financial year (as on 22 November 2022). The grants include Post Devolution Revenue Deficit Grant, Disaster Management Grand (Union Share), Local Bodies Grants, and Health Sector Grants. The data is sourced from the Department of Expenditure.

The Union Government has taken consistent steps to support the state finances and incentivize States to move forward on the reforms agenda. To meet the shortfall in GST compensation for States, the Government borrowed ₹2.69 lakh crore during FY21 and FY22 and passed it on to States on a back-to-back basis. Moreover, the cess payments and tax devolution installments to the States were frontloaded to give them early access to funds. The Government of India released ₹1.16 lakh crore towards the total GST compensation payable to States up to 30 June 2022 (as of 25 November 2022) and even released the balance from its resources. Box III.3 further discusses the impact of GST on the flow of resources to the states. The data is sourced from the Economic Survey 2022-23.

explanations: The total fiscal resources available to the states from the GST system from the fiscal years 2019 to 2023 are provided. It includes the SGST, IGST for states, devolution from Centre's GST, compensation, and loans, and shows a CAGR (compound annual growth rate) of 10.9%.
The nominal GDP of India is provided for the fiscal years 2019 to 2023, and shows a CAGR of 9.6%.
The post-GST buoyancy of GST revenues accruing to states, excluding compensation and loans, is 1.13, indicating that the revenue accruing to states from GST is greater than 1.

A compensation scheme was designed to safeguard the states for any difference in the new versus the old tax regime by ensuring steady revenue growth of 14 per cent per annum for five years. The compensation arrangement was also meant to help states ride out the differences in the inter-state distribution of GST.

The incidence of the pandemic has highlighted the relevance of GST Compensation as a buffer to the States' revenues. During FY21, revenues for Centre and states were adversely affected due to the economic contraction. The compensation requirement by the states increased substantially amidst a decline in the CGST and the compensation cess collections.

In addition to the release of regular GST compensation to the states, the Centre borrowed funds and passed them on to States on a back-to-back loan basis during FY21 amidst limited fiscal resources in the middle of a crisis. These loans will be repaid from future inflows into the GST Compensation Cess Fund and hence are not a burden on the states.

explanations: The given content talks about the revenue generated from SGST and IGST taxes from FY19 to FY23. Table 3C illustrates the compensation scheme of SGST revenue from FY19 to FY23. The data in the table is in ₹ lakh crore, unless specified. The table contains three items. The first item comprises SGST and state's share in IGST. Comparing the growth in aggregate SGST (item 1 in the table) is a better measure to gauge the performance of SGST revenues of the States. The above content also talks about the enhanced limit of borrowing for states and incentives for reforms during the pandemic outbreak. The Centre kept the net borrowing ceiling of the State Governments above the Fiscal Responsibility Legislation (FRL) threshold. It was fixed at 5% of GSDP in FY21, 4% of GSDP in FY22, and 3.5% of GSDP in FY23. Additional borrowing was linked to reforms encouraging the states to undertake them. In FY21, a part of the additional borrowing ceiling was conditional on implementing the 'One Nation One Ration Card' System, ease of doing business reform, urban Local body/utility reforms, and power sector reforms. 17 states implemented One Nation One Ration Card System, 20 states completed the stipulated reforms in the Ease of Doing Business, 11 states had done local body reforms, and 17 states carried out fully/partly Power Sector Reforms. Further, additional borrowing was earmarked for incremental capital expenditure to be incurred by states during FY22. Sixteen states accessed additional borrowings upon meeting the Capex target.

headings: Fifteenth Finance Commission recommendation for additional borrowing for power sector reforms
Centre's support for State capital expenditure
Details of Scheme for Special Assistance to States for Capital Investment for FY23
Initiatives by State Governments to improve their own resources
explanations: The Fifteenth Finance Commission recommended a performance-based additional borrowing space of 0.50 per cent of Gross State Domestic Product (GSDP) to the States in the power sector. This special dispensation has been recommended for each year for four years, from FY22 to 2024-25. For the financial year FY22, additional borrowing permission of ₹39,175 crore was allowed to 12 States for meeting the stipulated reform criteria.

The Union government has provided 50-year interest-free loans to state governments under the 'Scheme for Special Assistance to States for Capital Investment' for the last three years. Amounts of ₹11,830 crore and ₹14,186 crore were provided to states in FY21 and FY22 respectively. During the year FY23, the allocation under the Scheme has been raised to ₹1.05 lakh crore to give further impetus to State Capex plans. This amount includes an unconditional component and smaller components linked to specific reforms/initiatives.

The Scheme for Special Assistance to States for Capital Investment for FY23 has an allocation of ₹1.05 lakh crore, which includes an unconditional component and smaller components linked to specific reforms/initiatives. The unconditional component is allocated proportional to the share of tax devolution for FY23. The smaller components include PM Gati Shakti-related expenditure, PMGSY, incentives for digitisation, optical fiber cable, urban reforms, disinvestment and monetisation.

During the pandemic, state finances were stretched due to increased expenditure needs and reduced revenues. In addition to the Union Government's support through various initiatives, state governments have taken steps to enhance their resource pool. One such step is the reform of property taxation practices, as recommended by the RBI's recent report on municipal finances. States like Tamil Nadu are actively pursuing this reform to increase their own revenue.

During the FY23, Telangana and Kerala have revised their property taxes to support their revenues. Several other states like Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Haryana, Kerala, Assam, and UT of Puducherry have considered revising their power tariffs in FY23. Uttar Pradesh has announced a new liquor policy by increasing the license fee, renewal fees, processing fee, and registration fee across various categories of liquor/distilleries. Many states have also made efforts towards privatising SPSEs and monetising assets in FY21 & FY22 to unlock money trapped in unproductive assets and freeing it up for productive use. Additionally, some states have implemented revenue-generating measures like Assam's liquidation scheme for payment of arrears, Haryana's one-time scheme for settlement of old VAT dues, and Assam and Kerala's Green tax to discourage the use of old vehicles.

The unprecedented fiscal expansion in 2020 has resulted in government liabilities emerging as a significant concern across the globe. The IMF projects the global government debt at 91 per cent of GDP in 2022, about 7.5 percentage points higher than the pre-pandemic levels. While countries worldwide had started winding up the fiscal support provided during the pandemic, challenging global financial conditions and uncertainties have tightened budget constraints. Several European economies are expanding their budgets to provide relief to households and small businesses from mounting energy bills. Rising interest rates, the fear of slower growth, and these factors make the sustainability of sovereign debts a concern worldwide. The given figure showcases the increase in primary balance as a percentage of GDP in some countries.

headings: Components of Total Liabilities of the Union Government
explanations: India's government debt profile has been stable as a percentage of GDP over the past decade. However, the pandemic-induced higher government borrowings resulted in a sharp spike in debt in FY21. The total liabilities of the Union Government moderated from 59.2 per cent of GDP in FY21 to 56.7 per cent in FY22 (P).

The major components of the total liabilities of the Union Government are listed in Table III.9, which includes public debt, internal debt, and external debt. Public debt is further categorized into marketable and non-marketable securities, while internal debt is the sum of marketable and non-marketable securities.

Table III.9 shows the debt position of the Union Government for the years FY16 to FY22 (PA). The total liabilities have been increasing every year; standing at 121.21 lakh crore in FY21 and 123.8 lakh crore in FY22 (PA). The internal debt stood at 114.62 lakh crore in FY22 (PA), while the external debt was 6.59 lakh crore in the same year.

The Figure III.14 shows the government debt-GDP ratio of India, which increased to 59.2 per cent in FY21 due to pandemic-induced higher borrowings. However, it moderated to 56.7 per cent in FY22 (P). The Figures for FY22 are Provisional.
The various issues of Status Paper on Government Debt is the source of the data mentioned in the Economic Survey 2022-23.
India's public debt profile is relatively stable and is characterised by low currency and interest rate risks.

Of the Union Government's total net liabilities in end-March 2021, 95.1 per cent were denominated in domestic currency, while sovereign external debt constituted 4.9 per cent, implying low currency risk. Further, sovereign external debt is entirely from official sources, which insulates it from volatility in the international capital markets.

The weighted average maturity of the outstanding stock of dated securities of the government has increased from 9.7 years in end-March 2010 to 11.71 years in end-March 2022, thus reducing interest rate volatility and providing stability to interest payments.

The General Government finances give an overview of fiscal position of the Government sector as a whole. Figure III.17 shows the trends in General Government debt and deficits over the past few years. The General Government liabilities as a proportion of GDP increased steeply during FY21 on account of the additional borrowings made by Centre and States on account of the pandemic. However, the ratio has come off its peak in FY22 (RE). The General Government deficits as a per cent of GDP have also consolidated after their peak in F21. The General Government is expected to follow the path of fiscal consolidation in the medium term.

The emphasis on capex in recent years is expected to boost GDP growth directly, and indirectly through multiplier effects on private consumption expenditure and private investment. Higher GDP growth would thereby facilitate buoyant revenue collection in the medium term, and thereby enable a sustainable fiscal path. The General Government Debt to GDP ratio increased from 75.7 per cent of end-March 2020 to 89.6 per cent at the end of the pandemic year FY21. It is estimated to decline to 84.5 per cent of GDP by end-March 2022. The emphasis on capex-led growth will enable India to keep the growth-interest rate differential positive. A positive growth-interest rate differential keeps the debt levels sustainable. Box III.5 shows that steady economic growth will accelerate fiscal consolidation in the economy.
Over the last few years, the proportion of dated securities maturing in less than five years has declined, whereas long-term securities have shown an increasing trend.

headings: Incentivizing States for Reforms and Higher Capital Spending
explanations: India's debt and deficit ratios have increased not only due to the higher spending caused by the pandemic but also due to the slower growth or contraction of the nominal GDP. In FY20, India's GDP growth slowed down due to the ongoing stress in the financial system. Slow credit growth led to slower GDP growth. The pandemic further worsened the situation in FY21 causing the nominal GDP to contract. A detailed discussion on this is available in Chapter 2 of the Economic Survey 2022-23.

As India's economic recovery advances amidst global uncertainties, the fiscal glide path illuminates the path for fiscal policy. It will ensure larger fiscal space for policy action in uncertain times. Fiscal discipline translates into a fiscal stimulus for various sections of society through lower interest rates. As governments make their fiscal situations sustainable, the risk premium embedded in their interest rates comes down, thereby lowering the cost of capital for all sections of society. For EMDE, the stimulus effect of fiscal deficit, via diminishing risk-premium, is likely greater than it is for advanced economies. Therefore, it is crucial for governments to maintain fiscal prudence, especially in an era of rising interest rates.

The Centre should continue to incentivize states for reforms and higher capital spending to ensure a stronger General government. A capex-led growth strategy will ensure sustainable debt levels in the medium term. This is particularly relevant in the current situation where India's debt and deficit ratios have been affected by the pandemic and the slower growth of nominal GDP. IMF Working paper (WP/22/137)- Financial Sector and Economic Growth in India by Margaux MacDonald; TengTeng Xu (July 2022) provides a more detailed discussion on this.

headings: Deduction of tax at source on benefit or perquisite
Tax incentives for medical treatment of Covid-19
explanations: A Dispute Resolution Committee has been constituted to reduce litigation and give an impetus to dispute resolution for small taxpayers. A taxpayer having taxable income up to ₹50 lakh and disputed income up to ₹10 lakh shall be eligible to approach the Committee. The procedure of the Committee will be conducted electronically to ensure efficiency, transparency and accountability.

To avoid repetitive appeals, a new provision has been made under the Income-tax Act, 1961, wherein if a question of law in the case of an assessee is identical to a question of law pending in appeal before the jurisdictional High Court or the Supreme Court in his case or any other case, the filing of further appeal to the Appellate Tribunal or the jurisdictional High Court in the case of the assessee shall be deferred till such question of law is decided by the relevant Court subject to certain conditions.

A formal mechanism of sharing information through the Annual Information Statement (AIS) and e-Verification scheme has recently been enabled. These measures further the aim of widening and deepening the tax base by ensuring authorities possess all relevant financial information of an assessee, thus allowing access to such information to a taxpayer for accurate filing of his return of income.

The Finance Act 2022 has introduced specific provisions for the taxation of virtual digital assets (VDA), where the transfer of VDA is to be taxed at the rate of 30% with no deduction in respect of expenditure (other than the cost of acquisition) to be allowed. Moreover, loss from the transfer of virtual digital assets cannot be set off from any other income and cannot be carried forward to subsequent years. Further, the transfer of VDA is subject to TDS of 1% of the transaction value (whether in cash/ kind/ both). The gift of VDA would also be taxed in the hands of the recipient.

Deduction of tax at source on benefit or perquisite in respect of business or profession has also been introduced in Finance Act 2022 to widen and deepen the tax base. A person providing any benefit or perquisite to a resident would deduct TDS of 10% of the value or aggregate of the value of such benefit or perquisite (whether in cash/kind/ both).

Finance Act 2022 has provided that no set off of any loss shall be allowed against undisclosed income detected during search and survey operations to bring certainty and increase deterrence among tax evaders.

Vide Finance Act 2022, provisions applicable to bonus stripping have also been made applicable to securities. It has also been provided that the provisions on bonus stripping and dividend stripping shall also apply to units of an Infrastructure Investment Trust or a Real Estate Investment Trust, or units of Alternative Investment Funds.

Finance Act 2022 has provided income tax relief to the amount received by a taxpayer for medical treatment from an employer or from any person for treatment of Covid-19 during FY 2019-2020 and subsequent years. Income-tax relief has also been provided to ex-gratia

headings: Tax Relief for Families of Covid-19 Victims
Tax Relief for Persons with Disabilities
Enhanced Social Security Benefits for State Government Employees
Reduced Minimum Tax Rate for Cooperatives
Extended Date for Concessional Tax Regime for Manufacturing Entities
Tax Exemptions for Units in International Financial Services Centre (IFSC)
Customs Duty Rates Aligned with Make in India Initiative
explanations: The Economic Survey 2022-23 mentions that tax relief has been widened to the families of people who died due to Covid-19 during the FY 2019-2020 and subsequent years. This includes payment received from the employer or other person by family members of the deceased person.

As per the Economic Survey 2022-23, tax relief has also been extended to persons with disabilities. Annuity and lump sum amount from an insurance scheme is to be allowed to disabled dependents during the lifetime of their parents or guardians, once the parents or guardians attain the age of 60 years or more, and where such contributions to the scheme have been discontinued.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 states that to bring parity between employees of the state and central government, the tax deduction limit on employer contribution has been increased from 10% to 14% of salary in NPS Tier-I Account for State Government employees. This move is expected to enhance social security benefits for state government employees.

In order to promote start-ups, the Income Tax Act of 1961 allows for a deduction of 100% of the profit and gains of eligible start-ups for three consecutive years out of ten years. However, due to Covid-19, there have been delays in setting up such eligible businesses. As per the Economic Survey 2022-23, to lend a supporting hand to these start-ups, the period of incorporation of the eligible start-up has been extended to 31.03.2023 vide Finance Act 2022.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 mentions that the alternate minimum tax rate paid by cooperatives has been reduced from 18.5% to 15% to provide a level playing field between cooperative societies and companies. Additionally, for cooperative societies having total income of more than ₹1 crore and up to ₹10 crore, surcharge has been reduced from 12% to 7%.

To establish a globally competitive environment, the date of commencement of manufacturing or production of an article or thing for a newly established manufacturing entity for availing 15% concessional tax rate under section 115BAB of the Income-tax Act, 1961 has been extended from 31st March 2023 to 31st March 2024, as per the Economic Survey 2022-23.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 mentions that several tax concessions have been provided to units located in International Financial Services Centre (IFSC) under the Income-tax Act, 1961, to make it a global hub of the financial services sector. To further incentivise operations from IFSC, the following have been made exempt from tax subject to specified conditions vide Finance Act, 2022: i. Income of a non-resident from offshore derivative instruments ii. Income from over-the-counter derivatives issued by an offshore banking unit iii. Income from royalty and interest on account of the lease of a ship iv. Income received from portfolio management services in IFSC.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 mentions that the Customs duty rate structure has been guided by a conscious policy of the government to incentivise domestic value addition under Make in India and Aatmanirbhar Bharat initiative. This includes imposition of lower duty on raw materials and providing reasonable tariff support to goods being manufactured in India. Additionally, the customs duty structure has been calibrated to incentivise investment in key areas such as petroleum exploration.

headings: Risk Management based uniform cargo examination orders
explanations: This topic talks about the fiscal policies adopted by the Indian government to boost domestic manufacturing and trade, and facilitate taxpayers.
