The Minister of Finance introduced policies to encourage domestic manufacturing through a calibrated increase in BCD rates. This has seen a significant upward calibration of BCD for 4000 tariff lines over the past six years. These items include metals, auto parts, chemicals, toys, machinery, kitchen appliances, mobiles, and televisions.

The Phased Manufacturing Plan has been implemented for significant products like mobile phones and electronic goods (televisions, solar panels, etc.), electric vehicles, and batteries to encourage deepening of domestic value addition. The BCD rates have been calibrated in a phased manner in accordance with their value chain.

India has achieved full compliance with all the commitments under the WTO's Trade Facilitation Agreement well within the stipulated timeline of February 2022. This has resulted in significant improvements in trade facilitation, as is evident in the United Nation's Global Survey on Digital and Sustainable Trade Facilitation, where India has scored 90.32% in 2021, up from 78.49% in 2019. India is the best-performing country compared with the South and South-West Asia region (63.12%) in this regard.

CBIC has introduced Risk Management based uniform cargo examination orders across all customs locations in India, vide Circular No. 16/2022-Customs. This policy is aimed at enhancing the uniformity in the physical examination process of EXIM cargo, reducing time and cost involved in the process.

CBIC has introduced the Customs (Electronic Cash Ledger) Regulations, 2022, to facilitate taxpayers. The importer, exporter, or any person liable to pay Customs duty, fees, etc., can now deposit an advance with the government instead of making transaction-wise payments, as was being done earlier. This advance deposit can be utilized for paying duties and other sums related to Customs.

To further facilitate taxpayers, CBIC has launched an Anonymized Escalation Mechanism for handling grievances related to clearance delays. ICEGATE registered users can submit their grievances under faceless assessment and escalate them anonymously to the concerned assessing officers and higher officers at relevant FAG Ports. Users can track the status of their grievances till the final resolution.

headings: CBIC Launches Electronic Cargo Tracking System (ECTS)
Changes in Customs Law and Procedure
Postal Exports (Electronic Declaration and Processing) Regulations, 2022
Export of Containerised Cargo from ICD to Bangladesh
explanations: CBIC has launched a pilot project for implementation of Electronic Cargo Tracking System (ECTS) on 14.10.2021, based on blockchain technology for tracking movement of goods from the port to a warehouse at ICD Tughlakabad ensuring secured documentation & GPS based tracking of containers.

Indian Customs has notified IGCRS Rules, 2022 vide Notification 74/2022 dated 9th September, 2022 superseding the existing Customs (Import of Goods at Concessional Rate of Duty) Rules, 2017. These rules have come into effect from 10th September 2022. These rules have introduced significant changes for simplifying and automating the procedures for import of goods at concessional Rate of Duty in accordance with the larger goals of 'Ease of doing business' by accommodating long standing demands from the trade such as inclusion of job work, clearance of capital goods at depreciated value, making the entire process simple and online and doing away with any need for physical interface with officers.

As a trade facilitation measure, the validity of e-scrips issued under the Electronic Duty Credit Ledger Regulations, 2021, has been increased from one year to two years from the date of their generation. Further, the recovery provisions from the transferee holder of the e-scrips (issued under RoDTEP and RoSCTL schemes) and suspension of its credit account have also been omitted.

In order to leverage the vast network of post offices across the country and enable MSME's (Micro Small and Medium Enterprises) to export to global markets using e-commerce or other regular channels, the CBIC in collaboration with the Department of Posts (Dop) has notified the Postal Exports (Electronic Declaration and processing) Regulations, 2022. Under the new system, an exporter need not visit a Foreign post Office (FPO) to file the Postal Bill of Export (PBE) and present export parcel. Rather, he is enabled to file the PBE online from his home/office and handover the export parcel to postal authorities at a nearby booking post office. Postal authorities shall arrange secure transport of export parcel from booking post office to an FPO, where customs clearance shall take place.

Circular No.8/2022-Customs dated 17.5.2022 has been issued to enable exports from Bangladesh to India by rail in closed containers, with clearance at hinterland ICDs. A transshipment module has also been developed in the Indian Customs EDI system to digitise the procedure. This would decongest the border trade points and facilitate Bangladesh's exports.

Vide Circular No. 17/2022-Customs dated 9.9.2022, CBIC has enabled export of containerised cargo from any inland Container Depot (ICD) to Bangladesh using a combination of rail/road route and riverine route. For instance, the containerised cargo after customs clearance at an ICD shall be transported to Kolkata/Haldia port by rail or road, from where it shall be loaded on a barge for export to Bangladesh using riverine route. Customs clearance shall take place at the ICD and only preventive checks are conducted at Kolkata/Haldia. This facility is expected to help reduce congestion of export cargo at land Customs Stations.

headings: Inland Waterways Trade Route for Bangladesh
Simplified Regulatory Framework for E-Commerce Exports of Jewellery
Reduction in Excise Duty on Petrol and Diesel
explanations: CBIC has allowed the movement of containerised export goods from Bangladesh through India using a combination of riverine and rail routes. The Circular lays down the detailed procedure and documentation and provides for track and trace facility using ECTS. This alternative trade route is expected to save time and cost for the traders.

CBIC has put in place a simplified regulatory framework for e-commerce exports of jewellery via international Courier Terminals (ICTs). For this purpose, the Courier import and export (Electronic Declaration and Processing) Regulations, 2010 have been amended. This reform is aimed at supporting the Make-in-India brand in the international markets and enhancing the competitiveness of Indian jewellery exports.

Due to the upward trend in crude prices and Dollar exchange rate impacting the prices of Petrol and Diesel, it was decided to rationalise Central Excise Duty rates on Petrol and Diesel by ₹8 per litre on Petrol and ₹6 per litre on Diesel. The proposed reductions have been given effect by reducing the Road and Infrastructure Cess (RIC).

In 2022, the GST Council increased the GST rates on items such as Printing, writing or drawing ink, Power driven pumps primarily designed for handling water such as centrifugal pumps, Pawan Chakki, Drawing and marking out instruments, Solar Water Heater and system, etc., to correct inverted duty structure in these items. Similarly, GST rates on certain services such as Services supplied by foreman to chit fund, Job work in relation to processing of hides, skins and leather, Job work in relation to the manufacture of leather goods and footwear, etc., were also calibrated to correct the inverted duty structure.

headings: Changes in GST Law and Procedure
explanations: The 47th GST Council Meeting has revised the scope of exemption for specified food items, grains etc by excluding prepackaged and pre-labelled retail packs. The Council has also recommended withdrawing GST exemption on items such as Cheques, Maps, and Hydrographic or similar charts. Exemptions in form of a concessional rate of GST for items such as Petroleum/ Coal bed methane, Scientific and technical instruments, and E-waste are being rationalized.

The 2022-23 Economic Survey highlights several measures undertaken for trade facilitation and ease of doing business under GST. A retrospective amendment has been made in section 50 of CGST Act to provide interest only on wrongly availed ITC that is also utilized, and the rate has been reduced to 18% from 24%. UPI & IMPS have been provided as an additional mode for payment of GST, and CGST/IGST cash ledger balance transfer has been allowed between 'distinct persons' and refund application withdrawal facility provided. Additionally, a mechanism has been prescribed for refund of accumulated ITC on export of electricity and IGST refund sanction procedure streamlined for risky exporters.

Several measures have been undertaken to facilitate trade under GST. These include the retrospective amendment made in section 50 of CGST Act and the reduction of interest rate on wrongly availed ITC. The provision of UPI & IMPS as an additional mode of payment for GST and the transfer of CGST/IGST cash ledger balance between 'distinct persons' have been made possible. Additionally, a mechanism has been prescribed for refund of accumulated ITC on export of electricity, and the IGST refund sanction procedure has been streamlined in case of risky exporters.

The 2022-23 Economic Survey has undertaken several measures to improve ease of doing business. These include the reduction of the threshold for mandatory issuance of e-invoice to ₹10 crore and the provision of facilities for small taxpayers in making the supply of goods through e-commerce operators.
This section is about recent updates related to tax and revenue policies.

The article mentions a decision to waive mandatory registration under GST for intra-state supply of goods through ECOs to provide parity in offline and online supply of goods. This is expected to benefit small taxpayers as they can sell their goods on the huge e-commerce market without getting mandatory registration.

The article talks about allowing ECO's Composition taxpayers to make intra-state supply through ECOs subject to certain conditions. This will enable small businesses to take advantage of the e-commerce market.
The article states that Composition taxpayers will also be allowed to make intra-state supply through ECOs. This is good news for small taxpayers as it reduces the burden of mandatory registration.

The article mentions that the changes would be notified in due course of time, as it would require amendment in GST provision as per recommendations of GST Council. This highlights the importance of the GST Council in making decisions related to GST policies.

headings: Monetary Policy Transmission and Domestic Financial Conditions
Appetite for Credit and Financial Institution Health
explanations: In 2022, there was a synchronous and sharp cycle of monetary tightening across countries due to high inflation, including in advanced and emerging economies. Major central banks implemented sharp increases in policy rates, with the Federal Reserve, ECB, BoE, and RBI raising rates by 425 bps, 300 bps, 250 bps, and 225 bps, respectively. These developments have contributed to a dampened global outlook.

The change in RBI's policy stance in FY23 led to a moderation of surplus liquidity conditions that prevailed during the pandemic years. Monetary policy transmission is well underway as lending and deposit rates increased following the hike in policy rates. Domestic financial conditions began to tighten, which was reflected in the lower growth of monetary aggregates. Bond yields were on an upward trajectory until June 2022 on concerns of high inflation and policy rate hikes. These yields moderated in November and December 2022, aided by lower crude oil prices, a slower pace of rate hikes, and general moderation in global sovereign bond yields.

Despite the global tightening cycle, the domestic appetite for credit has been on an upswing. Non-food credit offtake by SCBs has been growing in double digits since April 2022, with the increase being broad-based. Credit disbursed by NBFCs has also been on the rise. The balance sheet clean-up exercise has been vital in enhancing the lending ability of financial institutions. The GNP A ratio of SCBs has fallen to a seven-year low of 5.0, while the CRAR remains healthy at 16.0 and well above the regulatory requirement of 11.5. The health of NBFCs has continued to improve as well. The recovery rate for the SCBs through IBC was highest in FY22 compared to other channels.

Despite increased volatility in global capital markets due to political and economic developments such as conflicts in Europe, high inflation, and raising interest rates, domestic capital markets displayed some encouraging trends. The primary equity markets witnessed participation from all segments, especially with increased SME contributions.

India's financial system saw growth in primary private debt markets, performed better than their peers in secondary capital markets, and had a trend of decreasing volatility. The outreach of the banking sector and the capital markets is also growing, as seen in the insurance and pension sectors.

India's insurance market has been steadily growing, with life insurance penetration above average. Government interventions and a supportive regulatory environment have aided the growth of the market, leading to increased partnerships, product innovations, and vibrant distribution channels. India is expected to become one of the fastest-growing insurance markets in the coming decade.

Since the introduction of the National Pension Scheme (NPS) and the Atal Pension Yojana (APY), India's pension sector has been seeing a robust increase in subscribers and assets under management (AuM). Government measures like relaxation in the CCS (Pension) Rules, integration of e-PPO with DigiLocker, and relaxation in the timeline for submitting Digital Life Certificate have aided the sector's growth.

Inflationary pressures have been dominating the global economic landscape, resulting in a sharp and synchronous monetary tightening cycle. The chapter discusses the impact of monetary policy actions on system liquidity, evaluating the performance of the banking system and sectoral credit developments, and reviews various insolvency frameworks.

RBI's support to the growth will ensure adequate liquidity in financial markets, and the growth in credit offtake is expected to sustain. The credit upcycle will also be aided by constant monitoring of risks in the financial system by regulators, alongside strong macroeconomic fundamentals. India's financial system will play a key role in realizing the objectives of Amrit Kaal.

The Monetary Policy Committee maintained a status quo on the policy repo rate between May 2020 and February 2022 after implementing a 115 basis points (bps) reduction between March 2020 and May 2020. Retail inflation has crossed the upper limit of RBI’s tolerance band since January 2022. Sensing a serious risk to price stability, RBI initiated the monetary tightening cycle.  In its April 2022 meeting, the committee introduced the Standing Deposit Facility (SDF), which allowed for the deposit of excess funds by banks with the RBI without the necessity of collateral in the form of government securities, thereby allowing effective liquidity management in a collateral-free manner. The SDF, introduced at a rate of 3.75 per cent, replaced the reverse repo rate as the new floor of the Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF) corridor. The MPC also indicated a change in stance from ‘Accommodative’ to ‘Accommodative and focused on the withdrawal of accommodation, while supporting growth’ in this meeting, signalling the start of the monetary tightening cycle.

The figure iV .1 shows the policy rates trend. During the period of February 2020 and February 2022, the repo rate remained stable while the SDF rate has just been introduced at the rate of 3.75% replacing the reverse repo rate as the new floor of the Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF) corridor.

Recognising the sizeable upside risk imparted by adverse global developments, such as the generalised hardening of commodity prices and an increased likelihood of prolonged supply chain disruptions, the MPC convened an off-cycle meeting in May 2022. Members unanimously voted for an increase of 40 bps each in the policy repo rate, the SDF and the Marginal Standing Facility (MSF), and a 50 bps increase in the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR). Between May 2022 and December 2022 and over five meetings, the MPC implemented a cumulative hike of 225 bps each in the policy repo rate, the SDF, the MSF and the bank rate. In the initial phases of the tightening cycle, the committee noted that commodity price-driven inflationary pressures, increased volatility and initial signs of a slowdown in output characterised the global outlook. In its latest meeting of December 5-7 2022, the MPC hiked the policy repo rate by 35 bps and reiterated its focus on withdrawal of accommodation to ensure that inflation remains within the target going forward, while supporting growth.

The reserve money (M0) has increased by 10.3% compared to last year with an adjusted YoY growth of 7.8% due to changes in the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR). The expansion in M0 during FY23 was driven by bankers’ deposits with the RBI.

The table shows YoY growth in different monetary aggregates in percentages. The Reserve Money (M0) has grown by 10.3%, Currency in Circulation (CiC) by 8.2%, and Bankers’ Deposits with the RBI by 17.6% in FY23. Narrow Money (M1) has grown by 7.6%, and Broad Money (M3) has grown by 8.7%. The demand deposits have shown a lower growth rate of 6.2% compared to other aggregates.

The monetary developments of recent times reflect the tightening financial conditions. The figure shows declining YoY growth of broad money and converging money multiplier (MM) measures. The charts show a slow increase in the aggregate deposits and currency with the public, while MM adjusted for reverse repo has shown a decline.

As on 30th December 2022, broad money stock (M3) increased by 8.7 per cent YoY. Bank credit to the commercial sector drove the expansion of broad money, and net bank credit to the government supplemented this expansion. The money multiplier – the ratio of M3 and M0 – has broadly remained stable at an average of 5.1 over April – December 2022 period compared to 5.2 in the corresponding period of the previous year.

Surplus liquidity conditions that prevailed post-Covid-19 in response to the Reserve Bank’s conventional and unconventional monetary measures moderated during FY23 in consonance with the changed monetary policy stance that focused on the withdrawal of accommodation.
The RBI’s move to hike the CRR by 50 bps resulted in a withdrawal of primary liquidity to the tune of ₹87,000 crore from the banking system.
Overnight call money rates are now trending well inside LAF corridor.

During FY23, the daily net liquidity absorption averaged ₹2.5 lakh crore as compared with ₹6.7 lakh crore in FY22. The Reserve Bank remained agile in liquidity management by conducting two-way operations. It injected liquidity to assuage transient liquidity tightness through variable rate repo auctions. The WACR traded 6 bps above the policy repo rate, on an average, during H2.interest rates on various money market rates - 91-day T-Bills, 3-month certificates of deposit and commercial papers - gradually firmed up in line with the increase in the repo rate.

During FY23, lending and deposit rates of banks increased in consonance with the policy repo rate changes.The weighted average lending rate on fresh and outstanding rupee loans rose by 135 bps and 71 bps, respectively in FY23 (up to November 2022). On the deposit side, the weighted average domestic term deposit rate on outstanding deposits increased by 59 bps in FY23 (up to November 2022).An analysis of transmission across bank groups indicates that the increase in the WALRs on fresh loans was higher in the case of public sector banks, while that of the WADTDR on outstanding deposits and WALR on outstanding loans was higher for private banks.

The policy repo rate is the operating target of monetary policy. The WACR - the operating target of monetary policy - traded 6 bps above the policy repo rate, on an average, during H2 (up to 21 December 2022) compared to 28 bps below it during H1.

headings: Transmission of lending and deposit rates
explanations: Table IV.2 provides information on the transmission of lending and deposit rates across different bank groups. It shows the variation in basis points (bps) between February 2019 and March 2022 for outstanding and fresh rupee loans, as well as outstanding deposits. The table also provides data for the period between April and November 2022. It can be observed that PSBs, PVBs, and SCBs (which include public, private, and foreign banks) have all experienced a decrease in WALR (Weighted Average Lending Rate) and WADTDR (Weighted Average Domestic Term Deposit Rate) over the indicated period, with some fluctuations in between. However, there was an increase in WALR and WADTDR for fresh rupee loans between April and November 2022.

The yield of the 10-year government bond has experienced variability in recent years, with a rise in 2022 after remaining steady in 2020 and 2021. This rise was a result of several factors, including uncertainty in crude prices, a hawkish stance of major central banks, a hardening of global bond yield, and pressure on the rupee. In December 2022, the monthly average yield was 7.3%, having peaked at 7.5% in June 2022. However, yields moderated towards the end of the year due to declining inflation and smaller rate hikes by major central banks. Figure IV.5 shows the easing of G-sec yields since July 2022, which was attributed to the decline in oil prices and global bond yields. This softening of yields also resulted in reduced volatility in the second half of 2022.

The trading volume in G-Secs including T-Bills and SDLs reached a two-year high of ₹27.7 lakh crore during Q2 FY23, registering a YoY growth of 6.3 per cent. The higher trading volume reflects the growing interest of market players/ traders in the government security market. Private Sector Banks emerged as the dominant trading segment in the secondary market during the quarter under review.

According to Table IV.3, Private Sector Banks had a share of 25.0 per cent in 'Buy' deals and 24.8 per cent in 'Sell' deals in the total outright trading activity in G-Secs during Q2 FY23. Foreign banks, public sector banks, primary dealers, and mutual funds also had a sizable share, while cooperative banks, insurance companies, and financial institutions had comparatively smaller shares.

Since the mid-2000s, RBI and the government have made dedicated efforts in terms of calibrated policy measures like strengthening the regulatory and supervisory framework, implementation of 4R approach of Recognition, Resolution, Recapitalisation and Reforms to clean and strengthen the balance sheet of the banking system. These continuous efforts over the years have culminated in the enhancement of risk absorption capacity and a healthier banking system balance sheet both in terms of asset quantity and quality over the years.

headings: Banking System: Improvement in Asset quality and strengthening of balance sheet
explanations: The Economic Survey for the year 2022-23 has been released to provide an overview of the current state of the Indian economy. The Survey highlights various aspects of the economy, including the banking system.
The Survey discusses the improvement in asset quality and strengthening of balance sheet in the banking system.

Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) have shown a steady improvement in their asset quality over the years across all major sectors. According to Figure iV .6a, the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio has decreased from 8.2% in March 2020 to a seven-year low of 5.0% in September 2022. This decline is likely to continue and is projected to reduce further to 4.9% in March 2023 according to the baseline scenario of RBI’s stress testing framework.
The Provisioning Coverage Ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) has also improved. According to Figure iV .6b, the ratio has increased from 48.12% in March 2020 to 80% in September 2022.

Agriculture and industry sectors have shown significant improvements in their GNPA ratios over the year, as per data in Figure iV .7. The improvement in the GNPA ratio was broad-based across the industrial sector, while the gems and jewellery, and construction sub-sectors show elevated GNPA ratios. The Services and Personal Loans sectors also witnessed a decline in their GNPA ratios from March 2021 to September 2022.

headings: Monetary Management And Financial Inter Mediation
Return on Equity and Return on Assets
explanations: The report talks about the performance of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) in terms of their capital adequacy ratio, provisioning coverage ratio and profitability indicators like Return on Equity(ROE) and Return on Assets (ROA).

The report states that the Capital Adequacy Ratio (CAR) of SCBs has been rising sequentially since the asset quality review period, and it remained well above the minimum capital requirement, including Capital Conservation Buffer (CCB) requirements of 11.5 per cent in September 2022. Figure iV.8 shows that the CAR of PSBs, PVBs, FBs, and SCBs remained well above the requirement norms.
The Provisioning Coverage Ratio (PCR) has been increasing steadily since March 2021 and reached 71.6 per cent in September 2022, which is a positive sign for the banking sector.

During the first half of FY23, the profitability of SCBs in terms of ROE and ROA improved to levels last observed in FY15. Figure IV.9a shows the ROE-annualised, and Figure IV.9b shows ROA-annualised. Strong growth in Net Interest Income (NII) and a significant lowering of provisions led to a double-digit growth of 40.7 per cent in Profit After Tax (PAT) in the quarter ending September 2022. The macro-stress tests conducted by RBI for credit risk reveal that SCBs are well-capitalised and can comply with the minimum capital requirements even under adverse stress scenarios.

The recovery in economic activity in FY22, along with the enhanced financial soundness of banks and corporates, has bolstered the expansion of non-food bank credit since June 2021. The YoY growth in non-food bank credit accelerated to 15.3 per cent in December 2022. This not only shows an acceleration in the growth of current economic activities but also an anticipation of continued momentum in economic activity in future.

The non-food bank credit growth has been in double digits since April 2022, as per RBI's data. This indicates an expansion in current economic activities and a continuation of momentum in economic activity for the future.

Credit growth has been broad-based across sectors, with retail credit leading the growth primarily due to rising demand for home loans. Agriculture and allied activities also gained momentum supported by the government's concessional institutional credit and higher agricultural credit targets. Industrial credit growth has been buoyed by a pick-up in credit to MSMEs, assisted by the benefits accrued from the effective policy measures.

headings: Monetary Management and Financial Intermediation: A Good Year
Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) Continue to Recover
explanations: The Emergency Credit Line Guarantee Scheme (ECLGS) implemented by the government and production-linked incentive scheme led to improvement in capacity utilization which resulted in a good year for credit growth in services. Moderation in overseas issuances and lower investments by PE/VC led to financing needs of corporate sectors being met through domestic resources. Incremental Credit-Deposit ratio rose sharply indicating reliance on bank credit for funding operations and capacity expansion. With well-capitalized banking system and more robust corporate sector fundamentals, the flow of bank credit into productive investment opportunities will continue to increase despite rising interest rates.

The NBFC sector has been rising consistently as a proportion to GDP and the credit extended by SCBs. NBFCs have built up financial soundness marked by balance sheet consolidation, improvement in asset quality, augmented capital buffers, and profitability. Improvement in asset quality is seen in the declining GNPA ratio of NBFCs reaching close to the pre-pandemic level. Although the softening was observed across sectors, the GNPA ratio of the services sector remains in double digits.
The figure iV .13 shows the declining GNPA ratio and how the asset quality of NBFCs is improving across sectors.
The table shows the percentage of GNPA in different sectors as of September 2022, with agriculture having 1.6%, industry with 46.2%, services with 27.4%, personal with 23.5%, and others with 1.2%.
The figure iV .14 shows the recouping RoA of NBFCs with a robust capital position, from 0.0% to 3.0%.

The decline in GNPAs has caused the capital position of NBFCs to remain robust, with a CRAR of 27.4% in end-September 2022, slightly lower than 27.6% in March 2022. The RoA has recouped over successive half-years.

RBI's stress test assessed the resilience of the NBFC sector to credit risk shocks for a sample of 152 NBFCs, revealing that the number of NBFCs that would fail to meet the minimum regulatory capital requirement of 15% stood at 8% under the baseline scenario. It increases to 10% and 13% under medium and severe stress scenarios, respectively.

Credit extended by NBFCs is picking up momentum, with the aggregate outstanding amount at ₹31.5 lakh crore as of September 2022. NBFCs continued to deploy the largest quantum of credit from their balance sheets to the industrial sector, followed by retail, services, and agriculture. Loans to the services sector (share in outstanding credit being 14.7%) and personal loans (share of 29.5%) registered a robust double-digit growth.

headings: Monetary Management And Financial Inter Mediation
Progress made under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code
explanations: The credit disbursement by NBFCs across sectors has grown robustly with a slight moderation in the industry sector. As per the data by RBI, Agriculture sector has 1.7%, Industry sector has 37.5%, Services sector has 14.7%, Personal sector has 29.5% and Other sector has 16.5% of outstanding loans in Sep-22.

The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) has facilitated the exit of distressed firms, thereby allocating scarce economic resources towards more productive use. As per the data, since the inception of the IBC in December 2016, 5,893 Corporate Insolvency Resolution Processes (CIRPs) had commenced by end-September 2022, of which 67% have been closed.

As per the data from Insolvency and Bankruptcy Board of India, (IBBI), 5,893 CIRPs were commenced since the inception of the IBC in December 2016, of which 67% have been closed by end-September 2022. 4.26 Sectoral analysis reveals that 52% of the ongoing CIRPs belong to the industry sector, followed by 37% in the services sector by September 2022. Within the industry sector, 74% of the initiated CIRPs were from the manufacturing sector. Of these, the textile, basic metals, and food sectors accounted for 48% of the ongoing CIRPs.

The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) has facilitated the exit of distressed firms, thereby allocating scarce economic resources towards more productive use. As per the data, since the inception of the IBC in December 2016, 5,893 Corporate Insolvency Resolution Processes (CIRPs) have commenced by end-September 2022, of which 67% have been closed. Of these, around 21% were closed on appeal or review or settled, 19% were withdrawn, 46% ended in orders for liquidation, and 14% culminated in the approval of resolution plans.

The Corporate Debtor (CD) can voluntarily liquidate itself subject to the fulfillment of certain conditions as prescribed under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code. As of end-September 2022, 1,351 corporate persons initiated voluntary liquidation under the Code.

The ongoing Corporate Insolvency Resolution Processes (CIRPs) in India as of September 2022 primarily belong to the Real Estate, Renting, and Business Activities sector, which accounts for 60% of the total CIRPs. These CIRPs are for both the manufacturing and services sectors. For the manufacturing sector, the ongoing CIRPs are mainly in the Food, Beverages, and Tobacco Products (15%), Textiles, Leather, and Apparel Products (16%), and Basic Metals (16%) categories. While in the Services sector, Real Estate, Renting, and Business activities dominate CIRPs with a 60% share. Wholesale and Retail Trade (27%), Hotels and Restaurants (6%), and Transport, Storage, and Communications (7%) are the other prominent categories of ongoing CIRPs.

headings: Value Realization for Initiators of CIRPs
explanations: The Code had a positive impact on the settlement of debts as more debtors preferred to settle their dues before the initiation of insolvency proceedings.
The fear of losing control over the CD upon initiation of CIRP has nudged thousands of debtors to settle their dues even before the initiation of insolvency proceedings.
The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code has facilitated the rescue of 69% of distressed assets from failing firms. Realization value was around 178% of the liquidation value for the 553 companies rescued.

For Financial Creditors, Operational Creditors, and Corporate Debtors, the resolution plans for the 553 rescued CDs realized ₹2.4 lakh crore which is 177.6% of the liquidation value and 841% of the fair value of the 553 CDs rescued. For financial creditors, the realisation value in comparison to liquidation value was 201%, while the realisation by them was 33% of their claims.

1807 CDs ended up with orders for liquidation as of September 2022. 76% of the CIRPs ending in liquidation were earlier with the Board for Industrial and Financial Reconstruction (BIFR) and/or are defunct. The economic value of most of the corporate debtors that ended in liquidation had almost completely eroded even before they were admitted into CIRP. The Code has facilitated the realization of 92% of the value for the 429 CDs that have been completely liquidated.

Out of the 2360 total companies under the Code as of September 2022, 553 were rescued while 1807 were ordered for liquidation. The aggregate claims for these companies totaled ₹16,18,806 crore, the liquidation value was ₹1,97,261 crore, and the resolution value was ₹2,43,452 crore. The average time taken for resolution was 561 days and the cost % of resolution value was 0.6%.

headings: Mode of Sale in Insolvency and Bankruptcy Cases
explanations: Section 9.2.2 of the Economic Survey 2022-23 discusses the mode of sale in insolvency and bankruptcy cases, referring to a report by IBBI. The report highlights that the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) is the most effective tool for recovering debts, outperforming other channels like Lok Adalats, DRTs, and SARFAESI Act. The table in the report shows that during FY2021-22, SCBs recovered INR 47,421 crore through IBC, compared to Lok Adalats (INR 2,777 crore), DRTs (INR 12,114 crore), and SARFAESI Act (INR 27,349 crore). The recovery rate depends on various factors like the macroeconomic environment, growth prospects, and erosion in intrinsic value of the entity.

Section 4.31 of the Economic Survey 2022-23 presents the development in the global and Indian capital markets. It mentions that global macroeconomic uncertainty, inflation, and monetary policy tightening affected investor sentiments, leading to a downbeat performance of global capital markets. However, India's capital market had a good year, overall. The section further elaborates on the primary market, stating that despite the turmoil in global financial markets, the primary market's performance was buoyant from April to November 2022. The number of firms opting to list on the bourses increased by 37% compared to FY22, though the amount raised declined to nearly half of the previous year.

The year so far has seen a significant increase in the number of SMEs coming out with public offer compared to the same period last year. The total funds raised by SMEs through IPOs were almost three times more than the funds raised by them in the same period last year.

The Central Government's dilution of its stake in Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) of India resulted in LIC's IPO becoming the largest IPO in the history of India and the sixth biggest IPO globally of 2022. Listing of LIC accounted for more than a third of resources mobilized in the primary equity market until November 2022.

The issuance of debt securities in the primary market increased by 5% in April-November 2022, with the total number of issues increasing by 11% compared to the same period last year. Although public issues of debt increased by 10% in the same period compared to last year, the amount raised by public issues of debt decreased by 27%. However, the underactivity in public debt issuances was more than compensated by private debt placements.

From April to November 2022, a total of ₹5,06,358 crores were mobilized from the primary market, with equity and debt accounting for ₹1,14,361 crores and ₹3,91,997 crores respectively. Private debt placements contributed significantly to the mobilization of resources.

The Indian stock market showed a resilient performance in April-December 2022 with the bluechip index Nifty 50 registering a return of 3.7% during the period while the US dollar adjusted return stood at -4.7%. Sensex also closed 3.9% higher from its closing level on March 31, 2022. Even among major emerging market economies, India outperformed its peers in April-December 2022.

In April-December 2022, global stock markets experienced a decline due to geopolitical uncertainty. The S&P 500 Average Index declined by 15.3% while Nasdaq Composite heavily weighted (49%) towards technology sector companies, declined sharply by 26.4%.

The table shows the performance of various stock markets across the world. India outperformed its peers, recording a positive change in April-December 2022 while other emerging markets like China, Brazil, and Korea recorded a negative change. Developed markets like the US, France, Germany, and Japan also recorded negative changes in performance except for the UK, which recorded a marginal negative change.

headings: Monetary Management And Financial Inter Mediation
Indian Benchmark Indices witnessed swift recovery
Heightened geopolitical uncertainty and supply chain disruption post-Russia-Ukraine crisis
explanations: Monetary Management and Financial Intermediation are essential aspects of any economy. The financial sector of an economy is responsible for directing funds from savers to investors. Monetary management involves the management of money supply and interest rates by the central bank, in order to achieve macroeconomic objectives. It includes controlling the money supply, monitoring interest rates, and ensuring the stability of the financial system.

The figure IV .20 depicts the recovery of the Indian benchmark indices. The Nifty 50 and S&P BSE Sensex had witnessed a decline due to the impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflict on the global stock markets. However, both indices made a quick recovery in March 2022, reflecting the positive sentiment in the market.

The figure IV .21 depicts the trend in the India VIX, which is a measure of expected short-term volatility in the stock market. The index witnessed a rise in February 2022 due to the geopolitical crisis caused by the Russia-Ukraine conflict. However, the impact started to wane as the year progressed, and the index witnessed a declining trend from April to November 2022.

The Russia-Ukraine crisis had a significant impact on the global economy, which was reflected in the increased volatility of the stock markets. The India VIX and CBOE VIX, which measure short-term volatility in the Indian and US equity markets respectively, showed a rise during the crisis period. However, the Indian stock market recovered quickly and witnessed a declining trend in the India VIX as the impact of the crisis started to wane over the year.

The figure IV.22 shows the annualized volatility in the Indian indices during FY23 (April-November) which remained relatively low. The different indices are plotted against their annualized percentage change with respect to time. It can be observed that India, South Africa, and Brazil had the highest volatility among the listed countries, with India having the highest volatility among them.

The Nifty-50 shares showed a valuation of 21.8 times the earnings of the constituent stocks (P/E ratio) on a trailing basis at the end of December 2022. Compared to global markets, Nifty-50 is expensive, but it's lower as compared to its own last five-year average. Figure IV.23 represents Nifty 50 standing expensive vis-à-vis the global markets, although it's lower than its own five-year average.

The MSCI World Index captures the large and mid-cap representation across 23 Developed Markets (DM) countries, while the MSCI Emerging Markets Index is designed to capture the large and mid-cap representation across 24 Emerging Markets (EM) countries. The MSCI BIC Index is a free float-adjusted market capitalisation weighted index intended to measure the equity market performance across the three Emerging Markets country indexes: Brazil, India, and China. Figure IV.23 represents Nifty 50 in comparison with the MSCI World Index, MSCI EM Index, and MSCI BIC Index. Based on the P/E ratio, the Nifty 50 valuation is the highest, followed by MSCI World, and then MSCI BIC and MSCI EM.

headings: Retail Participation in the Capital Market
Equity, Commodity and Currency Derivatives Turnover
explanations: Retail participation in the Indian capital market showed some interesting trends during FY23, as per data released by NSE and BSE. While the share of individual investors in the cash segment declined slightly over the April-November period compared to the same period last year, the number of demat accounts rose significantly. However, the incremental rise in demat accounts has been slowing down in FY23 relative to FY22, possibly due to increased volatility in secondary markets and subdued primary market performance. Individual investors include domestic investors, NRIs, sole proprietorship firms and HUFs.

The cash segment of the Indian capital market saw a decline in turnover between April and November 2022, compared to the same period last year. This coincided with a considerable jump in equity derivatives volumes, as individual and proprietary traders shifted interest from the equity cash segment to the equity derivatives segment. A rise in currency and commodity derivatives volumes was also observed during the same period. SEBI data shows a 21% decline in cash segment turnover, while equity derivatives volumes jumped by a whopping 113%.

The FY23 period from April to November saw a sharp rise in turnover volumes for equity, currency and commodity derivatives in the Indian market, as per SEBI data. Equity derivatives turnover volumes jumped by a massive 113% compared to the same period last year. Currency derivatives turnover also surged, recording an 87% rise. Meanwhile, commodity derivatives witnessed a 42% increase in turnover. However, interest rate derivatives saw a decline in turnover of 17%.

The Russia-Ukraine conflict caused a disruption in the supply of commodities, leading to a surge in the prices of crude oil and some base metals. However, the Federal Reserve's decision to increase interest rates in March 2022 led to a sharp correction in commodity prices. The MCX iCOMDEX Base Metal Index declined by 19.1% by November 2022 in comparison to March 2022. The bullion index (-3.5%) and Energy index (-1.0%) also witnessed a decline in prices. As of November 2022, prices of Aluminium, Copper, Zinc, and Nickel at MCX had also declined.

During April-November 2022, Mutual Funds recorded lower net inflows compared to the previous year. However, during the same period, some schemes comprising growth/equity-oriented schemes and solution-oriented schemes saw significantly higher inflows compared to the previous year. By contrast, income/debt-oriented schemes and hybrid schemes saw outflows compared to inflows in the same period last year. Outflows from liquid funds and hybrid schemes were mainly caused by increasing interest rate cycles, liquidity requirements, and advance tax commitments by corporates. Despite this, thanks to the market performance, the mutual fund industry's assets under management (AuM) increased by 8.1% as of November 2022 on a YoY basis.

According to Table IV .11, as of November 2022, the mutual funds industry's assets under management (AuM) have increased by 8.1% on a YoY basis, with a net resource mobilization of ₹0.7 lakh crore. Table IV .12 shows that in FY23, equity-oriented schemes saw net inflows of ₹0.9 lakh crore, whereas income/debt-oriented schemes saw outflows of ₹1.1 lakh crore and hybrid schemes saw outflows of ₹13,649 crore. Other schemes, including Index Funds, Gold ETFs, Other ETFs, and FoFs investing overseas, saw a net resource mobilization of ₹0.7 lakh crore.

headings: Monetary Management And Financial Inter Mediation
Net Investments by FPI registered outflows
Assets Under Custody for FPIs increased
explanations: This refers to the management of money supply and financial transactions in an economy. It includes policies and strategies implemented by the central bank to regulate inflation, interest rates, and ensure the smooth functioning of financial intermediaries. In India, strong macroeconomic fundamentals have ensured that the country remains an attractive destination for foreign portfolio investments.

Foreign Portfolio Investments (FPIs) refer to investments made by non-Indian entities in Indian financial assets such as stocks, bonds, and other securities. The table given in the content shows the assets under custody for FPIs which reflects the total market value of holdings. The total assets under custody with FPIs have increased by 3.4% at the end of November 2022 compared to November 2021, despite the outflows driven by global factors.

The overall net investments by Foreign Portfolio Investors during FY23 registered an outflow of ₹16,153 crore at the end of December 2022 from an outflow of ₹5,578 crore during FY22 at the end of December 2021. Both the equity segment and the debt segment witnessed net FPI outflows. The table provided in the content depicts the monthly FPI net investments (FY23) with equity, debt, debt-VRR, hybrid, and total investments in crore rupees.

Table IV .13 in the content shows the assets under custody for FPIs have increased in India despite the outflows driven by global factors. The table specifies the equity, debt, debt-VRR, hybrid, and total investments in lakh crore rupees at the end of November 2022 and November 2021. The increase in the total assets under custody with FPIs at the end of November 2022 compared to November 2021 was 54.0-52.2=1.8 lakh crore rupees.
Large capital outflows from EMDEs such as India and China, which are importers of commodities, were matched by inflows into commodity export-oriented markets such as Indonesia, Malaysia and Brazil.

Investments by Domestic Institutional Investors (DIIs) acted as a countervailing force against FPI outflows during recent years, rendering the Indian equity market relatively less susceptible to large scale corrections. Net DII inflows and net investment by mutual funds in equities were observed during FY23 (until November 2022).

The recent collapse of the crypto exchange FTX and the ensuing sell-off in the crypto markets have placed a spotlight on the vulnerabilities in the crypto ecosystem. Crypto assets are in need of a common approach to regulating the crypto ecosystem.

headings: Monetary Management And Financial Inter Mediation: A Good Year
Disqualification of Crypto Assets as Securities
Tricky Monitoring and Regulating of Cryptocurrencies
Crypto Intermediaries and Systemic Financial Market Infrastructures
explanations: The article discusses the current state of the crypto asset market and the concerns of regulators. It also highlights the need for a globally coordinated approach to regulating crypto assets.
US regulators have made the decision to disqualify certain crypto assets, including Bitcoin and Ether, as securities because they do not meet the criteria of being a financial asset.

The Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency released a joint statement on their concerns about the risks of crypto-assets to the banking system.
The article discusses the evolving global response to cryptocurrencies and highlights Box iV .1, which captures the current state of regulatory approaches to cryptos worldwide.
The article provides a graph of the crypto market capitalization over time.

Regulating and monitoring cryptocurrencies has been difficult for regulators across the globe. New intermediaries, such as crypto asset exchanges and wallet providers, have emerged and require users to trust centralised entities.

The increasing importance of crypto intermediaries may force regulators to consider them as systemic financial market infrastructures, but they are currently largely unregulated and a cause for concern globally.
Entities holding 85% of circulating Bitcoins are only 4.5% which is a concern
Underlying protocols used in crypto asset creation may conflict with public policy objectives like massive energy intensity of 'mining'
There are minimal global standards applicable to unbacked crypto assets which leave risks and vulnerabilities.
There are regulatory gaps in each stage of crypto assets' issuance, transfer, exchange, or storage by non-bank entities which limits the effectiveness of uncoordinated national approaches.
The terminology used to describe different activities, products and stakeholders is not globally harmonized.
Crypto actors like miners, validators and protocol developers may not be easily covered by traditional financial regulations.
European Union, Japan and Switzerland are among the countries and jurisdictions attempting to regulate unbacked crypto assets.

headings: Crypto asset regulation in United Kingdom
Legalization of crypto assets in Albania
Regulations on crypto assets in Nigeria
AML/CFT obligations for crypto asset providers
explanations: The Financial Conduct Authority published the Final Guidance on Crypto assets in June 2019 that declared security tokens within the regulatory purview, while unbacked crypto assets were outside of prudential and conduct regime. The UK Treasury proposed bringing crypto assets within its Financial Promotions Regime in January 2022, proposing subjecting crypto asset promotions to the same standards as for other financial promotions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore published guidelines in January 2022 to restrict the marketing of crypto assets, limiting promotions to an entity’s corporate website, official social media accounts, and mobile applications.

Albania's law on 'DLT-based Financial Markets' legalized crypto assets for investment purposes in May 2020. The regulation covers the issuance of digital tokens, virtual currencies, and the licensing, monitoring, and supervision of entities involved in distribution, trading, and custody. Albanian Financial Supervisory Authority and the National Agency for Information Society are competent authorities for unbacked crypto assets, and the Bank of Albania is responsible for stablecoins. Licensing of crypto asset providers relies heavily on third-party agents, Digital Token Agents licensed by AFSA and Innovative Service Providers licensed by NAIS.

The Central Bank of Nigeria declared in February 2018 that crypto assets are not legal tender in Nigeria. In February 2021, CBN prohibited dealing in crypto assets and facilitating payments for crypto asset service providers. The Securities and Exchange Commission published New Rules on Issuance, Offering Platforms and Custody of Digital Assets in May 2022, outlining digital asset offerings as within the purview of the SEC and imposing requirements on digital asset offering platforms and custodians.

FATF has stipulated AML/CFT obligations for crypto asset providers, however, their implementation is still a work in progress, leading the virtual asset and virtual asset service providers sector vulnerable to criminal and terrorist misuse. As of March 2022, only 11 jurisdictions have enforced and supervisory measures out of 29 responding jurisdictions that passed Travel Rule legislation. Global standards must be comprehensive and consistent, regulatory responses need to be based on standard taxonomies, reliable data, and flexible enough to be adjusted in the future.

headings: International Financial Services Centre (IFSC) in GIFT City
Emerging as a Preferred Jurisdiction for International Financial Services
explanations: The establishment of India's maiden International Financial Services Centre (IFSC) in GIFT City has opened up new opportunities for capital market players. The aim is to facilitate India in emerging as a significant economic power by accelerating the development of a strong base of International Financial Services in the country. This topic talks about the key role that IFSC can play in facilitating India's emergence as a preferred jurisdiction for international financial services and encouraging easier access and greater participation from foreign investors to bring in capital to further promote India's growth.

International Financial Centres (IFCs) contribute enormously to the growth of international financial transactions. The aim of this topic is to highlight the importance of setting up and operationalising India's maiden IFSC in GIFT City, which has played a pivotal role in accelerating the pace of financial globalisation. GIFT-IFSC is housed in India's first fully operational Smart City with world-class commercial, social and physical infrastructure. To bolster the development of IFSC, the Government took a major policy decision to establish the first of its kind, unified and agile financial sector regulator for IFSCs viz International Financial Services Centres Authority (IFSCA) through an Act of Parliament in 2019.

In pursuit of its vision to become an international financial centre of global stature, IFSCA has continuously engaged in deliberations with many globally prominent financial authorities and standard-setting bodies. To date, the Union Cabinet has approved the signing of 2 Multilateral MoUs.

IFSCA has signed Multilateral and Bilateral MoUs with foreign regulators to deepen cooperation and mutual exchange of information for the development of financial products and services in GIFT-IFSC. Multilateral MoUs have been signed with IOSCO and IAIS, and Bilateral MoUs have been signed with DFSA, QFCA, ADGM FSRA, AMF, CSSF Luxembourg, FI Sweden, and MAS.

IFSCA has entered into agreements for technical cooperation and capacity building for the development of a world-class regulatory environment for financial products and financial services in IFSC. One such agreement is the fintech bridge with Monetary Authority of Singapore to facilitate regulatory collaboration and partnership in Fintech and promote a Joint Regulatory Sandbox Collaboration.

NSE IFSC-SGX Connect is an essential milestone in the cross-border collaboration between India and Singapore in the area of capital markets. It is expected to consolidate volumes and deepen liquidity in derivative instruments at GIFT IFSC, bring in more international participants, and positively impact other financial ecosystems in GIFT IFSC.

IFSCA, with support from the Government of India, has instituted a flagship financial technology and global thought leadership event, “InFinity Forum” as an annual feature beginning in 2021. It aims to promote the FinTech ecosystem at GIFT IFSC and create visibility amongst the Global FinTech community.

headings: Cooperation agreement between India INX and Luxembourg Stock Exchange
explanations: The International FinTech Forum is a platform that brings together leading minds in policy, business, and technology to discuss and develop actionable insight into how the FinTech industry can leverage technology and innovation for inclusive growth. The first edition of the Forum held on the 3rd and 4th of December 2021, was inaugurated by the Prime Minister, with Indonesia, South Africa and the United Kingdom participating as partner countries. The event saw a total of 94,300 registrations, leaving behind a massive international footprint.

India INX, an IFSC-based exchange, signed a cooperation agreement with Luxembourg Stock Exchange on June 01, 2022. The two exchanges will endeavour to enhance the visibility of listed Indian securities towards international investors by facilitating the admission of such securities listed on LuxSE. The Agreement builds on the Memorandum of Understanding signed between the two institutions in November 2020, which focuses on advancing green finance in India. The green corridor opportunity established with this dual listing cooperation agreement between India INX and LuxSE will go a long way in attracting more issuers from India and the region and provides access to green capital from international investors.

FY23 is a watershed year for IFSC. It marks a decade of India’s maiden IFSC. The vision plan beyond 2022 revolves around elevating GIFT-IFSC to a virtuous self-sustaining trajectory towards becoming the nerve centre of new-age global financial services and activities. This aspirational pursuit of integrating our economy with the global financial ecosystem has been rich in learnings which are being systematically capitalised to design cutting-edge statutory and regulatory frameworks to lift the centre into a higher orbit of financial innovation and dynamism. Within years of its establishment, GIFT-IFSC has become a prominent gateway for the flow of global capital into India. Significant gains have been made in kickstarting experimental and innovative financial services such as bullion trading, aircraft and ship leasing, global-in house centres, Fintech, sustainable financing and cross-border bill discounting and factoring. Sophisticated financial products such as Bullion Depository Receipts, unsponsored Depository Receipts, and financial and operational leases have been introduced, with many more in the pipeline. State-of-the-art infrastructure has been created for wholesome quality of life with essential projects including metro connectivity, integrated residential projects, Central Park, Riverfront and recreational centres on the anvil. The foundation has been laid for creating a thriving knowledge economy by allowing foreign universities to set up operations in IFSC free of domestic regulations. Simultaneously, external assistance is mobilized to establish India’s premier Fintech Institute and Innovation Centre in GIFT City. The Centre, with an estimated cost of ₹800 crore, will underpin India’s growing stature and leadership in Fintech and attract the best of talent globally. Significantly, the Government’s vision for GIFT-IFSC transcends much beyond traditional finance and ventures into thought leadership. It is envisioned as the embodiment of Aatmanirbhar Bharat, a hub of ingenuity and innovation. As we advance, the vision entails a quantum leap in imagination and endeavors to transform GIFT City into a bustling financial hub, a vibrant city bearing a distinctively international character and pioneering solutions to complex problem statements involving finance.

headings: Monetary Management And Financial Inter Mediation
De-tariffication and its effect on premiums
explanations: The article discusses the good year for the insurance market, which is an integral part of the financial sector. Insurance plays a significant role in economic development by protecting against mortality, property, and casualty risks and providing a safety net. Moreover, the insurance sector encourages savings and provides long-term funds for infrastructure development. The development of the insurance sector is necessary to support its continued economic transformation.

The insurance market's potential and performance are generally assessed based on two parameters, viz., ‘insurance penetration' and ‘insurance density'. Insurance penetration is the ratio of total insurance premiums to Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in a year, while the insurance density is the ratio of insurance premium to population, i.e.; insurance premium per capita and is measured in US Dollar. Both parameters reflect the level of development of the insurance sector in a country. In 2021, total global insurance premiums grew by 3.4%, with the non-life insurance sector registering 2.6% growth, driven by rate hardening in commercial lines in developed markets. However, in China, the largest emerging market, non-life premium volumes contracted by 0.7% due to fierce competition and rate reductions arising from de-tariffication of motor insurance.

The life insurance segment bounced back strongly in global premium growth, registering an increase of 4.5%. The US remained the largest insurance market globally with $2.8 trillion total premiums (non-life and life) in 2021, followed by China and Japan. Emerging markets are expected to outpace developed markets in the insurance industry growth this year, with emerging Asia in the lead.

De-tariffication means removing the tariff structure, allowing insurance companies to charge premiums that match the risk profiles of its consumers. Different insurance companies can charge different prices to consumers for the same risk behavior based on their business risks models and strategies.

headings: Growth of Insurance Industry in India
explanations: Insurance penetration in India has increased steadily from 2.7 per cent around the turn of the millennium to 4.2 per cent in 2020 and remained the same in 2021. Life insurance penetration in India was 3.2 per cent in 2021, almost twice more than the emerging markets and slightly above the global average. However, most life insurance products sold in India are savings-linked, with just a small protection component. Hence, households remain exposed to a significant financing gap in the event of the premature death of the primary breadwinner. The insurance density in India has increased from US$ 11.1 in 2001 to US$ 91 in 2021 (density for Life insurance was US$ 69 and Non-Life insurance was US$ 22 in 2021) in keeping with the relatively faster expansion of the insurance market in the country.

During FY22, the gross direct premium of non-Life insurers (within and outside India) registered YoY growth of 10.8 per cent, primarily driven by health and motor segments. The net incurred claims of non-Life insurers stood at ₹1.4 lakh crore in FY22, primarily driven by rising per capita income, product innovations and customisation, development of strong distribution channels, and rising financial literacy. The life insurance premium registered YoY growth of 10.2 per cent in FY22, with new businesses contributing 45.5 per cent of the total premiums received by the life insurers. The life insurance industry paid benefits of ₹5.02 lakh crore in FY22, out of which 8.3 per cent benefits were on death claims.

Public listings improve public disclosure, corporate governance, and valuation. In keeping with this understanding, India’s largest life insurer, the Life Insurance Corporation of India, went public in May 2022, raising US$ 2.7 billion in the country’s largest IPO to date. The private insurance providers have also been seizing such opportunities. The largest private-sector health insurer in the country, was listed in December 2021, making it the fifth private-sector insurer to IPO. The insurance sector is highly competitive and is already witnessing mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity as insurers have tremendous opportunities and volume to co-

headings: Micro Insurance Regulations for Rural and Urban Poor
explanations: The Indian insurance market is growing rapidly with various government initiatives such as Ayushman Bharat Yojana, promoting financial inclusion and penetration of insurance across different sectors. Government schemes and financial inclusion programs have driven the adoption of insurance, leading to increased M&A activities in the sector along with various FDI inflows, IPOs, simplified rules & regulations and improved corporate valuations.

The General Insurance Business (Nationalisation) Amendment Act, 2021 allows the central government to pare its stake to less than 51 per cent of the equity capital in a specified insurer, thereby providing a lucrative opportunity for the government to privatize its stake in the insurance business.

In 2015, the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI) issued IRDAI (Micro Insurance) Regulations, 2015, which provide a platform for distributing affordable insurance products to the rural and urban poor segments of the population, thus promoting financial inclusion. Further, the IRDAI (Obligations of Insurers to Rural and Social Sectors) Regulations, 2015 stipulate obligations for insurers in rural and social sectors; promoting micro-insurance products in India. In FY21, 10.7 lakh new micro-insurance policies were issued to individuals with a new business premium of ₹355.3 crore (in the life-insurance segment), and 53,046 new microinsurance policies were issued in the general insurance segment (excluding standalone health insurers).

The government has initiated various insurance schemes and financial inclusion programs, for example, Ayushman Bharat Yojana, Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY), and IRDAI initiatives towards boosting insurance penetration. These programs have helped establish a strong insurance market, which is growing due to favorable demographic factors, product innovations, a conducive regulatory environment, and vibrant distribution channels. Ayushman Bharat Yojana provides health coverage of ₹5 lakh per beneficiary family per annum to poor and vulnerable families identified based on select deprivation and occupational criteria. Since inception, 19.7 crore beneficiaries have been provided Ayushman cards, and over 4.3 crore hospital admissions worth over ₹0.49 lakh crore have been authorized through a network of 28,667 empanelled health-care providers, including 13,115 private hospitals as of 20th January 2023.

headings: Pradhan Mantri Jeevan Jyoti Bima Yojana
explanations: Pradhan Mantri Suraksha Bima Yojana is a scheme aimed at providing risk coverage for accidental death, complete disability, and partial disability to its beneficiaries. As of 30th November 2022, 31.3 crore beneficiaries have been enrolled under the scheme, and 1.07 lakh claims have been disbursed.

Pradhan Mantri Jeevan Jyoti Bima Yojana is a scheme which credits ₹2 lakh to the savings bank account of the holder in case of the death of the insured. As of 30th November 2022, 14.4 crore beneficiaries have been enrolled under the scheme, and 6.3 lakh claims have been disbursed.

Pradhan Mantri Vaya Vandana Yojana provides old age income security to senior citizens through an assured pension/return linked to the subscription amount based on a government guarantee to LIC. A total of 8.6 lakh subscribers with a subscription amount of ₹84,659.4 crore deposited by these subscribers have benefited under the scheme as of 30th September 2022.

Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana provides risk insurance to farmers against crop damage due to non-preventable natural risks from pre-sowing to post-harvest for the crops/areas notified by the concerned State Government. During 2016 and 2022, 2763.9 lakh applications were received under the scheme, and claims of about ₹ 1.28 lakh crore have been paid to the farmers.

As per the Swiss Re Institute World Insurance: ‘Inflation risks front and centre report’, Global life premiums are expected to contract slightly in 2022 after last year’s robust recovery from pandemic-induced lows driven by inflationary pressures, economic uncertainty, and monetary tightening. Saving premiums are expected to decline due to volatility in the financial markets and as disposable incomes fall. Heightened risk awareness due to Covid-19 may continue to support demand for life protection (and health) insurance products.

India is one of the fastest-growing insurance markets in the world, with an estimated market share of 1.9% in 2021. India is expected to emerge as one of the top six insurance markets in the world by 2032, ahead of Germany, Canada, Italy, and South Korea. Further, the growth in the non-life insurance sector is likely to be driven by demand for health coverage, with people more aware of health security post-Covid-19 and strong support.

India's insurance market is rapidly digitising, with telematics and customer risk assessment being just a part of it. Various digital platforms have emerged over recent years, offering numerous services, including insurance purchases. The increase in Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) limit for insurance companies is likely to facilitate an increased flow of long-term capital, global technology, processes, and international best practices, which will support the growth of India's insurance sector.

The Pension sector in India has demonstrated remarkable performance during the Covid-19 pandemic. Pension systems have evolved globally, with advanced countries having substantial pension sectors, partly stemming from a large share of formal salaried employment. Pension assets in OECD countries stood at US$ 38.5 trillion, 66.9% of GDP. Countries undertook unprecedented and swift health and pension-related reforms to address health challenges, limit the impact of the crisis on labour markets, support incomes and adjust macroeconomic policies. India's Government announced various measures to provide pensions to families who have lost their earning members due to Covid and initiatives towards enhancing and liberalising insurance compensation.

Countries took measures to minimise the impact of Covid-19 on the marginalised, poor, and vulnerable sections such as subsidising wages and pension entitlements through the Job Retention Scheme (JRS), broadening access to unemployment benefits or grant of unemployment insurance to new groups of workers. The United States expanded the coverage of unemployment benefits to the self-employed and Chile permanently expanded the coverage to workers. New Zealand introduced a temporary benefit paid for up to three months to employees who lost their jobs and to the self-employed who stopped their activity.

Amid the unprecedented pandemic, Rule 64 of the CCS (Pension) Rules, 1972, was relaxed to ensure immediate provisional sanction of pensionary benefits. To enhance the 'Ease of Living' of pensioners, the government has done away with the requirement of a family pensioner to submit a non-earning certificate twice a year and exempted bereaved families of the need for a copy of Death Certificate.

Ayushman Bharat is a government-sponsored mass health program that aims to protect the economically vulnerable families in India from the financial burden of medical expenses. Amid the pandemic, the Government introduced initiatives for dependent family members of earning members who have lost their lives due to Covid-19. These members are entitled to a pension equivalent to 90% of the average daily wage drawn by the worker as per the existing norms.

As India's middle class expands and more people buy cars, compulsory motor third-party insurance is likely to multiply. This insurance provides coverage against damage caused to third party vehicles or property and bodily injury to third party personal or passengers. This insurance is mandatory as per the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, and underinsured motor insurance can result in heavy financial implications for the vehicle owner.

Dependent family members of earning members who have lost their lives due to Covid-19 are entitled to a pension equivalent to 90% of the average daily wage drawn by the worker as per the existing norms. The benefit of the Employee State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) pension scheme was extended to include these family members, even if they were not part of the scheme earlier.

Insurance benefits under the Employees Deposit Linked Insurance (EDLI) scheme were enhanced and liberalised. This scheme is for employees working in covered establishments such as factories, educational institutions, hospitals, among others, and it provides a lump sum amount payable to the nominee or family members in case of the employee's death while in service.

headings: Pension schemes under National Social Assistance Programme (NSAP)
Survey by PFRDA on NPS Subscribers
explanations: The 'Living' of Central Government Civil Pensioners integrated with Digi Locker, creating a permanent PPO record in the Digi Locker. Also, the timeline for submitting Life Certificate was relaxed, and doorstep facility was provided for pensioners for submission of the life certificate digitally.

Various pension schemes such as Indira Gandhi National Old Age Pension Scheme (IGNOAPS), Indira Gandhi National Widow Pension Scheme (IGNWPS), Indira Gandhi National Disability Pension Scheme (IGNDPS) are implemented under the National Social Assistance Programme (NSAP) to provide social security to the underprivileged and low-income individuals. The total beneficiary coverage of such schemes is 4.7 crore.

NPS is the primary pension system for government employees with a pay-as-you-go defined benefit plan. NPS for government employees is a defined contribution plan with co-contribution from the government. The value of the pension corpus is marked-to-market, and the rate of return is market determined. NPS was extended to all the citizens of the country in the age group of 18-70 years, including the unorganised sector workers (on a voluntary basis) in 2009. PFRDA launched “NPS-Corporate Sector Model” in 2011 to provide NPS to the employees of corporate entities, including PSUs.

APY was introduced in June 2015 to provide universal social security to all individuals aged 18-40 years, with an emphasis on underprivileged, unorganised, and low-income individuals. The total number of subscribers under APY registered a YoY growth of 25.1 per cent in November 2022. Female subscribers under APY have increased from nearly 16% in FY17 to 30.4% in FY21.

India's pension sector has expanded with the introduction of NPS and APY. In November 2022, the total number of subscribers under the NPS and APY registered a YoY growth of 25.1 per cent, with Assets under Management(AuM) witnessing a growth of 22.7 per cent during the same period. The overall contribution recorded an increase of 27.6 per cent in November 2022. Among the models, the All-Citizen model followed by the Corporate Sector recorded maximum growth.

A survey by PFRDA on the socio-economic characteristics of NPS subscribers (All Citizen Models) for the five-year period FY17 to FY21 showed that 24% were female subscribers, with the balance 76% being male subscribers. This contrasts with a better gender balance in the case of APY.

headings: Coverage of population under NPS and APY
Measures to ease accessibility of NPS and APY
Scope for growth in India's pension sector
Expansion of NPS expected from private sector
explanations: Enrollment in APY has increased from 38% to 44% between FY17 and FY22, with Maharashtra contributing the highest number of subscribers at 17%. The age profile of subscribers shows an increasing trend of enrollment among younger people, with 44.8% subscribers being between 18 and 25 years as of August 2022, compared to 29.3% in March 2016.

As of March 2022, around 76% of subscribers have opted for a monthly pension amount of ₹1000, compared to 38% in March 2016. The number of subscribers opting for ₹5000 per month pension has declined from 47% as of March 2016 to 15% as of March 2022.

The coverage of the population in pension under NPS and APY as a share of the total population has raised from 1.2% to 3.7% during the six years FY17 to FY22. Assets as a proportion of GDP have increased from 1.2% to 3.2%, reflecting that the pension sector is progressing much faster than the nominal growth of the economy and population.

PFRDA has taken various measures to ease the accessibility of NPS and APY to subscribers, such as reducing timelines for processing settlements to T+2 days. Central Recordkeeping Agencies have integrated their systems with DigiLocker to provide Subscriber Centric Services such as electronic-Pension Retirement Account Number (e-PRAN), electronic Account statements, and Aadhar & DigiLocker-based account openings. Government sector subscribers can change their investment choices online by submitting the request directly in the CRA login. The contributions through the UPI handle can be accepted for the benefit of NPS subscribers, permitting them to remit funds into their PRAN via the Virtual account number provided by CRA.

There is tremendous scope for growth in India’s pension sector as per capita income is expected to rise further as the economy transitions to a high-middle-income country. However, financial literacy is a significant challenge. PFRDA has taken several steps to enhance financial education so that consumers can make informed decisions and reap the benefit of the formal financial sector while being cognizant of risks and various trade-offs involved.

The future expansion in NPS is expected to emanate from the private sector, both the salaried and self-employed. Steps towards enhanced pension literacy, both of the subscribers and the intermediaries, coupled with a nudge from the regulator and the government, along with encouragement to young adults to join a pension scheme, would accelerate the movement towards a pensioned society.

India’s pension sector provides a flexible mode of old-age income security for salaried employees and the common person. In the recent five years, FY18 to FY22, the number of subscribers has multiplied over three-fold, led by APY, and AUM by over four-fold, led by NPS.

The domestic financial system has shown resilience, as shown by the healthy balance sheet of banks, strong capital levels of NBFCs, and robust growth in the AuM of domestic mutual funds. This robustness is enabling the system to absorb external spillovers while benefiting from improving asset quality and a return to profitability.
The buoyant demand for bank credit and early signs of a revival in the investment cycle are being supported by a return to profitability and resilient capital and liquidity buffers.
The IBC mechanism continues to support the ‘Ease of Doing Business’ in India by facilitating easy exit with time-bound resolutions for firms.

India is emerging as one of the top six insurance markets by 2032, with the digitisation of the insurance market and an increase in FDI limit for insurance companies facilitating an increased flow of long-term capital, global technology, processes, and international best practices.
