headings: Impact of Covid-19 Pandemic and Russia-Ukraine conflict on Human Development
explanations: The Human Development Report estimates the HDI in terms of three basic parameters: to live a long and healthy life, to be educated and knowledgeable, and to enjoy a decent economic standard of living. The HDI is calculated using four indicators: life expectancy at birth, mean years of schooling, expected years of schooling, and GNI per capita. As per the UNDP report, 90% of countries have registered a reduction in their HDI value in 2020 or 2021, indicating that human development across the world has stalled for the first time in 32 years. India ranked 132 out of 191 countries and territories in the 2021/2022 HDI report. India’s HDI value of 0.633 in 2021 places the country in the medium human development category, lower than its value of 0.645 in 2019. However, India’s HDI value continues to exceed South Asia’s average human development. It has been steadily increasing and moving towards the world average since 1990 due to priority placed on investment in social infrastructure, including ensuring universal health and education.

The Gender Inequality Index (GII) measures inequality in achievement between women and men in three dimensions: reproductive health, empowerment, and the labour market. It shows the loss in potential human development due to inequality between female and male achievements in these dimensions. As per the UNDP report, on the parameter of gender inequality, India’s GII value is 0.490 in 2021 and is ranked 122. This score is better than that of the South Asian region (value: 0.508) and close to the world average of 0.465. This reflects the Government’s initiatives and investments towards more inclusive growth, social protection, and gender-responsive development policies.

The aftermath of the peak of the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020 and 2021 and the ensuing Russia-Ukraine conflict in 2022 have impacted the development trajectory of India and the world. In the wake of these developments, there was a global decline in human development as per the UNDP report. 90% of countries have registered a reduction in their HDI value in 2020 or 2021, indicating that human development across the world has stalled for the first time in 32 years.

India’s HDI value has been steadily increasing and moving towards the world average since 1990 due to the priority placed on investment in social infrastructure, including ensuring universal health and education. This shows that social infrastructure development is crucial to improve human development parameters.

As per the UNDP report, India ranked 132 out of 191 countries and territories in the 2021/2022 HDI report with an HDI value of 0.633, placing the country in the medium human development category, lower than its value of 0.645 in 2019. However, India’s HDI value continues to exceed South Asia’s average human development. The table in the given data shows India's position and trends in the global HDI 2021 with other countries' HDI values and ranks.
The country’s progress in dealing with multidimensional poverty is presented in Box VI.1, which is not included in the given data.

headings: United Nations Development Programme's Global Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI)
explanations: Poverty is not solely a lack of financial means for basic living but includes numerous components that lead to various disadvantages such as poor health, malnutrition, lack of sanitation, clean water or electricity, deficient quality of education, and much more.

Multidimensional poverty measures reveal a more comprehensive picture of poverty, who is poor, how they are poor, and the various deprivations they experience. One such measure is the UNDP's global Multidimensional Poverty Index, which measures acute multidimensional poverty across over 100 developing countries.

MPI measures acute multidimensional poverty across more than 100 developing countries, measuring each person's overlapping deprivations over 10 indicators in three dimensions: health, education, and the standard of living. Health and education dimensions are based on two indicators each, while the standard of living is based on six indicators. The MPI ranges from 0-1, and higher values imply higher multidimensional poverty.

All the indicators used to build MPI for a country are taken from the same household survey. Each indicator receives an equal weighting within its dimension; the health and education indicators are weighted 1/6 each, and the standard of living indicators are weighted 1/18 each.
The MPI complements the USD 1.90-a-day poverty line an identifies who is multidimensionally poor, highlighting the composition of multidimensional poverty.

According to the 2022 UNDP MPI report that covers 111 developing countries, 16.4% of India's population (228.9 million people in 2020) is multidimensionally poor, while 18.7% are vulnerable to multidimensional poverty (260.9 million people in 2020). The average deprivation score among the multidimensionally poor in India is 42%, and the MPI value is 0.069.

The percentage of multidimensionally poor people in India has decreased from 55.1% in 2005-2006 to 16.4% in 2019-2021. Similarly, the number of multidimensionally poor people in India has decreased from 65 crores in 2005-2006 to 23 crores in 2019-2021.

headings: Percentage of People Multidimensionally Poor and Deprived
Progress in physical infrastructure in villages
explanations: The report compares multidimensional poverty with monetary poverty measured by the percentage of the population living below the 2011 PPP of US$1.90 per day. It shows that monetary poverty does not present the complete picture. The headcount or incidence of multidimensional poverty is 6.1 percentage points lower than the incidence of monetary poverty. This implies that individuals living below the monetary poverty line may have access to non-income resources.

The report suggests that in India, 41.5 crore people exited poverty between 2005-06 and 2019-21, demonstrating that the SDG target 1.2 of reducing at least by half the proportion of men, women, and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions by 2030 is possible to achieve. The poorest states and groups (children, lower castes and those living in rural areas) reduced poverty the fastest in absolute terms, although the data do not reflect post-Covid-19 pandemic changes. Among the multidimensionally poor, deprivation prevalence declined across deprivation categories.

The data shows the percentage of people who are multidimensionally poor and deprived of various indicators such as nutrition, child mortality, years of schooling, school attendance, cooking fuel, sanitation, drinking water, electricity, housing, and assets in 2015-16 and 2019-21.

Dr. Sundipto Mundle reports about considerable progress in physical infrastructure such as roads, houses, digital connectivity, adequate irrigation facilities, Public Distribution System (PDS), education facilities in four backward villages in Jharkhand. With the intervention of the State and the general market development, extreme deprivation and hunger have been eliminated in these villages.

The Government of India launched the ‘Transformation of Aspirational Districts’ (Aspirational Districts Programme (ADP)) initiative in January 2018. The vision of the program is to raise living standards of its citizens and ensuring inclusive growth of all in the burgeoning economy. The districts are prodded and encouraged first to catch up with the best district of their state, and subsequently aspire to become one of the best in the country by 2022.

The Aspirational Districts (ADs) Programme is a programme launched by NITI Aayog, which identifies 117 districts across 28 states and Union Territories based on composite indicators such as health and nutrition, education, agriculture, and water resources, financial inclusion and skill development, and basic infrastructure. The programme aims to drive convergence, collaboration and competition among districts through a mass movement, and focuses on the strengths of each district to identify low-hanging fruits for immediate improvement. Progress is measured through ranking districts every month based on incremental progress made across 49 Key Performance Indicators (KPI) under five broad socio-economic themes.

NITI Aayog has developed a broad template for the formulation of district plans, which can be customised by different districts depending on their opportunities and challenges. Additionally, a primer comprising steps to be taken to improve each of the indicators has also been developed with the help of Central Ministries and the States and shared with district administration.

The Aspirational Districts Programme has led to several achievements, such as many ADs surpassing the average state values in several indicators under the Health and Nutrition theme monitored under the programme. The programme monitors progress across five focus sectors and all districts have made significant improvements across different indicators. While monitoring the outcome of financial inclusion, it was seen that ADs have performed better than non-aspirational districts. Several ADs have also reported saturation in the basic infrastructure indicators such as the percentage of households with electricity connection and the percentage of habitations with drinking water facility.

The government has implemented the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) to provide all-weather roads. The percentage of completion of this work as per the total sanctioned kilometres and the percentage of households with individual household washrooms are monitored to improve social infrastructure and employment opportunities.

The Aspirational Districts Programme (ADP) has emerged as a template for good governance, especially in remote and difficult areas. Two new programmes - 'Mission Utkarsh' and 'Aspirational Blocks Programme' (ABP) have been launched following the ADP template. These programmes aim to bring underperforming districts at par with an average district in the state in one year and close to the all-India average in another. The ADP template is also being used to identify and develop the 500 most backward blocks across states and UTs.

29 Central Labour Laws were amalgamated, rationalised, and simplified into four Labour Codes - Code on Wages, 2019, Industrial Relations Code, 2020, Code on Social Security, 2020, and Occupational Safety, Health & Working Conditions Code, 2020. These laws accommodate the minimum wage requirement and welfare needs of the unorganised sector workers, including the self-employed and migrant workers, while aligning with the present economic scenario and technological advancements. Compliance mechanism has been eased to promote ease of doing business/setting up of enterprises and catalyse creation of employment opportunities while ensuring safety, health and social security of every worker.

Rules made under the Labour Codes have been entrusted to the Central and State Governments. Pre-publication of draft rules in the official gazettes for public consultation is mandatory. As of 13 December 2022, many states have pre-published draft rules under each Labour Code.

headings: Status of rules under the four labor codes
explanations: The table Vi.3 of the Economic Survey 2022-23 lists the names of States/UTs which have pre-published the draft rules for the Code on Wages 201, the Industrial Relations Code 2020, the Code on Social Security 2020, and the Occupational Safety Health and working Conditions Code 2020. The data shows that majority of the States and UTs have published draft rules under all four labor codes.

The Ministry of Labour and Employment (MoLE) has developed the e-Shram portal for creating a National database of unorganized workers verified with Aadhaar. It captures details of workers and includes migrant workers, construction workers, gig and platform workers, etc. Currently, e-Shram portal has been linked to NCS portal and ASEEM portal for seamless facilitation of services. As of 31 December 2022, more than 28.5 crore unorganized workers have been registered on eShram portal, of which 52.8% are females.

The e-Shram portal has received a total of 155 crore registrations, with 52.4% of the total registrations coming from workers in the agriculture sector. Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and West Bengal accounted for nearly half of total registrations, and the majority of registrations (approximately 91%) were from workers below the age of 40.

Aadhaar is a 12-digit unique identification number that provides a digital identity to the residents of India. It is a tool for social delivery by the state, with 318 Central schemes and over 720 state DBT schemes using Aadhaar for targeted delivery of financial services, subsidies, and benefits. As of November 2022, 135.2 crore Aadhaar numbers have been generated. Aadhaar serves as a crucial connection between the photograph of the Aadhaar holder, their fingerprints, and iris scan details, and has been described by Nobel laureate Paul Romer as 'the most sophisticated ID programme in the world.'

Aadhaar has replaced the need for multiple IDs for multiple purposes, simplifying the process of identification and securing the social contract between the state and the citizen. The digital identity provided by Aadhaar plays a vital role in the development of India's digital economy and gives the country a global competitive advantage in how money and goods move around the country over its competitors.

headings: One Nation One Ration Card (ONORC) Scheme
explanations: This topic covers the statistics of Aadhaar updates, authentication and eKYC, along with the usage of Aadhaar in different services.

This topic highlights the usage of Aadhaar in Direct Benefit Transfer, wherein an individual's Aadhaar number when linked with their bank account serves as the 'Financial Address' for payment transfers, leading to financial inclusion. It also mentions the successful implementation of various schemes through the JAM trinity empowered by Aadhaar.

This topic explains the usage and benefits of AEPS, through which banking transactions like withdrawal, deposit, and transfer can be done using Aadhaar. It has made doorstep banking services feasible, especially during the Covid-19 pandemic.

This topic explains the implementation of the ONORC Scheme, with Aadhaar being crucial in eliminating ghost and duplicate beneficiaries through seeding in PDS database. It has brought transparency and back-office improvement in the logistic network of PDS.
This topic highlights the usage of Aadhaar in the implementation of PM Kisan Samman Nidhi Scheme, starting from registration to DBT through APB.
This topic explains the importance of Aadhaar in the successful management of the Covid pandemic through the development of the Co-WIN platform and transparent administration of vaccine doses.

headings: Measures to cushion the impact of Covid-19 on MSMEs
explanations: The use of face as an additional modality of authentication is increasing. This has helped, especially the elderly, to get ‘Jeevan Praman’ through their smartphones to avail of pension.

The UIDAI is mandated to develop the policy, procedure, and system for issuing an Aadhaar number to each resident individual and performing authentication. The ecosystem for the purpose consists of Aadhaar counters, Child Enrolment Lite Client devices, Active Registrars, Enrolment Agencies, Aadhaar Sewa Kendra, Village Level Entrepreneurs, postmen/Grameen Dak Sewaks, Aadhaar User Agencies, and e-KYC user agencies.

Employment trends can be studied from the supply side of labour through household surveys and the demand side of labour through enterprise or establishment surveys. Broad-based improvement in employment indicators is observed in data covering both the supply side and demand side of the labour market. The unemployment rate has fallen from 5.8% in 2018-19 to 4.2% in 2020-21. Rural FLFPR has risen from 19.7% in 2018-19 to 27.7% in 2020-21. The net addition to EPFO payroll is moving upward in 2021-22. Employment in nine major sectors has increased by 10 lakh over the year 2021-22. Employment in the organised manufacturing sector has also been rising over the years.
Multiple measures have been taken to cushion the impact of Covid-19 on MSMEs, which may have contributed to the steady increase in employment levels.

headings: Employment Trends as per Usual Status
explanations: The Economic Survey 2022-23 shows trends in employment on the supply and demand side from various data sources.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 presents data on the supply side of employment, which includes labour force participation rate (LFPR), worker population ratio (WPR) and unemployment rate (UR) for both males and females in rural and urban areas.

The labour force participation rate (LFPR), worker population ratio (WPR) and unemployment rate (UR) in Annual Periodic Labour Force Survey 2020-21 for both males and females in both rural and urban areas has improved compared to previous years.
Employment trends based on the usual status (principal status + subsidiary status) for persons for all ages in rural, urban and rural+urban areas.

Current weekly status (CWS) is a stricter benchmark than the usual status, which captures the loss of employment duration during events such as a pandemic. CWS shows that labour market indicators recovered swiftly from 2019-20 to 2020-21 for both males and females.

Rural labour market indicators have been improving for both males and females, while the urban labour market is slightly behind pre-Covid levels in 2020-21. However, the recovery of urban labour markets beyond pre-Covid levels is discernible.

The Annual Periodic Labour Force Survey defines LFPR as the percentage of working-age population engaged in work or making tangible efforts to seek 'work'. WPR is defined as the percentage of employed persons in the total population. UR is the percentage of unemployed persons in the labour force.

For a person to be categorized as employed as per usual status (ps+ss), they must have pursued an economic activity for at least 30 days during the 365 days preceding the date of the survey. For a person to be categorized as employed as per current weekly status, they must have pursued an economic activity for at least 1 hour in the preceding 7 days.

The employment trends in India have seen a decline from 8.3 per cent in July-September 2019 to 7.2 per cent in July-September 2022. The labor force participation rate (LFPR) has increased from 47.3 per cent to 47.9 per cent during the same period. Data from Table Vi.5 indicates the employment trends for ages 15-plus in rural, urban, and rural+urban areas.

Table Vi.5 provides data on the Current Weekly Status of Employment for ages 15-plus in rural, urban, and rural+urban areas. It includes data on male and female labor force participation rate (LFPR), work participation rate (WPR), and unemployment rate (UR) for 2018-19, 2019-20, and 2020-21. The data shows an increase in male and female LFPR and WPR, but a decline in UR in 2019-20 as compared to 2018-19. However, the urban UR has increased in 2019-20 as compared to 2018-19. In 2020-21, there is a further increase in male and female LFPR and WPR, but a decline in UR in both urban and rural areas.

According to Paragraph 6.30, there has been an increase in the share of self-employed and a decline in the share of regular wage/salaried workers in 2020-21 as compared to 2019-20 in both rural and urban areas. The share of casual labor has also slightly declined in rural areas. Figure Vi.3 shows the trends in broad employment status for persons in rural+urban areas.

Based on the industry of work, the share of workers engaged in agriculture has risen marginally from 45.6 per cent in 2019-20 to 46.5 per cent in 2020-21. The share of workers engaged in manufacturing, however, has declined, as stated in Paragraph 6.31.

headings: Changes in Sectoral Shares of Employment
Changes in Female Labour Force Participation Rate across States
Measurement Issues in Female Labour Force Participation Rate
explanations: The share of employment in the manufacturing sector declined faintly from 11.2% to 10.9% while construction increased from 11.6% to 12.1%. The share of trade, hotel & restaurants declined from 13.2% to 12.2% over the period of July 2020 to June 2021, which could be a result of the impact of Covid on manufacturing and services employment, while agricultural growth remained strong. This data is presented in Economic Survey 2022-23.

The rising FLFPR (by 9.5 percentage points (pp) in 2017-18 to 2020-21 for usual status and by 8.3 pp for CWS) shows positive development on the gender aspect of employment. This could be attributed to rising rural amenities freeing up women’s time and high agricultural growth over the years. The changes in FLFPR are depicted in Figure Vi.4. The measurement issues in female labour force participation rate are covered under Box Vi.2. PLFS, MoSPI is the data source for the data presented in both cases.

Figure Vi.4 depicts the change in female labour force participation rate across various states of India. The percentage points change is shown on the y-axis and states are shown on the x-axis. The source of data is PLFS, MoSPI.

Box Vi.2 covers the measurement issues in female labour force participation rate. These issues arise due to the survey design and content, which can have a significant impact on the final LFPR estimates, particularly for measuring female LFPR compared to male LFPR. The three main measurement issues highlighted are overly broad categories, reliance on a single question to categorize labour force status, and the narrow approach of limiting productive work to labour force participation. The source of information is the Economic Survey 2022-23.

headings: No recovery questions in the PLFS questionnaire
explanations: The augmented female LFPR is the proportion of women in Activity code 93 added to the official LFPR. The value for FY21 for ages 15 years and above is 46.2 per cent, which is much higher than the conventional definition's estimate of 32.5 per cent. A similar attempt made by ILO research paper arriving at a female LFPR of 56.4 per cent in India for 2012, against the far lower official estimate of 31.2 per cent for 2012.

Female LFPR for rural and urban areas is shown for the period 1999-00 to 2020-21. The official and augmented values are estimated using NSO data with the source being NSS Employment Unemployment Survey for 1999-00 to 2011-12 and PLFS from 2017-18 to 2011-12. However, NSS-EUS and PLFS may not be comparable, given different sampling weights, frequencies, and data collection techniques.

The PLFS questionnaire does not have any recovery questions for measuring labour force status of an individual. The survey design relies mainly on a single question, eliminating scope to rectify any error in self-reporting. This can lead to underestimation of female employment-to-population ratio, as seen in a World Bank and ILO study in Sri Lanka.

There is a need to broaden the horizon of measuring work, which constitutes the whole universe of productive activities alongside employment. Productive work is not limited to labour force participation according to the latest ILO standards. The definition of work is aligned with the General production boundary as defined in the System of National Accounts 2008, including own use production work and volunteer work.

headings: Role of Self-Help Groups in Women's Empowerment
explanations: The current market-based measures of work do not include the value of women's unpaid domestic work, such as collecting firewood, cooking, tutoring children, and other activities that contribute significantly to the household's standard of living. Therefore, improved quantification through redesigned surveys is necessary to provide a more comprehensive measurement of work.

The current measures to nullify gender-based disadvantages to enable free choice of women to join the labor market need improvement. To unlock the gender dividend for inclusive and broad-based growth, the introduction of ecosystem services, including affordable creches, career counseling/handholding, lodging, and transportation would be helpful.

Self-Help Groups (SHGs) can play a crucial role in shaping rural women's potential into concrete developmental outcomes of financial inclusion, livelihood diversification, and skill development. SHGs in India have existed for around 50 years, and more than 88% of them are all-women SHGs. Success stories include Kudumbashree in Kerala, Jeevika in Bihar, Mahila Arthik Vikas Mahila Mandal in Maharashtra, and Looms of Ladakh. The SHG-BLP covers 14.2 crore families through 119 lakh SHGs with savings deposits of `47,240.5 crore and 67 lakh groups with collateral-free loans outstanding of `1,51,051.3 crore, as of March 31, 2022. The number of SHGs credit linked has grown at a CAGR of 10.8% during the last ten years (FY13 to FY22), while credit disbursement per SHG has grown at a CAGR of 5.7% during the same period.

More than 75% of rural female workers in India are employed in the agricultural sector. Therefore, there is a need to upskill and create employment for women in agriculture-related sectors such as food processing. Self-Help Groups (SHGs) can support women's empowerment in agriculture-related sectors by forming partnerships for financial inclusion, increasing livelihood diversification, and improving skill development.

headings: Impact of SHGs on Women Empowerment
Covid-19 Response as a Montage of SHG’s Potential
explanations: This table displays the progress made under the SHG-Bank Linkage Programme from 2019-20 to 2021-22. It includes the number of SHGs, amount of savings with banks, and loans disbursed to SHGs during the year. The table also provides a breakdown of data for all women SHGs and DAY-NRLM SHGs. Figures in parentheses indicate the increase or decrease over the previous year. The data is sourced from NABARD.

This section highlights the positive impact of women's economic SHGs on women's economic, social, and political empowerment. These SHGs provide various pathways for empowerment such as familiarizing with handling money, financial decision-making, improved social networks, asset ownership, and livelihood diversification. An assessment of DAY-National Rural Livelihood Mission shows high impacts of the programme in areas related to women empowerment and self-esteem enhancement among others. The assessment also shows medium impacts in terms of better education, higher participation in village institutions, and better access to government schemes.

The Indian government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic includes a package for SHGs. Under the PMGKY, the limit for collateral-free loans for women's SHGs was doubled from `10 lakh to `20 lakh, which is expected to benefit 63 lakh women SHGs and 6.85 crore households. This section emphasizes the potential of SHGs to contribute to the COVID-19 response.

headings: SHGs and their Role in Crisis Management during Covid-19 Pandemic
Additional Vulnerability Reduction Fund for Village Organisations under NRLM
Contribution of SHGs in Producing Masks During Covid-19 Pandemic
Quarterly PLFS Data for Urban Areas
explanations: The years of pestilence acted as an opportunity towards mobilising SHG women to unite, transcend their group identity, and collectively contribute to crisis management. SHGs played a crucial role in producing masks, delivering essential goods, running community kitchens, supporting farm livelihoods, and delivering financial services. By 4th January 2023, more than 16.9 crore masks were produced by SHGs under DAY-NRLM. SHGs are well-placed to facilitate overall rural development due to their access to the last mile, community's trust and solidarity, knowledge of local dynamics and ability to manufacture simple products and services through the aggregation of members' economic activities. The demonstration of their resilience and flexibility during crises, including Covid, needs to be regularised for long-run rural transformation. Hence, addressing inter-regional disparity in the deepening of the SHG movement, graduating SHG members into micro-entrepreneurs, culturally contextualised skill development, and including the least privileged under the SHG umbrella needs to be addressed.

The NRLM has allowed for an additional Vulnerability Reduction Fund of `1.5 lakh to be extended to Village Organisations (VOs) in Covid hotspot areas and for vulnerable groups. This additional fund will help in reducing the vulnerability of VOs and support them in crisis management during the pandemic.

SHGs played a significant role in producing masks during the Covid-19 pandemic. They produced masks with cultural variants such as Gamusa Masks in Assam, enabling access to and use of masks by communities in remote rural areas, providing vital protection against the Covid-19 virus. SHGs women united and collectively contributed towards producing masks, and it emerged as a noteworthy contribution. By 4th January 2023, more than 16.9 crore masks were produced by SHGs under DAY-NRLM.

The MoSPI conducts Quarterly PLFS for urban areas, and the data until July-September 2022 is available. The data shows an improvement in all key labour market indicators both sequentially and year-on-year, as per the CWS. The Labour Participation Rate increased to 47.9% in July-September 2022 from 46.9% a year ago, while the Worker-Population Ratio strengthened from 42.3% to 44.5% in the same period. The Unemployment Rate declined from 9.8% in July-September 2021 to 7.2% in July-September 2022. This trend highlights that the labour markets have recovered from the Covid impact.

explanations: The figure VI.5 in the given content presents the quarterly urban employment indicators. It shows the data for the period July-September 2019 to January-March 2022 in terms of the following indicators: Labour Force Participation Rate, Worker Population Ratio, and Unemployment Rate. The data has been sourced from Quarterly PLFS Reports, MoS&PI.

The given content highlights the composition of the urban workforce for the period July-September 2022. The share of self-employed, regular wage/salaried, and casual labour was 39.7%, 48.7%, and 11.6% respectively. The share of workers engaged in the secondary sector was 33.4%, while the share of workers engaged in the tertiary sector was 60.9%.

The Quarterly Employment Survey (QES), conducted by the Labour Bureau, covers establishments with ten or more workers in nine major sectors such as manufacturing, construction, trade, transport, education, health, accommodation & restaurants, IT/BPOs, and financial services. The nine sectors account for around 83% of the total employment in establishments with ten or more workers as per the 6th Economic Census (2013-14) conducted by MoSPI. So far, results of four rounds of the QES have been released, covering four quarters of FY22. The estimated total employment in the nine selected sectors according to the fourth round of QES (January to March 2022) stood at 3.2 crore, which is nearly ten lakh higher than the estimated employment from the first round of QES (April-June 2021).

In the nine selected sectors covered by the QES, regular employees constituted the majority of workers across sectors, with a share of 86.4% in the total workforce in Q4FY22. Contractual employees formed a relatively small proportion of the workforce in these nine sectors, except Manufacturing (12.4%) and Construction (19.0%). The rise in employment estimates from Q1FY22 to Q4FY22 was driven by rising employment in sectors such as IT/BPO, health, and education, due to the rising digitisation and resurgence of the services sector economy.

The ASI, conducted by MoSPI, is an important source of industrial statistics of the registered organized manufacturing sector of the economy. As per the latest ASI FY20, employment in the organized manufacturing sector has maintained a steady upward trend over time, with the employment per factory increasing gradually.

The food products industry (11.1 per cent) remained the largest employer in the organized manufacturing sector, followed by wearing apparel (7.6 per cent), basic metals (7.3 per cent), and motor vehicles, trailers, and semi-trailers (6.5 per cent).

State-wise, Tamil Nadu had the largest number of persons engaged in factories (26.6 lakh), followed by Gujarat (20.7 lakh), Maharashtra (20.4 lakh), Uttar Pradesh (11.3 lakh), and Karnataka (10.8 lakh).

The ASI survey covers all factories registered under Sections 2m(i) and 2m(ii) of the Factories Act, 1948, i.e., those factories employing ten or more workers using power; and those employing twenty or more workers without using power.

explanations: The given chart shows the total number of persons engaged in factories by various states/UTs in India as per ASI data in FY20. The chart depicts that Tamil Nadu has the highest number of persons engaged in factories with over 30 lakhs, followed by Gujarat and Maharashtra with around 20 lakhs each. Uttar Pradesh and Karnataka also have a significant number of persons engaged in factories with over 15 lakhs each. The chart highlights that states/UTs with at least one lakh total persons engaged in the factory sector have been shown.

The given content highlights that out of 1,98,628 factories in operation, 1,34,577 factories have less than 50 employees each. This data shows a skewed distribution of a larger number of factories with low employment sizes and a few factories with higher employment sizes. However, the distribution of persons engaged shows that larger factories account for a greater share of employment. In fact, 77.3% of the total persons engaged in factories are in factories engaging more than 100 persons.

The chart 'Vi.9' depicts trends in employment in factories as per ASI data. It can be observed that most factories have low employment ranges with factories employing 50-99 employees being the most common. However, larger factories employing more than 100 workers have seen a rise in their numbers by 12.7% from FY17 to FY20, compared to a broadly constant number of smaller factories. Further, total persons engaged in larger factories rose by 13.7% between FY17 and FY20, compared to 4.6% in smaller factories. This suggests a scaling up of manufacturing units with employment rising in larger factories (employing more than 100 workers) than in smaller ones.

headings: Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority (PFRDA) data
explanations: The organised sector job market conditions measured by payroll data for Employees’ Provident Fund Organisation (EPFO) and Employees’ State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) reveal the benefits of the government initiatives towards improvement in the labour market. EPFO data indicates a consistent YoY increase in payroll addition, pointing towards improved formalisation as economic activities picked up. The net addition in EPF subscriptions during FY22 was 58.7 per cent higher than in FY21 and 55.7 per cent higher than that in the pre-pandemic year 2019. In FY23, net average monthly subscribers added under EPFO increased from 8.8 lakh in April-November 2021 to 13.2 lakh in April-November 2022. The swift rebound of formal sector payroll addition can be attributed to the Aatmanirbhar Bharat Rojgar Yojana (ABRY), launched in October 2020 to boost the economy, increase the employment generation in post Covid-19 recovery phase, and to incentivise creation of new employment along with social security benefits and restoration of employment lost during the pandemic. As on 7 January 2023, total registration under the scheme is 75.1 lakh, and total benefits of `8,210 crore have been given to 60.2 lakh beneficiaries through 1.5 lakh establishments. Average monthly subscriber additions under ESIC for April-October period improved from 11.9 lakhs in 2021 to 14.4 lakh in 2022. Similarly, under National Pension Scheme (NPS), the average monthly net subscriptions increased from 61.9 thousand in 2021 to 63.2 thousand in 2022 for the April-October period.

According to the ASI, MoSPI data, factories employing less than 100 workers and those employing more than 100 workers provide employment to lakhs of people. The table shows the number of workers by employment size of factories for the years between 2016-17 and 2019-20. Similarly, the table shows the total persons engaged by employment size of factories for the same years. The data suggests that the size of the factory plays a significant role in determining the employment opportunities.

The government's focus is on generating employment opportunities while improving employability. The priority is to formalise employment, which has shown a consistent YoY increase in payroll addition as per EPFO data. The Aatmanirbhar Bharat Rojgar Yojana (ABRY) has contributed to the swift rebound of the formal sector payroll addition. The scheme was launched to boost the economy, increase employment generation in the post-COVID-19 recovery phase, incentivise the creation of new employment, and restore employment lost during the pandemic. The increase in average monthly subscriber additions under ESIC and NPS also indicates an improvement in social infrastructure for employment.

The data from Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority (PFRDA) shows the average monthly net subscriptions under National Pension Scheme (NPS) increasing from 61.9 thousand in 2021 to 63.2 thousand in 2022 for the April-October period.

Expert services comprising of manpower agencies, private security agencies, and small contractors form the largest share of EPFO payroll addition (41.1% in FY23, April-November), followed by trading-commercial establishments (6.9%). The number of persons demanding work under MGNREGS in FY23 was 6.49 crore households, out of which 6.48 crore households were offered employment. Strong agricultural growth and a swift recovery from Covid induced slowdown led to better employment opportunities, contributing to the normalisation of the rural economy.

The number of works done under MGNREGS has increased over time, with 85 lakh completed works in FY22 and 70.6 lakh completed works so far in FY23 (as on 9 January 2023). The majority of completed works in FY22 were 'works done on individual's land' and this has had a significant positive impact on agricultural productivity, production-related expenditure, and income per household, as well as reducing migration and fall in indebtedness.

'Works done on individual's land' refer to creating household assets such as animal sheds, farm ponds, dug wells, horticulture plantations, vermicomposting pits etc., where the beneficiary gets both labour and material costs as per standard rates. The share of these works has increased from 16% of the total completed works in FY15 to 73% in FY22, and has long-term implications for aiding income diversification and infusing resilience into rural livelihoods.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 provides data on the number of completed and ongoing projects under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS) for the financial years 2013-14 to 2022-23. The data is presented in two figures, namely, Figure Vi.12 and Figure Vi.13. Figure Vi.12 shows the number of projects under MGNREGS and their count in lakh. Figure Vi.13 presents the share of completed works under the scheme by count for different financial years.

The MGNREGS has various project categories that aim to create employment opportunities in rural areas. These categories include land development share, micro irrigation share, renovation of traditional water bodies, rural connectivity, rural sanitation, water conservation and water harvesting, work on individual's land, flood control & protection, drought proofing, and others. The data on completed and ongoing projects under each of these categories can be obtained from the MGNREGS web portal, with data for FY23 being available as of 10th January 2023.

The National Career Service (NCS) project is a measure taken by the government to enhance the reach of employment opportunities to all eligible and willing to work individuals. Details on this project are available in Box VI.4 of the Economic Survey 2022-23.

The National Career Service (NCS) project is a one-stop solution providing employment and career-related services, with the aim of bridging the gap between candidates and employers. It has a job fair module to streamline the process of job fair activity on a single online platform by engaging stakeholders like model career centres, nodal officers, job seekers, and employers. As of January 5, 2023, 2.8 crore jobseekers and 6.8 lakh employers have registered on the NCS portal. NCS has partnered with the private sector under DigiSaksham to offer a free, self-paced Online/Offline Training Programme to equip job seekers with an array of soft and digital skills. It is also working closely with the Ministry of Education, All India Council for Technical Education, and All India Survey of Higher Education to ensure its benefits reach prospective students/candidates. Online integration with EPFO and ESIC has been done to link willing employers to a countrywide database of workforce on NCS portal. NCS has recently added an 'International Job' module on the portal, facilitating employers registered with the Ministry of External Affairs to post international job opportunities on the NCS portal and job seekers to search and apply for these opportunities via the NCS portal.

Nominal rural wages have increased at a steady positive rate during FY23 (till November 2022). In agriculture, the YoY rate of growth of nominal wage rates was 5.1 per cent for men and 7.5 per cent for women, during the period April-November 2022. In non-agriculture, the YoY rate of nominal wage rates was 7.9 per cent for men and 10.5 per cent for women, during the same period.

explanations: The Economic Survey for 2022-23 presents data on the trends in nominal and real rural wages in the agriculture and non-agriculture sectors. The growth of nominal wage rates during the last year for men and women was 4.7% and 3.7%, respectively. However, growth in real rural wages has been negative due to elevated inflation. It is expected that as inflation softens with the easing of international commodity and domestic food prices, there will be a rise in real wages.

Figure Vi.14 presents trends in rural wages in the agriculture and non-agriculture sectors. The first set of graphs show trends in nominal rural wages for men and women in agriculture and non-agriculture sectors. The second set of graphs show trends in real rural wages for men and women in agriculture and non-agriculture sectors. These graphs indicate the changes in rural wages from May-2020 to Nov-2022.

The Economic Survey for 2022-23 highlights the importance of quality education for all. It is the foundation of an individual's and society's development. Education enhances the employability of the working-age population, and it also has an equalising impact in breaking the cycles of poverty and social marginalisation. As quoted by Dr. A.P.J Abdul Kalam, ‘Learning gives creativity, creativity leads to thinking, thinking leads to knowledge, and knowledge makes you great !’

Goal 4 under UN SDGs (SDG4), aims to “Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all” by 2030. This goal is of critical importance because of the transformative effects that it can have on most other SDGs, such as “no poverty”, “zero hunger”, “gender equality” etc.

The NEP 2020 was laid down as the first education policy of the 21st century for India, aiming to address the many growing developmental imperatives of the country. Recognising that education is the lifeblood of human capital formation, this policy provided for the revision and revamping of all aspects of the education structure. This includes its regulation and governance, creation of a new system that is aligned with the aspirational goals of 21st century-education, including SDG4, while building upon India’s traditions and value systems. The NEP provides for nurturing all-around development and skill acquisition by youth in an inclusive, accessible, and multilingual set-up.

As part of the whole-of-ecosystem approach, the Union Government launched Samagra Shiksha in 2018 as an overarching programme for the school education sector extending from pre-school to class XII with an aim to ensure inclusive and equitable quality education at all levels of school education.

The year FY22 saw improvement in Gross Enrolment Ratios (GER) in schools and improvement in gender parity. GER in the primary-enrolment in class I to V as a percentage of the population in age 6 to 10 years - for girls as well as boys have improved in FY22. GER in Upper-Primary (enrolment in class VI to VIII as a per cent of the population in age 11-13 years), which was stagnant between FY17 and FY19, improved in FY22. In corresponding age groups in Primary and Upper-Primary levels, girls’ GER is better than boys.

Table VI.9 shows the School gross enrolment ratios (in per cent) for girls and boys in primary, upper primary and secondary schools over the years 2013-2014 to 2020-2021. The data is sourced from Unified District Information System for Education (UDISE+), which comes with more than one-year lag. GER greater than 100 per cent might represent the presence of over or under-age children in a particular level of education.

headings: Table: Trends in Number of Recognised Schools
explanations: In FY22, a total of 26.5 crore children were enrolled in schools and 19.4 lakh additional children were enrolled in Primary to Higher Secondary levels. Total enrolment of Children With Special Needs (CWSN) in FY22 stands at 22.7 lakh as compared to 21.9 lakh in FY21, which is an increase of 3.3 per cent. The enrolments increased across all levels viz., Primary, Upper-Primary, Secondary, and Higher Secondary except for the Pre-Primary level. At the Pre-primary level, enrolment reduced from 1.1 crore in FY21 to 1.0 crore in FY22. During the year, about 1.0 crore children were enrolled in pre-primary, 12.2 crore in Primary, 6.7 crore in Upper Primary, 3.9 crore in Secondary and 2.9 crore in Higher Secondary.

School dropout rates at all levels have witnessed a steady decline in recent years. The decline is for both girls and boys. The schemes such as Samagra Shiksha, RTE Act, improvement in school infrastructure and facilities, residential hostel buildings, availability of teachers, regular training of teachers, free textbooks, uniforms for children, Kasturba Gandhi Balika Vidyalaya and the PM POSHAN Scheme play an important role in enhancing enrolment and retention of children in schools. The below table shows the dropout rates at different levels.

The below table shows the dropout rates at different levels. Dropout rate is defined as the proportion of pupils from a cohort enrolled in a given level in a given school year that are no longer enrolled at any grade in the following school year.

The education infrastructure in the form of schools, amenities, and digitalisation has been steadily promoted along with a focus on pedagogy. The dividends of the structural reforms in the education sector will enrich the nation’s growth and development prospects in decades to come. The basic infrastructure facilities in schools – both in terms of the number of recognised schools and teachers’ availability reflected in the Pupil-Teacher Ratio, showed an improvement in FY22. The trend in number of recognised schools for various levels show a steady progress. The below table shows the trends in number of recognised schools.
The below table shows the trends in number of recognised schools for different years and levels.

The availability of basic facilities such as girls and boys toilets, hand washing facilities, and libraries in Government schools has significantly improved over the years. The Samagra Shiksha Scheme and Swachh Bharat Mission have played a critical role in providing these resources and creating assets in schools. The Samagra Shiksha Scheme also supports the establishment of smart classrooms, ICT labs in schools, including support for hardware, educational software, and e-content for teaching. Medical check-ups were affected due to Covid school closures.

The pupil-teacher ratio, which affects the quality of education, has continuously improved at all school level from FY13 to FY22. This improvement in the number of schools, teachers’ availability, and facilities in schools is expected to help improve enrolment and reduce dropout rates.

The Indian government launched a scheme called PM Schools for Rising India (PM SHRI) which aims to strengthen the existing schools by equipping them with modern infrastructure and showcasing the implementation of the NEP. Over the period of FY23 to FY27, there is a provision for setting up more than 14,500 such schools managed by Central Government/State/UT Government/local bodies.

headings: National Curriculum Framework (NCF) for Foundational Stage
Strengthening Teaching-Learning and Results for States (StarS)
explanations: The Green Schools Scheme aims to provide an inclusive and accessible learning environment for students while promoting water conservation, waste recycling, and energy-efficient infrastructure. The scheme will also integrate organic lifestyle in the curriculum. More than 20 lakh students are expected to benefit from this scheme.

The NCF for Foundational Stage is a new 5+3+3+4 curricular structure that integrates early childhood care and education for all children aged 3 to 8. The NCF will use 'play' at the core of its approach to curriculum organization, pedagogy, time and content organization, and the overall experience of the child. The framework will also highlight the role of teachers, parents, and communities in enhancing the developmental outcomes sought during this stage.

Project Balvatika, or the Preparatory Class, is a pilot project launched to focus on developing cognitive, affective, and psychomotor abilities, as well as early literacy and numeracy skills for students aged 3+, 4+, and 5+. The project is currently implemented in 49 Kendriya Vidyalayas.

The handbook for Toy-based pedagogy aims to promote the integration of indigenous toys and their pedagogy into school education, early childhood care and education, and teacher education curricula. The handbook will help teachers select or create age-appropriate toys to explain various concepts to students.

PRASHAST is a mobile app for screening disabilities, including 21 benchmark disabilities as per the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act 2016. The app will facilitate the screening of disability conditions at the school level and generate school-wise reports for certification process initiation, as per Samagra Shiksha guidelines.

The NCrF is an umbrella framework that aims to seamlessly integrate credits earned through school education, higher education, and vocational and skill education. The framework will encompass the National Higher Education Qualification Framework (NHEQF), National Skills Qualification Framework (NSQF), and National School Education Qualification Framework (NSEQF). This integration will offer numerous options for further student progression, intermingling of school and higher education with vocational education and experiential learning. The Framework was released for public consultations on 19 October 2022.

The STARS Project is a Central Sector Scheme implemented in Himachal Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Maharashtra, Odisha, and Kerala over five years. The Scheme aims to improve the quality and governance of school education in selected states through better teaching-learning and result management. The project will be supported by funding from the World Bank.

Vidyanjali is a school volunteer management program initiated by the Indian Government with the aim of enhancing the quality of school education through community, Corporate Social Responsibility, and private sector involvement. Through the Vidyanjali portal, community members and volunteers can connect with Government and Government-aided schools to share their knowledge, skills, and resources to cater to the needs of the schools. As of January 20th, 2023, 3,95,177 schools and 1,14,674 volunteers have been registered on the portal. The program has impacted 11,34,218 students across the nation, offering support in several areas, including subject assistance, mentoring gifted children, teaching vocational skills, providing ceiling fans and water purifiers, and much more.

The Samagra Shiksha Scheme is an overarching program for the Indian school education sector from pre-school to class XII. It has been aligned with the recommendations of the NEP 2020 and will extend from FY22 to FY26. The ICT component of the Scheme aims to provide computer literacy and computer-enabled learning to children by initiating curriculum-based interactive multimedia, digital books, virtual labs, and more. The scheme supports the establishment of smart classrooms and ICT labs in schools and provides support for hardware, educational software, and e-content for teaching. The plan covers all Government/Government-aided schools with classes VI to XII. As of November 2022, ICT labs have been approved in 1,20,614 schools and smart classrooms in 82,120 schools across India.

Indian higher education system caters to one of the largest young populations in the world, with more than 27% of India's population in the 15-29 years age bracket. Over the years, the infrastructure for higher education has been enhanced. The number of medical colleges in India grew from 387 in 2014 to 648 in 2022, and MBBS seats have increased from 51,348 to 96,077. The number of Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) and Indian Institute of Management (IIMs) rose to 23 and 12 respectively, in 2022 from 16 and 13 in 2014. The strength of Indian Institutes of Information Technology (IIITs) increased to 25 in 2022 from 9 in 2014. The number of Universities in India increased from 723 in 2014 to 1,113.

The total enrolment in higher education in India increased to nearly 4.1 crore in FY21 from 3.9 crore in FY20. Since FY15, there has been an increase of around 72 lakh in enrolment, which is a 21% increase. Female enrolment has increased to 2.0 crore in FY21 from 1.9 crore in FY20.

headings: Total Students' Enrolments in Higher Education
Students' Enrolment in Higher Education by Year and Gender
Gross Enrolment Ratio (GER) in Higher Education
Number of Universities, Colleges, and Standalone Institutions
Number of Male and Female Teachers in Higher Education
explanations: The figure Vi.15 shows the total enrolment of students in higher education over the years from 2016-17 to 2020-21. In 2016-17, the total enrolment was 3.6 crore, which increased to 4.1 crore in 2020-21. The data is taken from the All India Survey on Higher Education (AISHE) report 2020-21 published by the Ministry of Education.

Table Vi.13 shows the enrolment of students in higher education based on gender and year. In each year, male enrolment was higher than female enrolment. In 2020-21, male enrolment was 2.1 crore and female enrolment was 2.0 crore. Overall, the total enrolment in higher education has been increasing over the years, reaching 4.1 crore in 2020-21. The data is taken from the AISHE report 2020-21.

As of FY21, the enrolment in Distance Education was 45.7 lakh, which is an increase of around 7% since FY20 and 20% since FY15. Out of the total enrolment in Distance Education, 20.9 lakh were females. The data suggests that Distance Education has become more popular in recent years. The information is presented in section 6.70 of the Economic Survey 2022-23.

The Gross Enrolment Ratio (GER) in higher education, based on 2011 population projections (revised), was recorded at 27.3% in FY21. This is an improvement from 25.6% in FY20. The GER for males increased from 24.8% in FY20 to 26.7% in FY21, and the GER for females showed improvement from 26.4% to 27.9% during the same period. The data indicates that more students are pursuing higher education in India. The information is presented in section 6.70 of the Economic Survey 2022-23.

As of end FY21, the total number of Universities/University institutions registered were 1,113, the number of colleges were 43,796 and the number of standalone institutions was 11,296. The data is taken from the Economic Survey 2022-23.

As of end FY21, the total number of faculty/teachers in higher education was 15,51,070. Of these, about 57.1% were male and 42.9% were female. The data indicates that there is a gender imbalance among teachers in higher education, with more male teachers than female teachers. The information is presented in the Economic Survey 2022-23.

headings: Number of Teachers in Higher Education Institutions
Research & Development Cell in Higher Education Institutions
Guidelines for Pursuing Two Academic Programs Simultaneously
Central Scheme on Interest Subsidy for Education Loans
explanations: The table Vi.14 mentions the number of male and female teachers in higher education institutions from the years 2016-17 to 2020-21. The data is compiled from the AISHE report of 2020-21. From 13.6 lakh teachers in 2016-17, the number increased to 15.5 lakh in 2020-21, with the number of female teachers increasing at a higher rate than male teachers.

The University Grants Commission (UGC) launched the Research & Development Cell (RDC) initiative for Higher Education Institutions with a mandate to promote quality research in line with the NEP 2020 goals of a self-reliant India. The Guidelines for RDC were issued in March 2022, which aim to create a conducive environment for enhanced research productivity, encourage collaboration between industry and government, and facilitate greater access to research through mobilization of resources and funding.

The University Grants Commission (UGC) issued guidelines in April 2022 that allow students to pursue two academic programs simultaneously to promote flexible curricular structures and interdisciplinary thinking in line with NEP 2020 objectives. Students can pursue two full-time academic programs or one full-time program and one Open and Distance Learning (ODL)/Online program, as well as up to two ODL/Online programs simultaneously, governed by UGC regulations.

The Central Scheme on Interest Subsidy (CSIS) was launched in 2009 to provide full interest subsidy during the moratorium period on education loans taken by students from economically weaker sections (EWS) with parental income less than `4.5 lakh per annum for professional study in India. The scheme provides education loans without any collateral or third-party guarantee to support financially weaker students in the pursuit of higher education.

A three-day Akhil Bharatiya Shiksha Samagam was organised at Varanasi on 7-9 July 2022 by the Ministry of Education in association with the UGC and Banaras Hindu University. The event brought together over 300 Vice Chancellors and Directors from public and private universities, educationists, policymakers, as also industry representatives to deliberate on how the implementation of NEP 2020 can be taken further across the country after successful implementation of several initiatives in the last two years. The Summit provided a platform for thought-provoking discussions that helped articulate the roadmap and implementation strategies, foster knowledge exchange, build networks through interdisciplinary deliberations, and discuss challenges being faced by educational institutions and articulate solutions. The Samagam was witness to India’s extended vision and a renewed commitment to help achieve the goals of the higher education system with education leaders resolving to work collectively for transforming India into an equitable and vibrant knowledge society.

Skill development is aimed at the removal of the disconnect between demand and supply of skilled manpower, building vocational and technical training framework, skill up-gradation, and building of new skills, and innovative thinking not only for existing jobs but also jobs of the future. In order to address the incremental manpower requirement and to empower youth with adequate skills, the Ministry of Skill Development and Entrepreneurship (MSDE) was created in 2014 and Skill India Mission was launched in 2015. With the establishment of a Central Ministry, efforts to improve and streamline the skilling ecosystem were ramped up as the government launched the National Skill Development Mission as well as the National Policy on Skill Development and Entrepreneurship. Under the NEP 2020 also, there is a special focus on vocational education and skill development. Integration of vocational education with general education and mainstreaming of vocational education have been identified as the key reform in the education System of the country. PLFS FY21 shows that formal vocational/technical training among youth (age 15-29 years) and the working population (age 15-59 years) have improved in FY21 over FY19 and FY20. The improvement in skills has been for males and females, both in rural and urban sectors.

headings: Establishments Imparting Formal And On-The-Job Training
explanations: The table Vi.15 shows the distribution of persons who received formal vocational/technical training in India from 2018-19 to 2020-21. The data is segregated by age group, rural-urban location and gender.

As per the reports of the fourth round of the QES (for Q4 FY22) in respect of establishments employing at least 10 workers in major nine sectors, 15.6 percent of estimated establishments imparted formal skill training and 20.5 percent imparted on-the-job training. The health sector had the highest percentage of estimated establishments imparting formal skill training (24.7 percent) and on-the-job training (31.6 percent), followed by financial services (20.4 percent of establishments imparting formal training and 26.4 percent imparting on-the-job training). The data is further elaborated in table Vi.16 and segregated by sector and quarter of FY22.

The Skill Indian Mission focuses on skilling, re-skilling and up-skilling through short term and long term training programmes. Under the Mission, the government, through more than 20 Central Ministries/Departments, is implementing various skill development schemes across the country. These include Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Grameen Kaushalya Yojna (DDU-GKY), Rural Self Employment Training Institutes (RSETI), Deen Dayal Antyodaya Yojana- National Urban Livelihood Mission (DAY-NULM). MSDE is implementing Schemes such as Pradhan Mantri Kaushal Vikas Yojana (PMKVY), Jan Shikshan Sansthan (JSS), National Apprenticeship Promotion Scheme (NAPS) and Craftsmen Training Scheme (CTS). The advocacy of the programmes is being done through print media, electronic media, and State Governments’ campaigns.

PMKVY was first launched in 2015. Presently, the third phase of PMKVY , i.e., PMKVY 3.0 is being implemented across the country since January 2021. PMKVY has two training components, viz., Short Term Training (STT) and Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL). Pradhan Mantri Kaushal Kendra set up at District level, are envisaged as state of the art, visible and aspirational model training Centres. Between FY17 and FY23 (as of 5 January 2023), under PMKVY 2.0 about 1.1 crore persons have trained: 83 per cent certified and about 21.4 lakh placed. Under PMKVY 3.0, during FY21 to FY23 (as on 5 January 2023) 7.4 lakh persons have been trained, 66 per cent certified and 41,437 placed. PMKVY also provided training to Shramiks (migrant labourers) affected by Covid-19. This component covered 116 districts of 6 States, viz., Assam, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Odisha, Rajasthan, and Uttar Pradesh. As on 31 October 2022, 1.3 lakh migrants have been trained/oriented (0.88 lakh in STT and 0.38 lakh in RPL).

Jan Shikshan Sansthan Scheme provides for a lump sum annual grant is released to Jan Shikshan Sansthans (NGOs) for skill training to non-literate, neo-literates, persons with a rudimentary level of education and school dropouts up to class XII in the age group of 15-45 years. The priority groups are women, SC, ST, and other backward sections of society. From FY20 to FY23 (as of 5 January 2023), 16.0 lakh beneficiaries have been trained of which 28.4 per cent are from urban areas and 69.0 per cent are from rural areas and 2.7 per cent are from tribal areas. Notably, 81 per cent of the trainees are women.

National Apprenticeship Promotion Scheme provides financial support to industrial establishments undertaking apprenticeship programmes under the Apprentices Act, 1961. Since the launch of the scheme in 2016, as on 31 December 2022, 21.4 lakh apprentices have been engaged by Industries.

Craftsmen Training Scheme provides long-term training in 149 trades through 14,938 Industrial Training Institutes (ITIs) across the country. Since 2015, 91.7 lakh students have been trained as on 30 October 2022.

Under the Skill India Mission, PMKVY, Jan Shikshan Sansthan Scheme, National Apprenticeship Promotion Scheme and Craftsmen Training Scheme have made significant progress. As of 5 January 2023, under PMKVY 2.0 about 1.1 crore persons have trained: 83 per cent certified and about 21.4 lakh placed. Under PMKVY 3.0, during FY21 to FY23 (as on 5 January 2023) 7.4 lakh persons have been trained, 66 per cent certified and 41,437 placed. Between FY20 to FY23 (as of 5 January 2023), 16.0 lakh beneficiaries have been trained under Jan Shikshan Sansthan Scheme of which 81 per cent of the trainees are women. Since the launch of National Apprenticeship Promotion Scheme in 2016, as on 31 December 2022, 21.4 lakh apprentices have been engaged by Industries. Since 2015, 91.7 lakh students have been trained under Craftsmen Training Scheme as on 30 October 2022.

headings: Skill acquisition and Knowledge Awareness for livelihood promotion (SanKalp)
Quality and affordable Health for all under National Health Mission
explanations: The Craft instructor training Scheme provides comprehensive training in both skills and training methodology for instructor trainees to become conversant with teaching methodology and transfer hands-on skills for industry. As of FY22, 8,847 trainees have been trained in various National Skill Training Institutes and Institute of Training of Trainers.

With an aim to make India a Skill Capital of the World, the National Skill Development Corporation International (NSDC) has been set up to create a network of institutions called the Skill India International (SII) Network through the empanelment of state-of-the-art government and private institutions. MSDE has signed MoUs with 11 countries, including Australia, China, France, Germany, and the United Kingdom in the field of skill development and vocational education training. NSDC has also signed 18 B2B MoUs with countries such as Australia, Canada, and Saudi Arabia.

SanKalp is a World Bank loan-assisted programme launched in 2018 to decentralise skilling initiatives and align skill development programmes with local demand and aspirations of the youth. Under the National Component and State Components of SANKALP, 64 and 700 projects respectively have been taken up in the area of skill and Entrepreneurship development and strengthening of monitoring. 724 District Skill Committees have been constituted, which are mandated to plan, manage and monitor skilling activities at the District level.

Under the National Health Mission, the government has made concerted efforts to engage with all relevant sectors and stakeholders to achieve universal health coverage and deliver quality healthcare services to all at an affordable cost. Today, the Indian healthcare network is among the largest in the world. The results of an effective health approach are visible in the improvement of important health-related indicators.

headings: Major initiatives for better overall health
National Strategic Plan for TB Elimination
explanations: Some of the major initiatives taken from 2014-2022 for better overall health are Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN), e-Sanjeevani OPD, Social Awareness and Actions to Neutralize Pneumonia Successfully (SAANS), Free Drugs and Diagnostic Service, Maternity Benefits Act -6 months paid maternity leave, Pradhan Mantri Ujjawala Yojana, Pradhan Mantri National Dialysis Programme, A yushman Bharat -Health and Wellness Centres, A yushman Bharat -PM Jan Aarogya Yojana, POSHAN Abhiyaan, Anemia Mukt Bharat Strategy 2018, COVID -19 Vaccination Programme, XV-Finance Commission –Health Sector Grants to Local Bodies, A yushman Bharat Digital Mission, A yushman Bharat –Health Infrastructure Mission, and Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021.

There has been a significant improvement in health-related indicators from 2015-16 (nfHS-4) to 2019-21 (nfHS-5). The percentage of households with any usual member covered under a health insurance/ financing scheme has increased from 28.7% to 41.0%. The total fertility rate (children per woman) has decreased from 2.2 to 2.0. The current use of family planning method has increased from 53.5% to 66.7%. The percentage of mothers who had at least 4 antenatal care visits has increased from 51.2% to 58.1%. The percentage of institutional births has increased from 78.9% to 88.6%. The neonatal mortality rate (per 1000 live births) has decreased from 29.5 to 24.9. The infant mortality rate (per 1000 live births) has decreased from 40.7 to 35.2. The under-five mortality rate (per 1000 live births) has decreased from 49.7 to 41.9. The percentage of children age 12-23 months fully vaccinated based on information from either vaccination card or mother’s recall has increased from 62.0% to 76.4%. The percentage of children under age 6 months exclusively breastfed has increased from 54.9% to 63.7%. The percentage of children under 5 years who are stunted (height-for-age) has decreased from 38.4% to 35.5%. The percentage of children under 5 years who are wasted (weight-for-height) has decreased from 21.0% to 19.3%. The percentage of children under 5 years who are underweight (weight-for-age) has decreased from 35.8% to 32.1%. The percentage of children under 5 years who are overweight (weight-for-height) has increased from 2.1% to 3.4%. The percentage of women who are overweight or obese (BMI≥25.0 kg/m2) has increased from 20.6% to 24.0%. The percentage of men who are overweight or obese (BMI≥25.0 kg/m2) has increased from 18.9% to 22.9%. The percentage of women age 15-24 years who use hygienic methods of protection during their menstrual period has increased from 57.6% to 77.3%.

The National Health Policy was launched in the year 2017 and it aims to achieve the highest possible level of good health and well-being for all. The policy focuses on creating an enabling environment for achieving universal health coverage through primary health care. It also aims to provide access to affordable health care services to all citizens.

The Mental Healthcare Act was launched in 2017 to provide mental healthcare services to people affected by mental illnesses. The act aims to protect the rights of persons with mental illness and ensure that they receive treatment and care in a humane and non-discriminatory manner. The act also lays down the procedures for admission, treatment, and discharge of mentally ill persons.

The National Strategic Plan for TB Elimination was launched in the year 2017 with an aim to achieve the target of ending TB in India by 2025. The plan aims to provide universal access to quality diagnosis and treatment for TB. It focuses on finding the missing patients who are not diagnosed and treated for TB. It also aims to engage the private sector in the fight against TB.

The HIV and AIDS (Prevention & Control) Act was launched in the year 2017 to provide legal protection and welfare measures to persons affected by HIV and AIDS. The act aims to prevent and control the spread of HIV and AIDS in India. It also lays down the rights and duties of persons living with HIV and AIDS.

The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan was launched in the year 2014 to achieve the aim of a clean India by October 2, 2019, which is also the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi. The campaign aims to eradicate open defecation, promote cleanliness and hygiene in the country. The campaign has two components - Swachh Bharat Abhiyan (Clean India Mission) and Swachh Bharat Abhiyan Gramin (Clean India Mission Rural).

The Pradhan Mantri TBMukt Bharat Abhiyaan was launched in the year 2018 with an aim to end TB in India by 2025. The campaign aims to create a TB-free society by focusing on preventive measures such as early diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up of TB cases. The campaign also focuses on engaging the community in the fight against TB.

headings: Improvements in Maternal and Child Health
explanations: India has made notable progress in improving maternal and child health through the implementation of the Reproductive, Maternal, New-Born, Child, and Adolescent Health Plus Nutrition (RMNCAH+N) strategy. The Sample Registration System (SRS) data indicates that India has successfully reduced the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) to below 100 per lakh live births by 2020, with eight states already achieving the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) target. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR), Under Five Mortality Rate (U5MR), and Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) also reflect a downward trend due to the countrywide efforts towards increasing health service coverage through strengthening of service delivery, quality assurance, community processes, and supply chain management.

The table VI.18 displays the trends in mortality indicators from 2014 to 2020. The data highlights a notable reduction in Maternal Mortality Ratio (per lakh live births) from 167 (2011-13) to 97 in 2018-20. Infant Mortality Rate (per 1000 live births), Neonatal Mortality Rate (per 1000 live births), and Under 5 Mortality Rate (per 1000 live births) also reflect a consistent decrease over the years. Early Neonatal Mortality Rate – 0- 7 days (per 1000 live births) also indicate a downward trend from 20 in 2014 to 15 in 2020.

The National Health Account (NHA) for the year FY19 highlights the rising importance of public healthcare and social security in ensuring universal health coverage. The NHA shows that there has been an increase in the share of Government Health Expenditure (GHE) in the total GDP from 1.2% in FY14 to 1.3% in FY19. Additionally, the share of GHE in Total Health Expenditure (THE) has also increased over time, substantially higher at 40.6% in FY19 than it was in FY14 at 28.6%. GHE constitutes spending under all schemes funded and managed by Union, State, and Local Governments including quasi-Governmental organisations and donors if funds are channelled through Government organisations. THE constitutes current and capital expenditures incurred by government and private sources, including external funds.

The GHE for India is estimated to be `5,96,440 crore (3.2 per cent of GDP and `4,470 per capita) for FY19. Of the GHE, Union Government’s share is 34.3 per cent and the State Governments’ share is 65.7 per cent. Current Health Expenditure (CHE) constitutes 90.6 per cent of THE and capital expenditures constitutes 9.4 per cent of THE.

Government's focus is to provide healthcare services to all: one of the policy recommendations of the National Health Policy 2017. The expenditure on primary healthcare increased from 51.1 per cent in FY14 to 55.2 per cent in FY19. This ensures quality services at the grassroot level and reduces the chances of ailments requiring secondary or tertiary healthcare services. Between FY14 and FY19, the share of primary and secondary care in the GHE increased from 74.4 per cent to 85.7 per cent. On the other hand, share of primary and secondary care in private health expenditure has declined from 82.0 per cent to 70.2 per cent during the same period.

The social security expenditure on health, which includes the social health insurance programme, government-financed health insurance schemes, and medical reimbursements made to government employees, has increased from 6 per cent in FY14 to 9.6 per cent in FY19. Due to several such steps, Out-of-Pocket Expenditure (OOPE) as a percentage of THE has declined substantially from 64.2 per cent in FY14 to 48.2 per cent in FY19.

OOPE are expenditures directly made by households at the point of receiving health care. This expenditure is usually incurred when an individual’s visit to healthcare provider is not provided for ‘free’ through a government health facility or a facility run by a not-for-profit organisation or if this individual is not covered under a government/private health insurance or social protection scheme. OOPE as a percentage of THE has declined substantially from 64.2 per cent in FY14 to 48.2 per cent in FY19 which shows that the citizens are better equipped and better provided in terms of healthcare at their doorstep making it more accessible.
