headings: Importance of Health Infrastructure in India
Recent Health Sector Reforms in India
explanations: Health infrastructure is a key indicator for understanding a country's healthcare delivery provisions and welfare mechanisms. It forms the basic support system for the delivery of public health services. Human resources for health, including physicians, nursing professionals, pharmacists, midwives, dentists, allied health professionals, community health workers, social health workers, and other health care providers, are identified as one of the core building blocks of the health system.

The recent health sector reforms in India have emphasized strengthening health infrastructure as well as human resources in the public sector system. This is evident in the rise in the number of Sub-centres (SCs), Primary Health Centres (PHCs), and Community Health Centres (CHCs) in rural areas, along with the rise in doctors, nurses, and other medical personnel over time. The Ayushman Bharat programme has been implemented to strengthen SCs and PHCs by converting them into Health and Wellness Centres (HWCs) to deliver comprehensive Primary Healthcare services through these Centres. As of December 31, 2022, over 1.5 lakh HWCs have already been set up.

In India, the healthcare system in rural areas consists of three tiers: Sub Centers (SC), Primary Health Centers (PHC), and Community Health Centers (CHC). The Sub-Center is the most peripheral contact point between the Primary Health Care System and the community. It is manned by one Health worker (female)/Auxiliary Nurse Midwife & one Health Worker (male). The Primary Health Center serves as a referral unit for six sub-centers and is manned with a Medical Officer in charge and subordinate paramedical staff. The Community Health Center is a 30-bedded Hospital/Referral Unit for four PHCs with specialized services.

The table shows the progress in health infrastructure as of March for each year from 2014 to 2022. It indicates the number of sub-centers, primary health centers, community health centers, doctors, specialists, auxiliary nurse midwives, nursing staff, pharmacists, and lab technicians at various healthcare facilities. The greener shades represent improvements.

This section talks about the efforts made by the government towards universal immunization. Under the Universal Immunization Programme (UIP), free immunization is provided for 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. To increase immunization coverage, Mission Indradhanush (MI) was launched in 2014. Intensified MI was launched in 2017, covering 190 districts/urban areas. In FY23, Intensified MI 4.0 covered 416 districts, including 75 districts under Azadi Ka Amrit Mahotsav, to cover children and pregnant women who missed routine immunization during the Covid-19 pandemic. As of December 2022, a total of 11 phases of MI have been completed, covering 701 districts across the country, resulting in a 14.4% increase in Full Immunization Coverage (FIC) from NFHS-4 and an increase in the percentage of FIC in 30 states/UTs.

eSanjeevani is a cloud-based telemedicine system that enables patient-to-doctor teleconsultation to ensure the continuity of care and provide health services to all citizens in the comfort of their homes, free of cost. It is operational in all states and UTs across India.

headings: eSanjeevani - National Telemedicine Service of India
Ayushman Bharat Pradhan Mantri - Jan Arogya Yojana (AB PM-JAY)
Ayushman Bharat - Heath and Wellness Centres (AB-HWCs)
explanations: eSanjeevani is an innovative solution that enables 1,12,553 HWCs in rural areas and 15,465 Hubs at tertiary level hospitals and medical colleges in the states. It has served over 9.3 crore patients across the country and currently serving around 4 lakh patients daily. It has evolved into the world’s largest outpatient services system.

AB PM-JAY is the world’s largest health insurance scheme that provides health cover of `5 lakh per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalisation to over 10.7 crore poor and vulnerable families (approximately 50 crore beneficiaries) that form the bottom 40 per cent of the Indian population. As of 4 January 2023, approximately 21.9 crore beneficiaries have been verified under the Scheme including 3 crore beneficiaries verified using State IT systems. Approximately 4.3 crore hospital admissions, amounting to `50,409 crore, have also been authorised under the Scheme through a network of over 26,055 hospitals.

Under the scheme, 1.5 lakh AB-HWCs were envisaged to be established by upgrading the SHCs and PHCs in rural and urban areas. These AB-HWCs provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care, by expanding and strengthening the existing Reproductive & Child Health services and Communicable Diseases services and by including services related to Non- Communicable Diseases such as hypertension, diabetes and 3 common cancers, viz. Oral, Breast and Cervix. As of 31 December 2022, 1,54,070 HWCs were operationalized across the country with more than 135 Crore cumulative footfall, more than 87.0 Crore cumulative screening of Non communicable diseases and more than 1.6 crore Wellness Sessions, including Yoga.

More than 9.3 crore tele-consultations have been provided through functional HWCs at 15,465 Hubs (comprising MBBS/ Specialty/Super-Specialty doctors at zonal level) and 1,12,987 Spokes (AB-HWCs at state level) across the country, as on 17 January 2023.

ABDM aims at creating a secure online platform based on open, interoperable digital standards. This will enable access and exchange of health records of citizens with their consent through Services such as the issuance of Health ID, Healthcare Professionals Registry, Health Facility Registry and Health Records. This will boost the adoption of digital technologies in healthcare, thereby making

National Deworming Day (NDD), launched in 2015 in 11 states and expanded to the whole country in 2016, is a fixed-day approach to treating intestinal worm infections in children aged 1-19 years with Albendazole tablets.
The programme is held every year on 10 February and 10 August through schools and Anganwadis, followed by mop-up days to cover those left out due to absenteeism or sickness.
Besides Government and Government-aided schools and Anganwadis, special efforts are made to reach out-of-school children, and private schools have also enthusiastically joined the programme.

During Covid-19, the continuity of deworming efforts were maintained while minimising risks. Frontline health workers were trained to follow appropriate safety guidelines during home visits or through staggered “Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Day” based model.
Soil-Transmitted Helminthiases (STH), also known as parasitic intestinal worm infection, is a public health concern adversely affecting children’s physical and cognitive growth.

Intestinal worm infection is known to cause, aggravate, and intensify nutritional losses, particularly of Vitamin A and Iron. Micronutrient deficits and worm infestation together culminate into stunted growth and development in children.
Worming can have an impact on stunting, anemia, school absenteeism, cognitive function, years of schooling, productivity, and quality of life.

headings: Impact of Deworming on School Absenteeism
Impact of Deworming on Health and Nutrition
Impact of Deworming on Learning Outcomes
Impact of Deworming on Higher-Wage Jobs
Logistical Challenges Faced by National Covid-19 Vaccination Programme
Success of National Covid-19 Vaccination Programme
explanations: Eminent research has shown the significant impact of deworming on school absenteeism, health, nutritional, and learning outcomes. It contributes to achieving better nutrition and health and supplements the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan in eliminating sanitation-related health risks. The benefits of deworming lead to a remarkably high benefit-to-cost ratio, as estimated in a 20-year long study in Kenya. National Deworming Day is, thus, a low-hanging fruit of programme innovations in health.

India's National Covid-19 Vaccination Programme began on 16 January 2021, with the aim of covering the adult population of the country in the shortest possible time. The programme was expanded to include all persons aged 12 years and above and for the precautionary dose for all persons aged 18 years and above. The programme faced many challenges, including research and development for new Covid vaccines, training of vaccinators and other vaccination team members, and logistical challenges such as storage and decentralised distribution of vaccines. However, the programme was able to overcome these challenges and meet its goals within a short time frame. As on 6 January 2023, India has been able to administer more than 220 crore Covid vaccine doses across the country.

Eminent research, including by Prof. Michael Kremer, Nobel Laureate in Economics in 2019, has shown the significant impact of deworming on school absenteeism. Regular deworming thus contributes to achieving better education outcomes.

Eminent research has also shown the significant impact of deworming on health and nutritional outcomes. Regular deworming contributes to achieving better nutrition and health and supplements the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan in eliminating sanitation-related health risks.
Eminent research has also shown the significant impact of deworming on learning outcomes. Regular deworming contributes to achieving better education outcomes.
Long-duration studies have found that deworming significantly increased the likelihood of higher-wage jobs, ten years after deworming treatment.
The combined benefits of deworming lead to a remarkably high benefit-to-cost ratio, as estimated in a 20-year long study in Kenya.

India's National Covid-19 Vaccination Programme faced logistical challenges such as storage and decentralised distribution of vaccines across 29,000 cold chain points, augmenting cold chain capacity, and developing IT platform for registering the beneficiaries and vaccine service delivery.

Despite the challenges faced, India's National Covid-19 Vaccination Programme was able to meet its goals within a short time frame and has administered more than 220 crore Covid vaccine doses across the country as on 6 January 2023.

As of January 2023, 4.2 crore adolescents have received the first dose of the Covid-19 vaccine and 22.4 crore precautionary doses have been administered. The vaccination drive started in India in early 2021 and has been scaled up over time. The graph in figure Vi.20 shows the number of vaccinations administered on a monthly basis.

Indias response to Covid-19 was agile and based on feedback loops, real-time monitoring of actual outcomes, flexible responses, and safety-net buffers. Over two years, the government ramped up health infrastructure, both physical and digital, enhanced training of health professionals, and continued with the mass vaccination drive. The Union Government also invested in grassroots health institutions and ramped up HWCs (Health and Wellness Centres) in rural and urban areas. Critical care hospital blocks have been set up in all districts, and the laboratory network and surveillance have been strengthened by integrated public health laboratories in all districts and blocks and public health units to manage pandemics. This was complemented by digital infrastructure through Co-WIN for mass vaccination and e-Sanjeevani for telemedicine to reach the last mile. The timely intervention at all levels helped India navigate the Covid pandemic successfully despite successive shocks. (Source: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Economic Survey 2021-22 and 2020-21).

The caseload has subsided significantly in India in the last few months, where the active caseload is below 4000 and daily new cases recorded below 300 (as of 29 December 2022). This decrease in caseload is a result of India's successful response to the pandemic, which included ramping up health infrastructure and continuing with the mass vaccination drive. The state governments also took various measures to fight the pandemic. The graph in figure Vi.9 shows the number of Covid-19 cases in India from February 2021 to January 2023.

The pandemic has been a major challenge for nations worldwide, but India has implemented necessary measures to protect its citizens and economy through a three-tier arrangement of dedicated Covid-19 health facilities while rolling out indigenous vaccines. Various entities such as tertiary care hospitals, Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO), and PSA Oxygen Generation Plants helped to strengthen the healthcare system during the pandemic.

A three-tier arrangement of health facilities has been implemented in India to reduce the risk of cross-infection to non-Covid patients and provide non-Covid essential health services. It includes the Dedicated Covid Care Centre, Dedicated Covid Health Centre, and Dedicated Covid Hospital providing isolation beds, oxygen-supported isolation beds, and ICU beds to treat mild, moderate, and severe Covid cases respectively. Tertiary care hospitals and DRDO's field hospitals were also leveraged for case management.

PSA Oxygen Generation Plants have been established in hospitals, especially in far-flung areas, enabling them to become self-sufficient in generating oxygen, thereby reducing the burden on the medical oxygen supply grid. The guidelines for setting up oxygen plants have also been shared with the states, with the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare Commissioning 4,135 PSA Oxygen Generation plants from various sources such as PM-CARES, Central Government PSUs, foreign aid, and State/CSR Initiatives. The government has also ensured adequate supply of medical oxygen through oxygen cylinders, with 4,02,517 oxygen cylinders supplied to States/UTs/Central Government hospitals until now.

headings: Initiatives for Increasing/hiring/recruitment of Doctors & Staff
explanations: The Government has procured a total of 1,13,186 oxygen concentrators for Covid management, and all domestically procured concentrators have already been allocated to states/UTs. States have been advised to promptly issue oxygen concentrators to districts and enter data on the OC-MIS portal.

As per the National Medical Commission, there are 1,308,009 registered allopathic doctors and an estimated 5.7 lakh AYUSH doctors in India. With an assumed 80% availability of registered allopathic doctors, the doctor-population ratio in the country is 1:834, which is better than the WHO norms of 1:1000.

The Government has introduced various short and long-term measures to augment medical education facilities, strengthen/upgraded existing medical colleges, and increase the number of MBBS and PG seats. These measures include establishing new medical colleges, constructing super specialty blocks, setting up new AIIMS, and relaxing norms for setting up medical colleges. Diplomate of National Board qualification has also been recognized for faculty appointments.

While 'Public Health' is a State Subject, the Government has taken significant measures to improve health infrastructure and governance systems in India in recent years. No set of measures is sufficient to counter any instantaneous shock like the Covid pandemic, but planning ahead and better management of the crisis can help deal with such situations in the future.

The first dose of vaccine was registered for smallpox in India in 1802. Over the years, the government has focused on digital health service delivery to achieve mass vaccination as year-long programs were running for several other diseases.

Co-WIN (Covid Vaccine Intelligence Network) is a comprehensive cloud-based IT solution developed as an extension of the eVIN platform for planning, implementing, monitoring, and evaluating Covid-19 vaccination in India. It provided an end-to-end solution with utilities for the entire public health system.

Co-WIN provided real-time stock tracking at the national, state, and district levels for accountability and transparency in supply chains for vaccination. It allowed registration using any of the 10 photo identity cards and enabled the issuance of digitally verifiable certificates. Special provisions were made available for those having limited access to physical facilities during times of Covid.

The robust digital infrastructure of Co-WIN and the Government's vigour of continuously improving its outreach for better inclusion enabled the administration of over 220 crore Covid-19 vaccine doses. The present administration was made possible because of Co-WIN, which contributed to a quick and durable economic recovery while continuing to secure both lives and livelihoods.

Thanks to the Government's vision of the JAM trinity (Jan Dhan Yojana, Aadhaar, and Mobile Number), the critical challenge of achieving herd immunity during the pandemic was addressed in a time-bound manner through Co-WIN. More than 84.7 crore Co-WIN beneficiaries seeded with Aadhaar among the total 104 crore (between January 2021 to September 2022), proving the seeds of JAM sown in FY15 to be a life saver for the nation.

headings: Social Infrastructure and Employment: Big Tent
pradhan mantri Jeevan Jyoti bima yojana (pmJJy)
pradhan mantri Shram yogi maan-dhan yojana (pm-Symdy)
pm Street Vendor’s atmanirbhar nidhi Scheme (pm SV anidhi)
explanations: This section talks about the importance of social protection for citizens in the wake of crisis situations in their lifetime.

PMVVY is a scheme offered by the Life Insurance Corporation of India and supported by the Government of India. It provides an assured minimum pension for a term of 10 years to senior citizens of age 60 years or more. As of 31 December 2022, there were 8,59,708 subscribers benefitting from the scheme through deposits worth `87,081.1 crore collectively under 11,97,159 policies.

This scheme is available to people in the age group of 18 to 50 years and provides a risk coverage of `2 lakh in case of death of the insured, due to any reason, at an annual premium of `436/. As on 11 January 2023, 14.96 crore persons have been enrolled cumulatively and 6,39,032 claims have been paid under PMJJY.

PM-SBY provides a risk coverage of `2 lakh in case of accidental death or total permanent disability and `1 lakh for partial permanent disability due to accident at a premium of `20 per annum. As on 11 January 2023, 32.1 crore persons have been enrolled cumulatively and 1,10,298 claims have been paid under PMSBY.

PM-SYMDY is a voluntary and contributory pension scheme for providing a monthly minimum assured pension of `3,000 upon attaining the age of 60 years to workers in the age group of 18 to 40 years having a monthly income of `15,000 or less and not a member of EPFO/ ESIC/ NPS (Govt. funded). As of 2 November 2022, over 49.1 lakh beneficiaries have been enrolled under the Scheme.

This is a Central Sector Scheme launched on 1 June 2020, to empower street vendors by extending working capital loans of up to `10,000 with a one-year tenure and free onboarding of beneficiaries on digital payment platforms. Beneficiaries are also eligible for the second tranche of loan up to `20,000 with 18 months tenure after timely repayment of the first tranche. As of 12 January 2023, 45,74,866 loan applications have been sanctioned in all tranches together; out of which 39,43,094 loans have been disbursed. The scheme is available for beneficiaries belonging to only those states/ UTs which have notified the Rules and Scheme under the Street Vendors (Protection of Livelihood and Regulation of Street Vending) Act, 2014.

The Pradhan Mantri Mudra Yojana (PMMY) was launched in April 2015, to provide loans on easier terms for income generating activities. The scheme grants loans of up to `10 lakh to manufacturing, trading, and service sectors, including activities allied to agriculture such as poultry, dairy, beekeeping, etc. Under PMMY, both term loan and working capital requirements can be met. Loans are extended through Member Lending Institutions (MLIs) viz; Banks, Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) and Micro Finance Institutions (MFIs). The salient features of the Scheme are: Under the aegis of PMMY, MUDRA has created three products namely ‘Shishu’ (loans up to `50,000/-), ‘Kishore’ (loans above `50,000/- and up to `5 lakh) and ‘Tarun’ (loans above `5 lakh and up to `10 lakh) signify the stage of growth/development and funding needs of the beneficiary micro unit/entrepreneur and also provide a reference point for the next phase of graduation/growth; There is no insistence on collateral(s) during sanction of loan; Rate of Interest is decided by the lending institution, interest is charged only on the money held overnight by borrower; A Credit Guarantee Fund for Micro Units (CGFMU) was set up for guaranteeing loans extended to eligible micro units under PMMY by MLIs and overdraft loan amount sanctioned under Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana (PMJDY) accounts.; From FY21 onwards, loans sanctioned to SHGs between `10 lakh to `20 lakh are also eligible for coverage under CGFMU. The National Credit Guarantee Trustee Company Ltd., a wholly-owned company of Government of India is the trustee of the Fund. More than 38.4 crore loans, amounting to `21.5 lakh crore, have been sanctioned since the launch of the scheme. Out of this, more than 8.2 crore loans amounting to `6.8 lakh crore have been extended to new entrepreneurs/accounts which is approximately 21 per cent of total loans extended under the scheme. About 68 per cent of the loans have been sanctioned to women entrepreneurs.

Around 65 per cent of India's population lives in rural areas, out of which, 47 per cent depends on agriculture for livelihood. The focus of the government has been on improving the quality of life in rural areas to ensure more equitable and inclusive development. The aim of engagement of the government in the rural economy has been “transforming lives and livelihoods through proactive socio-economic inclusion, integration, and empowerment of rural India.”

headings: Social Infrastructure and Employment: Big Tent
Multifaceted Initiatives to Improve the Ecosystem of Quality of Life
explanations: Discusses various measures taken to enhance the quality of life in rural areas, including rural housing, drinking water, sanitation, clean fuel, social protection, rural connectivity, and rural livelihoods. Digitisation and technology are used to serve the rural economy in agriculture and governance. The health parameters of the rural population are improved with enhanced emphasis due to the pandemic.

Highlights various initiatives taken to improve the quality of life in rural areas, including affordable quality healthcare, all-weather roads, well-equipped schools with trained teachers, social security, livelihood security, skill development, clean cooking fuel, sanitation, drinking water, electricity, and housing for all.

Discusses the improvement in quality of life due to initiatives such as the construction of 2.1 crore houses under PMAY-G, 22 crore AB-JAY beneficiaries, 7.2 lakh km roads constructed since 2000 under PMGKSY. The National Education Policy aims to revolutionise education, 14500 PM-SHRI schools to be set up, and 30 crore enrolments in PMSBY and 49 lakh enrolments in PM-SYM. Additionally, 6.5 crore households offered MGNREGS work in FY23, 11 crore LPG connections provided under PMUY, and 13 lakh candidates trained under DDU-GKY. Furthermore, 2.9 crore rural households electrified under Saubhagya and 11 crore tap water connections under JJM.

Discusses the significant improvement in an array of indicators concerning the quality of rural lives, including access to electricity, presence of improved drinking water sources, coverage under health insurance schemes, etc., according to the NFHS data for 2019-21. Women empowerment has also gained momentum, with visible progress in female participation in household decision-making, owning bank accounts, and use of mobile phones. Most indicators concerning the health of rural women and children have improved, which demonstrates tangible medium-run progress in rural living standards through policy focus on basic amenities and efficient programme implementation.

Details some of the crucial schemes/programmes of the Government in various areas to improve the quality of life in rural areas, including the Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana-Gramin (PMAY-G), Atal Bhujal Yojana (AB-JAY), PM Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGKSY), National Education Policy (NEP), Pradhan Mantri Suraksha Bima Yojana (PMSBY), Pradhan Mantri Shram Yogi Maandhan Yojana (PM-SYM), Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS), Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY), Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Grameen Kaushalya Yojana (DDU-GKY), Saubhagya Yojana, and Jal Jeevan Mission (JJM).

Sex Ratio at Birth is an important indicator to measure the prevalence of sex-selective abortions which is a matter of concern in India. The data shows that in rural areas, the sex ratio at birth for children born in the last five years was 927 females per 1000 males in NFHS-4 (2015-16) and it improved to 931 females per 1000 males in NFHS-5 (2019-21).

Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the average number of children born to a woman over her reproductive lifetime. The data shows that in rural areas, TFR decreased from 2.4 children per woman in NFHS-4 (2015-16) to 2.1 children per woman in NFHS-5 (2019-21). This indicates a declining trend in fertility rates.

Access to basic amenities such as electricity, clean drinking water, and clean fuel for cooking has improved in rural areas between the period of NFHS-4 and NFHS-5. The data shows that the percentage of population living in households with electricity increased from 83.2% in NFHS-4 to 95.7% in NFHS-5. The percentage of population living in households with an improved drinking-water source increased from 89.3% in NFHS-4 to 94.6% in NFHS-5. The percentage of households using clean fuel for cooking also increased from 24.0% in NFHS-4 to 43.2% in NFHS-5.

Access to improved sanitation facilities is crucial for disease prevention and overall well-being. The data shows that the percentage of population living in households that use an improved sanitation facility increased from 36.7% in NFHS-4 to 64.9% in NFHS-5. This indicates a significant improvement in the availability of safe and hygienic sanitation facilities in rural areas.

The data shows that there has been a positive trend in key health indicators in rural areas between the period of NFHS-4 and NFHS-5. The percentage of households with any usual member covered under a health insurance/financing scheme increased from 28.9% in NFHS-4 to 42.4% in NFHS-5. Infant mortality rate decreased from 46.0 per 1000 live births in NFHS-4 to 38.4 per 1000 live births in NFHS-5. The percentage of mothers who had an antenatal check-up in the first trimester increased from 54.2% in NFHS-4 to 67.9% in NFHS-5.

Vaccination coverage is an important aspect of child health and well-being. The data shows that in rural areas, the percentage of children aged 12-23 months who are fully vaccinated based on information from the vaccination card only increased from 61.3% in NFHS-4 to 84.0% in NFHS-5. Additionally, the percentage of children aged 12-23 months who received most of their vaccinations in a public health facility increased from 94.2% in NFHS-4 to 97.0% in NFHS-5.

The data shows that the prevalence of undernutrition among children under 5 years of age has decreased in rural areas between the period of NFHS-4 and NFHS-5. The percentage of children under 5 years who are stunted (height-for-age) decreased from 41.2% in NFHS-4 to 37.3% in NFHS-5. The percentage of children under 5 years who are wasted (weight-for-height) decreased from 21.5% in NFHS-4 to 19.5% in NFHS-5. The percentage of children under 5 years who are underweight (weight-for-age) decreased from 38.3% in NFHS-4 to 33.8% in NFHS-5.

Diarrhoea is a common health problem among children in rural areas, and its prevalence is an important indicator of public health. The data shows that the prevalence of diarrhoea in the 2 weeks preceding the survey decreased from 9.6% in NFHS-4 to 7.7% in NFHS-5. This indicates a positive trend in overall community health and well-being.

The data provides definitions for basic amenities such as water sources, cooking fuels and sanitation facilities. For water sources, the indicator includes piped water into the dwelling/yard/plot, piped to a neighbour, public tap/standpipe, tube well or borehole, protected dug well, protected spring, rainwater, tanker truck, cart with small tank, bottled water, or community RO plant. For cooking fuels, it includes electricity, LPG/natural gas, or biogas. For sanitation facilities, it includes flush to the piped sewer system, flush to a septic tank, flush to a pit latrine, flush to don't know where, ventilated improved pit (VIP)/biogas latrine, pit latrine with slab, twin pit/composting toilet, which is not shared with any other household. This indicator does not denote access to a toilet facility.

headings: Social Infrastructure and Employment: Big Tent
explanations: This section highlights various parameters related to social infrastructure and employment in rural areas between 2015-16 and 2019-21. The parameters include adequate diet for children, Body Mass Index (BMI) of women, anemia prevalence in children and women, women empowerment, and various ownerships and uses of banks, mobile phones, and the internet by women. The data is sourced from National Family Health Surveys (NFHS) conducted by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW).

This section focuses on the various aspects of women empowerment, including their participation in household decisions, income through work paid in cash, ownership of assets like house and land, bank or savings account usage, mobile phone usage, and internet usage. The data is sourced from the National Family Health Surveys (NFHS) conducted by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) and compares the data from 2015-16 and 2019-21.

This section talks about the Deendayal Antyodaya Yojana-National Rural Livelihood Mission (DAY -NRLM), which aims to provide gainful self-employment and skilled wage employment opportunities for economically weak households in rural areas. The program intends to offer sustainable and diversified livelihood options for them. The mission has four core components, including (a) social mobilization and promotion and strengthening of self-managed and financially sustainable community institutions of the rural poor women; (b) financial inclusion; (c) sustainable livelihoods; and (d) social inclusion, social development, and access to entitlements through convergence. The mission has a community-driven approach and provides a platform in the form of community institutions for women empowerment. Rural women are at the core of the program, which is extensively focused on their socio-economic empowerment.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 focuses on building capacities of women from poor and vulnerable communities by providing financial support, training, and livelihood activities through the DAY-NRLM. The Mission has its presence across 6,880 blocks in 723 districts across all states and UTs except Delhi and Chandigarh, and has mobilized a total of 8.7 crore women into 81 lakh SHGs. Community Resource Persons (CRPs) trained under the programme help in the implementation of the Mission at the ground level.

The DAY-NRLM aims to provide financial inclusion and affordable financial services, engender farming and farmers’ collectives, promote food, nutrition, health, and WASH, ensure social inclusion, and impart skill and entrepreneurship training. The progress under the programme shows a cumulative coverage of 81.1 lakh SHGs and 875 lakh households mobilized up to December 2022. The programme has provided capitalization support of INR 20,250 crores to SHGs and facilitated bank credit access of INR 5.9 lakh crore by SHGs. Under the Start-Up Village Entrepreneurship Programme (SVEP), 2.2 lakh individual enterprises have been set up, and 22,208 vehicles have been deployed under the Aajeevika Grameen Express Yojana (AGEY). The programme has also established 26,026 Custom Hiring Centres and covered 196 lakh Mahila Kisans. Additionally, 110.3 lakh households have kitchen gardens.

One of the key components of DAY-NRLM is to provide financial inclusion and affordable financial services to women from poor and vulnerable communities. The programme has facilitated bank credit access of INR 5.9 lakh crore by SHGs and provided capitalization support of INR 20,250 crores to SHGs. It aims to empower these women by providing them access to financial resources to undertake livelihood activities and become financially independent.

Another important component of DAY-NRLM is engendering farming and farmers’ collectives. The programme has covered 196 lakh Mahila Kisans and established 26,026 Custom Hiring Centres. It aims to promote women's participation in agriculture and other allied activities and facilitate the establishment of women-led farmers' collectives to improve their bargaining power and access to inputs and markets.

DAY-NRLM aims to ensure food, nutrition, health, and WASH for women from poor and vulnerable communities. The programme has mobilized 110.3 lakh households to have kitchen gardens and aims to promote micro-nutrient-rich crops. It also aims to promote WASH practices and ensure access to basic health services.

The DAY-NRLM aims to ensure social inclusion of women from poor and vulnerable communities. It is focused on mobilizing them into SHGs and providing them with access to financial resources, training, and livelihood activities to improve their socio-economic status.

One of the key objectives of DAY-NRLM is to impart skill and entrepreneurship training to women from poor and vulnerable communities. The programme has established 2.2 lakh individual enterprises under the Start-Up Village Entrepreneurship Programme (SVEP) and trained nearly 4 lakh SHG members as Community Resource Persons (CRPs) (viz. Pashu Sakhi, Krishi Sakhi, Bank Sakhi, BimaSakhi, PoshanSakhi etc.) to facilitate the implementation of the Mission at the ground level.

headings: Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme
Progress under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme
Achievements under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme
Geo-tagging of completed works under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme
Expenditure on agriculture and allied activities under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme
E-payments under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme
Direct Benefit Transfer under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme
explanations: The Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act 2005 (MGNREGA) aims at enhancing the livelihood security of households in rural areas by providing at least 100 days of guaranteed wage employment in a financial year to every household whose adult members volunteer to do unskilled manual work. 5.6 crore households availed employment and a total of 225.8 crore person-days employment has been generated under the Scheme (until 6 January 2023).

According to the Ministry of Rural Development, in the year 2022-23(as of 6 January 2023), about 225.8 crore person-days were generated, and an average of 40.7 person-days were generated per household. Women participation rate (per cent) being 56.3.

The box VI.11 lists some important achievements and governance measures under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme. It includes geo-tagging of over 5.2 crore assets, mandatory expenditure on agriculture and allied activities is 68.5 per cent in FY23(as of 6 January 2023), e-payments through NeFMS/e-FMS accounting for 99.7 percent of the total expenditure through the scheme, and 99 percent of wage seekers receiving their wages directly into their bank accounts through DBT.

Under the Geo MGNREGA Phase-I and II, Geo-tagging of assets in MGNREGA is carried out in three stages viz: before initiation of work, during the work, and after completion of work. Over 5.2 crore assets have been geo-tagged (as of 6 January 2023) and made available in the public domain.

According to the provision of the Act, the District Programme Coordinator is required to ensure that at least 60 per cent of the works to be taken up in a district in terms of cost shall be for the creation of productive assets directly linked to agriculture and allied activities through development of land, water, and trees. The expenditure on agriculture and allied activities for FY23 (as of 6 January 2023) is 68.5 per cent.

E-payments are done under MGNREGA using National Electronic Fund Management System (Ne-FMS)/ Electronic Fund Management System (e-FMS) for the payment of wages of workers directly to their bank/post office accounts. So far, total expenditure through Ne-FMS/e-FMS is 99.7 per cent.

Under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme, 99 per cent of wage seekers are receiving their wages directly into their bank accounts through DBT. It is a big step towards transparency.

headings: Reduction of registers maintained at gram panchayat
Cases of violation of guidelines and schedules
explanations: The MIS system currently has 14.0 crore Aadhaar seeded, which constitutes 92.0% of total active workers. Additionally, there are 7.9 crore workers linked to the Aadhaar-based payment system.
To eliminate bogus or duplicate job cards and manage migration and death, the states/UTs have taken an initiative to verify/update job cards.
The number of registers maintained at grams panchayats has been reduced to seven from the previous average of 22, as part of a good governance initiative.

Cases of violation of guidelines and schedules are being followed up regularly through the interstate Standard Operating Procedures (SoP) for visits. Additionally, an independent audit unit, director and human resources team has been established to train Village Resource Persons (VRPs).

Training initiatives such as Bare Foot Technicians (BFT) and project UNNATI have been launched to upgrade the skills of MGNREGA workers, whereby BFT has trained over 8,394 workers in 20 states and UNNATI aims to skill 2 lakh beneficiaries in 26 states and 2 UTs.

Around 5.5 crore households that fall under the category of landless households dependent on manual casual labour for livelihood have been identified. The government is making efforts to get these households that do not have job cards employed under MGNREGA, with about 4.6 crore such households surveyed.

The Area Officer Monitoring App facilitates authorities to record their findings online, as well as capture time-stamped and geo-coordinate tagged photographs for all schemes. It aims to provide better implementation of the programme by analyzing recorded findings.

The National Mobile Monitoring Software App allows real-time attendance of workers at MGNREGA worksites and has geo-tagged photographs to increase transparency, proper monitoring of schemes and overall citizen oversight of the programme.

DDU-GKY is a placement-linked skill development programme for rural poor youth under the NRLM. It is a market-led, placement-linked skill development programme for providing wage employment to rural poor youth. Until 30 November 2022, a total of 13,06,851 candidates have been trained under this scheme of which 7,89,685 have got job placements.

PMAY-G was launched in November 2016 with the aim of providing around 3 crore pucca houses with basic amenities to all eligible houseless households living in kutcha and dilapidated houses in rural areas by 2024. Through convergence with other Government Schemes, the PMAY-G also addresses basic needs such as the construction of the toilet, piped drinking water, electricity connection, LPG gas connection, and 90/95 person-days of unskilled labour from MGNREGS. To ensure that assistance is targeted at those who are genuinely deprived and that the selection is objective and verifiable, PMAY-G selects beneficiaries using housing deprivation parameters in the SECC, 2011 date which is to be verified by the Gram Sabhas. A total of 2.7 crore houses have been sanctioned and 2.1 crore houses have been completed by 6 January 2023 under the Scheme. Against the total target of completion of 52.8 lakh houses in FY23, 32.4 lakh houses have been completed.

On the 73rd Independence Day, 15 August 2019, the Jal Jeevan Mission (JJM) was announced, to be implemented in partnership with States, to provide tap water connection to every rural household and public institutions in villages like schools, Anganwadi centres, ashram shalas (tribal residential schools), health centres, Gram Panchayat building, etc., by 2024. At the time of the rollout of the JJM in August 2019, about 3.2 crore (17 per cent) households out of the total of 18.9 crore rural households had a tap water supply. Since the launch of the Mission, as of 18 January 2023, of 19.4 crore rural households, 11.0 crore households are getting tap water supply in their homes. Further, four States, i.e., Goa, Gujarat, Telangana & Haryana, and three UTs, i.e., Andaman & Nicobar Islands, Dadra Nagar Haveli & Daman Diu and Puducherry have become ‘Har Ghar Jal’ State/ UT, i.e., 100 per cent households are having tap water supply. Similarly, 121 districts, 1,515 Blocks, 82,071 Gram Panchayats, and more than 1.5 lakh villages have also become ‘Har Ghar Jal Block’ , ‘Har Ghar Jal Panchayat’.

India has made considerable progress in providing drinking water and safe sanitation to urban and rural households. Some details of key schemes/programmes under operation towards achieving the SDG goal on water and sanitation, are listed below.
The content describes the Jal Jeevan mission as an instrument of public health that has reduced water-borne diseases in rural India. Steps taken for ensuring water quality are also highlighted.

Jal Jeevan mission is an initiative that aims to provide safe and potable drinking water to every rural household. As per data from Directorate General of Health Services, M/o Health and Family Welfare, availability of safe and potable drinking water has drastically reduced water-borne diseases from 1.8 crore in 2019 to 59.0 lakh in 2021.

A recent study estimates that supply of microbiological contamination-free water through Jal Jeevan Mission can prevent 1.36 lakh deaths of under-5 children every year. This shows that water treatment is likely to have sizeable net benefits and is complementary to steps such as Swachh Bharat Abhiyan in preventing child mortality through improved hygiene.

JJM stresses on the provision of potable water of adequate quantity and good quality as prescribed by the Bureau of Indian Standards. Water quality monitoring & surveillance activities are given top priority under the mission. To bring focus on water supply, sanitation and hygiene (WASH), a nation-wide Water Quality Management Information System (WQMIS) has been launched on using field testing kits as well as water quality testing in laboratories. The data is uploaded, analyzed and in case of quality issues, local authorities are alerted to take up immediate remedial action.
Percentage of rural households with functional tap water connections as on 15 August 2019 was 17.7% and as on 21 January 2023, it is 34.7%. The data is sourced from Jal Jeevan Mission Dashboard.

headings: Tap Water Supply for Schools and Anganwadi Centers
explanations: The government has trained five women in each village, with at least one ASHA worker and one Anganwadi worker, to test water samples for contamination using Field Test Kits (FTKs). FTKs are provided to Panchayats and tested for nine parameters. As of December 2022, 16.2 lakh women have been trained in nearly 2.0 lakh villages, and more than 58.0 lakh water samples have been tested.

There are 2,067 water testing laboratories in India, out of which 657 laboratories are NABL accredited. Water testing laboratories have been made public at nominal rates for people to get their water samples tested, and many States have provided mobile vans for testing water samples in remote villages. As of December 2022, more than 27.0 lakh water samples have been tested in laboratories.

A functionality assessment exercise is undertaken annually to assess the status of water service delivery to households in various local water utilities in states/UTs. As per the household tap connection - 2022 assessment, 87% of the sample households received potable water.

As of October 10, 2022, 8.7 lakh schools (84.6%) and 8.9 lakh Anganwadi centers (80.6%) have been provided with potable tap water supply for drinking, cooking mid-day meals, hand-washing, and use in toilets.

The government launched the 100-day campaign 'Swachh Jal Se Suraksha' on October 2, 2022, to create awareness on the importance of water quality through Information, Education, and Communication, training activities, and capacity building of villagers using a citizen science approach.

Mission Amrit Sarovar was launched on National Panchayati Raj Day on April 24, 2022, with the aim of developing and rejuvenating 75 water bodies in each district of the country during this Amrit Varsh, 75th year of Independence. More than 93,291 Amrit Sarovar sites have been identified, and works have begun on more than 54,047 sites. Out of these, more than 27,071 Amrit Sarovars have been constructed with an impact of enhancing about 32 crore cubic meters of water holding capacity. Participation of local communities has been encouraged by involving water users' groups and freedom fighters, Martyr's families, Padma Awardees, and eldest citizens of the local areas.
People’s participation has been seen in a mission in the form of “Shram -Daan,” which will result in the creation of a total carbon sequestration potential of 1,04,818 tonnes of carbon per year.

JALDOOT app was launched on 27 September 2022 for measuring the water level in a Gram Panchayat through 2-3 selected open wells twice a year (pre-monsoon and post-monsoon). Gram Rojgar Sahayak is required to measure the water level and document the same at the Central server using the Jaldoot mobile app. This will enable groundwater monitoring, water budgeting, and planning for water harvesting and conservation-related works. A total of 3,66,354 wells have been measured as on 7 December 2022.

SBM(G) was launched on 2 October 2014 to ensure cleanliness in India and make it Open Defecation Free (ODF), and the ODF status of villages in the country was achieved by 2 October 2019. Phase-II of SBM (G) is now being implemented during FY21 to FY25, with the focus to sustain the ODF status of villages and covering all the villages with Solid and Liquid Waste Management, i.e., to convert the villages from ODF to ODF Plus. About 1,24,099 villages have been declared ODF plus till 10 November 2022 under this Mission. Andaman & Nicobar Islands has declared all its villages as ODF plus model, thus becoming the first Swachh, Sujal Pradesh.

The government is continuing to support the vulnerable as commodity prices, including that of essentials, have remained volatile in the past year. This includes supporting the households with subsidised cooking fuel. Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY) was launched in May 2016 as a flagship scheme to make clean cooking fuel such as LPG available to rural and deprived households which were otherwise using traditional cooking fuels such as firewood, coal, cow-dung cakes, etc. The release of 9.5 crore LPG connections under the scheme has also helped in increasing the LPG coverage from 62 per cent on 1 May 2016 to 99.8 per cent as on 1 April 2021. Under the Union Budget for FY22, provision for the release of an additional one crore LPG connections under the PMUY scheme, i.e., Ujjwala 2.0, has been made. This scheme will offer deposit-free LPG connection, first refill and hot plate free of cost to beneficiaries, and a simplified enrolment procedure. In this phase, a special facility has been given to migrant families. Under this Ujjwala 2.0 scheme, 1.6 crore connections have been released until 24 November 2022.

headings: SAUBHAGYA- Pradhan Mantri Sahaj Bijli Har Ghar Yojana
Social Infrastructure and Employment: Big Tent
explanations: PMGSY is a government initiative launched in three phases for providing single all-weather road connectivity to rural areas of the country. The program aims to connect all eligible unconnected habitations with a population of 500+ in plain areas and 250+ in North-Eastern and Himalayan States. The program has an upgradation component in addition to the connectivity objective. PMGSY has provided access to basic services and helped in improving agriculture, health, education, urbanization, employment generation, etc. A total of 1,84,984 roads measuring 8,01,838 km and 10,383 Long Span Bridges (LSBs) have been sanctioned under all the interventions/ verticals of PMGSY.

SAUBHAGYA is another government initiative launched to achieve universal household electrification by providing electricity connections to all willing un-electrified households in rural areas and all willing poor households in urban areas in the country. The scheme involved the organization of camps in villages or clusters of villages for on-spot registration and release of the connections. The connections were given free for economically poor households and for others, it was charged `500 after the release of the connection in 10 instalments. The scheme was successfully completed and closed on 31 March 2022.

DDUGJY is a government initiative launched in November 2014 with the objective to improve the quality and reliability of power supply in rural areas. It aimed to create basic electricity infrastructure in villages or habitations, strengthen and augment existing infrastructure, and meter existing feeders or distribution transformers or consumers to improve the quality and reliability of power supply. The scheme provided last-mile connectivity and free electricity connections to BPL households identified by the States as per their list. Since its launch, a total of 2.9 crore households have been electrified under various schemes viz (Saubhgaya, DDUGJY, etc.).

It is a government initiative to provide social infrastructure and employment opportunities to the rural masses. The initiative has multiple schemes under it like PMGSY, SAUBHAGYA, DDUGJY, and more. The schemes aim to provide basic infrastructure like roads, electricity, etc. to rural areas and empower people by providing access to education, healthcare, and employment opportunities. The initiatives have had a positive impact on agriculture, health, education, urbanization, and employment generation in rural areas.

Rural connectivity is a critical aspect of the government's initiatives for social infrastructure and employment in rural areas. PMGSY is a major initiative under this, providing all-weather road connectivity to unconnected habitations in rural areas. Such connectivity helps in improving access to basic services and mobility, thereby spurring economic growth in rural areas.

Electricity is another critical aspect of the government's initiatives for social infrastructure and employment in rural areas. SAUBHAGYA and DDUGJY are notable initiatives for achieving universal household electrification and improving the quality and reliability of power supply in rural areas. Access to electricity is critical for various activities like agriculture, education, healthcare, and employment generation, thus spurring overall growth in rural areas.

headings: Direct Benefit Transfer: A Game Changer
Role of DBT during COVID-19 Pandemic
End-to-End Digitization of Major DBT Schemes
explanations: The Economic Survey 2022-23 is a report by the Government of India that analyzes and presents the state of the economy. It contains an overview of India's economic performance, major policy initiatives, and suggestions for growth.

Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) is a mechanism that aims to transfer subsidies and other benefits directly to the bank account of the intended beneficiary. It eliminates the need for middlemen and reduces leakages and corruption. DBT aims to benefit the needy in a targeted and less distortive way, reducing market distortions caused by price subsidies.

Since the inception of DBT, cumulative transfers of over `26.5 lakh crore in respect of Central schemes have been made through the DBT route. This has resulted in total savings of over `2.2 lakh crore due to the removal of 9.4 crore duplicate, fake/non-existent beneficiaries across databases.

DBT played a significant role in sustaining the livelihoods of millions of citizens during the COVID-19 pandemic. It provided immediate relief to underprivileged segments of society through cash transfers under central schemes like PM-KISAN, MGNREGS, NSAP, PMMVY, NRLM, NHM, scholarship schemes, and food subsidy.

To make DBT schemes more accessible and transparent, major DBT schemes are being end-to-end digitized (EED) with provisions for online and mobile-based access. Over 1000 States / UTs DBT schemes are EED. Services available on UMANG are also available in assisted mode through Common Service Centres (CSCs) across India, making it accessible to all citizens.

India’s successful implementation of DBT has won recognition from International Monetary Fund and World Bank, among other international organizations, for efficiently providing support directly to large masses at low-income levels.

headings: Progress in Direct Benefit Transfer Scheme
Enhancing Rural Governance for Inclusive Growth
explanations: Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) is a scheme launched in 2013 to transfer benefits directly into the bank accounts of accurately targeted beneficiaries using modern Information and Communication Technology. It has expanded from a mere 24 schemes in 2013 to over 300 Central schemes and greater than 2000 State schemes across India by December 2022. Its operation has enabled accurate identification and targeting of beneficiaries, greater inclusion and ease of availing services through online application, transparency in fund transfers, curbing of leakages in the benefit delivery processes, creation of greater accountability on behalf of the Government, facilitating reforms in Government processes through re-engineering, increase in efficiency in scheme delivery processes, and effectiveness of schemes through timely implementation. The table in Vi.13 shows overall DBT progress report.

Box Vi.13 shows the progress in the Direct Benefit Transfer Scheme which has expanded from a mere 24 schemes in 2013 to over 300 Central schemes and greater than 2000 State schemes across India by December 2022. The table in Vi.13 shows that the total funds transferred through the scheme have increased each year, with a total of 3,80,380 crore transferred till 5th January 2023. The DBT paradigm has enabled accurate identification and targeting of beneficiaries, greater inclusion and ease of availing services through online application, transparency in fund transfers, curbing of leakages in the benefit delivery processes, creation of greater accountability on behalf of the Government, facilitating reforms in Government processes through re-engineering, increase in efficiency in scheme delivery processes, and effectiveness of schemes through timely implementation.

Good rural governance is imperative to help translate various programmes and schemes of the Government at the grassroots level, ensure equal rights to all, and achieve sustainability of rural development programmes. Some recent measures taken towards improving rural governance include enhancing rural governance for inclusive growth.

To improve rural governance for inclusive growth, measures have been taken towards enhancing good rural governance. These measures include ensuring equal rights to all and achieving sustainability of rural development programmes by translating various Government programmes and schemes at the grassroots level.

A CSS was approved to strengthen Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs) for achieving SDG’s with the main thrust on convergence with Mission Antyodaya and emphasis on strengthening PRI’s in the 117 Aspirational Districts. The major focus was on Capacity Building and Training (CB&T) to empower PRIs and to prepare convergent Plans at the respective level of Panchayats. The scheme has been revamped to strengthen the capacities of institutions for rural local governance to become more responsive towards local development needs, prepare participatory plans leveraging technology, and efficiently utilize available resources for realizing sustainable solutions to local problems linked to SDGs adopting the nine thematic approaches of LSDGs.

SV AMITV A is a Central Sector Scheme launched to provide the ‘Record of Rights’ to village household owners possessing houses in inhabited rural areas. The scheme covers multifarious aspects facilitating monetization of properties and enabling bank loans; reducing property-related disputes; comprehensive village-level planning and making rural India Atmanirbhar. The scheme aims to create accurate land records for rural planning and reducing property-related disputes. It will bring financial stability to the citizens in rural India by enabling them to use their property as a financial asset for raising loans and other financial benefits. It will determine property tax, which would accrue to the Gram Panchayats directly in states where it is devolved or else, add to the state exchequer. It will also create a survey infrastructure and GIS maps that can be leveraged by any department for their use.

Following are the themes for LSDGs: Poverty Free and Enhanced Livelihoods in Village; Healthy Village; Child-Friendly Village; Water Sufficient Village; Clean and Green Village; Village with Self-Sufficient Infrastructure; Socially Secured and Socially Just Village; Village with Good Governance and Women Friendly Village.

headings: GIS mapping for Gram Panchayat Development Plan
Social Sector Improvements during the Pandemic
Vision of Minimum Government and Maximum Governance
explanations: The government plans to use GIS maps to support the preparation of a better-quality Gram Panchayat Development Plan.

Drone surveys have been completed in 2.15 lakh villages across India as on 31 December 2022. Property cards have been prepared for nearly 65,000 villages, and property cards of all the inhabited villages of Haryana, Uttarakhand, and Puducherry have been prepared.

For equitable development, India requires the implementation of broad-based inclusive social policies, supported by adequate and commensurate financial resources. Social sector development schemes need to involve the grassroots level of governance to ensure the intended outcomes of these schemes reach the targeted citizens.

Technology has revolutionized the delivery of services in India, ensuring transparency and accountability. It has been a great enabler in ensuring the last-mile connectivity of government schemes to the targeted citizens. Technology needs to be harnessed further to help the government attain the lofty SDGs on the social front.

Despite the ground lost as regards social sector improvements due to the pandemic, India recouped it largely, powered by prompt policymaking and efficient implementation interwoven with technology. Further developments will hold the key to attaining more equitable economic growth.

Going forward with the vision of ‘Minimum Government; Maximum Governance’, further developments will hold the key to attaining more equitable economic growth in India. These developments include stepping up learning outcomes through digital and teaching interventions in schools, enhancing the role of community workers in healthcare, pushing SHGs through better product design and upscaling enterprises.

Channelizing women’s economic potential through ecosystem services such as affordable market alternatives for care work, safe transportation and lodging, and long-term counseling support, can help capitalize the gender dividend for the country’s future economic and social development.

The Honorable Prime Minister's vision is to promote all-round development, employment generation through skill, synced with production and benchmarked to quality to meet global standards driving prosperity while ensuring that prosperity is for the welfare of all.

headings: India's Efforts for Financing Climate Action
India's International Engagement on Climate Change
explanations: Climate change is primarily attributed to disproportionately high cumulative emissions, both historical and high per capita annual emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) of the developed countries. The global nature of the problem makes India one of the most vulnerable regions despite having contributed only about 4 per cent in the cumulative global emissions (for the period 1850-2019) and maintaining its per capita emission at far less than the world average.

While India is less responsible for the high stock of emissions, however, it has consistently engaged in demonstrating global leadership towards adopting various measures and ensuring a low-emission growth pathway with a commitment to the net-zero emissions goal by 2070. India has integrated the development goals with ambitious climate action goals, be it in the form of augmented solar power capacity (installed), higher energy saving targeting notified in P AT cycle-VII, improved green cover facilitated by Green India Mission, among other targeted Government actions.

As part of dedicated efforts to preserve ecosystems, India now has 75 Ramsar sites for wetlands, in addition to various regulatory and promotional measures to protect and conserve mangroves. Continued river conservation and rejuvenation efforts are underway through Namami Gange and National River Conservation Plan (NRCP).

In August 2022, the country updated the Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) in line with the Hon’ble PM’ s vision expressed in the 26th meeting of the Conference of Parties of UNFCCC. In terms of transition to renewable energy sources, India has already achieved its target of 40 per cent installed electric capacity from non-fossil fuels ahead of 2030. It has advanced the target to 50 per cent, which shall also translate to a significant reduction in the average emission rate. The National Hydrogen Mission and Green Hydrogen Policy have been introduced to enable India to be energy independent by 2047. Its pivotal role is also reflected in India’ s Long Term Low Emissions Development Strategy (LT-LEDS).

The availability of adequate and affordable finance remains a constraint in India’ s climate actions. The country has so far largely met its requirements from domestic sources only. Finance is a critical input for its climate actions. Therefore, the country has scaled up its efforts towards mobilising private capital, including through sovereign green bonds, to meet climate action goals. A framework for the latter has been issued in compliance with International Capital Market Association (ICMA) Green Bond Principles (2021).

India’ s initiatives on the international stage have been noteworthy. The country has actively engaged in global actions by championing the formation and strengthening of various intergovernmental organisations.

Climate change is the long-term change in temperature and weather patterns. Since the beginning of the industrial revolution in the 19th century, anthropogenic activities have been the predominant cause for climate change. Rising temperatures due to enhanced emissions could have severe impacts on the environment such as sea level rise, changes in monsoon cycles, and impact on land systems.

GHG emissions are the most significant threat to humanity and an inescapable reality the world faces. Urgent action is required to reduce carbon emissions and adapt to climate change as the world has already started to experience severe impacts, such as 700 million people worldwide at risk of displacement by drought alone, estimated by 2030.

Global warming is a reality, and human activity is primarily responsible for it. Climate change occurred in the distant past even when Planet Earth was scarcely populated. Accelerating global warming is mainly caused by the emission of GHGs and carbon.

Reducing emissions of GHGs, including carbon, is one way to slow down and even reverse global warming. Many nations have pledged to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, and some wish to achieve it by 2060 or 2070. Figure vii.1 shows the net-zero pledges of countries, with the year pledged on top of the bars. The source is the Emissions Gap Report 2022 published by UNEP.

headings: Impact of GHG emissions by developed and developing countries
Vulnerability to climate change in Asia
Uncertainty over the reversal of global warming
Trade-off between development priorities and reducing GHG emissions
Challenges in switching to renewable or non-fossil fuel energy
Difficulty in retraining and relocating people
Most recent World Economic Outlook report
explanations: The share of industrialization-driven GHG emissions has been mostly contributed by developed nations in North America and Europe. Developing nations have a minimal role in GHG emissions. The impact of global warming is mainly due to the cumulative historical and current GHG emissions of developed countries, and developing countries have to bear the brunt of climate change.

As per the IPCC Sixth Assessment Report, Asia is most vulnerable to climate change compared to other regions. Extreme heat, floods, sea-level rise, and erratic rainfall pose significant risks to countries in the region.

Reducing emissions may not guarantee the reversal of global warming because significant GHG emissions have already been accumulated in the atmosphere. Future emission reduction may not be enough to stop or reverse it.

Developing countries face a dilemma in prioritizing resources between developmental priorities and adapting to climate change while reducing GHG emissions. Developed countries have previously prospered by using unrestricted fossil fuels. It is challenging to switch to renewable or non-fossil fuel energy sources, and job creation in the green economy is tilted toward skilled and technology-intensive sectors.

Governments face significant challenges, such as securing future energy supplies before dispensing with existing energy sources or a lack of technology, financial resources, skilled and trained human resources, or some combination of all three. Despite the theoretically elegant argument of transitioning to renewable energy to generate investments and jobs, it seldom works out smoothly in practice.
Retraining and relocating people may not be easier than speaking about it theoretically, in case the jobs in the green economy are tilted towards skill and technology-intensive sectors.
The World Economic Outlook report from October 2021 contains a chapter on the recovery during the pandemic and discusses the economic situation of countries around the world.

headings: Importance of Economic Growth in Combating Climate Change
Challenges in Implementing Climate Change Policies
explanations: Nobel Laureate Thomas Schelling argued that economic growth is the most effective way to combat climate change. He believes that if developing countries are allowed to grow, their resources and ability to adapt will increase. This would ultimately make them less vulnerable to climate change. Additionally, companies generate profits and internal resources to fund their investments. For countries, this could be a realistic solution as well since securing funding from developed nations or multilateral organizations is difficult. Lastly, it is not unreasonable for developing countries to prioritize their own growth and development aspirations when developed countries prioritize burning more coal over reducing their dependence on it.

According to a survey conducted by the OECD and the Social Economics Lab at Harvard, citizens in developed countries are reluctant to change their lifestyles and habits to reduce emissions. Additionally, policies to implement carbon pricing have not been easy to implement in all European countries as evidenced by France's failed attempt in 2018 and Switzerland's failed proposal in a 2021 referendum.

headings: Geopolitical Battleground for Rare Earth Elements and Critical Minerals
Macroeconomic Costs of Accelerated Net Carbon Emissions Reduction Targets
Challenges and Actions Needed for Countries to Adapt and Mitigate Climate Change Impacts
explanations: The limited availability of rare earth elements (REE) and critical minerals (CM) is a major challenge for achieving a globally synchronised energy transition. REE and CM are essential for the generation of renewable energy, but they are produced in a few countries and processed in even fewer countries. Inability to secure adequate amounts of REE and CM could lead to fossil fuel-based assets being stranded for many countries’ economies,

According to Jean Pisani-Ferry, accelerating the targets for net carbon emission reductions too aggressively could create much larger economic disruptions than generally anticipated. Pisani-Ferry presciently wrote in 2021 that such a transition is 'unlikely to be benign and policymakers should get ready for tough choices.' In 2022, he added that while climate action has become a major macroeconomic issue, the macroeconomics of climate action is far from the level of rigour and precision that is now necessary to provide a sound basis for public discussions and to guide policymakers adequately. The policy conversation now needs methodical, peer-examined assessments of the potential costs and benefits of alternative plans for action.

The issue of climate change has become increasingly relevant and will occupy the attention of policymakers. Even if countries wait for financial, technological and human resources for emissions mitigation, they have to take action to make their people resilient and adapt to climate change. This requires actions on multiple fronts including the estimation of resources, lifestyle adjustments etc. India, considered one of the most vulnerable countries, is one of the leading examples in this regard, having contributed only 4% of cumulative global emissions until 2019 and per capita emissions far below the world average. The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and its Paris Agreement call for collective action based on the differentiated responsibility of countries and the higher developmental needs of developing countries in view of their role in GHG emissions.

headings: Principles of Equity and Common But Differentiated Responsibility and Respective Capabilities (CBDR-RC)
National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC)
Progress on Eight National Missions of the NAPCC
explanations: The collective action to combat climate change is based on principles of equity and CBDR-RC. Each country has made a commitment through NDCs to work towards a collective goal of keeping temperature rise to below 2°C above pre-industrial levels.

India is committed to sustainable development and has taken ambitious measures to transition to clean energy. The country has enhanced its climate ambition despite the adverse impacts of Covid-19 on the economy. India’s climate vision is integrally linked to its vision of development that foregrounds the goals of poverty eradication and guaranteeing basic well-being to all its citizens.

India initiated action on addressing climate change even before the Paris Agreement came into being. In 2008, India launched the National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC), establishing eight National Missions, covering several initiatives and a slew of measures in the area of solar, water, energy efficiency, forests, sustainable habitat, sustainable agriculture, sustaining Himalayan ecosystem, capacity building, and R&D.

India has made significant progress in achieving the targets set out in the eight National Missions of the NAPCC. These missions cover various domains such as solar power capacity, energy efficiency, sustainable habitat, afforestation targets, sustainable agriculture, and sustaining Himalayan ecosystems. The progress made in each of these domains is highlighted in the figure.

headings: National Adaptation Fund for Climate Change (NAFCC)
Increase in Share of Non-Fossil Sources in Electricity Capacity
explanations: The NAFCC is a central sector scheme initiated in 2015-16 to support adaptation activities in the States and Union Territories of India that are vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change. NAFCC is implemented in project mode, and to date, 30 projects have been sanctioned in 27 States and UTs with a total project cost of ₹847.5 crore. NAFCC supports adaptation action, in, inter alia, agriculture, water, forestry, livestock, and restoring ecosystems. At present (November 2022), 28 projects are under implementation.

India submitted its first NDC to UNFCCC in October 2015. This was updated in August 2022, to reflect higher ambition in its climate action. The new NDC with enhanced targets translates the vision of the Hon’ble PM expressed through the “Panchamrit” at the UNFCCC Conference of Parties (COP 26) in Glasgow in November 2021. The vision mentions of sustainable lifestyles and climate justice to protect the poor and vulnerable from the adverse impacts of climate change. Including the large hydro, the share of non-fossil sources in total installed electricity capacity is estimated to be about 40.4 per cent (on 31.09.2022) compared to 27.3 per cent in 2014-15. This period has seen a sizeable enhancement in the share of installed electricity capacity in solar and wind energy from 8.9 per cent in 2014-15 to 25.1 per cent in 2022-23 (April-Sept). The updated NDC comprises several goals, including reducing the emissions intensity of GDP by 45 per cent by 2030, achieving about 50 per cent cumulative electric power installed capacity from non-fossil fuel-based energy resources by 2030, and creating additional carbon sinks of 2.5 to 3 billion tonnes of CO2 equivalent through additional forest and tree cover.

India's first NDC, submitted to UNFCCC in October 2015, comprised eight goals, three of which were quantitative targets to be achieved up to 2030. The three targets included cumulative electric power installed capacity from non-fossil sources to reach 40 per cent, reduction in the emissions intensity of GDP by 33 to 35 per cent compared to 2005 levels, and creation of additional carbon sink of 2.5 to 3 billion tonnes of CO2 equivalent through additional forest and tree cover.

In accordance with Article 4 of the Paris Agreement, India updated its first NDC to reflect higher ambition in its climate action. The updated NDC comprises several goals, including reducing the emissions intensity of GDP by 45 per cent by 2030, achieving about 50 per cent cumulative electric power installed capacity from non-fossil fuel-based energy resources by 2030, and creating additional carbon sinks of 2.5 to 3 billion tonnes of CO2 equivalent through additional forest and tree cover. Additionally, India aims to put forward and further propagate a healthy and sustainable way of living based on traditions and values of conservation and moderation, including through a mass movement for ‘LIFE’– ‘Lifestyle for Environment’ as a key to combating climate change, and to adopt a climate-friendly and cleaner path than the one followed hitherto by others at the corresponding level of economic development.

The share of non-fossil sources in total installed electricity capacity (including large hydro) is estimated to be about 40.4 per cent (on 31.09.2022) compared to 27.3 per cent in 2014-15. The share of installed electricity capacity in solar and wind energy has seen a sizeable enhancement over this period, from 8.9 per cent in 2014-15 to 25.1 per cent in 2022-23 (April-Sept).

headings: India's NDC targets for Climate Change
Forest and Tree Cover in India
Carbon Stock in India’s Forest and Tree Cover
explanations: India has set various mitigation and adaptation targets in its NDC. One of the quantifiable targets is to achieve an additional carbon sink of 2.5 billion to 3.0 billion tonnes through additional forest and tree cover by 2030. India plans to better adapt to climate change by enhancing investments in development programmes in sectors vulnerable to climate change, particularly in agriculture, water resources, the Himalayan region, coastal regions, and health and disaster management. India aims to mobilise domestic and new & additional funds from developed countries to implement the above mitigation and adaptation actions.

India's forest and tree cover are continuously increasing. India ranks third globally in terms of net gain in average annual forest area between 2010 and 2020. The National and State Governments' robust framework and policies have been critical in promoting and safeguarding forests. Various schemes like the Green India Mission (GIM), Compensatory Afforestation Fund Management and Planning Authority (CAMPA), National Afforestation Programme (NAP), Green Highway Policy - 2015, Policy for enhancement of Urban Greens, National Agro-forestry Policy, and Sub-Mission on Agro-forestry (SMAF) have been among the most important ones.

Forest ecosystems are a vital sink of carbon, and India's forest ecosystem has sequestrated around 30.1 billion tonnes of CO2 equivalent. Forest Survey of India (FSI) assessed carbon stock of India's forests for the first time in 2004 and then biennially since 2011. The Indian State of Forest Report (ISFR) estimates the carbon stock of forests to be about 7,204 million tonnes in 2019, which is an increase of 79.4 million tonnes of carbon stock as compared to the estimates of the previous assessment for 2017.

The carbon stock in forests across India has been increasing over the years, according to the Forest Survey of India's data. The highest carbon stock is reported in Arunachal Pradesh (1023.84 million tonnes), followed by Madhya Pradesh (609.25 million tonnes). Jammu & Kashmir has the maximum per-hectare carbon stock among different States/UTs.

Ecosystems play a critical role in carbon storage, protecting coastal areas, and enhancing water quality, besides providing cultural, spiritual or tourist attractions. Wetlands act as sponges, storing peak rainfall and releasing water gradually during the lean season, and are natural buffers against floods, droughts, and tropical cyclones. Ramsar Convention, signed by member countries to preserve wetlands of international importance, now encompasses 75 Ramsar sites covering 13.3 lakh ha in India.

Mangroves and coastal wetlands act as the first line of defence against climate devastation like storms surges, flooding, and hurricanes. The government has taken both regulatory and promotional measures to protect and conserve mangroves, and National Coastal Mission Programme on 'Conservation and Management of Mangroves and Coral Reefs' is being implemented. As per a recent study, certain mangrove species in Chilika and Sundarbans along the east coast and Dwarka and Porbandar along the west coast of India are expected to shift landward by 2070 due to a decline in suitable habitats.

headings: Approach to Transition to Renewable Energy Sources
