explanations: India has enacted several Acts such as the Protection Act, 1986; the Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972; the Indian Forest Act, 1927; the Biological Diversity Act, 2002 to protect the environment. According to ISFR 2021, India has shown an increase in mangrove cover by 364 sq. km. in 2021 compared to 2013.

The Indian government is working on mapping and converging the 5Ps - People, Policy, Plan, Program and Project - to improve river conservation efforts. The Namami Gange Central Sector Scheme and National River Conservation Plan Centrally Sponsored Scheme provide financial and technical assistance for abating pollution in rivers. Detailed Project Reports for the rejuvenation of 13 major rivers have been released by ICFRE, Dehradun with proposed works including afforestation, soil erosion containment, groundwater table recharge, carbon dioxide sequestration, ecological restoration, moisture conservation, livelihood improvement and income generation.

India has achieved the target of 40% installed electric capacity from non-fossil fuel sources by 2030, as stated in the initial NDC submitted in 2015. India is now striving to achieve the target of 50% cumulative electric power installed capacity from non-fossil fuel-based energy resources by 2030 in line with updated NDCs.

headings: Installed Electricity Generation Capacity in India
Projected Optimal Generation Capacity Mix by CEA
explanations: India has been gradually increasing its installed electricity generation capacity with a rising share of non-fossil fuel-based capacity. According to Figure vii.5 from the Economic Survey 2022-23, the per cent of non-fossil fuel based capacity has been increasing over the years. The data is taken from the Ministry of Power from the year 2014-15 to 2021-22. The figure also shows that thermal and nuclear energy sources have a higher installed capacity than renewable energy sources and large hydro. However, renewable energy sources have been gaining momentum in recent years.

India is becoming a favoured destination for investment in renewables. According to the Renewables 2022 Global Status Report and Figure vii.6 from the Economic Survey 2022-23, investment in renewable energy has been close to or higher than US$ 10 billion per year since 2016, except for a dip in 2020 likely due to various Covid-19 restrictions. Total investment in renewables stood at US$ 78.1 billion in India during the period 2014 -2021. The figure shows that investment in renewables has been increasing continuously except for a dip in the year 2020.

The Central Electricity Authority (CEA) has projected the optimal generation capacity mix to meet the peak electricity demand and electrical energy requirement for 2029-30. The estimate builds in improved efficiency and minimises the total system cost subject to various technical/financial constraints. According to the Economic Survey 2022-23, the likely installed capacity by the end of 2029-30 is expected to be more than 800 GW of which non-fossil fuel would be more than 500 GW. This projection shows that the non-fossil fuel-based capacity will continue to increase in the future.

headings: Projected optimal mix of installed capacity
Projected fall of average Co2 emissions rate
Green hydrogen as a critical source of alternate energy
explanations: According to the Central Electricity Authority, the projected optimal mix of installed capacity for the year 2029-30 is estimated based on percentages of different sources of energy such as Hydro, Small Hydro, PSP, Coal + lignite, Gas, Nuclear, Solar, Wind, Biomass, including hydro imports of 5856 MW.

The Central Electricity Authority has estimated that the average emission rate will decline by around 29 per cent by 2029-30 compared to 2014-15. There is also a projected fall of average Co2 emissions rate per kWh of electricity due to significant additions in non-fossil fuel-based installed capacity.

From the emerging global momentum on green hydrogen, India can situate this decarbonisation opportunity not just within the context of a low-carbon economy but also as an enabler of energy security and economic development for the nation. It will be crucial for achieving decarbonisation of harder-to-abate sectors such as fertilisers, refining, methanol.

headings: Electrolyser Costs and Green Hydrogen Economics
explanations: The Government of India has approved the National Green Hydrogen Mission with an initial outlay of ₹19,744 crore. Its goal is to make India an energy-independent nation and de-carbonize critical sectors. The mission aims to facilitate demand creation, production, utilization, and export of green hydrogen and mobilize over ₹8 lakh crore of investment by 2030. Some salient features of this mission include green hydrogen production capacity of at least 5 MMT per annum, cumulative reduction in fossil fuel imports over ₹1 lakh crore and creation of over 6 lakh jobs, renewable energy capacity addition of about 125 GW and abatement of nearly 50 MMT of annual GHG emissions. By 2030, the mission is expected to achieve financial incentives targeting domestic manufacturing of electrolysers and production of green hydrogen, development of enabling policy frameworks to support the establishment of green hydrogen ecosystems, robust standards and regulations frameworks, public-private partnership frameworks for R&D, and skill development programmes.

A report by NITI Aayog shows that in the case of India, renewable tariffs have fallen in recent years, and electrolyser costs are expected to fall in the future. The cost of electrolysers is crucial for making green hydrogen economically viable. The report underscores the importance of innovation in electrolyser technology and the rapid increase in its scale of production as the main factors that would drive down the cost of electrolysers and green hydrogen. The electrolyser market is expected to be approximately US$ 5 billion by 2030 and US$ 31 billion by 2050. The report estimates that the cumulative value of the green hydrogen market in India will be US$ 8 billion by 2030 and US$ 340 billion by 2050. Additionally, the adoption of green hydrogen will also result in 3.6 Giga tonnes of cumulative CO2 emission reduction by 2050, generating enormous energy import savings, ensuring stability in industry input prices, and strengthening foreign exchange reserves in the long run.

headings: Falling levelised cost of hydrogen (LCOH) for green hydrogen
Concerns regarding access to critical minerals
Critical minerals and their role in the green transition
Variety of minerals required for renewable energy technologies
Disparity between mineral requirements for clean energy and traditional hydrocarbon resources
explanations: Figure vii.10 shows the falling levelised cost of hydrogen (LCOH11) for green hydrogen over the years from 2020 to 2050. The prices for green hydrogen are expected to range from $1.7 to $2.4/kg for 2030 and $0.6 to $1.2/kg for 2050. On the other hand, the prices for grey hydrogen are expected to range from $1.8 to $2.7/kg for 2030 and $1.9 to $2.9/kg for 2050.

There is a concern that access to critical minerals essential for renewable energy at a reasonable cost may be constrained due to the concentration of these minerals in certain geographies with a monopoly in access to some countries. This assumption could impact the costs of renewable energy.

Box vii.2 discusses the importance of critical minerals for the green transition. Cobalt, copper, lithium, nickel, and rare earth elements (REEs) are crucial for producing electric vehicles and batteries, as well as harnessing solar power and wind energy. The demand for critical minerals is set to increase due to the global preference towards renewable energy; however, the global supply chain of critical minerals is highly concentrated and unevenly distributed, posing a potential supply risk in the face of increased demand.

The types of mineral resources required for renewable energy technologies vary. Lithium, nickel, cobalt, manganese, and graphite are essential for battery performance, longevity, and energy density. REEs are critical for permanent magnets that are necessary for wind turbines and EV motors. Copper and aluminum are necessary for electricity networks.

Renewable energy technologies require significantly more minerals than traditional hydrocarbon resources. For instance, a typical electric car requires six times the mineral inputs of a conventional car, and an onshore wind plant requires nine times more mineral resources than a gas-fired plant. This disparity emphasizes the need for a steady and reliable supply chain of critical minerals.

India needs a multi-dimensional mineral policy that reduces dependence on foreign minerals and creates strategic mineral reserves. Further exploration and investment in internal research including technological innovation for mineral exploration and processing and the development of recycling, reusing, and repurposing technologies are necessary. Khanij Bidesh India Ltd (KABIL) has been created to identify and acquire overseas mineral assets. The Ministry of Mines, Government of India and the Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources (DISER), Government of Australia, signed an MoU for cooperation in the field of mining and processing of critical and strategic minerals. KABIL has also signed a detailed MoU with the Critical Minerals Facilitation Office under the DISER to identify lithium and cobalt mineral assets for final joint investment decisions and acquisition of the assets in Australia catering to the critical and strategic ecosystem of both the countries.

India submitted its Long-Term Low Carbon Development Strategy (LT-LEDS) on November 14, 2022, at COP 27. The salient features of LT-LEDS are to focus on the rational utilisation of national resources with due regard to energy security. The transitions from fossil fuels will be undertaken in a just, smooth, sustainable, and all-inclusive manner. The strategy also encompasses the objectives of the National Hydrogen Policy. Rapid expansion of green hydrogen production, increasing electrolyser manufacturing capacity, and creating a market for fuel-cell electric vehicles are the three main pillars of the policy.

India has set several milestones in the power and transport sectors, aims for climate-resilient urban development, and seeks to continue industrial growth while transitioning to a low-carbon development pathway.

India's climate actions have largely been financed domestically, but estimates indicate a need for significant investment. Developed countries are expected to mobilize resources to enable financial flows at a reasonable cost, while India aims to mobilize private capital for its ambitious climate goals.

Green bonds are financial instruments used to invest in environmentally sustainable and climate-suitable projects. They have become widely accepted in response to growing focus on project sustainability.

headings: SEBI’s data on green debt securities
explanations: Green Bonds are a type of bond used to raise funds for climate and environmental projects. They offer a relatively lower cost of capital compared to regular bonds. Major countries like UK, France, Germany, USA, and China have issued green bonds. According to IMF data, around US$ 620 billion worth of green bonds were issued globally in 2021. In India, 15 corporates have issued green bonds worth ₹4,539 crore between 2017 and September 2022, mostly for renewable energy generation and tertiary treatment of wastewater.

Sovereign Green Bonds are issued by governments to raise finance for public sector projects aimed at reducing the carbon intensity of the economy. In Union Budget 2022-23, the Indian government announced the issuance of Sovereign Green Bonds to reduce the carbon intensity of the economy significantly. The final Sovereign Green Bonds framework of India has been issued, complying with the components and key recommendations of the International Capital Market Association (ICMA) Green Bond Principles (2021). A Green Finance working committee has been set up to oversee and validate key decisions on the issuance of Sovereign Green Bonds. The committee will select the projects for allocation of proceeds, do a time-bound review of the allocation and carry out annual reporting along with an impact assessment of the proceeds from sovereign green bonds issued. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has notified the indicative calendar for the issuance of Sovereign Green Bonds (SGrBs) for the fiscal year 2022-23. The issuance would take place through two auctions on January 25, 2023, and February 9, 2023, respectively, for ₹8,000 crore each, totaling ₹16,000 crore. Five per cent of the notified amount of sale has been reserved for retail investors.

For each of the Sovereign Green Bond auctions, there would be a security-wise allocation of 5-year and 10-year SGrBs worth ₹4,000 crore each. Five per cent of the notified amount of sale has been reserved for retail investors.
The SGrBs will be designated as specified securities under the 'Fully Accessible Route' for investment in Government Securities by non-residents.

IMF Climate Change Dashboard is a visual representation of data related to countries that have issued green bonds to raise funds for climate and environmental projects. The Dashboard shows the amount of green bonds of value around US$ 620 billion issued globally in 2021, in which countries issued green bonds of value US$ 587.7 billion, and international organizations issued bonds of value US$ 32.3 billion. The Dashboard also shows the status of Sovereign green Bond issuances in 2021 of various countries like UK, France, Italy, Germany, China, Hong Kong, Spain, Serbia, Rep. of Korea, Hungary, Colombia, etc.

According to SEBI's data, between 2017 and September 2022, 15 Indian corporates have issued green bonds worth ₹4,539 crore. Most of these are related to renewable energy generation, while one is slated to be used for the tertiary treatment of wastewater.

headings: Regulatory Framework for Issuance of Green Debt Securities
explanations: Climate Change and Environment are important topics that have significant implications for the future of our planet. It is important to take action to mitigate the effects of climate change and protect our environment for future generations.

Preparing for the future is important to mitigate the effects of climate change and ensure a sustainable future. It is important for private sector entities to take action to reduce their environmental impact and promote sustainable development.

The regulatory framework for issuance of green debt securities is an important aspect of sustainable finance. The Reserve Bank of India and SEBI have introduced policies that incentivize lending towards greener industries and projects, and have created a framework for the issuance of green debt securities.

SEBI has introduced subcategories of green debt securities such as blue bonds for water management and marine sector, yellow bonds for solar energy, and transition bonds. These green debt securities promote sustainable development and investing in resilience.

SEBI requires mandatory ESG-related disclosures for top listed entities, and new sustainability reporting requirements have been issued under the Business Responsibility and Sustainability Report (BRSR) which is more quantifiable and in line with the National Guidelines on Responsible Business Conduct. Early research shows that ESG performance reduces stock return volatility and build investors' confidence, creating long-term value for investors.

India participated in COP 27 with a focus on mainstreaming the theme of LiFE - Lifestyle for Environment, inviting all countries to join the pro-people and pro-planet effort of shifting the world to mindful utilization of natural resources. The Sharm el-Sheikh Implementation Plan, a major decision at COP 27, highlights the importance of transitioning to sustainable lifestyles and consumption patterns, and other decisions were the setting up of a Just Transition and Mitigation Work Program and Joint work on the implementation of climate action on agriculture and food security. Developing nations strongly voiced setting a fund for loss and damage, and a transitional committee has been established to work on the modalities.

headings: India's Initiatives at the International Stage
explanations: The Sharm el-Sheikh Implementation Plan covered several elements including the importance of science in guiding climate action, doubling adaptation finance, dialogue on making finance flows consistent with low-emissions and climate-resilient development, and calls for Multilateral Development Banks (MDB) reform for delivering climate finance at scale. The COP 27 also saw progress on adaptation on the Global Goal on Adaptation that will conclude at COP 28 and inform the first Global Stocktake in 2023. However, the target of US$100 billion per year has yet to be achieved. The COP 21 decided that, prior to 2025, a New Collective Quantified Goal (NCQG) on climate finance from a floor of US$100 billion per year will be set. To further the agenda of setting the NCQG by 2024, COP 27 decided that Four Technical Expert Dialogues (TEDs) will be carried out prior to COP 28.

The International Solar Alliance (ISA) is a treaty-based inter-governmental organisation that creates a global market system to tap the benefits of solar power and promote clean energy applications. ISA's mission is to unlock US$1 trillion of investments in solar by 2030 while reducing the cost of technology and financing. ISA partners with multilateral development banks (MDBs), development financial institutions (DFIs), private and public sector organisations, civil society, and other international institutions to deploy cost-effective and transformational solutions using solar energy, especially in the least Developed Countries (LDCs) and the Small Island Developing States (SIDS). ISA has expanded its coverage to all its 110 member countries, and through programmatic support, has identified a pipeline of 9.5 GW of solar energy capacity in its member countries, including large-scale solar parks in multiple developing countries.

The Coalition for Disaster Resilient Infrastructure (CDRI) is a global partnership of national governments, UN agencies and programs, multilateral development banks and financing mechanisms, the private sector, and academic and knowledge institutions. It was launched by the Hon'ble Prime Minister of India during the United Nations Climate Action Summit in 2019. CDRI aims to promote the resilience of infrastructure systems to climate and disaster risks, thereby ensuring sustainable development.

As of June 29, 2022, thirty-one countries, six international organizations, and two private sector organizations have joined as members of CDRI, which aims to develop a network of organizations and stakeholders to advance disaster-resilient infrastructure in India and other partner countries.

LeadIT is a group of countries and companies committed to achieving the Paris Agreement and progressing on low-carbon pathways. During COP 27, LeadIT members adopted a joint statement agreeing to promote value chain partnerships, invest in infrastructure, give mandates to multilateral development banks and funds, and formulate roadmaps for heavy industry sectors to transition finance.

Conservation of biodiversity is crucial for the sustenance of all living beings and provides resources and services necessary for human beings. India ranks eighth in the world and fourth in Asia among mega-diverse countries, with rich fauna and wild ancestors of crop plants. May 22 is celebrated annually as International Day for Biological Diversity to create awareness on the need for conservation.

The Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) is a legally binding international instrument adopted in 1992 at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. Its objectives are to conserve, sustainable use, and fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from the use of biological diversity.

The fifteenth meeting of the Conference of Parties (COP 15) to the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) was held in Montreal, Canada in December 2022. Key outcomes of the COP 15 include effective conservation of at least 30% of the world's lands, inland waters, coastal areas, and oceans, reducing global food waste and overconsumption, and phasing out subsidies that harm biodiversity.

India enacted the Biological Diversity Act in 2002 in conformity with the spirit of the CBD. The Act mandates the implementation of the objectives through a decentralised system with the National Biodiversity Authority at the national level, the State Biodiversity Boards at the State level, and Biodiversity Management Committees at the local body level.

In August 2022, India and Nepal signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on biodiversity conservation to strengthen and enhance the coordination and cooperation in the field of forests, wildlife, environment, biodiversity conservation, and climate change.

Project Cheetah is the world’s first inter-continental large wild carnivore translocation project, which involves reintroducing cheetahs in India after their extinction from the country in 1952. Eight Namibian wild cheetahs, including five females and three males, were introduced to Kuno National Park in Madhya Pradesh on 17 September 2022. The reintroduction of cheetahs can help restore open forest and grassland ecosystems in India, ultimately benefiting society by conserving biodiversity and enhancing ecosystem services like water security, carbon sequestration, and soil moisture conservation. The government has constituted a Task Force for monitoring the reintroduction, which will review, progress, and monitor the health status of cheetahs, as well as assess their hunting skills and adaptation to the habitat of Kuno National Park. The Task Force will also suggest regulations for opening cheetah habitats for eco-tourism and for developing tourism infrastructure in the fringe areas of Kuno National Park and other protected areas.

India has a rich heritage of wildlife and a long history and tradition of conservation. The Wildlife (Protection) Act 1972 provides special legal protection to India's wildlife and endangered fauna. Preservation of keystone and flagship species like tigers, lions, and elephants can benefit entire ecosystems. India is home to 53 Tiger Reserves covering approximately 75,796.8 sq. km area in 18 states, with about 75% of the global wild tiger population. The country achieved the goal of doubling its tiger numbers in 2018, four years before the targeted year of 2022. Additionally, 17 Tiger Reserves in India have CA|TS international accreditation, and two have received the International Tx2 Award. Concern for wildlife preservation and protection is, in fact, the concern for human well-being since all forms of life – human, animal, and plants – are so closely interlinked that disturbance in one leads to an imbalance in others.

India has made significant strides in wildlife conservation with populations of Asiatic lions, leopards, tigers, and elephants showing steady growth. Additionally, the government has amended the Wild Life (Protection) Act multiple times to strengthen conservation measures and fulfil multilateral commitments on wildlife preservation, with the most recent amendment in 2022 seeking to increase the number of species protected under the law and implement the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora.

India has taken measures to reduce pollution caused by littered single-use plastics, including a per capita plastic consumption rate of 11 kg compared to the global average of 28 kg. The Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, Government of India, notified the Plastic Waste Management Amendment Rules, 2021, on August 12, 2021, and a ban was imposed on the manufacture, import, stocking, distribution, sale, and use of identified single-use plastics as of July 1, 2022.

The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) is an international agreement between governments aimed at ensuring that international trade in specimens of wild animals and plants does not threaten the survival of the species. India is committed to implementing CITES and has brought in the Wild Life (Protection) Amendment Act, 2022, seeking to implement CITES and increase the number of species protected under Indian law.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 emphasizes the use of identified single-use plastic items, which have low utility and high littering potential, all across the country. The measures will promote a circular economy, reduce the plastic footprint of plastic packaging, promote the development of new alternatives to plastic packaging and provide the next steps for moving towards sustainable plastic packaging by businesses.

The Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change notified the Guidelines on Extended Producer Responsibility for plastic packaging vide Plastic Waste Management Amendment Rules, 2022, on 16 February 2022. The guidelines include mandatory registration of Producers, Importers, and Brand Owners (PIBOs) and Plastic Waste Processors (PWPs) through a centralized online portal; coverage of four categories of plastic packaging; clearly defined targets for EPR; mandatory targets for reuse of rigid plastic packaging, minimum level of recycling of plastic waste and use of recycled plastic content in plastic packaging; centralised online portal to support the implementation of EPR; provision for the sale and purchase of surplus EPR certificates; levy of environmental compensation for non-fulfilment of EPR obligations and provision for verification, audit and monitoring of obligated entities.

The Plastic Waste Management (Second Amendment) Rules, 2022, were notified on July 6, 2022. The amendment aligns the rules with the Guidelines on Extended Producer Responsibility for plastic packaging. The amendment provides a statutory framework for biodegradable plastics after conforming to BIS Standards and the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) certification. The rules mandate that environmental compensation shall be levied based upon the polluter pays principle, on persons not complying with the provisions of these rules, as per guidelines notified by the Central Pollution Control Board.

The waste management infrastructure in the States/UTs is also being strengthened through the Swachh Bharat Mission. All States/UTs have constituted a Special Task Force for eliminating single-use plastics and effectively implementing Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016. A National Level Taskforce has been formed by the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change to make coordinated efforts to eliminate identified single-use plastic items and effective implementation of Plastic Waste.

The resumed session of the fifth United Nations Environment Assembly held in Nairobi on 2 March 2022 adopted a resolution “End plastic pollution: towards an international legally binding agreement on plastic pollution”. The resolution aims to address the plastic pollution crisis and develop a new global agreement on plastic pollution, covering the various aspects of the plastic life cycle, including design, production, consumption, and waste management.

India engaged constructively with all member states to develop consensus on the resolution for driving global action on plastic pollution. On the insistence of India, the principle of national circumstances and capability while addressing plastic pollution was included in the resolution text to allow developing countries to follow their development trajectories.

The Government published the Battery Waste Management Rules, 2022 on August 24, 2022, to ensure environmentally sound management of waste batteries. The rules function based on the concept of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR), where the producers of batteries are responsible for the collection and recycling/refurbishment of waste batteries and the use of recovered materials from wastes into new batteries. To meet the EPR obligations, producers may engage themselves or authorise any other entity to collect, recycle or refurbish waste batteries.

The Government notified the E-Waste (Management) Rules, 2022, on November 2, 2022. These rules will replace the E-waste (Management) Rules, 2016, and will be effective from April 1, 2023. These rules will launch a new Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) regime for e-waste recycling. The rules are applicable to every manufacturer, producer, refurbisher, dismantler, and recycler who must register with CPCB. Producers of notified EEE have been given annual E-Waste Recycling targets based on the generation from the previously sold EEE or based on sales of EEE, as the case may be. The recycled quantity will be computed based on end-products to avoid false claims. Provision for generation and transaction of EPR Certificate has been introduced. Provisions for environmental compensation and verification & audit have been introduced.

headings: Provision for reducing hazardous substances in EEE manufacturing
India's commitment to combating climate change
Expectations of further large-scale climate measures
Importance of advanced countries setting policy and behavioural examples
explanations: Under the Economic Survey 2022-23, a provision for reducing hazardous substances in the manufacturing of EEE has been provided. It mandates that every producer of EEE and their components shall ensure that their products do not contain lead, mercury, and other hazardous substances beyond the maximum prescribed concentration. It also provides for recognition and registration, skill development, monitoring, and ensuring the safety and health of workers involved in dismantling and recycling e-waste.

India is spearheading one of the world's most ambitious clean energy transitions and remains steadfast in its commitment to combating climate change, according to the Economic Survey 2022-23. Despite the adverse impacts of Covid-19 on the economy, India has enhanced its climate ambition manifold and embarked on a long-term strategy towards a Low GHG Emission Development Strategy by adopting a multi-pronged approach. The energy transition plan is complemented by numerous policies intended to improve the ecosystem to deploy promising technological innovations, like green hydrogen. The country has consistently modified/amended regulatory standards and adopted policy-level interventions to support the development and adoption of new technology. India's progress on energy transition may be understood from the fact that it has enhanced its non-fossil fuel-based installed capacity target to 50 per cent in its updated NDC as the target of 40 per cent of the first NDC was achieved well in advance.

As per the Economic Survey 2022-23, India's sustainable finance framework has also evolved from the initial steps covering the top listed 100 companies required to conform to sustainability standards. The requirement has now not only been extended to 1000 top listed companies on a mandatory basis but also the sustainability standards have become much stronger and measurable that correspond to the best practices while taking into account the specific context of India.

According to the Economic Survey 2022-23, resources have competing use, and development strategies are not substitutable. Modification in the development pathway has a transition cost, including social and economic costs. India's climate ambitions require resources to be dedicated to the cause of climate change, in addition to, what is needed for the country's development goals. Obligations on climate should be matched with the on-time availability of climate finance, technology, and inputs like critical minerals, while not jeopardizing the socio-economic development objectives and aspirations.

Even if India has so far undertaken climate actions on its own, the heightened expectations of further large-scale climate measures have to be equated with the enhanced initiatives by developed countries in terms of providing means of implementation, including finance, technology transfer, and capacity-building support, according to the Economic Survey 2022-23.

The global climate agenda will advance if advanced countries can set examples of policy and behavioural changes that work in their backyard and whose trade-offs are well recognised and accepted by their people, according to the Economic Survey 2022-23. Then, it might be realistic to expect such policies and behavioural expectations of households to succeed in developing countries with suitable adaptation.

headings: Performance of Animal Husbandry, Dairying, and Fisheries Sectors
explanations: The agriculture and allied activities sector in India has been growing at an average annual growth rate of 4.6% over the last six years. In recent years, India has also emerged as a net exporter of agricultural products, with exports growing by 18% in 2020-21. The growth can be attributed to the measures taken by the government to promote crop diversification, improve productivity through mechanization, and provide support through the Agriculture Infrastructure Fund.

The government has implemented various measures to augment crop and livestock productivity, ensure price support for farmers, promote crop diversification, and improve market infrastructure through the establishment of farmer-producer organizations. In addition, the government has also facilitated credit availability, mechanization, and horticulture and organic farming.
The animal husbandry, dairying, and fisheries sectors have been performing well relative to the crop sector and are important contributors to food security and farmers' incomes.

The NFSA is a legislation-backed nationwide food management program. To reduce the financial burden of the poor, the government has decided to give free foodgrains to 81.4 crore beneficiaries under the NFSA for one year from January 2023.

headings: Growth in Agriculture and Allied Sector
Crowding in of Private Investment in Agriculture
explanations: The content includes information from the Economic Survey 2022-23, highlighting the efforts made by the Indian government to support other countries during Covid-19, income support to farmers, and the promotion of allied activities, among other areas.

Despite the Covid-19 shock, the agriculture and allied sector shows resilient growth, as shown in Figure VIII.1. The figure indicates that the sector has consistently grown over the years, with the lowest growth being -0.2% and the highest being 6.8% between 2014-15 and 2021-22.

The Government's interventions have been in line with the recommendations of the Committee on Doubling Farmers' Income to improve crop and livestock productivity, diversify towards higher value crops, improve resource efficiency, enhance cropping intensity, improve real prices received by farmers, and shift from farm to non-farm occupations as being significant sources of growth. The interventions include measures such as the Minimum Support Price (MSP) to secure the price at one and half times the all-India weighted average cost of production, schemes and price measures to focus on high-value added crops such as oilseed, incentives for crop diversification through price policy measures, improvements in agricultural marketing, and enhancing resource use efficiency. The sector needs re-orientation in the backdrop of certain challenges like adverse impacts of climate change, fragmented landholdings, sub-optimal farm mechanisation, low productivity, disguised unemployment, rising input costs, etc.

Various policy initiatives have been introduced and implemented to deal with challenges facing the agriculture sector. These initiatives aim to address issues such as adverse impacts of climate change, fragmented landholdings, sub-optimal farm mechanisation, low productivity, disguised unemployment, rising input costs, among others.

Figure VIII.2 shows the crowding in of Private investment in agriculture. From 2011-12 to 2020-21, Private investment in agriculture has consistently remained above Public investment, indicating a growing interest in the sector.

headings: Increase in foodgrain production in India
explanations: Agriculture and food management play a crucial role in ensuring food security as well as nutritional security for a country's population. The production of food grains and oilseeds has been increasing in India. However, changing climate patterns have also adversely impacted agriculture.
India's agriculture sector consumes a significant amount of electricity every year. As of 2021, India's annual electricity consumption for agriculture was between 150-200 GWh.

The production of food grains has been consistently increasing, as per the Fourth Advance Estimates for 2021-22. Production of pulses has been notably higher than the average of the last five years. However, changing climate patterns have impacted agriculture adversely. Early heatwaves and deficient rainfall in 2022 led to a decline in the sown area for paddy cultivation.

As per First Advance Estimates for 2022-23 (Kharif only), total food grains production in the country is estimated at 149.9 million tonnes, which is higher than the average Kharif food grain production of the previous five years.

India has seen a sustained increase in food grain production over the years. The production of food grains has increased from 252.0 million tonnes in 2014-15 to 315.7 million tonnes in 2021-22, as per the 1st Advance Estimates (2022-23) of DA&FW released on 21.09.2022.

headings: Minimum Support Price (MSP) for selected crops
explanations: The Government of India has been increasing the MSP for all 22 Kharif, Rabi and other commercial crops with a margin of at least 50 per cent over the all-India weighted average cost of production since the agricultural year 2018-19. Given nutritional requirements and changing dietary patterns and to achieve self-sufficiency in pulses and oilseeds production, the Government has fixed relatively higher MSP for pulses and oilseeds.
The table shows the Minimum Support Price for selected Kharif and Rabi Crops (₹/Quintal) from 2013-14 to 2022-23.

The Kisan Credit Card Scheme (KCC) was introduced in 1998 for farmers to empower them to purchase agricultural products and services on credit at any time. As of 30 December, 2022, banks issued Kisan Credit Cards (KCC) to 3.89 crore eligible farmers with a KCC limit of ₹4,51,672 crore. With the Government of India extending the KCC facility to fisheries and animal husbandry farmers in 2018-19, the number of such cards in the fisheries and animal husbandry sector has also grown. As of 17 October 2022, 1.0 lakh KCCs have been sanctioned for the fisheries sector and 9.5 lakh (as of 4 November 2022) for the animal husbandry sector.

The Interest Subvention Scheme (ISS), now renamed Modified Interest Subvention Scheme (MISS), is introduced by the Government of India to provide short-term credit to farmers at subsidised interest rates. Under this scheme, short-term agriculture loan up to ₹3 lakh is available at 7 per cent per annum to farmers engaged in Agriculture and other Allied activities, including Animal Husbandry.
Ensuring hassle-free credit availability at a cheaper rate to farmers has been the top priority of the Government of India.

The agriculture credit flow has consistently increased over the years, exceeding the target every year for the past several years. In 2021-22, it exceeded the target of ₹16.5 lakh crore by about 13%. The target for the flow of credit to agriculture for 2022-23 has been fixed at ₹18.5 lakh crore.

Farm mechanisation helps increase productivity through timely and efficient use of other inputs and natural resources while at the same time reducing the cost of cultivation and the drudgery associated with various farm operations. Under the Sub Mission on Agricultural Mechanisation (SMAM), State Governments are being assisted in training and demonstrating agricultural machinery and helping farmers procure various farm machinery and equipment besides setting up Custom Hiring Centres (CHC). As of December 2022, 21628 CHCs and 467 Hi-Tech hubs and 18306 farm machinery banks have been established.

Organic and natural farming provides chemical fertiliser and pesticide-free food grains and other crops, improves soil health and reduces environmental pollution. India has 44.3 lakh organic farmers, the highest in the world, and about 59.1 lakh ha area was brought under organic farming by 2021-22. Sikkim voluntarily adopted going organic, and the process of getting the total cultivable land of 58,168 hectares under organic farming commenced at ground level in 1Agriculture Statistics at a glance 2021.

Organic farming has been promoted in India through two dedicated schemes - PKVY and MOVCDNER. PKVY is implemented in a cluster mode, and under the scheme, financial assistance of ₹50,000 per ha for three years is provided to farmers for organic inputs. As of 16 November 2022, 32,384 clusters totalling 6.4 lakh ha area have been covered. MOVCDNER promotes organic farming of niche crops of the North East Region through FPOs, and 177 FPOs/FPCs have been created, covering 1.5 lakh farmers and 1.7 lakh hectares. In addition, a 1.2 lakh ha area has been covered under organic farming in the Namami Gange Programme.

The promotion of natural farming began in 2019-20 through the BPKP sub-scheme of PKVY. The scheme helps farmers adopt indigenous practices for ecological farming, including Zero-Budget Natural Farming (ZBNF). Under the BPKP, 4.09 lakh ha of land have been brought under natural farming in 8 states.

PM KISAN Scheme is a Central Sector Scheme to provide financial assistance of ₹6,000 per year to land-holding farmer families through DBT. About 11.3 crore farmers were covered under the Scheme in its April-July 2022-23 payment cycle. Over a span of 3 years, the Scheme has provided more than Rs. 2 lakh crore to needy farmers. Studies show that the scheme has enabled farmers to address liquidity constraints for buying agricultural inputs, meet their requirement of funds for farm inputs and their daily consumption, education, health, and other expenses.

Agriculture Infrastructure Fund (AIF) is a financing facility operational from 2020-21 to 2032-33 for the creation of post-harvest management infrastructure and community farm assets. The scheme offers benefits such as 3% interest subvention and credit guarantee support. A provision of ₹1 lakh crore for 2020-21 to 2025-26 has been made under the scheme.

The AIF scheme provides subvention and credit guarantee assistance until 2032-33 and offers the facility of convergence with any other scheme of the State or Central Government. It has proved to be a milestone in investment in the agriculture sector since its inception. An amount of ₹13,681 crore has been sanctioned for agriculture infrastructure in the country, covering more than 18,133 projects, which includes 8,076 warehouses, 2,788 primary processing units, 1,860 custom hiring centres, 937 sorting & grading units, 696 cold store projects, 163 assaying units, and around 3613 other kinds of post-harvest management projects and community farming assets.

PMFBY is currently the largest crop insurance scheme in the world in terms of farmer enrolments, averaging 5.5 crore applications every year, and the third largest in terms of the premium received. The scheme promises minimal financial burden on the farmer, with farmers paying only 1.5% and 2% of the total premium for the Rabi and Kharif seasons, respectively, with the Centre and State Governments bearing most of the premium cost. During the last six years, farmers paid a premium of ₹25,186 crore and received claims amounting to ₹1.2 lakh crore (as of 31 October 2022). The share of non-loanee, marginalized, and small farmers has increased by 282% since the scheme’s inception in 2016, indicating its acceptability amongst farmers.

PMFBY covers all food & oilseeds crops and annual commercial/horticultural crops for which past yield data is available, and for which the requisite number of crop cutting experiments (CCEs) are being conducted under the General Crop Estimation Survey (GCES). It is implemented through empanelled general insurance companies on an ‘Area Approach’ basis. Admissible claims are worked out and paid directly to the insured farmer’s account by the insurance companies on the yield data based on the requisite number of CCEs per unit area furnished to the concerned insurance. However, losses due to localized risks of hailstorms, landslides, inundation, etc., are calculated on an individual-insured farm basis. The revamped Scheme w.e.f Kharif 2020 has many features, which include voluntary participation for all farmers, selection of Insurance Companies by the States for 3 years in a go, a two-step process of crop yield estimation, use of smart sampling technique through satellite data for crop cutting experiments, etc.

PMFBY is the largest crop insurance scheme in the world in terms of farmer enrolments with 5.5 crore applications every year. It has proved to be a decisive factor in securing the livelihoods of farmers during extreme weather conditions. The claims paid ratio in several states averaged more than 100 per cent against the gross premium collected. National Crop Insurance Portal has been developed to handle all grievances from end to end. The redressal of complaints within prescribed time limits is monitored through the portal by the Government officials.

MIDH is a scheme to promote horticulture covering fruits, vegetables, root and tuber crops, spices, flowers, plantation crops etc. The interventions include introducing improved varieties and quality seeds, incentives for plantation crops, cluster development, and post-harvest management. According to third advance estimates (2021-22), a record production of 342.3 million tonnes in an area of 28.0 million hectares was achieved. The Cluster Development Programme (CDP) pilot phase is designed to leverage the geographical specialisation of horticulture clusters and promote integrated and market-led development of pre-production, production and post-harvest activities, including the entire supply chain.

The e-NAM Scheme is an online transparent competitive bidding system to ensure farmers get remunerative prices for their produce. The scheme provides a single e-trading platform across the country for agricultural commodities where farmers can directly sell their produce to buyers residing in any part of India. The e-NAM platform has been integrated with various other platforms such as Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) e-Kuber system, GSTN, National Payment Corporation of India (NPCI), and Farmers Producers’ Organisations (FPOs) to ensure seamless business transactions.

The e-NAM Scheme is a Government initiative that provides free software and assistance of ₹75 lakh per APMC mandi for related hardware, including quality assaying equipment and the creation of infrastructure like cleaning, grading, sorting, packaging, compost unit, etc. As of 31st December 2022, more than 1.7 crore farmers and 2.3 lakh traders have been registered on the e-NAM portal.

Climate-Smart Farming Practices are slowly gaining acceptance among Indian farmers. They use clean energy sources like solar for irrigation and have been incentivised to transfer electricity generated through solar to the local grid. Crop yield prediction models using artificial intelligence and drones for monitoring soil and crop health have been initiated. Smart farming also enables crop diversification, which will help farmers reduce their dependence on monsoons for water. There are over 1,000 agritech start-ups in India that assist farmers in improving farming techniques.

The United Nations General Assembly declared 2023 the International Year of Millets (IYM) during its 75th session in March 2021. Millets are considered Smart Food with high nutritional value, are climate resilient, and align with several UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). They are also important by virtue of their mammoth potential to generate livelihoods, increase farmers’ income and ensure food and nutritional security all over the world.

India is a leading producer of millets, accounting for 80% of Asia's and 20% of global production, with an average yield of 1239 kg/ha. Millets are primarily a Kharif crop grown in rainfed conditions, requiring less water and agricultural inputs than other staple crops. The government notified millets as Nutri-cereals in April 2018, and a sub-mission on Nutri-cereals is being implemented since 2018-19 in 212 districts of 14 states. More than 500 start-ups work in the millet value chain in India, with 250 incubated under Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana - Remunerative Approaches for Agriculture and Allied Sectors Rejuvenation (RKVY-RAFTAAR).

The allied sectors of Indian agriculture - livestock, forestry and logging, and fishing and aquaculture - have become potential sources of better farm incomes, with high growth rates. The livestock sector grew at a CAGR of 7.9% from 2014-15 to 2020-21, and its contribution to total agriculture GV A (at constant prices) increased from 24.3% to 30.1% during this period. The annual average growth rate of the fisheries sector has been about 7% since 2016-17 and has a share of about 6.7% in total agriculture GV A.

Recognizing the growing importance of allied sectors, the Committee on Doubling Farmers' Income (DFI, 2018) considers dairying, livestock, poultry, fisheries, and horticulture as high-growth engines and has recommended a focused policy with a concomitant support system for the allied sector.

headings: Government interventions for livestock productivity and disease control
Renewed impetus given to cooperative sector growth
explanations: The dairy sector is a crucial component of the livestock sector in India. It employs more than eight crore farmers directly and is the most significant agrarian product. India ranks first in milk production in the world, ranks third in egg production, and eighth in meat production worldwide.

The Indian government has launched several critical interventions to enhance the infrastructure of the livestock sector and improve livestock productivity, disease control, and entrepreneurship development. The Animal Husbandry Infrastructure Development Fund (AHIDF) worth ₹15,000 crore and National Livestock Mission (NLM) scheme have been launched as part of the Aatmanirbhar Bharat stimulus package. The Livestock Health and Disease Control (LH&DC) Scheme and National Animal Disease Control Programme (NADCP) are also being implemented.

PMMSY was launched in 2020 as the highest-ever investment in the fisheries sector in India. It has a total outlay of ₹20,050 crore and aims to drive sustainable and responsible development of the fisheries sector while ensuring socio-economic development of the fishers, fish farmers, and fish workers. Before PMMSY, the Fisheries and Aquaculture Infrastructure Development Fund (FIDF) was established.

The cooperative societies in India, especially in agriculture, dairy, and fisheries sectors, provide the rural population with livelihood opportunities and a financial safety net with a community-based approach. Cooperatives hold the key to rural economic transformation. There are 8.5 lakh registered cooperatives in the country, having more than 29 crore members, mainly from the marginalized and lower-income groups in the rural areas, and 98 per cent of villages are covered by Primary Agriculture Credit Societies (PACS).

A renewed impetus has been given to the growth of the cooperative sector in India to realize the vision of 'Sahakar-se-Samriddhi.' Currently, around 19 per cent of agriculture finance in India is through cooperative societies.

headings: Top Ten States with Multi-State Cooperative Societies
explanations: Cooperative Societies are organizations that are formed by individuals with similar objectives who come together to pool resources and solve common problems. India has a rich history of cooperative societies that goes back over a hundred years. These societies are instrumental in promoting socio-economic development and empowering individuals and communities. An important step in this direction is the establishment of Ministry of Cooperation in July 2021 to provide greater focus to the cooperative sector. In addition, the Government has taken various initiatives to promote and strengthen PACS, like the computerisation of 63,000 functional PACS and the preparation of by-laws for enabling PACS to expand their activities. The Multi-State Cooperative Societies Act, 2002 (MSCS) is a key legislation that seeks to facilitate the democratic functioning and autonomous working of Multi-State Cooperative Societies in line with the established Cooperative Principles. As of date, there are 1528 registered societies under the Multi-State Cooperative Societies Act 2002. The MSCSs include 66 Multi-State Cooperative Banks with deposits of approx. ₹2.6 lakh crore. Maharashtra leads 661 cooperatives, followed by Delhi and Uttar Pradesh.

The top ten states with Multi-State Cooperative Societies as on 20 October 2022 are Maharashtra, Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Rajasthan, West Bengal, Gujarat, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh and Kerala. There are 661 cooperative societies in Maharashtra which is the highest number among all the states. This is followed by Delhi and Uttar Pradesh with 159 and 156 cooperatives respectively. Tamil Nadu, Rajasthan, West Bengal, Gujarat, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh and Kerala have 126, 72, 69, 42, 29, 29 and 28 societies respectively.

To strengthen the cooperative movement in the country, deepen its reach to the grassroots and promote cooperative-based economic development, a New National Cooperation Policy is being formulated. The policy involves relevant stakeholders such as experts of the cooperative sector, representatives from National/ State/ District/ Primary level cooperative societies, Secretaries (Cooperation) and Resident Commissioners from States/UTs, officers from Central Ministries/ Departments. The objective is to have a policy that unlocks the true potential of the Cooperation sector. In addition, the Government has also decided to introduce the Multi-State Co-operative Societies (Amendment) Bill, 2022 to amend the Multi-State Co-operative Societies Act, 2002. The Bill seeks to bring it in line with Part IXB of the Constitution and to strengthen the cooperative movement in the country by bringing in provisions relating to electoral reforms, strengthening governance and transparency, reforming the composition, meetings and membership of board; enabling the raising of funds by co-operative sector, strengthening monitoring mechanism, enhancing ‘Ease of doing business’, etc. The bill was introduced in the Lok Sabha on 7 December 2022 in the winter session of Parliament.

headings: Challenges faced by food processing sector
Government interventions for food processing sector
explanations: The food processing sector is a significant part of India's development as it promotes interactions between industry and agriculture. The sector has been growing at an average annual growth rate of around 8.3% for the last five years ending FY21. With the growing importance of processed food items in the consumer basket, new horizons are now open for both the agriculture and the industry sector pushing diversification and commercialisation in farming, improvement in the efficiency of resource use, enhancement in the income of farmers, expansion in the avenues to export agro foods, and generation of employment opportunities.

The food processing sector is significant as it contributes to tackling several developmental concerns such as disguised rural unemployment in agriculture, rural poverty, food security, food inflation, improved nutrition, prevention of wastage of food etc. Optimum development of the food processing sector will significantly improve these developmental concerns.

To facilitate the growth of the food processing sector, there is a continuous need for extensive investment in cold chain infrastructure and address logistical challenges. The lack of adequate and efficient cold chain infrastructure is a critical supply-side bottleneck that leads to massive post-harvest losses (mostly of perishables) estimated at ₹92,561 crore annually. The uneven geographic distribution of cold storage infrastructure also contributes to regional-level disparities. Indian national highways, while accounting for 2% of the total road network, carry 40% of all cargo, which is detrimental to food (and particularly perishables) transport.

Recognizing the abundant potential of the sector, the Government has been at the forefront with various interventions aimed at the development of food processing in the country. The Ministry of Food Processing Industries, through the component schemes of Pradhan Mantri Kisan SAMPADA Yojana (PMKSY), provide financial assistance for the overall growth and development of the food processing sector. Under PMKSY, 677 projects have been completed till 31 December 2022. The Ministry also launched in 2020 the Prime Minister's Formalisation of Micro Food Processing Enterprises (PMFME) Scheme as part of the ANB Abhiyan to enhance the competitiveness of individual micro-enterprises in the unorganized segment and promote the formalization of this sector by providing financial, technical and business support for up-gradation/setting up of 2 lakh micro units in the country. As of 31 December 2022, 15,095 loans of ₹1402.6 crore were sanctioned. The scheme adopts the One District One Product.

headings: Production Linked Incentive Scheme for Food Processing Industry (PLISFPI)
explanations: The One District One Product (ODOP) approach is being used to achieve economies of scale in procuring inputs, using shared services and marketing products. 713 districts with 137 unique products have been approved under this approach in 35 states/UTs.

The PLISFPI, launched in March 2022, aims to incentivize investments that create global food champions in high-growth potential sectors, such as marine products, processed fruits & vegetables, and 'Ready to Eat/ Ready to Cook' products. Phase-I will support 149 applications, and phase-II will support 33 applications (both organic and millet products). A separate PLI Scheme for millet-based products has been introduced with an outlay of ₹800 crore.

Krishi UDAN 2.0, launched in October 2021 as a six-month pilot project, aims to transport perishable food products, including horticulture, fishery, livestock, and processed products, from the Hilly Areas, North-Eastern States, and Tribal Areas. The Airports Authority of India (AAI) provides full waivers for Indian freighters and P2C aircraft at around 25 airports in North Eastern, Hilly and Tribal regions and 28 airports in other regions/areas.

India runs the most extensive legislation-based food security program in the world, covering about 80 crore people under the National Food Security Act (NFSA), 2013. The program involves procuring food grains from farmers at remunerative prices, distributing food grains to consumers, particularly the vulnerable sections of society, at affordable prices, and maintaining a food buffer stock for food security and price stability. The NFSA provides highly subsidized food grains at ₹1/2/3 per kg for coarse grains/wheat/rice, respectively. Additionally, the government has decided to provide free food grains to 81.35 crore NFSA beneficiaries for one year from January 1, 2023.

Procurement for the food security program is at MSP, and during KMS 2021-22, 581.7 LMT of Rice was procured against an estimated target of 532.7 LMT. In the current year, KMS 2022-23, a total of 355 LMT of rice had been procured up to December 31, 2022. Additionally, during Rabi Marketing Season (RMS) 2022-23, 187.9 LMT of rice was procured.

headings: Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Anna Yojana
One Nation One Ration Card Scheme
explanations: During the RMS 2021-22, 433.4 LMT of wheat was procured. However, during the following procurement season, the procurement was lower due to higher market prices than the MSP. The Government of India allocated 970.1 lakh tons of foodgrains to States/UTs under NFSA and other welfare schemes in 2022-23.

In 2022-23, the allocation of foodgrains under NFSA and other welfare schemes was 600.22 LMT for NFSA (including ICDS & PM-POSHAN), 358.83 LMT for PM GKAY allocations (VI & VII Phase), 5.53 LMT for Covid Allocation (Non-NFSA, OMSS Cost), and 5.55 LMT for Other Welfare Measures + Additional of Allocation at Economic Cost.

To ease the hardships faced by the poor due to economic disruption caused by Covid-19, the Government launched the Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Anna Yojana (PMGKAY) in April-June 2020, providing 5kg of additional food grains per person per month free of cost to NFSA beneficiaries in all phases. The scheme has been extended and implemented in various phases and has allocated about 1,118 LMT foodgrains to States/UTs.

The One Nation One Ration Card (ONORC) scheme was launched in 2019 to ease access to food. The intra-State and inter-State portability of ration cards enables migrants to access their food security entitlements from any fair price shop (FPS) of their choice by using the same ration card after biometric/Aadhaar authentication on electronic Point of Sale (e-PoS) devices at the FPS. The ONORC system is currently enabled in all 36 States/UT, covering 100% of the total NFSA population.

The food subsidy bill was higher during 2020-21 and 2021-22 due to the free food distribution programme of the government under PMGKAY. This dedicated support was provided to ensure that farmers and vulnerable households remained protected from Covid-19 led shocks.

The data presented in Figure VIII.10 shows the total food subsidy released by the government of India since 2014-15 in ₹ thousand crore. The figure has been increasing steadily over the years, with ₹529.7 crore being released in 2020-21. It is important to note that the subsidy figure includes repayment of NSSF loan of ₹40,000 crores in FY2017-18, ₹70000 crores in FY2018-19 and ₹44,164.02 crores in FY2019-20. Additionally, out of total funds released to FCI in FY2020-21, ₹462789 crores were utilised to repay the entire NSSF loan and as on 31.03.2021 NSSF loan is NIL.

The performance of the agriculture sector has immense importance in the growth and employment of India. The government has been taking various initiatives to encourage investment in the sector. The PM Kisan scheme provides income support to farmers, while strengthening of institutional finance and insurance through the PMFBY and the push given to Kisan Credit Cards as also access to machines and tools that improve productivity have been significant. With a focus on the horticulture sector and the thrust towards allied activities, farmers’ income has become more diversified and resilient to weather shocks. These initiatives have led to sustainable and inclusive development of the sector.

The development of the food processing sector can reduce wastage/ loss and increase the length of storage, ensuring better prices for the farmers. The government has introduced various initiatives like e-NAM and the Promotion of FPOs formation to strengthen the agricultural market. Attempts have been made to boost the food processing industries by introducing interventions including PMKSY , PMFME, PLI, etc. A well-developed food processing sector with improved infrastructure like cold storage and better logistics helps reduce wastage, improve value addition, ensure better farmers' returns, promote employment, and increase export earnings.

headings: Overall Contribution of Industry to Indian Economy
Challenges faced by Indian Industry in FY23
Impacts of Rising Commodity Prices on Indian Industry
Demand Stimulus to Industrial Growth in India
Challenges Faced by Indian Industry in Export Performance
Investment Demand as a Powerful Stimulus to Industrial Growth
Robust Supply Response of the Indian Industry
Uneven Growth Across Various Categories of Indian Industries
explanations: The industry holds a prominent position in the Indian economy contributing about 30 percent of total gross value added in the country.

In FY23, the Indian industry faced some extraordinary challenges as the Russian-Ukraine conflict broke out. That led to a sharp rise in the prices of many commodities. Prices of edible oil, crude oil, fertilisers and food grains rose sharply. They remained at elevated levels for several months.

Both the price and the availability of essential commodities had the potential to dent the industry’ s optimism on consolidating the recovery of FY22 and further accelerating it. However, the Indian industry acquitted itself rather well under trying circumstances. Overall Gross Value Added (GVA) by the Industrial Sector, based on data available for the first half of the FY23, rose 3.7 per cent, which is higher than the average growth of 2.8 per cent achieved in H1 of the last decade.

Robust domestic conditions since FY22 have provided a demand stimulus to industrial growth. Private Final Consumption Expenditure (PFCE) as a share of GDP in H1 of FY23 was the highest among all half years, H1 or H2, since FY15. Further, the strong export performance of FY22 continued somewhat in the first half of FY23. In this half of the year, exports of goods and services as a share of GDP have been the highest since FY16.

The performance began to wane in the first half itself as the Year-on-Year (YoY) growth of exports declined from Q1 to Q2 due to persistently high inflation and rising interest rates in the advanced economies.

The increase in investment demand has emerged as another powerful stimulus to industrial growth. It has been triggered by the augmented capex of the central government in the current and the previous year as compared to the pre-pandemic years. The leap also has crowded in private investment, already upbeat on the pent-up demand, export stimulus, and strengthening of the corporate balance sheets.

The supply response of the industry to the demand stimulus has been robust, as seen in high-frequency indicators. PMI manufacturing has remained in the expansion zone for 18 months since July 2021, and its sub-indices indicate an easing of input cost pressures, improving supplier delivery times, robust export orders, and future output.

While growth in the consumer durables component of the Index of Industrial Production (IIP) is on account of the release of ‘pent-up’ demand, the increase in capital goods and infrastructure/construction goods is indicative of the beginnings of a virtuous investment cycle that is expected to be led by the private sector. The growth of the eight core industries of coal, fertilisers, cement, electricity, steel, and refinery products has held steady, reflecting a broad momentum in industrial activity. However, the manufacturing landscape further shows uneven growth across various categories, with industries such as automobiles and INDUSTRY: STeaDY RecoveRY.

headings: India's Opportunity to become a Global Manufacturing Hub
explanations: Industrial activity in India has been supported by increased bank credit to the sector, with growth in total credit driven by MSMEs. Large industries have also increased their pace of credit off-take in recent months. This growth in credit demand combined with rising capacity utilisation indicates businesses' optimism regarding future demand.

Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in India has moderated in the first half of FY23 amidst heightened global uncertainty. However, inflows have remained significantly above pre-pandemic levels, driven by structural reforms and measures to improve the ease of doing business. India remains one of the most attractive FDI destinations in the world.

The electronics industry is rapidly growing in importance, with mobile phones, consumer electronics, and industrial electronics driving its growth. India has become the second-largest mobile phone manufacturer globally, with the production of handsets increasing significantly in recent years. Electronics is expected to enhance productivity, efficient service delivery, and social transformation.

The Indian Pharmaceuticals industry is a prominent player in the global pharmaceuticals industry, occupying a 20% share in global supply by volume. The sector is the largest provider of generic medicines globally and the leading vaccine manufacturer with a 60% market share. Despite global trade disruptions and a drop in demand for Covid-19-related treatments, the performance of pharma exports has been robust.

As companies adapt to supply chain shocks, India has a unique opportunity to become a global manufacturing hub this decade. The government's Make-in-India initiative, along with Production Linked Incentive (PLI) schemes, has facilitated investment, fostered innovation, and built world-class infrastructure. The PLI schemes are expected to generate over 60 lakh jobs and reduce net imports by building domestic manufacturing capacity.

headings: Growth and Share of Industrial components
explanations: The Indian industry holds a prominent position in the country's economy as it accounts for 31% of GDP and employs over 12.1 crore people. The sector's relevance is seen through its linkages with other sectors, contributing to economic growth and employment.

According to the First Advance Estimates for FY23, the industry sector witnessed modest growth of 4.1% compared to the strong growth of 10.3% in FY22. Manufacturing GV A has grown at an even higher rate when compared to overall GV A. The table shows growth and share of each component of the industry during FY23. Overall, the industry sector contributed 30% to the total GV A in FY23.

This chapter reviews the performance of the Indian industry in the current financial year. It explores the demand stimulants to industrial growth, the supply response of the industry, trends in credit to the industry and foreign investment in India's industrial sector. The chapter also addresses the developments in key sub-industries and their challenges. Finally, it evaluates India's aspirations and prospects of becoming a key player in global value chains.

headings: PFCE as a share of GDP
explanations: FY23 began with a month-old Russian-Ukraine conflict showing no signs of relenting.
Global commodity prices are yet to deescalate to their pre-pandemic levels throughout the year.
Industry, throughout the year, has faced high input costs imported into the country.
Fearing demand impact, the industry has been gradually passing on the higher production costs, which has led to sticky but non-rising core retail inflation.

Non-core retail inflation, on the other hand, comprising food and energy components, has been declining as local weather extremities have eased and interventions by the government to restrict price rises have proven effective.
The consequent decrease in overall retail inflation has thus sustained the pent-up consumer demand in the post-pandemic Indian economy, inducing an industrial recovery despite the global headwinds.

With world commodity prices now also on a downward trajectory and showing up in declining rates of India’s wholesale inflation, core retail inflation is expected to relent, making domestic consumption demand much stronger to further induce industrial growth in the country.
PFCE as a share of GDP in H1 of FY23 was the highest since FY15.
Strong external demand served the Indian industry well when manufactured exports soared, responding to a rebound in global growth.
Trade had also recovered and grown as bottlenecks in global supply chains eased.
Exports of goods and services as a share of GDP have been the highest since FY16.

However, the export impulse has been waning in the first half itself as the YoY growth of exports has declined from Q1 to Q2 due to persistently high inflation and rising interest rates in the advanced economies.
Indeed, an increase in investment demand has emerged as another powerful stimulus to industrial growth.
It has been triggered by a jump in the Capex of the central government in the current and the previous year as compared to the pre-pandemic years.
The leap also has crowded-in private investment, already upbeat on the pent-up consumption demand, export stimulus, and strengthening of the corporate balance sheets.
Capacity utilisation at 74.3 per cent in Q1 of FY23 has already reached the tipping point of 75.3 per cent in Q4 of FY22, at which investments in building new capacities are undertaken.

New Investment announced in the manufacturing sector during April-December of FY23 was five times the corresponding level in FY20. A beginning has been made in H1 of FY23, which recorded the highest share of Gross Fixed Capital Formation (GFCF) in GDP among all half-years since FY15.

The surge in investment is also attributable to the policy actions taken by the Government over the past several years. The strong domestic consumption growth and investment revival is expected to keep industrial production humming.

headings: Unfolding of Private Capital Investment Cycle
explanations: The graph depicted in Figure IX.1 represents the private investment in various industries in lakh crore for the first half of FY23 and FY22. The industries are Pharma, Cement, Textiles, Auto, Chemicals, Capital goods, Mining, Construction, Electricity, and Steel. The data shows that private investment is steadily recovering across all industries.

Box IX.1 talks about how private investment is on the rise again after a period of deleveraging among corporates and banks due to a credit boom in the first decade of the new millennium. The stress on balance sheets led to a decline in investment rates and an economic slowdown in the second decade. Measures were taken to mitigate these issues such as the implementation of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) for banks and the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rollout for corporates. The pandemic led to the implementation of ECLGS which further supported MSMEs in their investments. Advances in digital infrastructure have also enriched the current investment climate.

Figure a shows the deleveraging trend of the private non-financial sector from Jun-05 to Jun-22. The data, which captures the borrowing activity of the private non-financial sector, shows a decrease in core debt as a percentage of GDP from 120% in Jun-22 to 40% in Jun-05. This indicates that the private non-financial sector has been decreasing its debt over time.

The core debt of private non-financial sector in India reduced from 113.0% in December 2010 to 83.8% in December 2018 due to deleveraging. The process was delayed due to the pandemic but resumed from FY22. Interest coverage ratio was higher in H1:FY23, and debt-equity ratio also improved. These improvements absorbed the working capital requirements triggered by volatility in global commodity prices and supply chain disruptions. RBI’s Industrial Outlook Survey for the period till Q1 of FY24 shows optimism about production, order books, employment, and profit margins.

Profit margins in the private non-financial sector in India peaked in H2:FY21 due to low inflation and reduced overheads. However, subsequently started to decline due to input costs rising on the back of rising global commodity prices. With global commodity prices declining, input costs are expected to fall and thus profit margins are expected to increase. This is expected to make the corporate sector financially stronger and optimistic about increasing net sales. RBI’s Industrial Outlook Survey for the period till Q1 of FY24 supports this optimism as it points towards increased profit margins.

Net sales are expected to rise in the private non-financial sector in India as the corporate sector experiences increased profit margins due to falling input costs. Figure B shows the YoY net sales % from H2:FY18 to H1:FY23 with an expected increase in the coming years. Improved economic and investment growth cycles due to corporate tax cuts and election out of the way expected in May 2019 were delayed by the pandemic for two years, but de-leveraging resumed from FY22 and resulted in an improvement in investment and economic growth cycles.

The private non-financial sector in India saw a decline in the debt-equity ratio from 0.8 to 0.4 and a higher interest coverage ratio in H1:FY23 compared to its five-year average in FY20. These improvements are seen as further absorbers of the increased working capital requirements triggered by volatility in global commodity prices and supply chain disruptions.

The credit boom in the first decade increased the banking sector advances to the non-financial sector from 36.5 per cent of GDP in 2004 to 57.3 per cent in 2014, which led to more stringent assessment of NPAs.

NPA rose from 4.3 per cent of gross bank advances in FY15 to 11.2 per cent in FY18. However, with the enforcement of the IBC code and a more disciplined approach to credit disbursements, NPA fell to 7.3 per cent in FY21 and to a seven-year low of 5.0 per cent in September 2022.
The Capital-to-Risk-Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) has also improved and stood at 16.0 per cent in September 2022.
The supply response of the industry to the demand stimulus has been robust, as seen in high-frequency indicators.
The PMI-Manufacturing has remained in the expansionary zone for 18 months since July 2021.
The moderation in input cost inflation has also led to an easing in the momentum of output prices.
The pace of expansion in new export orders decreased, reflecting a subdued global demand.
Sustained growth of manufacturing output is seen within the overall IIP producing consumer durables in sync with the pent-up consumption demand.
PMI Manufacturing has remained in the expansionary zone, as can be seen in Figure IX.2, indicating growth in the manufacturing sector.

The sub-indices of IIP (Index of Industrial Production) have grown at a healthy pace from April-November, as shown in Figure IX.3. These sub-indices include manufacturing, capital goods, infrastructure/construction goods, and consumer durables.

The eight core industries of coal, fertilisers, cement, steel, electricity, refinery products, crude oil, and natural gas are critical in meeting the demand for inputs across industries. Their steady growth, as seen in Figure IX.4, reflects a broad momentum in industrial activity. The growth underscores the importance that nations have been attaching to the indigenous presence of core capacities in the aftermath of the pandemic and the Russia-Ukraine conflict breaking down the global supply chain.

Growth in industrial output would have been higher, but for some constraints it faced in the first half of FY23. These included seasonality which contributed to constraining the growth of production in respect of mining and quarrying, and construction. Further, as higher rainfall cooled temperatures, electricity demand fell, and hence output rose by less than 5 per cent in Q2 of FY23 over Q2 of FY22.

headings: Manufacturing of Computer, Electronic and Optical Products
explanations: The graph in Figure IX.5 shows the real Gross Value Added (GVA) of construction industry over time, as a proxy for construction output.
