The data suggests that the construction industry has been recovering steadily, despite being constrained by higher than usual rainfall. The graph also shows the actual rainfall in millimeters. The data is sourced from the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI).

The graph in Figure IX.6 shows the real Gross Value Added (GVA) of manufacturing industry over time, as a proxy for manufacturing output. The data suggests that the growth of manufacturing output has been restrained in Q2 of FY23 due to a large build-up in inventory, which was more than 1.3% of the annual GDP for five consecutive quarters. The graph also shows the change in stocks of Gross Fixed Capital Formation (GFCF) on the right-hand side. The use of stock to support demand and moderation in stocking and manufacturing amid uncertain external demand outlook, as well as restocking supported by increased manufacturing, have played important roles. The data is sourced from MoSPI.

The motor vehicles manufacturing segment has shown improvement in performance due to robust demand and an easing of chip shortage. The data implies that this segment is growing at a healthy pace. No specific data source mentioned.

The manufacturing of computer, electronic and optical products, which is an upcoming industry, has been on the rise. Multiple players are looking to make India a manufacturing hub of semiconductors, which is driving investment in this space. The data implies that this segment is also growing at a healthy pace. No specific data source mentioned.

The manufacturing sector has shown positive growth, with the production of coke and refined petroleum products contributing significantly to the increase in global market demand. Chemicals, caustic soda, soda ash, fertilizers and petroleum products have also performed well in sustaining growth momentum in the agriculture sector, while contributing to increased exports. However, certain product categories, such as textiles, apparel and leather, have been showing tepid growth, with slowing global output and demand affecting exports. Pharmaceutical output growth has also been affected due to an unfavorable base effect and the waning of the pandemic.

The table presents the percentage growth of various manufacturing sectors, classified into three categories: <0, >0 but <5, and >5. The sectors with the highest weights, such as coke and refined petroleum products, basic metals, and chemicals and chemical products, have shown growth rates within the range of 6.2% to 18.1%. Sectors such as textiles, wearing apparel, and leather and related products have negative growth rates, while some sectors, such as food products, beverages, and machinery and equipment N.E.C., have shown growth rates exceeding 5%.

The food products sector has shown positive growth, with an increased growth rate in April-May 2022, followed by a decline in June 2022. Beverages, on the other hand, have shown a consistently high growth rate, exceeding 29% in April 2022. These two sectors have contributed to the sustained growth momentum in the agriculture sector.

The sectors of textiles, apparel and leather have shown tepid growth due to mellowing export demand, as slowing global output and demand have affected exports. Textiles and apparel had a negative growth rate for most of 2022, with the highest negative rate of -21.6% in November 2022. Leather and related products had a mostly positive growth rate except for September and November 2022, with the highest growth rate of 47.5% in May 2022.

Pharmaceutical output growth has slowed down in the fiscal year 2022-23, due to factors such as an unfavorable base effect and the waning of the pandemic. The sector had a negative growth rate for most of 2022, with the highest negative rate of -21.2% in November 2022. The sector showed a positive growth rate of 10% in November 2022.

The sector of machinery and equipment N.E.C. has shown consistently positive growth rates, with the lowest positive growth rate of 2.9% in September 2022 and the highest growth rate of 38.8% in May 2022. The sector has contributed significantly to the growth of the manufacturing industry.

headings: Growth in Bank Credit to Industry
explanations: The data showcases a steady recovery in the industrial sector. The weights are given for the months starting from April 2022 to November 2022 for industries like Other Transport Equipment, Furniture, and Other Manufacturing. The source of data is MoSPI.

The data highlights the robust growth in bank credit to the industry, with sequential surge noticeable since January 2022. The credit growth pace is keeping up with industrial growth. Large industries still receive a major share of bank credit, but credit to MSMEs has also increased after the introduction of ECLGS that supports around 1.2 crore businesses, of which 95% are MSMEs. The data reveals that the impact of ECLGS was most visible during the pandemic affected times of 2020 and 2021. Credit growth to MSMEs continued in 2022, as the scheme was extended till March 2023. Consumption levels have also contributed to the growth in credit to MSMEs. This has resulted in the share of MSMEs in gross credit offtake to the industry increasing from 17.7% in Jan 2020 to 23.7% in Nov 2022. Figure IX.7 shows the double-digit credit growth in industries driven by MSMEs. The source of data is RBI.

As per the National Credit Guarantee Trustee Company Ltd. (NCGTCL), the agency which operates the ECLGS, the scheme had a significant impact on increasing the growth of credit to MSMEs during the pandemic affected years of 2020 and 2021. With the growth in total credit driven by increasing credit demanded by MSMEs, large industries have now also started to increase the pace of their credit offtake since the beginning of FY23. The source of data is RBI.

headings: Resilient FDI Inflow in Manufacturing Sector
explanations: Table IX.3 displays the YoY growth in credit deployed in various industry subsegments as of November 2021, April 2022, and November 2022. The data reveals that except for the textile industry, all segments within the manufacturing sector witnessed growth in credit offtake in November 2022. Some of the industry subsegments with the highest growth in credit were 'Petroleum, coal products and nuclear fuels', 'Rubber, plastic and their products', and 'Engineering'. The improved outlook of the cement and construction sectors led to an increase in the growth of credit to these segments over the past year.

FDI equity inflows in the manufacturing sector have been steadily increasing over the last few years, and the trend continued in FY22 despite the pandemic-driven economic downturn. The data indicates that FDI inflows in the manufacturing sector jumped to US$ 21.3 billion in FY22 from US$ 12.1 billion in FY21. The increase in FDI inflow can be attributed to the expansionary policies of advanced economies, which in turn led to a surge in global investments.

headings: FDI Inflow in Manufacturing in India
Steady Recovery of the Indian Industry
explanations: In the first half of FY23, FDI equity inflow in manufacturing in India fell below its corresponding level in the first half of FY22 due to global uncertainty and monetary tightening. However, a rebound in FDI inflows is expected as India sustains its high growth and inflationary pressures ease. According to DPIIT data, the sector-wise FDI equity inflows during April-September 2022 were: Services (22%), Computer Software & Hardware (34%), Telecommunications (4%), Trading (18%), Automobile (5%), Construction (Infra) Activities (5%), Chemicals (Other Than Fertiliser) (7%), Drugs & Pharma.(4%), and Others (1%).

India has implemented an investor-friendly FDI policy, which permits up to 100% FDI through automatic route in most sectors. The country continues to open up its sectors to global investors by raising FDI limits, removing regulatory barriers, developing infrastructure, and improving the business environment. In FY20, several radical and transformative FDI reforms were implemented across sectors such as Defence, Pension, e-commerce activities, etc. For instance, 100% FDI under automatic route was permitted for the sale of coal and coal mining activities, including associated processing infrastructure, subject to provisions of relevant acts. Also, 26% FDI under the government route was permitted for uploading/streaming of News & Current Affairs through Digital Media, and 100% FDI was permitted in Intermediaries or Insurance Intermediaries, including insurance brokers, reinsurance brokers, insurance consultants, corporate agents, third-party administrators, Surveyors and Loss Assessors, and such other entities as may be notified by the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority from time to time.

Despite an overall drop in FDI in the first half of FY23, inflows have stayed above the pre-pandemic levels in India, driven by structural reforms and measures improving the ease of doing business. India is one of the most attractive FDI destinations in the world, and the government is making continuous efforts to bolster investment by opening up its sectors to global investors, raising FDI limits, removing regulatory barriers, developing infrastructure, and improving the business environment.

To prevent opportunistic takeovers/acquisitions of Indian companies due to Covid-19 pandemic, the Indian government amended the FDI policy. Now, entities of countries sharing a land border with India or citizens/beneficial owners of investments from such countries can invest in India only under the Government route. Additionally, if the beneficial ownership of an existing or future FDI falls under the restriction of this policy amendment, any subsequent change in beneficial ownership will require government approval.

To promote ease of doing business and simplify the approval process for Foreign Investment in India, the Foreign Investment Promotion Board was abolished in May 2017. The processing of FDI applications has been delegated to concerned Ministries/Departments and the DPIIT governs the process. A revamped portal, the Foreign Investment Facilitation Portal (FIF Portal) has been launched as a single-window interface for investors to facilitate Foreign Direct Investment. The FIF portal is integrated with the National Single Window System (NSWS).

While the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) sector's contribution to overall Gross Value Added (GVA) increased from 29.3% to 30.5% between FY18 to FY20, the pandemic caused the sector's share to decrease to 26.8% in FY21. Similarly, its contribution to the manufacturing sector's GVA marginally fell to 36.0% in FY21. However, the sector has shown a smart recovery post-pandemic.

The government has taken multiple steps to cushion the economic impact of the pandemic on MSMEs through the AatmaNirbhar Bharat Package. Measures include the modification of the definition of MSMEs, the provision of ₹20,000 crore subordinate debt for stressed MSMEs, ₹50,000 crore equity infusion through Self Reliant India fund, waiving the global tender requirement for procurement of up to ₹200 crore, launching the Udyam portal for MSME registration, and more.

The Udyam portal is a paperless, zero-cost registration portal for MSMEs that is based on self-declaration and only requires Aadhaar. As of 7th January 2022, the portal has a total registration count of 1.32 crore, of which 1.27 crore have been classified as micro-enterprises. Enterprises registered on the portal employ 9.6 crore people, of which 2.3 crore are women. There are 1.5 lakh exporting units, which have contributed a cumulative ₹9.7 lakh crore worth of exports.

The Samadhaan Portal, set up under the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development (MSMED) Act to monitor the outstanding dues to the MSME sector, is helping MSMEs in resolving their cashflow difficulties. As of 7th January 2022, the portal has received a total of 1.3 lakh applications, of which 16.8% have been disposed while 25.0% are currently under consideration, and 25.1% have been rejected. The government has instructed Central Public Sector Enterprises (CPSEs) and all companies with a turnover of ₹200 crore or more to get themselves onboarded on the Trade Receivables Discounting System (TReDS) platform for facilitating the discounting of trade receivables of MSMEs through multiple financiers.

CHAMPIONS is a single-window grievance redressal portal for MSMEs launched by the Ministry of MSME in June 2020. As of 16th January 2023, the portal has received 56,825 grievances and responded to 55,878 of them. The portal continues to be improved through initiatives such as the localisation of the portal in 11 regional languages and the introduction of a Chatbot.

The government has initiated the ‘Raising and Accelerating MSME Performance’ scheme (RAMP) in FY23. The World Bank-supported scheme aims at strengthening institutions and governance at the Centre and State, improving Centre-State linkages and partnerships, improving access of MSMEs to market and credit, technology upgradation, and addressing issues of delayed payments and greening of MSMEs. The RAMP programme will be implemented over a period of five years. The total outlay for the scheme is ₹6,062.4 crore, out of which ₹3750 crore would be a loan from the World Bank, and the Government of India would fund the remaining ₹2312.4 crore.

Data from the National Credit Guarantee Trustee Corporation (NCGTC) shows that as of 30th November 2022, 1.2 crore MSME units availed the ECLGS scheme and raised collateral-free resources to the tune of ₹3.6 lakh crore. A recent CIBIL report showed that 83% of the borrowers who availed of the ECLGS were micro-enterprises, and more than half of these borrowers had an exposure of less than ₹10 lakh. The NPA rate in banks for the category of MSME borrowers who availed of ECLGS was lower than the category that did not avail of the scheme. The recovery of the MSME sector from the pandemic-induced shock is evident.

headings: Asset quality of ECLGS aided MSMEs
explanations: The GST paid by MSME sector in FY22 has surpassed the pre-pandemic level in FY20, as shown in Figure IX.10. The data shows that the total GST paid by Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) has increased from 4.6% in FY19 to 6.6% in FY22. This indicates an increase in business activity and growth in the sector.

Figure IX.11 shows the improvement in asset quality of MSMEs since the introduction of Emergency Credit Line Guarantee Scheme (ECLGS). The data shows that MSMEs that availed of ECLGS have better asset quality as compared to those who were eligible but did not avail. The NPA rate for ECLGS availed MSMEs is 5.5% as compared to 6.0% for those who were eligible but did not avail. This indicates that ECLGS has been successful in improving the financial health of MSMEs.

The electronics industry in India is rapidly growing, supported by continuously improving communication services, and is expected to contribute significantly to productivity, efficient service delivery, and social transformation. As of FY20, the domestic electronics industry in India is valued at US$118 billion, and India aims to reach US$300 billion worth of electronics manufacturing and US$120 billion in exports by FY26. The data shows that electronic goods were among the top five commodity groups exhibiting positive export growth in November 2022, with exports growing YoY by 55.1%. The major drivers of growth in the industry are mobile phones, consumer electronics, and industrial electronics. India has become the second-largest mobile phone manufacturer globally, and the production of mobile handsets is expected to increase further as more domestic and global players set up and expand their bases in India.

Domestic and global players have already embraced the Production Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme for electronics manufacturing in India, which is further expected to boost the growth of the electronics industry. The PLI scheme aims to provide incentives to companies for manufacturing in India and promoting domestic value addition, thereby making India a global manufacturing hub for electronics. Participation in the PLI scheme is expected to increase further in the coming years, contributing to the growth of the electronics industry in India.

headings: Incentives for Electronics Manufacturing in India
explanations: The industrial electronics sector is seeing growth due to improved digitisation and robotics applications in Industry 4.0. The impetus on Smart Cities and the Internet of Things (IoT) will further enhance the demand for smart and automated electronics.

The Indian Government has provided various schemes and initiatives to boost India's manufacturing capacity, reduce import dependence, and contribute to becoming a major player in global supply chains. Some of them include the PLI scheme for Large Scale Electronics Manufacturing, PLI scheme for IT hardware, and the Scheme for Promotion of Manufacturing of Electronic Components and Semiconductors (SPECS).

The global economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic exposed the frailties in the supply chains of many goods and services, including semiconductors. Countries are now diversifying their semiconductor supply chain. India has approved the comprehensive development of a sustainable semiconductor and display ecosystem in the country with an outlay of ₹76,000 crore under the Programme for Development of Semiconductors and Display Manufacturing Ecosystem in India.

The PLI scheme will help domestic players attain economies of scale in production through localization, further enhancing export competitiveness and increasing India's participation in the global value chain.
The graph shows the growth in electronics exports from FY18 to FY23 (Apr-Nov) in US$ Billion, sourced from DGCI&S.

headings: United States' CHIPS and Science Act, 2022
Incentives Breakdown under CHIPS and Science Act, 2022
explanations: The United States' CHIPS and Science Act, 2022 is a policy that aims to boost domestic semiconductor manufacturing capacity. The legislation directs $280 billion in spending over the next ten years, with the majority of it going towards Research and Development (R&D). The US produces only 10% of the world's semiconductors and heavily relies on importing chips from East Asia. This legislation is an effort to reduce the country's reliance on imports and to become more self-sufficient.

To become more self-reliant and integrate itself into the global value chain, India has announced a comprehensive program to attract investment for developing a semiconductor manufacturing ecosystem. The program has an outlay of INR 76,000 crore (approximately US$ 10 billion), and the government will provide financial support for 50% of the capital expenditure incurred by the investing firms. This program includes various scheme offerings such as financial support for setting up semiconductor fabs, display fabs, compound semiconductors/silicon photonics/sensors fabs, and semiconductor ATMP/OSAT facilities. These schemes will receive support for up to 2.5% of the program outlay, with 50% of the firm's Capex being provided by the government.

The CHIPS and Science Act, 2022 directs $280 billion in spending over the next ten years, distributed as follows: 71% for Research and Development (R&D), 19% for manufacturing, 9% for tax credits, and 1% for leading-edge tech and wireless supply chains.

India possesses 20% of the world's semiconductor design engineers but only a small share of the intellectual property (IP). The Government of India has announced a Design Linked-Incentive (DLI) scheme to help domestic semiconductor design companies by providing financial support of 50% of eligible expenditure on design, subject to a ceiling of ₹15 crore per applicant and a deployment-linked incentive of 4% to 6% of net sales achieved over five years, subject to a ceiling of ₹30 crore per applicant. This has attracted global and domestic players with Israel-based International Semiconductor Consortium expressing interest in investing ₹ 22,900 crore in Karnataka to set up India's first chip-making plant and domestic players like Vedanta and Tata indicating plans to establish semiconductor fabs in the country.

India's largely thermal-based power generation plants faced coal availability challenges due to a resurgence in economic activity, intense heat waves, and a decline in coal imports. The government of India undertook measures to address supply constraints, such as asking generators to import coal to the extent of 10% of their requirements, invoking Section 11 of the Electricity Act 2003 to direct imported coal-based plants to run at full capacity, enabling tolling to transfer allotted coal to private generators near the mines, and advising REC/PFC and commercial banks to facilitate the availability of additional working capital to power generating plants.

India's coal production in FY23 is estimated to increase to 911 million tonnes, about 17 per cent higher compared to the previous year. In April-December, 2022, coal production rose by 14 per cent on a YoY basis and was 21 per cent higher than the pre-pandemic of FY20. Production primarily comes from Coal India Limited (CIL), Singareni Collieries Company Ltd (SCCL) and Captives/Others. Different measures have been initiated towards achieving self-reliance in coal production, including private participation in coal production, FDI under the automatic route, auctioning of coal blocks for commercial production, expansion of existing mines and opening of new mines, greater use of mass production technology in mining, mechanisation of loading, and development of evacuation infrastructure. The coal industry is expected to grow at 6-7 percent annually to reach a production level of 1 billion tonnes by FY26 and about 1.5 billion tonnes by 2030. The enhanced domestic coal production is expected to meet domestic coal demand, replace substitutable imports, and escalate exports. The coal stock at power plants improved to 12 days as of 30 December 2022 compared to 10 days on 30 June 2022 and 8 days a year ago.

The Steel sector plays a crucial role in crucial sectors such as construction, infrastructure, automobile, engineering and defence. India is currently the second largest crude steel producer in the world, and the steel sector's performance in the current fiscal year has been robust, with cumulative production and consumption of finished steel at 88 MT and 86 MT, respectively, during April-December 2022, higher than the corresponding period during the previous four years. The reinvigoration of infrastructure sector and construction activity is expected to drive growth in the steel industry.

The figure IX.13 shows adequate coal production in India in FY23 while figure IX.14 shows the improvement in coal stock. In FY20, the production was around 30,405 thousand tonnes while it increased to 40,481 thousand tonnes in FY22 and is estimated to increase to 48,121 thousand tonnes in FY23. The monthly production varies, with a peak during the winter months (Jan-Feb) and monsoon season (Jun-Sep).

The finished steel production is growing due to the increased government Capex in the infrastructure sector. There has been double-digit growth in steel consumption (11 percent YoY), and 67 applications from 30 companies have been selected under the PLI scheme for speciality steel. This will increase the capacity by 26 million tons with an investment of ₹42,500 crore and generate employment for 70,000 people. Despite moderating exports due to global slowdown and export duty levied to enhance domestic availability, iron and steel exports still increased by 20 percent over the corresponding pre-pandemic levels of FY20.

The future of the steel industry seems promising due to government support towards infrastructure projects, pick-up in construction and real estate activity, and healthy demand from the automobile sector. However, export demand may remain subdued due to the global slowdown.

The textile industry is facing the challenge of moderating exports compared to FY22. However, the levels in the eight six months still prevail, which is 9.5 percent higher than the corresponding pre-pandemic level of FY20. Additionally, FDI inflows into the textile sector are yet to recover to pre-pandemic levels.

The textile industry is a significant source of employment generation with an estimated 4.5 crore people directly engaged in this sector, including a large number of women and the rural population. The government has extended support to help the textile industry weather current challenges.

The Indian textile industry is a vital sector for not just the country's economy but also for employment generation. The Economic Survey of 2022-23 states that India's textile industry saw an uptick in Readymade Garment exports, while exports of Textiles moderated. However, FDI equity inflows in Textile are yet to recover. To further boost the Textile industry, the government has approved the setting up of seven PM Mega Integrated Textile Region and Apparel (PM MITRA) Parks to develop integrated large-scale and modern industrial infrastructure facilities. The Textile PLI Scheme was also launched with an approved outlay of ₹10,683 crore over five years to promote investments and increase the production of Man-Made Fibre (MMF) Apparel, MMF Fabrics, and Products of Technical Textiles. This will enable the textile sector to achieve size and scale, enhancing export competitiveness. Additionally, the parks are expected to create a total of one lakh direct and two lakh indirect employment.

The Indian Pharmaceuticals industry plays a significant role in the global pharmaceuticals industry. The sector has sustained its growth momentum even after the pandemic. The domestic pharmaceutical market in India was estimated at US$ 41 billion in 2021 and is likely to grow to US$ 65 billion by 2024 and is further expected to reach US$ 130 billion by 2030. India is ranked 3rd worldwide in the production of pharma products by volume and 14th by value. The sector is the largest provider of generic medicines globally, with a 20% share in global supply by volume, and is the leading vaccine manufacturer globally with a market share of 60%.

Indian pharmaceutical exports achieved a healthy growth of 24 per cent in FY21, driven by Covid-19-induced demand for critical drugs and other supplies made to over 150 countries. The performance of pharma exports in FY22 has been robust, sustaining growth despite the global trade disruptions and drop in demand for Covid-19-related treatments. Carrying forward this growth momentum, drug and pharmaceutical exports during April-October 2022 was 22 per cent higher than the corresponding pre-pandemic period of FY20.

Cumulative FDI in the pharma sector crossed the US$ 20 billion mark in September 2022. Further, FDI inflows have increased four-fold over five years until September 2022, to US$ 699 million, supported by investor-friendly policies and a positive outlook for the industry.

Three PLI Schemes have been introduced to boost manufacturing capacity in the pharmaceutical sector. These schemes include critical KSMs/DIs/APIs, Medical Devices and Pharmaceuticals. The schemes have different tenures and outlays and each has seen progress with approved applicants, committed investments, employment generation and financial incentives.

This is a part of the PLI Schemes in the Pharmaceutical sector with a tenure from FY21 to FY30 and an outlay of ₹6,940 crore. Until December 2022, 51 applicants approved with committed investment of ₹4,138.4 crore. Estimated employment generation from 51 projects is 10,598 persons. There is no financial incentive for this scheme.

This is a part of the PLI Schemes in the Pharmaceutical sector with a tenure from FY21 to FY28 and an outlay of ₹3,420 crore. Until December 2022, 21 applicants approved with committed investment of Rs 1,058.97 crore. Estimated employment generation from 21 projects is around 6,411 persons. The financial incentive is a rate of 5 per cent on incremental sales of medical devices for 5 years.

This is a part of the PLI Schemes in the Pharmaceutical sector with a tenure from FY21 to FY29 and an outlay of ₹15,000 crore. Until June 2022, 55 applicants approved with actual investment of Rs 18,669 crore. Estimated employment generation from 55 projects is 20,000 direct and 80,000 indirect jobs. The financial incentive is on incremental sales under various categories at varying rate over the years ranging from 10 per cent to 3 per cent.
DGCI&S and DPIIT are the sources for figures Ix.19 and Ix.20 respectively. The Department of Pharmaceuticals is the source for the PLI Schemes.

The SPI scheme was launched with a total financial outlay of ₹500 crore for five years from FY22 to FY26. It aims to strengthen the existing infrastructure facilities of the pharma sector by providing financial assistance to pharma clusters to create common facilities. It also upgrades the production facilities of MSMEs to meet national and international regulatory standards by providing interest subvention or capital subsidy on their capital loans. Additionally, it promotes knowledge and awareness about the pharmaceutical and medical devices industry by undertaking studies, building databases, and bringing industry leaders, academia, and policymakers together to share their knowledge and experience.

India's automotive sector is a key driver of its economic growth. In December 2022, India became the world's third-largest automobile market, surpassing Japan and Germany in terms of sales. In 2021, India was the largest manufacturer of two-wheeler and three-wheeler vehicles and the world's fourth-largest manufacturer of passenger cars. The sector contributes 7.1% to the overall GDP and 49% to the manufacturing GDP while generating direct and indirect employment of 3.7 crore at the end of 2021.

The domestic electric vehicles (EV) market is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 49% between 2022 and 2030 and is expected to hit one crore units annual sales by 2030. The EV industry will create 5 crore direct and indirect jobs by 2030. To support and nurture this development, the government has undertaken multiple steps.
The industry is experiencing a steady recovery.
Sales of auto components are on the rise according to Figure IX.24.
OEM stands for Original Equipment Manufacture, and according to the Ministry of Heavy Industries: 'exports' and 'turnover' data for FY20, FY21, and FY22 are available.
The 'aftermarket' refers to the market for spare parts, accessories, and components for motor vehicles.

The Ministry of Heavy Industries offers consumption enhancing incentive schemes to incentivize purchases of electric vehicles. There are two phases: 1) Tenure: 2014-19, Budget allocation: ₹895 crore, Achievements include 2.8 lakh Hybrid/EV support, 425 E-buses across 10 cities, and 479 EV charging stations installed. 2) Tenure: 2019-24, Budget Outlay: ₹10,000 crore, Envisaged to support 1 million 2 Wheeler, 0.5 million 3 Wheeler, 55,000 cars and 7090 buses, Incentivised 7.1 lakh EVs, and sanctioned 7210 e-buses, 2172 e-buses deployed until Dec 2022, and 2,877 charging stations in 68 cities and 1,576 charging stations across expressways/highways.

headings: Production Linked Incentive Schemes for Advanced Chemistry Cell
Production Linked Incentive Schemes for Auto and Auto-component
India's Potential as a Global Manufacturing Hub
Make in India 2.0 and the PLI schemes
explanations: The Advanced Chemistry Cell Production Linked Incentive Scheme is a scheme with a tenure spanning FY23-FY27 and an outlay of ₹18,000 crore. Three applicants have been approved, and an investment of ₹27,000 crore is expected, leading to an employment generation projection of 2.7 lakh. The scheme aims to reduce the price of batteries and expedite the adoption of electric vehicles, resulting in a net savings of ₹2.0-2.5 lakh crore on oil import bills over the next five years.

The Production Linked Incentive Scheme for Auto and Auto-component is a scheme with a tenure spanning FY23-FY27 and an outlay of ₹26,000 crore. Eighty-five applicants have been approved, and an investment of ₹67,690 crore is expected, leading to an employment generation projection of 7.5 lakh. This scheme is aimed towards supporting the manufacturing of automobiles and their components in India.

The automotive industry faces near-term hurdles such as higher borrowing costs and tempering global demand. Additionally, there are structural issues, with the increase in long-term third-party vehicle insurance premiums leading to a total upfront insurance cost increase of about 10-11 percent. This factor affects the two-wheeler segment the most and has resulted in the segment's lowest sales in ten years. Addressing these challenges is crucial for boosting the automobile industry.

India has a distinct opportunity to become a global manufacturing hub in this decade due to a potential for significant domestic demand, a government drive towards manufacturing, and a young workforce. The manufacturing sector is shifting towards more automated and process-driven manufacturing, increasing efficiency and production. The 'Make-in-India' initiative launched in 2014 has facilitated investment and built world-class infrastructure to achieve this goal.

To further integrate India into the global value chain, 'Make in India 2.0' has been launched, alongside Production Linked Incentive Schemes. These schemes aim towards encouraging manufacturing and removing impediments in the manufacturing sector, furthering India's integration into the global value chain.

Make in India 2.0 is a program of the Indian government aimed at promoting domestic manufacturing and export of goods. It focuses on 24 sub-sectors in the manufacturing and service sectors in India, with the aim of increasing employability and boosting growth in a holistic and coordinated manner. These sub-sectors have been chosen while keeping in mind the Indian industries’ strengths and competitive edge, the need for import substitution, and the potential for export.

The Production Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme is a government initiative with a vision to achieve Aatmanirbharta or self-reliance of India. It aims to attract a capex of approximately ₹3 lakh crore over the next five years, generate employment for over 60 lakh people in India, and increase the share of the manufacturing sector in total capital formation. The scheme is spread across 14 sectors that currently constitute around 40 percent of the total imports in India. The scheme aims to make Indian manufacturers globally competitive, attract investment in the areas of core competency and cutting-edge technology, and create economies of scale.

The PLI Scheme can benefit the MSME ecosystem in the country. The anchor units built in every sector will require a new supplier base in the entire value chain. Most of these ancillary units will be built in the MSME sector. The scheme can enhance India’s annual manufacturing capex by 15 to 20 percent from FY23. It can make India an integral part of the global value chain and ensure efficiencies, create economies of scale, and reduce the trade deficit with domestic production substituting for imports.

The PLI programme has reported the generation of around 3 lakh and 106 per cent achievement of actual investment reported versus the corresponding projections of FY227. Key sectors such as Large-Scale Electronics Manufacturing, Pharmaceuticals, Telecom & Networking Products, Food Processing and White Goods have contributed considerably to investment, production, sales and employment. Some of the latest developments under the PLI programme include the launch of a design-led PLI in June 2022 to promote the entire value chain in telecom manufacturing and to build a strong ecosystem for 5G as part of the PLI Scheme for Telecom & Networking products. Approvals under this Scheme have already been granted to eligible companies. In September 2022, the Cabinet recently approved PLI Scheme (Tranche II) on ‘National Programme on High-Efficiency Solar PV Modules’, with an outlay of ₹19,500 crore to build an ecosystem for manufacturing of high-efficiency solar PV modules in India, thus reducing import dependence in the area of renewable energy.

The Shipbuilding industry is a strategically important industry due to its role in energy security, national defence and the development of the heavy engineering industry. With its immense direct and indirect linkages with most other leading industries, such as steel, aluminum, electrical machinery and equipment etc., and its huge dependence on infrastructure and services sectors of the economy, the shipbuilding industry has the potential to strengthen the mission of an ‘Aatmanirbhar’ Bharat. The Indian Navy (IN) shipbuilding projects currently in progress at various Indian shipyards are poised to provide the requisite impetus to the industry. With the objective to achieve strategic independence in shipbuilding and development of niche technology, as of date, more than 130 IN warships have been constructed at Indian shipyards, and presently, 41 of 43 ships and submarines are being constructed at various public and private sector Indian shipyards. These initiatives, through various channels, are contributing to economic growth and employment in the country.

Shipbuilding has links to other ancillary industries, including steel, engineering equipment, port infrastructure, trade and shipping services, and has the potential to create a collaborative production eco-system. With the development of these ancillary industries, the sector generates opportunities for smaller businesses and strengthens supply chain networks. It is noteworthy that a significant proportion of value addition, approximately 65 per cent, in the construction of a ship is derived from manufacturers of shipboard materials, equipment, and systems.

Shipbuilding has one of the highest employment multipliers of 6.4, capable of generating mass employment in remote, coastal and rural areas. Based on International shipbuilding statistics, an injection of approximately ₹1.5 lakh crore in naval shipbuilding projects would accrue a circulation of ₹2.73 lakh crore in the shipbuilding sector due to the multiplier effect.

The Indian Navy's Indigenisation initiatives have led to a significant infusion of economic activity and creation of employment opportunities for MSMEs, ancillary industries and shipyard employees. Indigenous shipbuilding industry can reduce freight bills and forex outgo, thereby reducing the current account deficit.

The government has taken several measures for fostering innovation including incubation, handholding, funding, industry-academia partnership and mentorship. India has witnessed a 46% growth in domestic filing of patents over 2016-2021, and has entered the top 40 innovating countries for the first time in 2022, becoming the most innovative nation in the lower middle-income group while overtaking Vietnam (48th) and leading the Central and Southern Asia region.

India ranks among the largest start-up ecosystems in the world, with over 9 lakh+ direct jobs created by DPIIT recognised start-ups. Start-ups from Tier II and III cities demonstrate tremendous potential, accounting for 48% of all Indian start-ups. The Indian government has targeted initiatives in place for the development of start-ups, including the umbrella schemes of the National Initiative for Developing and Harnessing Innovations and Atal Innovation Mission, Fund of Funds for Start-ups and Credit Guarantee.

The government of India offers support to start-ups through schemes such as the CGSS, MSH, and TIDe 2.0. These schemes provide funding, credit, and R&D platforms for technology sectors. Start-up India also facilitates engagement with global peers through partnerships, international forums, and hosting of events. The SIP-eIT scheme encourages international patent filing by Indian MSMEs and start-ups.
DPIIT Recognised Start-ups have created a total of thousands of jobs reported as of 17th January 2023. The data shows the number of jobs created in 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, and 2022.

Despite external support from the government, start-ups face several challenges such as funding, revenue generation struggles, lack of easy access to supportive infrastructure, and navigating the regulatory environment and tax structures. The 'flipping' phenomenon has also been observed, where Indian companies get headquartered overseas due to favourable legal environments, taxation policies, investor preferences, and other reasons.

'Flipping' is the process of transferring the entire ownership of an Indian company to an overseas entity, accompanied by a transfer of all IP and data. This effectively transforms an Indian company into a 100 per cent subsidiary of a foreign entity. 'Flipping' typically occurs at the early stage of start-ups and is driven by commercial, taxation and personal preferences of founders and investors. Factors such as market location, access to incubators, domicile preferences, and access to capital markets influence 'flipping.' Holding company jurisdictions like Singapore offer better protection and enforcement of IP, tax treatment of licensing revenue from IP, residential status of founders, and agile corporate structures.

The Production Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme extends an incentive of 4-6% on incremental sales for manufacturing companies and start-ups. The scheme covers pharmaceuticals, telecom, automobiles, and other sectors. This scheme is expected to boost domestic manufacturing, reduce import dependence, and create employment opportunities in these sectors.

headings: Dividend Repatriation in UAE and European Jurisdictions
explanations: Dividend repatriation through no withholding taxes in UAE and participation exemptions in European jurisdictions incentivise companies to store IPs and create holding companies.
Migration of existing structures to India triggers capital gains tax which slows down flipping. India currently does not provide participation exemptions on dividends and capital gains.

To accelerate reverse flipping in India, measures such as simplifying IMB certification process for startups, simplifying taxation of ESOPs, simplifying multiple layers of tax and uncertainty due to tax litigation, simplifying procedures for capital flows, facilitating collaboration and partnerships, and exploring incubation and funding landscape for startups are possible.

The flipping phenomenon reflects start-ups venturing out for short-term gains in the dynamic, uncertain geopolitical world. Collective action by government related regulatory bodies and other stakeholders can reverse the flip.
With solution-oriented strategies, such as those mentioned above, start-ups will continue to be the messengers of India’s entrepreneurial dynamism.

headings: Ease of Doing Business in India
Decriminalization of Provision Relating to Technical or Procedural Defaults
Self-Reliance in Semiconductor Technology and Production
explanations: The Make in India initiative has been successful in implementing various reforms that have enhanced the ease of doing business in India. Burdensome compliances have been reduced through simplification, digitization, and other measures. The Business Reform Action Plan (BRAP) 2020 shows that 7,496 reforms were implemented across States and UTs. Reduction of compliance burden (RCB) is a continuous exercise towards governance excellence aimed at improving the Ease of Living.

As of 17th January 2023, Ministries and States/UTs have decriminalized more than 3,500 provisions related to minor technical or procedural defaults. The details of the same have been uploaded to the DPIIT's Regulatory Compliance Portal, helping to significantly reduce the compliance burden on businesses and citizens.

The NSWS was soft-launched in September 2021 with the objective of improving the ease of doing business in India. It provides a single digital platform to investors for approvals and clearances and has already facilitated over 81,000 approvals as of 10th January 2023. The portal has integrated multiple existing clearance systems of various Ministries/Departments of the Government of India and State Governments to enhance investor experience.

Industry 4.0 or the fourth industrial revolution, which integrates new technologies into the manufacturing process, is underway in India. India has made significant strides in internet penetration in recent years, which is essential for the adoption of Industry 4.0 technologies. The government is focused on becoming a key player in global value chains and has launched initiatives such as the SAMARTH Udyog Bharat 4.0 to encourage technological solutions for Indian manufacturing.

The push towards self-reliance in semiconductor technology and production will help India establish a pillar of the industry 4.0 revolution - hyper-efficient processing technology. This is in line with the government's objective of achieving self-reliance or Aatmanirbharta and becoming a key player in global value chains.

headings: Positive Factors in Indian Industrial Growth
Initiatives for Industrial Growth in India
Conclusion and Outlook for Indian Industrial Growth
explanations: India's industrial production expanded during FY23 despite global headwinds, backed by sustained demand conditions. Credit growth in the industry has also increased remarkably, suggesting that prospects for Capex investments by companies are brighter. The PLI schemes are set to unlock manufacturing capacity, boost exports, reduce import dependence and lead to job creation for both skilled and unskilled labour.

FDI in the manufacturing sector moderated in the first half of FY23 amidst heightened global uncertainty. However, inflows stayed well above the pre-pandemic levels, driven by structural reforms and measures improving the ease of doing business, making India one of the most attractive FDI destinations in the world.

Exports are slowing down and are likely to moderate along with the probable global economic slowdown. V olatile international commodity prices and supply disruptions in raw materials can weigh on industrial growth in the wake of new disruptions at the global level. The re-emergence of Covid-19 in China can trigger supply chain disruptions, as was the case during the pandemic period.

Easing input cost pressures owing to a fall in international commodity prices augurs well for company margins. Capacity utilisation in the manufacturing sector has also been rising, which bodes well for new investment activity in creating additional capacity. Credit to MSMEs has seen a significant increase in part, assisted by the introduction of the ECLGS.

India has launched various initiatives to boost industrial growth, such as increasing bank credit, establishing the Centre for Fourth Industrial Revolution, and introducing PLI schemes. The Centre for Fourth Industrial Revolution in India, established in 2018, looks to develop policy frameworks for emerging technologies. The PLI schemes aim to unlock manufacturing capacity, boost exports, reduce import dependence, and lead to job creation for both skilled and unskilled labour.

Notwithstanding several open questions and challenges to industrial growth, industrial output in India should continue to grow steadily based on resilient domestic demand. If China returns to normalcy from Covid-19, there can be an increase in commodity demand, thus reversing the recent decline in commodity prices. The durability of the recovery in commodity prices will depend on many factors, such as the pace of China's economic recovery and growth outlook in North America and Europe.

headings: Rebound of India's Services Sector in FY22
Liberalisation of Investment in Various Industries
Improved Performance of Various Services Sub-Sectors
Source of Strength in Digital Services
explanations: India's services sector witnessed a swift rebound in FY22 driven by growth in the contact-intensive services sub-sector, which bore the maximum burden of the pandemic. This sub-sector completely recovered from the pre-pandemic level in Q2 of FY23, driven by the release of pent-up demand, ease of mobility restriction, and near-universal vaccination coverage. Going forward, strong momentum growth and an uptick in the High-Frequency Indicators (HFIs) for the contact-intensive services sector reflect a strong growth opportunity in the next fiscal.

India has been a major player in services trade, being among the top ten services exporting countries in 2021, having increased its share in world commercial services exports from 3 per cent in 2015 to 4 per cent in 2021. India's services exports have remained resilient during the Covid-19 pandemic and amid current geopolitical uncertainties, driven by higher demand for digital support, cloud services, and infrastructure modernisation catering to new challenges.

To ensure the liberalisation of investment in various industries, the Government has permitted 100 per cent foreign participation in telecommunication services including all services and infrastructure providers, through the Automatic Route. The FDI ceiling in insurance companies was also raised from 49 to 74 per cent. Measures undertaken by the Government, such as the launch of the National Single-Window system and enhancement in the FDI ceiling through the automatic route, have played a significant role in facilitating investment.

With the waning of the pandemic and external shocks on account of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, there is evidence of improvement in the performance of various services sub-sectors. The hotel industry is thriving with improvements in occupancy rate, increase in the Average Room Rate (ARR) and rise in Revenue Per Available Room (RevP AR) which are now much nearer to the pre-pandemic level of FY20. The tourism sector is also showing signs of revival, with foreign tourist arrivals in India in FY23 growing month-on-month with the resumption of scheduled international flights and the easing of Covid-19 regulations. The Real Estate sector has witnessed resilient growth in the current year, with housing sales and the launch of new houses surpassing in Q2 of FY23 the pre-pandemic level of Q2 of FY20. Information Technology-Business Process Management (IT-BPM) and the E-commerce industry have been exceptionally resilient during the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by accelerated technology adoption and digital transformation.
PMI services, indicative of service sector activity, has also witnessed a strong rebound in recent months with the retreating of the price pressures of inputs and raw materials.

The Government’ s push to boost the digital economy, growing internet penetration, rise in smartphone adoption and increased adoption of digital services have been attributed as the source of strength for various services sectors during the pandemic.

The COVID-19 pandemic had a profound effect on contact services sectors like tourism, retail trade, hotel, entertainment, and recreation. However, non-contact services sectors such as information, communication, financial, professional, and business services remained resilient. The services sector has witnessed a swift rebound in FY22, growing YoY at 8.4% compared to a contraction of 7.8% in the previous financial year. As per the First Advance Estimates, Gross Value Added (GVA) in the services sector is estimated to grow at 9.1% in FY23, driven by 13.7% growth in contact-intensive services sector. Figure X.1 shows broad-based growth in the Services sector. Even on a sequential basis, the rebound continued in Q2 of FY23, with the services sector recording 8.7% sequential growth.

The introduction and piloting of Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) are set to provide a significant boost to digital financial services. These may lay the framework for another generation of financial innovation.
HFIs have played a major role in driving the sector's growth with their robust performance. Payments have also given a renewed push to financial services industries.

As per figure X.2 from the Economic Survey 2022-23, the services sector has experienced strong growth momentum in Q2 of FY23. The graph depicts the YoY growth and sequential growth trends of the services sector from Q1 2019-20 to Q2 2022-23. The data used for the graph is sourced from NSO, MOSPI.

The Economic Survey 2022-23 discusses the trend in various high-frequency indicators to track the growth momentum of the services sector as a whole and also discusses the performance of various services sub-sectors. One of the indicators discussed is India's services sector activity, which is gauged by PMI Services. The PMI Services, which remained in the contractionary zone for several months during 2020 and 2021 due to restrictions imposed to tackle the Covid-19 pandemic, recovered swiftly with the waning of the Omicron variant at the beginning of 2022. However, it again witnessed a setback with the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The indicator moderated from May to September 2022. Further, price pressures and unfavorable weather also dampened domestic demand. However, following an overall easing of retail inflation leading to retreating price pressures of inputs and raw materials, PMI services witnessed an uptick and expanded to 58.5 in December 2022. The data used for the discussion is sourced from IHS Markit.

As mentioned in the Economic Survey 2022-23, one of the high-frequency indicators used to track the services sector is PMI Services. Figure X.3 from the survey shows the trend in PMI Services from March 2019 to December 2022. The graph shows that PMI Services remained in an expansionary zone despite geopolitical tensions. The data used for the graph is sourced from IHS Markit.

Bank credit to the services sector has witnessed significant growth since October 2021 with the improvement in vaccination coverage and recovery in the services sector. The credit to services sector saw a YoY growth of 21.3 per cent in November 2022, the second highest in 46 months, compared to a 3.3 per cent growth in November 2021. Within the services sector, credit to wholesale and retail trade increased by 10.2 per cent and 21.9 per cent in November 2022, respectively, reflecting the strength of the underlying economic activity. Credit to NBFCs grew by 32.9 per cent as NBFCs shifted to bank borrowings because of high bond yields. Uncertain growth prospects in the global markets and uneven credit allocation to the transport sector led to a decline in credit to the shipping and aviation sector by 7.9 per cent and 8.7 per cent respectively in November 2022. figure X.4: credit offtake by the services sector registering double-digit growth since April 2022

World services trade volume finally surpassed its pre-pandemic peak in the second quarter of 2022 and was expected to remain strong in the third quarter, buoyed by spending on travel, Information and Communication Technology (ICT) services, and financial services. However, WTO’s Services Trade Barometer Index reading fell to 98.3 for October 2022 (slightly below its baseline value of 100), well below the previous reading of 105.5 in June 2022 indicating that YoY growth in real commercial services began moderating in the third quarter of 2022 and may slow further in the fourth as well as into the first quarter of 2023 due to declining growth prospects in major service industry economies. Financial and ICT Services have been so far most resilient to the slowing global economy, whereas, construction services and container shipping fell into contraction territory.

Insofar as India is concerned, some headwinds may be observed in the coming months because of the slowing growth in some of India’s major trading partners. On the contrary, India’s services exports may improve as runaway inflation in advanced economies drives up wages and makes local sourcing expensive, opening up avenues for outsourcing to low-wage countries, including India. India is a significant player in services trade, being among the top ten services.

headings: Services Exports and Resilience Amid Covid-19 Pandemic
explanations: India has shown an increasing share in world commercial services exports, increasing from 3% to 4% between 2015 and 2021. Software exports have remained resilient during the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by higher demand for digital support, cloud services, and infrastructure modernisation. Transport and travel exports have been the most impacted sub-components of services exports in FY21 and FY22, which contracted due to the imposition of restrictions on international travel and tourism during the Covid-19 pandemic. The services continued their growth trend and registered a growth rate of 27.7%. If there is a meaningful economic slowdown in advanced nations, tourism and travel earnings in FY24 may be on the lower side.

India is the seventh largest recipient of FDI in the top 20 host countries in 2021. In FY22, India received the highest-ever FDI inflows of US$ 84.8 billion including US$ 7.1 billion FDI equity inflows in the services sector. To facilitate investment, the Indian Government launched the National Single-Window system, which is a one-stop solution for approvals and clearances needed by investors, entrepreneurs, and businesses. The government permits 100% foreign participation in telecommunication services, including all services and infrastructure providers, through the Automatic Route. The FDI ceiling in insurance companies was also raised from 49 to 74 per cent, under the Automatic Route. Further, the government has allowed 20% foreign investment in Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) under the automatic route.

headings: Performance of Global Tourism in Post-Pandemic era
explanations: The Indian Insurance sector is poised to become the 6th largest by 2032, ahead of Germany, Canada, Italy, and South Korea. The IRDAI has taken various steps to promote healthy growth of the insurance industry, rationalize the regulatory framework, and reduce the compliance burden of regulated entities. Towards the objective of universal insurance, the insurance regulator has taken initiatives to increase insurance penetration such that, when India celebrates 100 years of its independence in 2047, every Indian has appropriate life, health, and property insurance cover and every enterprise is supported by appropriate insurance solutions.

During FY23, IRDAI implemented measures to increase accessibility, innovation, competition, distribution efficiency, and choice availability while mainstreaming technology and moving towards a principle-based regime in the insurance sector in India. Easy entry into the insurance sector was facilitated by launching a Single Window NOC Portal (www.noc.irdai.gov.in) to aid the incorporation of an insurer without any hassles. IRDAI reduced the time taken to launch a new product in the market by eliminating the need to seek prior approval from IRDAI for a majority of Life Insurance and Health & General Insurance products. Several actions were taken to reduce the compliance burden of regulated entities in the form of rationalizing returns and repealing 85 circulars. Furthermore, the regulator is considering giving more flexibility to the entities in operational and business decisions.

IRDAI facilitated the introduction of tech-enabled concepts for Motor Insurance such as Pay as You Drive and Pay How You Drive by General insurers. The scope of the cashless facility in health insurance was expanded under IRDAI's measures. The Fire Insurance sector has been introduced to innovative products. IRDAI aimed to ease the living of Senior Citizens in their insurance policies.

After the pandemic, global tourism is gradually converging to the pre-pandemic scenario. International tourism has shown robust performance in January-September 2022, with international tourist arrivals reaching 63 per cent of the pre-pandemic level, boosted by strong pent-up demand, improved confidence levels and the lifting of restrictions. Although the pace of recovery would have been even stronger, it was impeded by lingering global uncertainties and higher inflation in advanced nations.

The Covid-19 pandemic affected the fortunes of the hospitality and tourism industries in recent years. The hotel industry closed the year 2020 with an average hotel occupancy rate of 33- 36 per cent, reflecting a decline of 32 per cent3.

However, hotel occupancy began a strong recovery in the third quarter of 2021 driven by domestic leisure travel growth, partial resumption of business travel in the country, as well as wedding and social events. Small-to-medium-sized domestic MICE (Meetings, Incentives, Conference, Exhibitions) events also made a comeback, fuelling demand for hotels. The sector ended the year with an average occupancy of 42-45 per cent, up 10-13 percentage points over the previous year.

The reintroduction of travel restrictions across States at the beginning of 2022 due to the emergence of a new Covid-19 strain, Omicron, again threw the Indian hospitality sector into an upheaval. Other leisure and business travel plans were put on hold, barring critical and urgent travel as people exercised caution. The low demand resulted in an average hotel occupancy rate of 50 per cent during January-March 2022. However, due to the lower severity and hospitalisation rate of the Omicron variant, travel demand in India began its return to normalcy in March 2022.

Aiding the revival of travel demand was the high vaccination rate in the country, as also effective pandemic management that ensured speed in imposing as well as the lifting of mobility restrictions closely tracking the spread and subsiding of the virus. After a two-year hiatus, India also resumed all regular international flights at full capacity as 2021-22 came to a close. Consequently, the entire aircraft movement (cargo aircraft + passenger aircraft) in the country increased by 52.9 per cent YoY between April and November 2022, reaching 93.9 per cent of the movement recorded between April and November 2019. Presently, the hotel industry is thriving with improvements in occupancy rate, an increase in Average Room Rate (ARR) and a rise in RevPAR5. The occupancy rate in November 2022 stood at around 68-70 per cent, completely recovering the average pre-pandemic level of 2019-20.

Tourism industry was another sector that was adversely impacted by the pandemic. A significant decline in Foreign Tourist Arrivals in India was witnessed in FY21. As per a study6 conducted by the Ministry of Tourism in collaboration with the National Council of Applied and Economic Research (NCAER), Tourism Direct Gross Value Added (TDGV A) witnessed a decline of 42.8 per cent in Q1, 15.5 per cent in Q2, and 1.1 per cent in Q3 of FY21 due to the overall economic slowdown in FY21. Tourism being a contact-intensive sector, employment in the sector was impacted due to the lockdown, and it was a global phenomenon. 14.5 million direct jobs in Q1, 5.2 million in Q2, and 1.8 million in Q3 are expected to have been lost compared to an estimated 34.8 million direct jobs in the tourism sector in the pre-pandemic period of FY20.

However, with the waning of the pandemic, India’s tourism sector is also showing signs of revival. Foreign tourist arrivals in India in FY23 have been growing month-on-month with the resumption of scheduled international flights and the easing of Covid-19 regulations. Yet, the arrivals are below the pre-pandemic level. Profitability ratios of the tourism industry further improved.

headings: Improvement in Average Daily Rate and Revenue per Available Room
explanations: The article mentions that services, particularly MICE tourism and bleisure travel, are rebounding in popularity in India. With infrastructure amenities constantly improving, India is increasingly becoming the preferred destination for MICE events.

The whitepaper on Blended Financing by AIM-NITI-IPE, available at https://www.niti.gov.in/sites/default/files/2022-02/AIM-NITI-IPE-whitepaper-on-Blended-Financing.pdf, may have a role to play in facilitating the revival of tourism in India.

The article points to an improvement in the Average Daily Rate (ADr) and revenue per Available Room (revPar) in India. These improvements, as shown in figure X.7, may indicate a strengthening of the tourism industry.

India is ranked 10th out of the top 46 countries in the world in the Medical Tourism Index FY21, released by the Medical Tourism Association. Factors such as the presence of world-class hospitals and skilled medical professionals, superior quality healthcare, low treatment costs compared with other countries, credibility in alternative systems of medicine, and increased global demand for wellness services make India a popular medical tourism destination. Medical Value Tourism (MVT) is expected to grow to US$ 13 billion by 2022.

Figure X.8 shows that foreign tourist arrivals in India are catching up with pre-pandemic levels. A positive trend is also seen in the average hotel occupancy rate, with figure X.6 indicating that it is nearing pre-pandemic levels.

headings: Initiatives to Boost Tourism in India
Measures to Boost Tourism in India
Impact of Covid-19 on Real Estate Sector
explanations: India has taken several initiatives to improve its attractiveness as a destination for specialized tourism. These include the Ayush visa for medical treatment, the National Strategy for Sustainable Tourism & Responsible Traveler Campaign, the Swadesh Darshan 2.0 scheme, and Heal in India. The G20 presidency presents an opportunity for the Indian travel and tourism industry to promote India as a 'major tourism destination'.

The Ministry of Tourism has undertaken measures to boost the tourism sector. The National Integrated Database of Hospitality Industry (NIDHI) is being used to register accommodation units in the country, which can help create policies and strategies for tourism development. The System for Assessment, Awareness, and Training for Hospitality Industry (SAATHI) was launched in association with the Quality Council of India to promote Covid-19 regulations and boost staff and guest confidence. The Loan Guarantee Scheme for Covid Affected Tourism Service Sector (LGSCATSS) provides working capital/personal loans to households impacted by the pandemic. Additionally, the first 5 lakh free Tourist Visas were announced by the Government for foreign nationals visiting India to boost tourism.

Better connectivity is key for flourishing tourism in any region. The Regional Connectivity Scheme (RCS-UDAN) was launched to facilitate and stimulate regional air connectivity by making it affordable. Presently, 51 out of the 59 Tourism RCS air routes are operational. During FY21 and FY22, the Airport Authority of India was reimbursed ₹104.19 crore in the form of Viability Gap Funding (VGF).

The onset of the Covid-19 pandemic exacerbated the slowdown in the real estate sector. There was a deferment of big-ticket purchases, stagnation of property prices, and scarce funding for developers, which induced slackening of demand. Project delays and the associated lockdown and migration of workforces further aggravated the situation.

headings: Impact of Pandemic on Real Estate Sector
Measures taken by the government to boost the housing sector
Liquidity Support provided by National Housing Bank
Impact of National Housing Bank's measures
explanations: The pandemic brought about a change in individual home buyers’ sentiment in favour of owning a house. With the easing of curbs, there was an increase in interest in the residential housing sector and more so in the readily available and affordable segment. The hybrid work mode with the privileges of working from anywhere encouraged first-time home buyers to move away from the conventional metros, and this brought about a pent-up demand in the residential real estate markets of Tier II and III cities. Improvement in affordability in response to measures taken by the government during the pandemic, such as lower interest rates, reduction in circle rates, and cut in stamp duties on transaction of sale/purchase of immovable property, the extension of the Real Estate Regulation Act (RERA) also played a significant role in post-pandemic rebound of Real Estate sector.

Various policy intervention by the government, including ‘Housing for All’, Aatmanirbhar Bharat, etc., provided an impetus to the Housing Finance sector. The permission by RBI to lending institutions to grant a total moratorium of 6 (3+3) months in case of payment failure due between 1st March 2020 to 31st August 2020, infusion of ₹75,000 crore for Non-Banking Financial Corporations (NBFCs), Housing Finance Companies (HFCs) and Micro Finance Institutions (MFIs), among others, have also contributed to the revival of the real estate sector. The interest subvention under Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana-Credit Linked Subsidy Scheme Urban) (PMAY-CLSS (U)) has been the demand-side driver in the residential housing space.This, along with streamlined policies to increase the credit flow, has helped in the creation of a consumer-friendly ecosystem for housing finance. Since its inception, the government has released a subsidy amounting to ₹ 53,548 crore benefitting approximately 22.87 lakh households. Further, the Affordable Housing Fund (AHF) created sufficient liquidity in the sector for viable growth.

National Housing Bank has provided Liquidity support of ₹ 88,400 crore through various refinance schemes since the onset of the Pandemic. The Smart City Project, with a plan to build 100 smart cities across India, was aimed at improving the overall opportunity for the real estate sector and encouraging investments. The overall affordability in the residential real estate sector was high during the post-pandemic period, as reflected by a decline in the weighted average annual interest rate on home loans from 8.6 per cent during January-March 2020 to 7.3 per cent during January-March 2022 for Scheduled Commercial Banks.
The Co-lending model has been put forward with the aim to leverage the liquidity base of the banks and reach of HFCs to deliver formal housing credit to the bottom of the pyramid.

Under the Affordable Housing Fund, National Housing Bank has disbursed ₹ 34,588 crore for 3.9 lakh dwelling units since its inception. Under the Special Liquidity Facility of RBI, National Housing Bank (NHB) disbursed ₹13,917 crore and ₹8,112 crore during the 1st and 2nd waves of the pandemic, respectively, to ensure seamless business as usual in the sector.

headings: Geopolitical tensions and impact on real estate sector
Resilient growth in the real estate sector
Recent government measures to cool off construction cost
Improvements in India's real estate transparency index
Sustained growth in housing sales and launches
explanations: The ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict has led to disruption in the global supply chain, resulting in a surge in prices of construction materials. Construction costs have increased due to the price escalations of steel, cement, finishing materials, imported chemicals, and fuel. This has resulted in a rise in housing prices.

Despite the current impediments such as rising interest rates on home loans and property prices, the sector has witnessed resilient growth in the current year with housing sales and launch of new houses surpassing the pre-pandemic level of Q2 of FY20. The unsold inventory in Q3 of FY23 dipped to 33 months from 42 months last year. The unsold inventory stood at 8.5 lakh at the end of 2022 with 80 per cent of the stocks under various stages of construction.

The Indian government has recently reduced import duties on steel products, iron ore, and steel intermediaries. These measures will help check the rise in housing prices and cool off the construction cost.

According to JLL's 2022 Global Real Estate Transparency Index, India's real estate market transparency is among the top ten most improved markets globally. The market transparency of the country has improved significantly in the past few years.

The real estate sector has witnessed sustained growth in housing sales and launches in the past few years. Sales and launches have surpassed the pre-pandemic level of Q2 of FY20. This is a positive indicator for the overall health of the real estate sector.

Inventory overhang refers to the estimated time period developers are likely to take to sell off the unsold inventory, based on the current sales velocity. The unsold inventory stood at 8.5 lakh at the end of 2022 with 80 per cent of the stocks under various stages of construction. The inventory overhang in Q3 of FY23 dipped to 33 months from 42 months last year.

headings: Top Countries with Improved Real Estate Transparency
Impact of COVID-19 on IT-BPM Industry
Major Factors Contributing to IT-BPM Industry's Resilience
explanations: Real estate transparency score in India has improved from 2.82 in 2020 to 2.73 in 2022 due to increased institutional investment and the growing number of Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs). Regulatory initiatives such as the Model Tenancy Act and digitisation of land registries & market data through the Dharani and Maha RERA platforms have helped to broaden the market and bring more formalisation to the sector. The figure X.11 shows the top transparency improvers in global real estate between 2020 and 2022.
The transparency index of Dubai, Abu Dhabi, France, Netherlands, USA, Germany, India, Belgium, Canada, and Spain has improved between 2020 and 2022.

COVID-19 has accelerated the pace of digital transformation across most of India’s end-user industries. India’s IT-BPM industry has been exceptionally resilient during the pandemic, driven by increased technology spending, accelerated technology adoption, and digital transformation. IT-BPM revenues registered YoY growth of 15.5% during FY22 compared to 2.1% growth in FY21, with all sub-sectors showing double-digit revenue growth.

India’s IT-BPM industry has been exceptionally resilient during the pandemic. The industry’s response to the second wave has moved beyond addressing the immediate challenges to significantly enhancing capabilities to become a future-ready organization.

An obsession with customer-centricity, domain-specific solutions, a digital-first talent pool, and a laser-sharp focus on creating future-ready solutions have been the key pillars that enabled technology firms to respond proactively to emerging customer demand throughout the pandemic.

IT-BPM revenues registered YoY growth of 15.5% during FY22 compared to 2.1% growth in FY21, with all sub-sectors showing double-digit revenue growth. Within the IT-BPM sector, IT services constitute the majority share (greater than 51%). Exports (including hardware) witnessed a growth of 17.2% in FY22 compared to 1.9% growth in FY21.

headings: Proportion of Digital Revenue in IT-BPM Industry
explanations: The IT-BPM industry recorded nearly 10 per cent estimated growth in direct employee pool in FY22 with a highest-ever net addition to its employee base. The domestic technology industry is estimated to grow at 10 per cent on account of enterprise digital acceleration and transformation. The industry undertook over 290 Mergers and Acquisitions in FY22, primarily focusing on digital services. Growth in exports was seen across all the major markets, with the USA, Europe (excl. UK), and the UK continues to be the major markets. Many firms are now focusing on new markets, more prominently the Middle East and Latin America leading to market diversification which will increase the IT-BPM sector’s resilience in the coming years.

Around 62% of IT-BPM exports (excluding hardware) come from the USA market while 17% and 11% come from the UK and Europe (excl. UK), respectively. The market share of Latin America and the Middle East is around 2%. The Asia Pacific Region (APAC) is the fourth biggest market, accounting for 8% of exports.

In FY22, IT services accounted for 51% of IT-BPM revenues. BPM accounted for 19%, while ER&D and Software Products accounted for 16% and 6%, respectively. Hardware accounted for the lowest share of 2%. The figures are according to NASSCOM.

India’s massive digital infrastructure played a crucial role in driving technology adoption, with public digital platforms becoming the bedrock of India’s digital advantage. In recent years, India has emerged as a global powerhouse for Engineering R&D (ER&D) and innovation and is steadfastly committed to ushering future growth and innovation for global enterprises. Many Global Competency Centres (GCCs) have been incorporated in India in the last six years. GCCs in India are increasingly performing complex R&D functions and are leveraging futuristic technologies and developing digitally innovative products as well building either the largest or the second-largest ER&D hubs in India. Patent filing has increased drastically, with over 138,000 patents filed between 2015- 21, with over 85,000 filed in emerging technologies.

In India, the proportion of digital revenue as a percentage of total revenue has increased from around 26-28 per cent in FY20 to 30-32 per cent in FY22. The increasing penetration of digital tech and “Made in India digital-first solutions for the world” is one of the major growth drivers of the IT-BPM industry.
NASSCOM’s quarterly review in August 2022 indicates that technology spending during FY23 is likely to see a relatively muted growth dampened by an expected global slowdown.

headings: India as a digital talent nation
Expansion of e-commerce to newer segments
Government's push to boost digital economy
explanations: India's growing demand for tech talent puts pressure on margins with limited opportunity to pass on the cost increase. Key margin levers include increased capacity utilisation, a higher share of offshore revenue, a declining share of travel and facility costs, and operating leverage.

India has emerged as a digital talent nation with a high share of the working population and growing undergraduate enrolments. Employment across technology companies witnessed an increase, with an uptrend in the digital talent base. New talent hiring from tier-2 cities, with a focus on reskilling non-tech talent, has led India to evolve as a significant sub-contractor base, with more women getting back into the workforce.

Indian tech industry led the adoption of hybrid work models. The technology used for augmenting employee experience and integrating tech solutions in aspects such as employee onboarding, communication, collaboration, and employee well-being & enablement has been the major driver. The HR functions at organisations are undergoing a transformation journey.

The expansion of e-commerce to newer segments like grocery, fresh-to-home fruits and vegetables, and general merchandise has contributed to the expansion of the customer base beyond traditional buyers. Emerging categories – fashion, grocery, general merchandise – would shore up e-commerce growth in India and would capture nearly two-thirds of the Indian e-commerce market by 2027.

The Government's push to boost the digital economy and the growing internet penetration, rise in smartphone adoption, innovation in mobile technologies, and increased adoption of digital payments further accelerated the adoption and growth of e-commerce.
