There has also been an increase in the adoption of digital solutions by MSMEs like e-commerce and e-procurement, realising the prospects of increased revenues and margins, improved market reach, access to new markets, and customer acquisition.

headings: Access to Suppliers for Small Business Owners
Geographical Expansion of E-commerce in Rural India
Focus on Local Solutions to Strengthen Rural Consumption
Projected Market Share of Indian E-commerce
Success of Indian E-commerce Start-Ups Post-Covid-19
explanations: The growth of e-commerce businesses has increased access to suppliers which has reduced procurement costs for small business owners allowing them to scale up at a lower investment level.

Increased smartphone penetration, internet adoption and purchasing power of rural customers have driven the growth of e-commerce businesses in rural India. Fiscal support during the pandemic has also contributed towards the increase in e-commerce penetration in rural areas.

The E-commerce industry is focusing on local solutions to penetrate rural areas, such as strengthening the network of rural distributors and retailers and using local distribution centers as pickup and drop-off points.

By 2027, fashion, grocery, and general merchandise are expected to capture nearly two-thirds of the Indian e-commerce market, with mobiles/electronics/appliances accounting for 45-50% and other products accounting for 5-10%.

Overall e-commerce order volume witnessed a growth of 69.4% YoY in FY22, driven mainly by consumers from tier-II and tier-III cities. The shoppers from tier-II and tier-III cities accounted for over 61.3% of the overall market share in FY22, increasing from 53.8% in FY21.
The Government E-Marketplace (GeM) has witnessed tremendous growth in Gross Merchandise Value (GMV) and is catching up with e-commerce giants like Amazon.

headings: GeM's Growth and Onboarding of MSMEs and Artisans
Initiatives taken by the Government for Promotion of e-Commerce
Launch of Open Network for Digital Commerce (ONDC)
Digital Financial Services for Financial Inclusion
Rise of Neobanking Platforms and Global Investments
explanations: GeM has achieved an annual procurement of ₹1 lakh crore within FY22, representing a 160 per cent growth over last FY. GeM has onboarded products of Self-Help Groups, tribal communities, artisans, weavers, and MSMEs. 57 per cent of the total business on GeM has come through MSME units, and female entrepreneurs have contributed over 6 per cent.

Initiatives taken by the Government for the promotion of e-Commerce, including the Digital India program, Unified Payment Interface (UPI), GeM, etc. have been major contributory factors to the growth of E-commerce in recent years. One District – One Product (ODOP) initiative has been facilitating the onboarding of sellers of identified products on e-Commerce platforms and www.tribesindia.com portal through Tribal Cooperative Marketing Development Federation of India Limited (TRIFED) has been onboarding tribal artisans with their products for online sales, ensuring tribal products find a larger audience in the international market as well.

The recent initiative of the launch of Open Network for Digital Commerce (ONDC) is playing a significant role in democratising digital payments, enabling interoperability, and bringing down transaction costs. ONDC provides better market access to sellers and helps bring the country's remotest corners into the e-Commerce framework by empowering them with digitisation. Details on the applicability and advantages of ONDC are further discussed in Ch-12 on Physical and Digital Infrastructure: Lifting Potential Growth.

Digital financial services enabled by emerging technologies and innovative solutions are accelerating financial inclusion, democratising access, and spurring the personalisation of products. With a strong foundation provided by the Jan Dhan-Aadhaar-Mobile (JAM) trinity, UPI, and other regulatory frameworks, the pandemic has aided acceleration in digital adoption and provided a fillip to digital financial services solutions by banks, NBFCs, insurers as well as fintech.

Over the last few years, the number of neobanking platforms and global investments in the neobanking segment has also risen consistently. Neobanks operate under mainstream finance's umbrella but empower specific services long associated with traditional institutions such as banks, payment providers, etc. Neobanks operate entirely online, with no physical presence apart from office space in the offline world. The growth of these institutions is spurred by the need for on-demand and easier-to-access financial solutions by a young and increasingly digitally savvy demographic. Neobanks have eased availability and provided access to financial services to MSMEs and underbanked customers and areas. The government also, through various initiatives, is promoting the growth of neobanks in the country.

The Union Budget 2022-23 announced the launch of 75 Digital Banking Units (DBU) across 75 districts in India to provide banking solutions to every nook and corner of the country. This push towards digital banking solutions is expected to bring efficiency and innovation in the payments system as well as foster financial inclusion.

CBDC is a digital version of a country's fiat currency that is backed by the central bank. The introduction of CBDC in India is expected to reduce operational costs involved in physical cash management, foster financial inclusion, and bring resilience, efficiency, and innovation in the payments system. Many countries have already launched CBDC while others are in the pilot stage. RBI has recently launched pilots of CBDC in both the Wholesale and Retail segments under the names Digital Rupee-Wholesale and Digital Rupee-Retail, respectively.

Digitisation of documents ensures safety, online verification, improved accessibility, and fraud reduction, enhancing use for end customers and the service provider. It has played a pivotal role in giving further impetus to digital financial services.

Account Aggregator (AA) is a Non-Banking Financial Company (NBFC) engaged in the business of providing the service of retrieving or collecting financial information pertaining to the customer. The AA transfers data from one financial institution to another based on an individual's instruction and consent. RBI has issued the Master Direction viz Non-Banking Financial Company – Account Aggregator (Reserve Bank) Directions, dated September 02, 2016. As on 31st December 2022, 27 Financial Institutions have gone live as FIPs, and RBI has granted a Certificate of Registration to six companies as AA.

119 financial institutions have gone live as FIUs, out of which 93 are RBI regulated, 12 are SEBI regulated, 12 are IRDAI-regulated, and 2 are PFRDA-regulated. This enables better tracking and monitoring of financial transactions.

23 banks have onboarded the Account Aggregator framework, providing eligibility for more than 1.1 billion bank accounts to share data. Out of 3.3 million users linked to the AA framework, 3.28 million successfully shared data via AA. This can be a significant step towards a more integrated financial system.
RBI has notified the Goods and Services Tax Network as FIP on 23rd November 2022. This move can enable digital invoice financing and provide credit support to the MSME sector.

National e-Governance Services Limited (NeSL) introduced the Digital Document Execution (DDE) platform in 2020. It digitizes all document and agreement execution steps, including submission, flexible accommodation of all agreement/document formats, consent-based processing, digital payment of stamp duty, identity verification, digital execution using electronic signature, secure storage and retrieval of digitally executed documents. This eliminates the need for physical presence and manual processes for document/agreement execution, generating benefits like lower execution time and cost, secure systems, authorized access, bulk processing, fraud prevention, legal robustness, and evidentiary value. Aadhaar e-Sign has enabled electronic signatures to citizens at a nominal cost. Currently, 23 States and Union Territories are available for digital e-stamping on the NeSL DDE platform used by 27 banks and NBFCs.

The NeSL-DDE platform provides a solution for the issuance, transfer, and management of electronic bank guarantees (e-BGs), which saves time and cost and eliminates physical bank guarantee-related issues. The platform can also function as a central repository of bank guarantees. The Department of Expenditure has amended the General Financial Rules, 2017, to allow the acceptance of e-BGs in the government procurement process. Given its secure, paperless, and hassle-free contracting, NeSL-DDE's adoption can contribute positively to the country's ease of doing business.

India's services sector growth has shown resilience in FY23 despite the volatility and fragility observed in the previous two fiscal years. The growth is driven by pent-up demand, ease of mobility restrictions, near-universal vaccination coverage, and government interventions. Recovery has been observed in recent months, with almost all sub-sectors reporting a pick-up, especially contact-intensive sectors. The performance of various sub-sectors like Tourism, Hotel, Real Estate, IT-BPM, and E-commerce indicates a brighter outlook. However, bleak economic outlook in the advanced economies could impact growth prospects of the services sector through trade and other linkages.

India's external sector has been affected by various shocks such as global commodity prices, international financial conditions, financial market volatility, capital outflows, currency depreciation, and global growth and trade slowdown. However, India has been able to withstand these shocks due to its strong macroeconomic fundamentals and buffers.

India's exports have shown resilience till December 2022, despite a slowing global economy, due to record levels of exports in FY22. Leading export items are petroleum products, gems & jewellery, organic & inorganic chemicals, drugs & pharmaceuticals. Various export promotion measures are being considered/implemented to nurture Indian exports' inherent comparative advantage. Additionally, the National Logistics Policy and Free Trade Agreements with UAE and Australia aim to ease internal and external frictions for exports.

India's economic revival has contributed to an increase in imports, including petroleum, crude & products, electronic goods, coal, coke & briquettes, machinery, electrical & non-electrical and gold. While global commodity price softening may moderate imports going forward, non-gold, non-oil imports may not decelerate significantly. Additionally, efforts are underway to promote international trade settlement in Indian Rupees to reduce dependence on foreign currency and make the economy less vulnerable to external shocks.

Balance of Payments (BoP) faced pressures during FY23 due to a sharp rise in oil prices, leading to a widening of the Current Account Deficit (CAD). However, the surplus on Invisibles cushioned some of the impact. Policy tightening by the US Federal Reserve and strengthening of the US dollar led to Foreign Portfolio Investment (FPI) outflows, further impacting the surplus of the capital account. Going forward, the expected easing of crude oil prices may provide some relief to BoP pressures.

The section talks about the impact of two global shocks, the global financial crisis and the Covid-19 pandemic, on the global economy. It also highlights the rise in inflation rates due to global commodity and food price spikes, and the acceleration of monetary policy normalisation by monetary authorities.

The global economic outlook has weakened considerably due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with global growth projected to slow down significantly. The section cites the International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecast of global growth slowing from 6.0% in 2021 to 3.2% in 2022 and 2.7% in 2023, the weakest growth profile since 2001.

Emerging markets face several risks, including elevated external borrowing costs, high inflation rates, volatile commodity markets, uncertain global economic growth outlook, and spill overs from policy tightening in advanced economies. The external public debt vulnerability concerns are also being exacerbated in developing economies where much of the debt is owed to private creditors and involve variable interest rates that could spike suddenly.

India's external sector has fortified shock absorbers in place to cushion the global headwinds with formidable forex reserves, sustainable external debt indicators, and a market-determined exchange rate. The forex reserves, as of the end of December 2022, stood at US$ 562.72 billion, accounting for 9.3 months of imports, and the ratio of external debt to GDP is at a comfortable level of 19.2 per cent, as of end-September 2022. The section also suggests lower CAD during the remainder of FY23 and is expected to be within sustainable limits, due to the resilience of net services exports and buoyant inward remittances.

The chapter chronicles the developments in the external sector of the Indian economy focusing on exports, imports, international investment, foreign exchange reserves, movement of the currency against the US dollar, external debt, and the BoP situation. Where available, a comparison of some of these indicators with some peer countries is also made to present India’s external sector situation in a proper perspective.

Trade is essential for developing countries to reap the benefit of increased globalisation of products and financial markets. Over time, the trade openness of countries across the globe has been increasing as measured by trade as a proportion of GDP. For India as well, the share of trade as a percentage of GDP has been steadily increasing, being above 40 per cent since 2005 (except 2020 being the pandemic year). The ratio stands at 46 per cent in 2021 and 50 per cent for H1 of 2022.

Post Covid-19-induced disruptions, global trade prospects have improved in FY22. Global trade exhibited resilience in the first half (H1) of 2022, notwithstanding the headwinds from the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Robust merchandise imports – emerging primarily from Europe, the United States, and parts of the developing world supported the growth of merchandise trade in H12022. This partially reflected pent-up demand relating to the legacy of the pandemic-driven spending shift from services towards goods that were constrained earlier because of the supply bottlenecks. Other factors contributing to the trend were the appreciation of the dollar in the case of the United States, the relative dynamism of intra-regional trade in Europe, and favourable terms-of-trade effects in some large emerging economies due to elevated energy prices.

The global trade volume grew by 4.8 per cent in H12022, on top of an impressive recovery of 9.7 per cent in 2021, as per the World Trade Organisation (WTO) statistics. The global merchandise trade in value terms rose year-on-year (YoY), by 22.2 per cent in 2021, reversing the deceleration observed in the previous three years. During the H1 of 2022, the trade-in value terms grew by 32 per cent compared to the corresponding period of 2019.

However, the global trade outlook turned grimmer in the second half (H2) of 2022 on the back of a confluence of adverse factors including the increasing likelihood of a recession in the major economies and the tapering demand for consumer durables; aggressive monetary policy tightening by several central banks; disorderly financial conditions; continued supply-chain disruptions and elevated freight charges. The leading indicators of global trade viz., inventories

The WTO Goods Trade Barometer released on 28 November 2022 predicts a decline in global trade growth in the closing months of 2022 and into 2023 due to strong headwinds. The current reading of 96.2 is below both the baseline value for the index and the previous reading of 100.0, reflecting the slowdown in demand for traded goods. The WTO forecasts global trade to grow by just 1% in 2023, a sharp downward revision from the previous estimate of 3.4%.

There is a high degree of uncertainty associated with the forecast due to shifting monetary policy in advanced economies and the unpredictability of the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), in its Global Trade update of December 2022, has also noted that the ongoing trade slowdown is expected to worsen for 2023 and further that while the outlook for global trade remains uncertain, negative factors appear to outweigh positive trends.

The WTO's Growth in Global Merchandise trade forecast shows a sharp decline in global trade volume percent change (Y-o-Y) in 2022 and 2023. The forecast for trade growth in 2023 is just 1%, a sharp downward revision from the previous estimate of 3.4%.

International trade has been an essential part of India's external sector for decades. Trade as a percentage of GDP for India has steadily increased from 12-15% in the 1980s to 25-50% in the 2000s. India's growing and diversifying trade has been critical to maintaining the resilience of India's external sector.

headings: Total Trade as percentage of GDP
Key aspects of India's trade (calendar year-wise)
explanations: India's external sector is being cautiously monitored with optimism. The country's trade levels have been increasing and catching up with global trade levels.
India's total trade as percentage of GDP has been increasing over the years. According to the World Bank database, it was at 45.3% in 1991 and reached 56.5% in 2021.

India's performance in exports and imports has been tracked in key aspects. These include its share in world merchandise exports, world commercial services exports, and world merchandise plus services exports, as well as its share in world merchandise imports, world commercial services imports, and world merchandise plus services imports. India's rank in world trade has also been noted, including its ranking in merchandise exports, merchandise imports, services exports, and services imports.
The data in this content is gathered from the World Bank database, as well as the DGFT Monthly Foreign Trade Statistics report from November 2022 based on data until October 2022.

headings: India's Merchandise Trade in FY22 and H1FY23
Bright spots in India's Trade Performance
explanations: India achieved an all-time high annual merchandise export of US$ 422.0 billion in FY22. However, the global economy has started facing formidable headwinds and the ripple effect of the global trade slowdown has started reflecting in India’s merchandise export growth, wherein moderation in pace is observed in 2022. Merchandise exports were US$ 332.8 billion over April-December 2022 against US$ 305.0 billion during the period April-December 2021. Non-petroleum and non-gems & jewellery exports in April-December 2022 were US$ 233.5 billion, as compared to US$ 230.0 billion in April-December 2021. Petroleum, oil, and lubricants (POL) exports constituted about 21.1 per cent and non-POL exports were 78.9 per cent of total exports during FY23 (until December 2022). Owing to the rise in global crude oil prices, petroleum products continued to be the most exported commodity in FY22 and April-December, 2022, followed by gems and jewellery, organic & inorganic chemicals, and drugs & pharmaceuticals.

Significant strides in exports were registered in drugs and pharmaceutical, electronic goods, engineering goods and organic and inorganic chemicals sectors in FY22. These sectors have sustained their growth momentum despite the global headwinds in H1FY23. India’s pharma exports grew despite Covid impacted disruptions in supply chain increasing significantly from US$ 15.4 billion in FY15 to US$ 24.6 billion in FY22 and stood at US$ 18.8 billion during April-December 2022, registering a positive growth of 3.6 per cent over April- December 2021. India has also been seeing consistent growth in exports of electronic goods. Electronic goods exports which remained below US$ 10 billion till FY19, have shown an increase of 51.6 per cent from US$ 11.0 billion during April-December.

India witnessed an increase in the export of engineering and chemicals goods in FY22. Engineering goods exports reached USD 100 billion while organic and inorganic chemicals exports registered a growth of 6.5% and summed up to USD 23.0 billion.

With the revival of domestic demand in India, import growth has been strong. Merchandise imports from April-December 2022 stood at USD 551.7 billion compared to the USD 441.5 billion during the same period in 2021. India's highest imports were petroleum crude and products that rose by 45.6% to USD 163.9 billion.

India's imports for fuel including coal and Petroleum, Oil & Lubricants (POL) rose to 37.1% of the total imports during April-December 2022 against 30.4% in the corresponding period last year. This can be attributed to the growing energy demand of the country. Other principal imports included electronic goods, coal, coke & briquettes, machinery electrical & non-electrical, and organic & inorganic chemicals.
The merchandise trade deficit for April-December 2022 was USD 218.9 billion as against USD 136.5 billion during the same period last year (April-December 2021).

headings: Trends in Merchandise Imports, Exports, and Trade Balance
India's Dominance in World Services Trade
Growth in Software and Business Services Exports
explanations: India's top export destinations are the USA, UAE, and the Netherlands according to data from April to November 2022. India has diversified its export destinations with the share of South Africa, Brazil, and Saudi Arabia increasing over the same period compared to previous years. The Netherlands has displaced China from the 3rd spot as India's exporting partner.

China, UAE, USA, Russia, and Saudi Arabia are the major import partners for India, jointly accounting for 40% of the total imports. However, the share of China has declined to 13.8% during April-November 2022 from 15.5% a year ago, while the share of the USA has declined to 6.9% in April-November 2022 from 7.2% a year ago.
The figure xI.5 shows the trends in merchandise imports, exports, and trade balance for India from the Department of Commerce. The data is provisional and covers the period up to April-November 2022.

India maintained its dominance in the world services trade in FY22 with services exports worth US$ 254.5 billion, recording a growth of 23.5% over FY21. India's services exports grew by 32.7% in April-September 2022 over the same period in FY22. Software and business services together make up more than 60% of India's total services exports, and they exhibited strong growth during Q2FY23.

The growth in software exports is due to strong revenues in IT companies from various segments such as retail and consumer business, communications and media, healthcare, and banking, financial, and insurance services. The growth in business services exports during Q2FY23 is due to a significant pick-up in engineering and research and development related services.

Services imports increased by 25.1% between FY22 and FY21, reaching US$ 147.0 billion, and registered a growth of 36.7% in April-September 2022 over the same period in FY22. The increase in services imports is mainly due to payments for transport services, travel, and other business services. Following the resumption of global activity, there are shortages of goods and services that are affecting trade balances.

The external sector of the Indian economy is watchful and hopeful. There has been a spike in transport payments due to shipping vessels and high transportation costs. However, there has been a growth in travel imports following the easing up of travel restrictions.

The table xI.2 shows a resilient performance of service trade with exports and imports of total services amounting to USD 206.1 billion and USD 117.5 billion respectively in 2020-21. It further increased to USD 254.5 billion and USD 147 billion in 2021-22. The figures for Apr-Sept 2022 (p) were USD 156.1 billion and USD 90.6 billion. The highest contributors to service exports were telecommunications, computer and information services while the highest contributors to service imports were travel and telecommunications, computer and information services.

Figure xI.6 shows an accelerating trend in services trade. The net of services has been increasing continuously from USD 21 billion in Q1 2020-21 to USD 35 billion in Q2 2021-22. The figures for Q3 and Q4 2021-22 are expected to be USD 39 billion and USD 42 billion respectively. In 2022-23 (p), the net of services is expected to be USD 46 billion.

headings: International Trade Settlement in Indian Rupees
explanations: India's service exports have been robust and continue to grow even amid a global economic slowdown. The estimated value of services export for April-December 2022 is US$ 235.8 billion compared to US$ 184.7 billion in April- December 2021. Supported by the services sector, India's overall exports (Merchandise and Services combined) in April-December 2022 are estimated to be US$ 568.6 billion, exhibiting a positive growth of 16.1 per cent over the same period last year.

India’s Foreign Trade Policy (FTP) provides a framework of rules and procedures for exports and imports and a set of incentives for promoting exports. The latest FTP for 2015- 2020 is in vogue at present and was extended till March 2023 on account of volatile global economic and geopolitical situations and currency fluctuations. In 2022, India signed Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) with UAE and with Australia to provide greater market access and make the exporters competitive. The Export Preparedness Index has also been introduced to evaluate States’ potentials and capacities towards strengthening the export ecosystem.

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) issued a circular permitting an additional arrangement for invoicing, payment, and settlement of exports/imports in Indian Rupees (INR) in July 2022. The framework involves invoicing of exports and imports in INR, market-determined exchange rates between the currencies of the trading partner countries, and settlement through special Rupee Vostro accounts opened with authorised dealer banks in India.

headings: Promoting INR as an international currency
Mitigating currency risk for Indian businesses
explanations: The commendable performance of India’s exports, standing at US$ 422.0 billion in FY22, exceeding the target of US$ 400 billion, has been the culmination of efforts from all quarters and across stakeholders. Some of the factors leading to the achievement of this target were putting in place of targets by the Government, including the setting of specific targets - country-wise, product-wise, and Export Promotion Council-wise; monitoring of the targets and course correction where required. The export growth was driven by an increase in demand for products like petroleum, cotton yarn, textiles, chemicals, and engineering goods. India was able to leverage the gap in the supply of certain products in the wake of the pandemic-related disruptions and meet the global demand. Exports were also helped by favourable global commodity prices. Some of the specific schemes of the Government which have and are facilitating and encouraging exports are as follows.

This mechanism shall make payment in INR which shall be credited into the Special V ostro account of the correspondent bank of the partner country, against the invoices for the supply of goods or services from the overseas seller /supplier, while (b) Indian exporters, undertaking exports of goods and services through this mechanism, shall be paid the export proceeds in INR from the balances in the designated Special V ostro account of the correspondent bank of the partner country. The above-mentioned framework for international settlement in INR acquires significance against the backdrop of the US Fed aggressively hiking the policy rates and its hawkish stand, the consequent rallying of the US dollar to multi-decade high levels, and concomitant weakening of currencies of various EMEs including the INR. The framework could largely reduce the net demand for foreign exchange, the US dollar in particular, for the settlement of current account-related trade flows. Further, the use of INR in cross-border trade is expected to mitigate currency risk for Indian businesses. Protection from currency volatility not only reduces the cost of doing business but also enables better business growth, improving the chances for Indian businesses to grow globally. It also reduces the need for holding foreign exchange reserves and dependence on foreign currency, making Indian economy less vulnerable to external shocks. Furthermore, it initiatives to enhance trade by promoting INR as an international currency once the rupee settlement mechanism gains traction. One of the prerequisites for the emergence of an international currency is that the said currency needs to be increasingly used for trade invoicing.

Further, it could assist Indian exporters in getting advance payments in INR from overseas clients and in the longer term promote INR as an international currency once the rupee settlement mechanism gains traction. In terms of foreign exchange market turnover (daily averages), as per the BIS Triennial Central Bank Survey 2022, the US dollar is the dominant vehicle currency accounting for 88 per cent of the global forex turnover. The INR accounted for 1.6 per cent. If the INR turnover rises to equal the share of non-US, non-Euro currencies in global forex turnover of 4 per cent, INR could be regarded as an international currency, reflecting India’s position in the global economy.

The use of INR in cross-border trade is expected to mitigate currency risk for Indian businesses. Protection from currency volatility not only reduces the cost of doing business but also enables better business growth, improving the chances for Indian businesses to grow globally. It also reduces the need for holding foreign exchange reserves and dependence on foreign currency, making Indian economy less vulnerable to external shocks.

headings: Remission of Duties and Taxes on Exported Products Scheme
explanations: The Economic Survey reported an impressive growth of US$ 26.8 billion during April-November 2022 for India's agricultural exports. This growth is attributed to the pro-active support of export promotion agencies including the Export Inspection Council, Plantation Boards, and Agricultural and Processed Food Products Export Development Authority (APEDA). The government has also facilitated exports through online issuance of certificates and participation in trade fairs and events. APEDA has also linked start-ups, entrepreneurs, and exporters in the region of Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh with importers. Regular shipments of high-value Kashmir Saffron (GI) are taking place to destinations including the Middle East, EU, and North America.

The Interest Equalisation Scheme was formulated to provide exporters with benefits in interest rates charged by banks on their pre- and post-shipment rupee export credits. The scheme has been extended, with the subvention rates being reduced to 3% (erstwhile 5%) and 2% (erstwhile 3%) for MSME manufacturing exporters and merchant/other manufacturer exporters, respectively, exporting along 410 (erstwhile 416) HS lines.

The Remission of Duties and Taxes on Exported Products Scheme is designed to remit the Central, State, and Local duties/taxes/levies incurred during the manufacturing and distribution of exported products. These duties/taxes/levies are currently not being refunded under any other duty remission scheme.

The Export Credit Guarantee Corporation (ECGC) provides export credit insurance services that protect Indian exporters and banks from payment risks. ECGC provides insurance cover on the export consignment and Export Credit Insurance to Banks (ECIB) to protect banks from losses due to insolvency and/or protracted default of the exporter borrower. The ECGC has launched a new scheme, enhancing the insurance cover to banks providing pre-shipment and post-shipment finance to support small exporters.

Krishi Udan Scheme was launched in August 2020 to transport agricultural products and improve their value realisation for farmers. Krishi Udan 2.0 was launched in October 2021, enhancing the existing provisions and primarily focusing on transporting perishable food products from hilly areas, North-Eastern states, and tribal areas. The Airports Authority of India provides a full waiver of Landing, Parking charges, Terminal Navigational Landing Charges, and Route Navigation Facility Charges for Indian freighters and Passenger-to-Cargo Aircraft for facilitating and incentivising the movement of agricultural produce by air transportation primarily around 25 airports focusing on North Eastern, Hilly and Tribal region and 28 airports in other regions/areas. The Scheme has been expanded, including five more airports, making it 58 airports.

The Government has been implementing the Trade Infrastructure for Export Scheme since FY18, designed to provide assistance to Central and State Government in export-related infrastructure development.

headings: India's Free Trade Agreements and Preferential Trade Agreements
explanations: The External Sector Infrastructure Scheme provides financial assistance in the form of grant-in-aid to Central/State Government owned agencies for setting up or upgrading export infrastructure as per the guidelines of the Scheme.

The One District One Product initiative is aimed at targeting export promotion, manufacturing, and employment generation at the grassroots level. The initiative seeks to select, brand, and promote products/services from each district of India for enabling holistic socioeconomic growth across all regions and attracting investment to boost manufacturing and exports.

India considers Regional Trading Arrangements (RTAs) as a complement to the multilateral trading system, and engages with its trading partners/blocs to expand its export market. The economic rationale for FTAs is the diversification and expansion of India’s exports to its trading partners, providing a level playing field vis-à-vis the competing countries having preferential access in our trading partners, as well as gain easier access to raw materials and intermediate products for stimulating value-added domestic manufacturing.

India has so far concluded 13 FTAs and 6 Preferential Trade Agreements (PTAs), including those with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), Korea, and Japan. These agreements cover FTA in goods, services, investment, and identify areas of economic cooperation, and are part of India's strategy for geopolitical positioning with the 'Look East Policy.'

The India-UAE Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) was signed on February 18, 2022, and officially entered into force on May 1, 2022. This agreement further strengthens the partnership between India and UAE in mutually beneficial areas such as trade, investment, and services, and is expected to lead to a significant expansion of trade and economic cooperation between the two countries.

India is presently engaged in FTA negotiations with some of its trading partners, notable among these FTAs are – (i) India-UK FTA, (ii) India-Canada CEPA/ Early Progress Trade Agreement (EPTA), (iii) India-EU FTA.  Moreover, India has also initiated action to review some of the existing FTAs, namely, India-Singapore CECA, India-South Korea CEPA, and India-ASEAN Trade in Goods Agreement and initiated discussions on scoping for the CECA with Australia, as envisaged under Ind-Aus ECTA.

FTAs or RTAs in terms of the WTO rules are economic instruments available to a country for leveraging its competencies in trade and investment. As of June 2016, all WTO members now have at least one RTA in force. There has been a substantial rise in the number of trade agreements with 355 notifications of RTAs having been made to the WTO (As of 1 December 2022– Source: WTO website). The limited progress in the multilateral trade negotiations at the WTO is one of the reasons responsible for the increase in FTAs. FTAs are viewed favourably by trading countries in comparison to multilateral negotiation at the WTO forum as they are easy to negotiate and provide flexibility to factor in geopolitical considerations.

Box XI.1 discusses the rise in the number of FTAs being entered into worldwide and various factors that determine their usefulness to a trading partner. The purpose of RTAs is to lower tariffs on goods and services and increase cooperation between trading partners with the aim of increasing trade, lower prices for consumers, and provide enhanced export opportunities for producers. RTAs can also have a larger impact on the economy. For instance, Bailé et al. (2019) found that FTAs are positively correlated with direct domestic value-added exports, as well as forward and backward participation in global value chains.

Many WTO members continue to be involved in negotiations to create new RTAs, which are mostly bilateral. However, a recent development has been negotiations and new agreements among more than two WTO members, such as: Pacific Alliance between Chile, Colombia, Mexico, and Peru; Tripartite Agreement, linking parties to the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, the East African Community and the Southern African Development Community; Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement; African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA); and Regional Comprehensive Partnership Agreement (RCEP) between the ASEAN members and six other WTO members.

The conventional gravity model developed by Tinbergen in 1962 states that bilateral trade between two countries is proportional to their respective sizes measured by their GDPs and inversely proportional to the geographic distance, which is a proxy for transportation cost. Over time, more variables have been added to the model, such as exchange rates, income levels, and changing demand patterns, to test their influence on trade.

FTA provides the environment needed to enhance trade by reducing tariff and non-tariff barriers (NTBs). However, the trade growth of a country depends on many factors, such as (a) Specific features of the FTA (b) The extent of concessions in terms of RoO and removal/easing of NTBs (c) The capacity of an economy to increase the supply of products/services (d) The effect of the FTA would also depend on income growth in the importing markets and the price competitiveness of exports of a partner country in a trade agreement to take advantage of the agreement. Moreover, not all trade may happen through the FTA route, especially if the RoO are cumbersome or goods are already trading at MFN zero duty.

The supply-response is governed by several factors, which include policies on production aspects, a country's institutional and physical infrastructure, and other elements that determine the short-term flexibility of an economy. The capacity to increase the supply of products/services is essential, and trade creation occurs when a member of an FTA, having a comparative advantage in producing a product, can now sell it to its members because trade barriers have been removed.

Not all trade may happen through the FTA route, especially if the RoO are cumbersome or goods are already trading at MFN zero duty. Thus, it may not happen that there will be a sudden or significant increase in trade after an FTA is signed between two or more countries. The trade balance will shift gradually and may also turn out not to be in favour of each partner.

[1] Baier, S.L., Y .V . Yotov, and T. Zylkin. 2019. “On the Widely Differing Effects of Free Trade Agreements: Lessons from Twenty Years of Trade Integration,” Journal of International Economics 116:206–226. [2] The MFN clause refers to a special trading status given by one country to another that gets applied to all the other members of the WTO. [3] Rules of origin are the criteria needed to determine the national source of a product. Their importance is derived from the fact that duties and restrictions in several cases depend upon the source of imports.

headings: Bilateral Trade Performance in West Africa
Composition of India's Current Account Balance
explanations: Osabuohien et al. (2019) conducted a study on bilateral trade performance in West Africa using a gravity model estimation. The study found that trade performance in West Africa is affected by factors such as distance, language, and colonial history.

Tinbergen (1962) proposed suggestions for shaping the world economy in his book 'Shaping the World Economy: Suggestions for an International Economic Policy'. The book outlined ideas for international economic policy that aimed to promote economic growth and development.

Viner (1950) analyzed the economic effects of customs unions in his book 'The Customs Union Issue'. In the book, he discussed the trade-offs involved in forming a customs union and analyzed the welfare effects of such an arrangement.

India's current account balance (CAB) recorded a deficit of US$36.4 billion (4.4% of GDP) in Q2FY23, compared to a deficit of US$9.7 billion (1.3% of GDP) during the same period last year. The increase in CAD was due to higher merchandise trade deficit and an increase in net investment income outgo. For the period April-September 2022 (H1FY23), India recorded a CAD of 3.3% of GDP, compared to 0.2% in H1FY22. However, when compared with the position of the CAB for selected countries, India's CAD is modest and manageable.

According to RBI data, India's current account balance for Q2FY23 was in deficit, with a net merchandise trade balance of -US$83.5 billion, net services at US$25.8 billion, net transfers at US$21.8 billion, and net income at -US$0.5 billion. Further, the CAB for H1FY23 was primarily driven by an increase in the merchandise trade deficit.

India's current account balance as a percentage of GDP compared to select countries listed in Q2-2022 and Q4-2019, according to the OECD Economic Outlook 112 Database. The values range from -12.0% to 4.0%. Countries listed include Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Turkey, Argentina, Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, Russia, and South Africa.

Breakdown of India's net invisibles, including net services receipts and net private transfer receipts, in US$ billions for H1FY22, H1FY23, and the previous year. Net services receipts increased from $51.4 billion to $65.5 billion primarily due to robust computer and business services receipts. Net private transfer receipts, mainly representing remittances by Indians employed overseas, increased from $38.4 billion to $48.0 billion due to a boost in remittance flows into India from high crude oil prices and the depreciation of the INR. Net services exports and remittances helped cushion the merchandise trade deficit.

Breakdown of India's net invisibles by quarter from Q1 2020-21 to Q2 2022-23 (P) in US$ billions for services, transfers, and income, according to RBI data. Robust services and buoyant transfers are major components of India's net invisibles.

Remittances are the second largest major source of external financing after service exports, contribute to narrowing the CAD, and have always been a stable constituent of the BoP. India has the largest emigrant population and is the top remittance recipient country, with remittances anticipated to reach a milestone of US$100 billion in 2022 according to the World Bank.

Indian migrants have shifted towards high-skilled jobs in countries like US, UK, Singapore, Japan, Australia, and New Zealand resulting in increase in remittances. India, Mexico, China, Philippines, Egypt, Arab Rep, Pakistan, France, Bangladesh and Nigeria are the top remittance recipients of the world in 2022.

Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) and foreign portfolio investment (FPI) are the major components of the capital account. Net capital inflows declined to US$ 29.0 billion in H1FY23 driven by the FPI outflow of US$ 14.6 billion in Q1FY23. Net FDI inflows at US$ 20.0 billion in H1FY23 were comparable with US$ 20.3 billion in H1FY22. Gross FDI inflows were US$ 39.3 billion during Apr-Sep 2022.
Net Other Capital (including RDS), Net Banking Capital, Net Loans and Net Foreign Investment are the major components of capital account.

Computer Software and Hardware attracted the highest share of FDI equity inflow (23.4 per cent) followed by Services (15.4 per cent) and Trading (12.2 per cent). Gross FDI inflows were US$ 39.3 billion during Apr-Sep 2022.
Narrowing surplus in capital account due to global economic uncertainty.

headings: FDI inflow by top investing countries
Types of capital flows in H1FY23
explanations: Singapore with 37.0% share is the top investing country in FDI inflow, followed by Mauritius (12.1%), UAE (11.0%), and the USA (10.0%).

FPI flows turned positive in Q2FY23 despite net outflow of US$ 2.5 billion during April-December 2022 as against an outflow of US$ 0.6 billion a year ago due to repercussions of the Russia-Ukraine conflict and aggressive monetary policy tightening by the US Fed leading to global financial market volatility.

Banking capital reported higher net inflows of US$ 10.6 billion and short-term credit receipts rose to US$ 10.1 billion in H1FY23 due to global liquidity conditions tightening. Meanwhile, external commercial borrowings (ECBs) to India recorded net outflows of US$ 3.0 billion in H1FY23 as against net inflows of US$ 5.0 billion a year ago.

headings: Import Coverage of Foreign Currency Reserves in India
India's Balance of Payments (BOP) and Foreign Exchange Reserves
explanations: Adverse global economic situation put pressure on India's BoP in 2022. Rise in oil prices led to a widening of CAD, while US Fed policy tightening and strengthening of US dollar caused FPI outflows. Net financial inflows fell short of CAD, leading to depletion of foreign exchange reserves on BoP basis to the tune of US$ 25.8 billion in H1FY23 in contrast to accretion of US$ 63.1 billion in H1FY22. Huge valuation losses (US$ 48.9 billion) led to the net depletion of US$ 74.6 billion of reserves in nominal terms during the period.

India's foreign exchange reserves were at US$ 532.7 billion as of end-September 2022, covering 8.8 months of imports. The reserves augmented to US$ 562.7 billion as of end-December 2022, covering 9.3 months of imports. As of end-November 2022, India was the sixth largest foreign exchange reserves holder in the world according to data compiled by the IMF. The import coverage of foreign currency reserves in India has increased from 95% in Q4 2019 to 96.5% in Q3 2022, which is higher than most emerging market economies.

Import coverage of foreign currency reserves in India has increased from 95% in Q4 2019 to 96.5% in Q3 2022. This is higher than most emerging market economies. Box XI.2 discusses some aspects of the literature on what constitutes adequate forex reserves for a country.

The figure XI.15 shows the adequacy of India's forex reserves (as a percentage of annual imports) in a cross-country perspective. India's foreign exchange reserves have covered around 90% to 100% of its annual imports in recent years. RBI data also shows that India's BoP balance has been mostly in surplus since 2019-20, and the foreign exchange reserves have been adequate to cover the CAD.

The figure shows India's BoP balance and import cover as a percent of GDP and in US$ Billion. The import cover of foreign exchange reserves has increased from 8.8 months of imports in September 2022 to 9.3 months in December 2022, which indicates adequate reserves. The BoP balance has been in surplus since 2019-20, although it has declined from the peak of US$ 634 billion in 2020-21 to an estimated US$ 533 billion in 2022-23. Capital account inflows have been strong, which has helped cover the CAD.

headings: International Benchmarks for Adequate Reserve Levels
Global Trends in Foreign Exchange Reserves
explanations: The external sector plays a significant role in maintaining a stable economy. This section focuses on the adequacy of foreign exchange reserves as a critical component of the external sector. The section offers insights and answers key questions related to the assessment of adequate levels of foreign exchange reserves, factors to consider when determining reserve thresholds, and how to ensure reserve liquidity.

Foreign Exchange Reserves (FERs) are essential for maintaining exchange rates within a certain range, ensuring liquidity, and serving as a buffer against adverse economic shocks. Achieving optimal levels of reserve empowers governments to maximize the welfare of the representative consumer while ensuring effective management of debt rollover crises. Conventionally, there are three measures of adequacy of reserves: ratios of reserves to imports, to monetary aggregates, and measures of external debt (IMF, 2000).

Determining the critical threshold levels of adequate reserves is influenced by various factors that include the country's monetary and exchange rate policies, goals, and precautionary measures. According to a recent study by Arslan Yavuz et al. (2019), the drivers behind reserve accumulation have evolved from initially being precautionary to currently focusing on monetary and exchange rate policies.

Conventionally, the traditional approach for determining the adequacy of reserves was to maintain a reserve level of three months of imports or full cover of short-term debt. However, there is little empirical support for whether the adequate coverage should be three months, as opposed to say two or six (IMF, 2011). The Guidotti–Greenspan-IMF rule suggests a ratio of reserves-to-short term debt of one. The rationale is that countries' reserves should equal short-term external debt (one-year or less maturity), which translates to a reserve level that is adequate for immediate liquidity concerns.

The total foreign exchange reserves excluding gold for selected countries as presented in the table shows a rise in reserves for several countries, more so since the global financial crisis of 2008. The figures indicate that countries have invested heavily in growing their reserves as a buffer from external economic shocks. According to IMF, the world's total foreign exchange reserves grew from 4395.0 in 2005 to 12195.3 in 2019, representing an 88% change by 2021.

headings: Optimal Size and Currency Composition of FERs
explanations: Reserve adequacy is the amount of foreign exchange reserves (FER) that an economy needs to have on hand to cope with the withdrawal of short-term foreign capital. Different indicators are used to assess the requirements of FERs for an economy, and adequate reserve levels should be considered against total resources available to meet shocks.

While foreign exchange reserves are important in preventing crises and mitigating their impact, they come at a cost. The costs borne by an economy for holding FER include opportunity cost, loss due to the value reduction in the denominated FER, and the social cost of FER which Rodrik (2006) finds amounts to close to one per cent of GDP.

Fukuda and Kon (2010) evaluate the macroeconomic impact of reserve accumulation and find evidence that an increase in foreign exchange reserves (FER) raises external debt outstanding but shortens debt maturity. Further, in the long-run, consumption declines, and exports are promoted by encouraging a switch from the non-tradable sector to the tradable sector through higher investment and growth.

An economy should organise its reserves FER, in terms of the optimal size and currency composition, considering the benefits, costs, and impacts of holding them. The dominant factors influencing the currency composition of FERs are the co-movement of the domestic currency with key currencies and the currency invoicing of trade (Ito, 2019); trade flows, financial flows, and currency pegs (Eichengreen, 2000). The Value at Risk (VaR) approach has also been employed to arrive at the optimal foreign exchange portfolio (Hung et al. (2008)).
The rich literature on reserve adequacy presents useful background information and empirical analysis for policy choices and likely outcomes.

Arslan, Yavuz and Cantú, Carlos (2019), “The size of foreign exchange reserves”, BIS Papers No 104. Chiou, J-S., Hung, J-C, and Hseu, M-M. (2008), “A VaR Investigation of Currency Composition in Foreign Exchange Reserves”, International Research Journal of Finance and Economics, 21, 76-92.

headings: Exchange rates Moving in tandem with Global developments
explanations: The external sector plays a crucial role in the stability and growth of an economy. Research studies have explored the impact of reserve accumulation, foreign exchange reserve composition, and inflation rates on the external sector. The International Monetary Fund has developed indicators like Debt- and Reserve-Related Indicators of External Vulnerability and Assessing Reserve Adequacy to assess the external vulnerability of economies. The optimal level of international reserves for emerging market countries has been studied, and empirical studies have been conducted on the impact of foreign exchange reserves and inflation rates on the economies.

The exchange rate of a currency is a crucial parameter that affects the external sector of an economy. The exchange rate of the Indian Rupee is market-determined, and the RBI intervenes mainly to contain volatility. On a financial year and a calendar year basis, the Indian Rupee has depreciated against the US dollar, and the US dollar index has appreciated. However, the external value of INR vis-à-vis the US dollar has seen very orderly movements during the year since the onset of the current geopolitical crisis. The INR has appreciated against select major currencies barring the US dollar, such as the Pound Sterling, Japanese Yen, and Euro.

headings: Index of 6-currency and 40-currency nEEr and rEEr
explanations: The figure xI.16 displays the exchange rate of the Indian rupee against major currencies like the US Dollar, Pound Sterling, Japanese Yen, and Euro. The data is sourced from RBI. It is important to note that the exchange rate for Japanese Yen is mentioned in Rupees per 100 Yen.

Cross-country comparisons of exchange rate movements are often made on an inflation-adjusted basis or what is called in real effective terms, viz. the Real Effective Exchange Rate (REER). The INR depreciated 3.4% and 4.0% in terms of 6-currency and 40-currency trade-weighted indices, respectively, between April 2022 and December 2022. Even in real terms, the INR witnessed modest depreciation in the face of global spill-overs.

The data from xI.17 titled 'Movement of Index of 6-currency and 40-currency nEEr and rEEr (trade-based weight)' displays the movement of the Index of 6-currency and 40-currency NEER (trade-based weight) where the base year is 2015-16. NEER is the weighted average of bilateral nominal exchange rates of the home currency in terms of foreign currencies, weights being based on the average of India's bilateral trade (exports plus imports) with countries/regions represented by the 6/40 currencies during the preceding three years. The REER, defined as a weighted average of nominal exchange rates adjusted for relative price differentials between the domestic and foreign countries, relates to the PPP hypothesis.

headings: India's International Investment Position in Sept 2022
explanations: The international investment position (IIP) is a statistical statement that shows at a point in time the value and composition of (a) financial assets of residents of an economy that are claims on non-residents and gold bullion held as reserve assets, and (b) liabilities of residents of an economy to non-residents. The difference between an economy’s external financial assets and liabilities is the economy’s net IIP, which may be positive or negative.

The Net IIP position determines whether a country is a net creditor or debtor nation by measuring the difference in its external assets and liabilities. These statistics serve as an indicator of a country’s financial condition and soundness. The Net IIP, along with the BoP transactions, reflects the domestic economy’s set of international accounts. For India, as of end-September 2022, Indian residents’ overseas financial assets at US$ 847.5 billion were lower by US$ 73.0 billion or 7.9 per cent compared to the level as of end-March 2022, mainly due to the reduction in reserve assets even as trade credit and overseas direct investment recorded an increase. Reserve assets at US$ 532.7 billion, accounting for around 62.9 per cent of India’s international financial assets fell by 12.3 per cent over the same period. International liabilities at US$ 1,237.1 billion as of end-September 2022 were lower by US$ 41.6 billion (3.2 per cent) as compared to the level as of end-March 2022. This fall was attributed primarily to direct investment (net) outflows, while variations in the exchange rate of the rupee vis-a-vis other currencies also had an impact on the change in liabilities when valued in US$ terms. The share of debt liabilities in total external liabilities was 50 per cent as of end-September 2022. Thus, the net claims of non-residents on India, valued at US$ 389.6 billion as of end-September 2022, increased by US$ 31.4 billion over the level as of end-March 2022. India’s international financial assets covered 68.5 per cent of international financial liabilities as of end-September 2022.

India's net International Investment position in end-September 2022 was -388 US$ Billion which is 16.4% of GDP. This is a decrease when compared to end-March 2022 which was -390 US$ Billion and 11.5 % of GDP. The asset liabilities ratio was 68.5 %. Countries with a positive Net IIP are net creditors to the rest of the world, while countries with a negative Net IIP are net debtors to the rest of the world. The Net IIP to GDP ratio serves as an important indicator of a country’s global economic integration and financial stability.

IMF, Balance of Payments and International Investment Position Manual, sixth edition (BPM6), is a manual that sets the standards for the compilation of balance of payments (BoP) and International Investment Position (IIP) statistics. The BPM6 focuses on current and capital transactions that comprise the BoP and on stock positions and valuations of financial assets and liabilities that comprise the IIP.

headings: Sovereign External Debt and Non-Sovereign External Debt
explanations: India's external debt stood at US$ 610.5 billion as of end-September 2022 which grew by 1.3 per cent (US$ 7.6 billion) over US$ 602.9 billion as of end-September 2021. External debt as a ratio to GDP fell to 19.2 per cent as of end-September 2022 from 20.3 per cent a year ago. The literature documents that the optimal threshold for India’s external debt is around 23-24 per cent of GDP. India has the potential growth positive space as far as the external debt level is concerned. India's external debt is denominated in the US dollar (55.5 per cent as at-September 2002) and the Indian rupee-denominated component (30.2 per cent) occupies the second largest position, insulating the external debt from foreign currency risk, thereby augmenting stability friendly characteristics of the external debt.

As of end-September 2022, India's long-term debt was lower at US$ 478.7 billion as compared to US$ 498.1 billion a year ago with the share of long-term debt falling to 78.4 per cent from 82.8 per cent during the same period. On the other hand, the short-term debt at US$ 131.7 billion as of end-September 2022 was higher than US$ 104.8 billion as of end-September 2021. Accordingly, the share of short-term debt in total debt went up to 21.6 per cent from 17.4 per cent. About 97 per cent of short-term debt is in the form of trade credit to finance imports and hence the rise in short-term debt is stability-friendly.

As of end-September 2022, Sovereign External Debt (SED) amounted to US$ 124.5 billion, decreasing by 5.7 per cent over the level a year ago. Non-SED, estimated at US$ 486.0 billion as of end-September 2022, posted a growth of 3.2 per cent over the level a year ago. Deposit-taking Corporations (except the Central Bank) and non-financial corporations accounted for the bulk of non-SED. The Ministry of Finance’s “India’s External Debt: A Status Report 2019-20”, provides details of the evolution of India’s external debt.

A discernible trend in the rise in external debt of the non-sovereign sector over the SED is seen since FY99. Typically, in a normal year, it is the relative movements in non-SED that influences the dynamics of the country’s external debt. In the pandemic year of FY21, it was the growth in SED that accounted for a larger share of the overall growth of foreign debt due to Covid-19 loans from multilateral institutions. As the pandemic receded and normalcy was restored with the revival of the economy, the usual dynamics of India’s external debt returned as the growth in non-SED constituted as much as 4.7 percentage points out of the overall external debt growth of 8.0 per cent at end-March 2022. However, the quarter ending September 2022, yet again witnessed deviation from the usual dynamics. It was the relative growth in SED (akin to the pandemic year) that influenced the overall external debt dynamics on the back decline in external assistance as well as other government debt which includes FPI investment in G-Sec and SDR. Out of the overall decline in India’s external debt by 0.4 per cent, the fall in the SED was 0.5 per cent, while the rise in non-SED was 0.2 per cent.

headings: India's Debt Vulnerability Compared to Peer Countries
explanations: India’s external debt vulnerability indicators continued to be benign. External debt as a ratio to GDP at 19.2 per cent as of end-September 2022 was lower than 19.9 per cent as of end-March 2022. The debt service ratio (principal repayments plus interest payments) stood at 5.0 per cent vis-à-vis 5.2 per cent as of end-March 2022.

Comparing various debt vulnerability indicators of India with peer countries for 2021 informs that the country is in a better position in terms of relatively low levels of total debt as a percentage of Gross National Income (GNI) and short-term debt as a percentage of total debt. The current stock of external debt is well shielded by the comfortable level of foreign exchange reserves.

The table xI.3 provides information on external debt outstanding in different sectors and instruments as of September 2021, June 2022, and September 2022. The table also shows the absolute and percentage variation of debt outstanding for different periods.

Gross External Debt (I to V) as a percentage of GDP was 602.9 (20.3%), 612.7 (19.3%), and 610.5 (19.2%) in September 2021, June 2022, and September 2022, respectively. The percentage variation of Gross External Debt over different periods is also provided in the table xI.3.
Table xI.3 also provides information on total long-term debt, short-term debt, and their absolute and percentage variation over different periods.

headings: Trend of India's Key External Debt Indicators from 2017-2022
explanations: The table xI.4 shows India's key external debt indicators. These indicators include external debt, ratio of external debt to GDP, debt service ratio, ratio of foreign exchange reserves to total debt, ratio of concessional debt to total debt, ratio of short-term debt (original maturity) to foreign exchange reserves, and ratio of short-term debt (original maturity) to total debt. These indicators are expressed in percentages unless otherwise indicated.

The table xI.4 shows the trend of India's key external debt indicators from 2017-2022. The indicators include external debt, ratio of external debt to GDP, debt service ratio, ratio of foreign exchange reserves to total debt, ratio of concessional debt to total debt, ratio of short-term debt (original maturity) to foreign exchange reserves, and ratio of short-term debt (original maturity) to total debt. The data indicates that India's external debt has been increasing over the years while the ratio of external debt to GDP has been fluctuating between 19.8% to 21.2%. The debt service ratio has been decreasing from 8.3% in 2017 to 5.2% in 2022 (partially revised). The ratio of foreign exchange reserves to total debt has also been fluctuating between 76.0% to 100.6%. The ratio of concessional debt to total debt has been decreasing from 9.4% in 2017 to 8.3% in 2022 (partially revised). The ratio of short-term debt (original maturity) to foreign exchange reserves has been fluctuating between 17.5% to 24.7%. The ratio of short-term debt (original maturity) to total debt has been fluctuating between 17.6% to 21.6%.

The figure xI.19 shows the debt ratios for a cross-country comparison for 2021. The countries included in the comparison are China, India, Philippines, Russian Federation, Indonesia, Brazil, Vietnam, and Mexico. The debt ratios depicted in the graph include short-term debt as a percentage of total debt, foreign exchange reserves as a percentage of total debt, and total external debt as a percentage of GNI. The graph indicates that China has the lowest total external debt as a percentage of GNI while Indonesia has the highest. Russia has the lowest percentage of short-term debt as a percentage of total debt while the Philippines has the highest. Vietnam has the highest percentage of foreign exchange reserves as a percentage of total debt while Brazil has the lowest.

headings: Impact of Global Growth on India's Exports
Market Share Gains through Efficiency, Productivity, Technology, and Innovation
Innate Buffers to India's External Sector
explanations: India's external sector outlook is cautious amidst global headwinds.

Global growth has a significant impact on India's real exports but the impact has reduced over the years. With global growth expected to slow down in 2022 and 2023, India's export outlook may remain flat.
Product basket and destination diversification, which India is taking through FTAs, would be useful to enhance trade opportunities during times when global growth is not growing.

Export growth will have to come predominantly through market share gains during times when global growth is not growing. That comes from the focus on efficiency, productivity, technology, and innovation.

India is facing competition from South Asian countries, especially in the textile sector. However, India has the potential to cater to the global demand for several products in a cost-effective manner due to the benefits of the lower average age of the working population along with the advantage of economies of scale.

The recent softening in crude oil prices augurs well for India's POL imports. Non-oil, non-gold imports, which are growth-sensitive, may not witness a significant slowdown as Indian growth continues to be resilient.

India's export of services, primarily contributed by software, business, and travel services, remains robust and embodies a greater degree of resilience. Inward remittances are projected to be at record levels during 2022. Net FDI flows remained robust during the current year and the net FPI inflows turned positive in recent months. The forex reserves remained comfortable at US$ 562.7 billion as of end-December 2022, covering 9.3 months of imports. The stock of India’s external debt has been prudently managed.

headings: Challenges Faced by India's External Sector
explanations: India's external sector has fared relatively better and positioned relatively stronger to face the evolving adverse global scenario as evidenced by the Indian rupee outperforming most EME currencies, comfortable import cover and moderate CAD. India's external debt vulnerability indicators are benign by international standards.
India's external sector does face challenges, but it is performing relatively better as compared to many of its peers as it has inbuilt shock absorbers to weather them.

The invention of the wheel and the need for travelable paths gave birth to the infrastructure development over time. India has been consistently building assets required by the nation across sectors since Independence. Infrastructure development has expanded across transportation, housing, commercial development, telecom, and sanitation. The government has pushed development in the remotest areas of India, expanding physical transportation, deepening digital penetration and providing services to point-of-use.

In 2019, the Government of India adopted a forward-looking programmatic approach towards infrastructure development. The National Infrastructure Pipeline is a comprehensive view of infrastructure development in the country. It has a projected investment of around ₹111 lakh crore for FY20-25. It enables monitoring of infrastructure progress at the highest levels of the government to ensure timely completion. Private participation in running risk-free brownfield assets helps in generating critical financial resources and ushering in operational efficiencies.

Funding for infrastructure comes from various sources. The government and private sector are involved, as well as multilateral institutions. To attract funding, a creative financing option such as asset monetisation was also envisaged through the 5 lakh crore National Monetisation Pipeline. Structural and financial reforms such as infrastructure financing options of InvITs and REITs, creation of Dedicated Financing Institution (NaBFID), recapitalisation of other sectoral DFIs, push to PPP ecosystem through Model Concession Agreements by line ministries and enabling social infrastructure development through the revamped Viability Gap Funding scheme have been implemented.

PM GatiShakti has sectoral complementarity of logistics facilitation through the National Logistics Policy launched in Sept 2022. It aims to bring in further convergence with comprehensive planning across centre and states.

Infrastructure is a melange of numerous sectors, and its multiplier effects in the economy cannot be realised if it operates in silos. The programmatic approach to infrastructure is expected to tighten the nuts and bolts for the arduous infrastructure journey that India has undertaken together by the Physical and digital infrastructure, lifting potential growth.

headings: Innovation in technology and digital connectivity by the public sector
explanations: India has seen unprecedented expansion in its infrastructure development in the last eight years. The focus has been on multi-modal transportation, modernisation, digital and communication development, and asset monetisation. The public sector has played a dominant role in innovation and implementation. The country is now moving towards providing more e-governance services to achieve its vision of a $1 trillion digital economy by 2025.

India has made significant progress in moving from unimodal to multi-modal transportation, with roads, railways, waterways, ports, and airports being substantially upgraded. The private sector has been encouraged to invest and reinvest in these assets, thanks to the policy of asset monetisation. The result has been a window of opportunity for the private sector.

India has made notable progress in its digital and communication development, with a strong emphasis on usability, interoperability, and accessibility. The country has come a long way from a time when a basic telephone connection was viewed as a luxury to a stage where most individuals have a mobile connection. The success of the Aadhar number has enabled the targeted beneficiary identification for various benefits, provision of healthcare and education services, and financial inclusion. The country has also seen a great multiplier effect on social and economic growth through the different uses of digital enablement led by the humble mobile phone. The success story of India’s sui-generis payment infrastructure (UPI) has travelled internationally with select adoption and global acclaim. The bouquet of digital public infrastructure products like e-rupi, e-way bill, TReDS for MSMEs etc have ensured real value for money to consumers while reducing the compliance burden for producers. With the vision of $1 trillion digital economy by 2025, the government is marching towards providing more and more e-governance based services. Empowering the end-users with control over their data is an essential ongoing task that is guided by the Account Aggregator framework.

India has been one of the few countries where innovation in technology and digital connectivity has been and continues to be led by the public sector. The success of UPI, a common platform that serves as the backbone for diverse developments, has prompted government to task itself with another innovative attempt towards democratising digital commerce through the ONDC which could potentially transform how businesses and consumers interact at present.

headings: Initiatives taken by the Indian Government for infrastructure development
Empirical evidence on the effect of infrastructure on Indian economy
explanations: India being the world's fifth-largest economy has a bright prospect for steady progress in the coming years. High-quality infrastructure investment is crucial for accelerating economic growth and sustaining it in the long run. Empirical evidence suggests that infrastructure has a salutary effect on the productivity and efficiency of Indian manufacturing firms, poverty reduction promoting rural and agricultural development.

The quantity and quality of infrastructure and the level of economic development across countries are strongly correlated, as per the World Bank, Global Infrastructure Hub, and World Economic Forum Global Competitiveness Index. This correlation emphasizes the crucial role played by infrastructure in economic growth.

During the times of pandemic and geo-political crisis, the Indian Government focused on reforms in areas of physical, digital, and regulatory infrastructure to increase the private sector's participation in creating new infrastructure and developing existing ones. The government took initiatives like Public-Private Partnership (PPP), National Infrastructure Pipeline (NIP), and National Monetisation Pipeline (NMP).

In a broad sense, the term infrastructure refers to the physical facilities, institutions and organizational structures, or the social and economic foundations for the operation of the society. The present context focuses on emerging issues in the context of physical and digital infrastructure.

Empirical evidence suggests that infrastructure has a positive effect on overall economic growth in India. Mitra, Varoudakis, and Véganzonès‐Varoudakis in their study on productivity and technical efficiency in Indian states' manufacturing concluded that infrastructure plays a significant role, while Dutt and Ravallion's study shows that infrastructure reduces rural poverty. Binswanger, Khandker, and Rosenzweig's study suggests that agriculture output and investment increases with improved infrastructure and financial institutions. Similarly, Fan, Hazell, and Thorat's study indicates that government spending on infrastructure leads to growth and poverty reduction in rural India. Sahoo and Dash's study showed that infrastructure development has a positive effect on economic growth in India.

The Indian government has launched various reforms related to infrastructure investment and project execution through initiatives like Shakti and National Logistics Policy (NLP). The government is also investing in traditional infrastructure, such as roads, railways, airports, ports, mass transport, and waterways to promote national integration and regional development. Multi-modal transport systems have been put in place to provide seamless connectivity between different modes of transportation, reducing travel time and logistics costs while promote export competitiveness. The development of underutilized modes of infrastructure has significant potential.

In addition to physical infrastructure development, digitization and innovation have emerged as a critical driver of economic growth. The pandemic has accelerated adoption, application, and coverage of digital services that have led to substantial improvements in financial inclusion. In 2009, only 17% of adults in India had bank accounts, 15% used digital payments, 1 in 25 had a unique ID document, and about 37% had mobile phones. Today, tele density has reached up to 93%, more than a billion people have a digital ID document, over 80% have bank accounts, and over 600 crore of digital payment transactions are completed each month. This transformation has allowed India to offer best practices in digital infrastructure innovation that can be emulated globally.

India has emerged as one of the world's most vibrant destinations for start-up ecosystems. Start-ups are seen as the spine of the new India, as they encourage young people to become job creators rather than job seekers. India has the highest FinTech adoption rate of 87% among the public compared to the global average of 64%. The fintech market in India was worth $31 billion in 2021, making it the third-largest in the world after the US and China. Indian start-ups have also had significant success in digital payments and other digital services, offering valuable lessons for other countries.

headings: Government’s Vision and Approaches to Infrastructure Development in India
Government’s Leverage of Digital Technologies in Public Services
Co-ordination and Efficiency in Infrastructure Projects
explanations: Physical and digital infrastructure play a significant role in the growth potential of the Indian economy. The rollout of 5G services can open the doors for traditional and new-age sectors while the development of a world-class FinTech Hub at Gujarat International Finance Tec-City holds significant growth potential for FinTechs in India.

The government aims to place India among the top three global economies by enhancing capital expenditure, which plays a crucial role in the potential growth of the economy. The outlay for capital expenditure in 2022-23 (BE) was increased by 35.4% from the previous year, and approximately 67% has been spent from April to December 2022.

With increased penetration of smartphones and digitization, the government has leveraged digital technologies in providing public services. The introduction of digital infrastructure has transformed the country and the government's vision towards infrastructure development is to advance the 'Digital India' vision.

The chapter addresses how the government has been able to determine the role of coordination and efficiency in infrastructure projects. The government's plan is to place India among the top three global economies and inch closer to the status of a developed nation by the 100th year of its Independence.

headings: National Bank for Financing Infrastructure and Development (NaBFID)
explanations: Capex spending of ministries/departments have increased by 67% compared to last year till December 2022 achieving 5 lakh crore against the budgeted Capex of 7.5 lakh crore.
