The steady increase in public capital expenditure supports economic growth and lays the foundation for future growth. It can also crowd in private investment, as capacity utilization in the private sector has been recovering.
NIP provides the necessary impetus for stepping up infrastructure investment.
NMP would provide the much-needed impetus for stepping up infrastructure investment.

NLP will address the gaps in services, digital infrastructure and skills in the logistics workforce. PM GatiShakti, with a multimodal approach, is designed to fill the gaps in physical infrastructure and to integrate existing and proposed infrastructure development.
NaBFID is a development financial institution to set in motion a virtuous investment cycle by providing the necessary support to physical infrastructure during its long gestation period.
PDCs have been created in all concerned ministries/departments of the Government of India to fast-track investments through institutional mechanism.
The government's vision for infrastructure includes advanced infrastructure that is energy-efficient, incorporates the idea of a circular economy, and transitions towards low-carbon development.
PPPs are vital instruments for governments to channel the strength of the private sector in critical areas of infrastructure. Private investment in infrastructure is mainly in the form of PPPs.

Private participation in infrastructure programs in India supports several PPP models, including BOT, DBFOT, ROT, HAM, and TOT models. Under the BOT model, there are two variants – BOT (Toll) and BOT (Annuity) depending on who bears the traffic risk.

headings: Viability Gap Funding (VGF) scheme for PPP projects
India Infrastructure Project Development Fund Scheme (IIPDF)
Traffic risk borne by PPP concessionaire or public authority
explanations: The Public Private Partnership Appraisal Committee (PPPAC) is the apex body for appraisal of PPP projects in the Central Sector. It has streamlined appraisal mechanism to ensure speedy appraisal of projects, eliminate delays, adopt international best practices and have uniformity in appraisal mechanism and guidelines. The PPPAC is chaired by Secretary, Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) with Secretaries of Department of Expenditure, Department of Legal Affairs, the Sponsoring Ministry/Department and CEO, NITI Aayog as members to consider and appraise the proposals for Central Sector PPP Projects. The Public Private Partnership Appraisal Committee has cleared 79 projects with a total project cost of ₹2,27,268.1 crore from FY15 to FY23.

To provide financial assistance to financially unviable but socially/ economically desirable PPP projects, DEA launched the Viability Gap Funding (VGF) scheme in 2006. Economic sector projects may get up to 40 per cent of Capex as VGF grant. The Scheme includes higher provisions of VGF grant for social sectors. Social sectors may get up to 80 per cent of the Capex and up to 50 per cent of the Operating Expenditure (Opex) for five years after Commercial Operation Date (CoD) as VGF grant. Social Sector projects get VGF under two categories: Sub Scheme-1 and Sub-Scheme-2. Sub-Scheme-1 caters to social sectors such as wastewater treatment, water supply, solid waste management etc. The projects under this category should have at least 100 per cent Operational Cost recovery. The Government of India (GoI) will provide a maximum of 30 per cent of Capex and the State Government concerned may provide an additional support of up to 30 per cent of Capex. Sub-scheme 2 supports demonstration/pilot projects from Health & Education sectors. The projects eligible under this category should have at least 50 per cent Operational Cost recovery.  The GoI will provide a maximum of 40 per cent of the Capex of the project and a maximum of 25 per cent of the Opex of the project for the first five years of commercial operations as VGF. From 2014-15 to 2022-23, under the VGF Scheme, 56 projects with TPC of ₹57870.1 crore were granted In-Principle Approval and 27 projects with TPC of ₹25263.8 crore were granted final approval with a Total Viability Gap Funding approval of ₹5813.6 crore (Both GoI & State Share). The GoI share of approved VGF is ₹3102.6 crore and the State Share of Total VGF approved is ₹2710.9 crore. The total VGF amount disbursed by DEA under the scheme from FY15 to FY23 is ₹2982.4 crore.

A scheme for financial support for project development expenses of PPP Projects – the ‘India Infrastructure Project Development Fund Scheme’ (IIPDF) – was notified by the government on 3 November 2022. The aim of the scheme is to develop quality PPP projects by providing necessary funding support to the project-sponsoring authorities, both in the Central and State Governments, for creating a shelf of bankable, viable PPP projects by on-boarding transaction advisers. IIPDF Scheme has a total outlay of ₹150 crore for a period of 3 years from FY23 to FY25. Under the scheme, a maximum amount of ₹5 crore for a single proposal, inclusive of any tax implications, can be funded, which can include the cost of consultants/transaction advisers of a PPP project. Any funding requirement over and above ₹5 crore may be borne by the project sponsoring authority itself, and funding under IIPDF shall not be recovered.
In the case of Toll projects, the traffic risk is borne by the PPP concessionaire, while in the case of BOT (Annuity), it is borne by the public authority.

The National Infrastructure Pipeline (NIP) is a government initiative that aims to provide high quality infrastructure across the country. The NIP has a projected infrastructure investment of around ₹111 lakh crore during FY20-25 for more than 8,964 greenfield and brownfield projects with a total investment of more than ₹108 lakh crore under different stages of implementation. The transport sector constitutes more than half of the projects. The NIP is hosted on the Invest India Grid (IIG) platform, which acts as a centralised portal to track and review project progress across all economic and social infrastructure sub-sectors.

The transportation sector is the dominant sector in the National Infrastructure Pipeline (NIP), constituting more than 50% of the projects. The NIP covers infrastructure projects of more than ₹100 crore in greenfield and brownfield investments. The NIP is hosted on the Invest India Grid (IIG) platform, which acts as a centralised portal to track and review project progress across all economic and social infrastructure sub-sectors.

The Invest India Grid (IIG) platform hosts the National Infrastructure Pipeline (NIP) and provides opportunities for States/UTs and Ministries to collate all major infrastructure projects at a single location. The IIG enables project-sponsoring authorities to showcase investment opportunities to national and international investors. The IIG acts as a centralised portal to track and review project progress across all economic and social infrastructure sub-sectors.

The Project Monitoring Group (PMG) is an institutional mechanism put in place by the government for resolution of issues related to large-scale projects. PMG is also involved in the fast-tracking of approvals/clearances.

headings: Monetisation process and key Asset classes
explanations: The NIP (National Infrastructure Pipeline) is being proposed to be integrated with PMG (Project Monitoring Group) portals. This will make NIP the first entry point for all infrastructure projects costing ₹100 crore or more, while PMG portal will pick up data (project cost of  ₹500 crore or more) from the NIP database. This integration will save time and effort while monitoring large infrastructure projects by Ministries and States/UTs.

The National Monetisation Pipeline (NMP) was announced on 23 August 2021, as the need for scaling up infrastructure investment despite fiscal pressures from Covid-19 pandemic required unlocking capital from various projects across sectors. It follows the principle of ‘asset creation through monetisation’ and taps private sector investment. Private players are expected to operate and maintain the assets. NMP provides an opportunity to deleverage balance sheets and provide fiscal space for new infrastructure assets while it provides an estimated aggregate monetisation potential under NMP is ₹6.0 lakh crore through core assets of the Central Government over FY20-25.

The process of monetisation entails a limited period license/ lease of an asset owned by the government or a public authority to a private sector entity for upfront or periodic consideration. Funds received by the public authority are reinvested in new infrastructure or deployed for other public purposes. NMP contains 20+ asset classes across 12+ line ministries/departments. The top 5 sectors (by estimated value) capture around 83 per cent of the aggregate pipeline value with roads (27 per cent) followed by railways (25 per cent), power (15 per cent), oil & gas pipelines (8 per cent), and telecom (6 per cent).

Against the monetisation target of ₹0.9 lakh crore in FY22, ₹0.97 lakh crore have been achieved under roads, power, coal and mines. The cumulative investment potential over the years of transactions completed is estimated at ₹9.0 lakh crore (value captured in the form of accruals, receipts, and/or private investment). NMP’s 2nd year, i.e., FY23, target envisaged is ₹1.6 lakh crore (27 per cent of overall NMP Target) under Core-Asset Monetisation.

India aims to increase its exports manifold, and reducing logistics costs is vital to achieving this goal. Logistics costs in India have been in the range of 14-18 per cent of GDP against the global benchmark of 8 per cent. Key aspects to be addressed to improve logistics for trade include: ensuring the efficiency of the clearance process, improving the quality of trade and transport-related infrastructure, easing competitively priced shipments, and enhancing the competence and quality of logistics services.

headings: Logistics Ease Across Different States (LEADS) Index
explanations: LPI is a measure developed by World Bank to track and trace consignments and ensure timely delivery. It is a measure of efficiency in logistics.
The Government of India has introduced several infrastructure initiatives such as UDAN, Bharatmala, Sagarmala, Parvatamala, and National Rail Plan to improve the logistics ecosystem.
To improve the logistics ecosystem, the Indian government has introduced several process reforms, such as GST, e-Sanchit, SWIFT, ICEGATE, and Turant Customs.

NLP is an interdisciplinary, cross-sectoral, and multi-jurisdictional framework launched by the Indian government to improve the logistics sector. It aims to develop a technologically enabled, integrated, cost-efficient, resilient, sustainable and trusted logistics ecosystem in the country for accelerated and inclusive growth.

The targets of NLP are to reduce the cost of logistics in India to be comparable to global benchmarks by 2030, improve the Logistics Performance Index ranking to be among the top 25 countries by 2030, and create a data-driven decision support mechanism for an efficient logistics ecosystem.

CLAP is the implementation plan for NLP that includes key action areas such as Integrated Digital Logistics Systems, standardisation of physical assets, Logistics Human Resources Development, State Engagement, EXIM Logistics, Service Improvement framework, Sectoral Plan for Efficient Logistics, and Facilitation of Development of Logistics Parks.

LEADS is a survey-based assessment initiated by the Indian government to gauge the logistics ecosystem of various States and UTs by analysing their business environments relating to the logistics infrastructure, policy framework, and regulatory regime.

LEADS survey report was released on 13 October 2022. The survey has garnered more than 6500 responses from more than 2100 respondents across the country. Unlike the previous versions of LEADS which were based on ranking systems for all states, LEADS 2022 has adopted a classification-based grading, and States have been now classified under four categories viz., coastal States, hinterland/landlocked States, North-Eastern States, and UTs for the assessment of how well a State or UT has performed in comparison to the top State/UT within the specific cluster. Taking a break from the past, states have not been ranked in order.

The states have been allotted three performance categories, namely, Achievers: States/UTs achieving a percentage score of 90 per cent or more, Fast Movers: States/UTs achieving percentage scores between 80 to 90 per cent, and Aspirers: States/UTs achieving percentage scores below 80 per cent.

The survey identified the top-performing states as Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, and Goa, followed by Tamil Nadu, Sikkim, Bihar, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Telangana, Tripura, and A&N Islands. The remaining states and UTs were classified as aspirers, fast movers, or achievers based on their scores.

The State LPI is arrived at using a ranking methodology for stakeholder engagement based on a series of meetings and online surveys in the key areas of logistics- infrastructure, services timelines, traceability, competitiveness, security, operating environments, and efficiency of regulation.

headings: GIS-based and data-driven decision support platform
explanations: PM GatiShakti is a national master plan introduced by the Government of India, which aims to create a common umbrella platform for all infrastructure projects pertaining to various ministries/departments to ensure efficient planning and implementation on a real-time basis. The master plan focuses on integrated planning and synchronised implementation across ministries/departments, with innovative use of technology. It is based on a data-driven decision support platform called PM GatiShakti National Master Plan. The touchstone of the Master Plan will be high quality modern infrastructure and logistics synergy among different modes of movement – both of people and of goods – and location of projects. This will help raise productivity, and accelerate economic growth and development.

This topic discusses the developments in the physical infrastructure sector in India. There has been an increase in the construction of National Highways (NHs)/roads over time, with 10,457 km of roads constructed in FY22 as compared to 6,061 km in FY16. In FY23, 4,060 km of NHs/roads were constructed until October 2022, which was around 91 per cent of the achievement in the corresponding period of the previous financial year. The total budgetary support for investment in the sector has been increasing rapidly in the last four years and stood at around ₹1.4 lakh crore during FY23 (as of 31 October 2022). The road infrastructure in the form of a network of national highways, state highways, district roads, rural roads, and urban roads acts as a major mode of transportation and connectivity for the country’s diverse population of consumers and businesses. Roads supplement the other modes of transport through last-mile connectivity to the far-flung regions of the country.

The GIS-based and data-driven decision support platform called PM GatiShakti National Master Plan has been introduced by the Government of India to facilitate integrated planning and coordinated implementation. Around 1950 data layers of 22 ministries/departments and 36 States/UTs were mapped up to the village, district, and taluka levels on the national master plan. It can be integrated with various applications of different ministries/agencies to prevent duplication of work and create a single window system for infrastructure planning. Data layers on important assets pertaining to health, education, culture, tourism, gram panchayats, municipal corporation, social welfare housing etc. are being mapped and data validation is being done for optimum use of PM GatiShakti principles in planning of both physical and social infrastructures. Use cases of GatiShakti National Master Plan include connectivity to model schools and disaster management planning etc.

headings: National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) InvIT
Budgetary Support for Investment in Road Sector
explanations: NHAI launched its InvIT in FY22 to monetise public sector assets and attract investors in the roads sector. It has raised more than ₹10,200 crore from foreign and Indian institutional investors so far.

National highways/road construction has increased since 2015-16, hitting unprecedented levels in 2020-21. The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways reported 5000 kilometers of road construction in April-Oct 2022.

Total budgetary support for investment in the road sector has tremendously increased from 2015-16 to 2022-23 (as of 31 October 2022). The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways reported Total Budgetary Support IEBR, Private Sector investment, and Total Investment.

Indian Railways is the fourth largest network in the world under single management. Passenger traffic has recovered from a dip in 2020-21, with 351.9 crore passengers in 2021-22 and 418.4 crore in 2022-23 (up to November). Freight traffic sustained and increased between FY20-21 and FY21-22.
Indian Railways carried 976.8 million tonnes of revenue-earning freight during FY22-23 (up to November 2022), reflecting the strong revival in economic activity in the domestic economy.

The railway passenger and freight traffic have shown strong growth post the COVID-19 period. In FY22-23, the railways handled 967.1 million tonnes of traffic (excluding KRCL11), as compared to 901.7 million tonnes during the corresponding period in FY21-22. This translated to an increase of 8.3%, as per the data provided by the Ministry of Railways. Similarly, the railway passenger traffic has also shown a steady growth in the past years. The data shows that the revenue earning freight traffic (excluding KRCL) was around 1415.9 crore in FY22-23 as compared to earlier years.

The capital expenditure on railway infrastructure has seen tremendous growth since 2014. In the last four years, the Capex (B.E.) of ₹2.5 lakh crore in FY23 has seen a continuous increase of around 29% compared to the previous year. In the current financial year, the Indian Railways has completed 2022 km of track kilometers (TKM), which includes 109 TKM of new line, 102 TKM of gauge conversion, and 1811 TKM of multi-tracking projects. From FY2014-22, across IR, 20,628 km sections have been commissioned, including 3,970 km of new line, 5,507 km of gauge conversion, and 11,151 km of doubling. Additionally, during the last eight years (2014-22), 30,446 Route Kilometers (RKM) have been electrified compared to an electrification of 4,698 RKM during the previous eight-year period.

The infrastructure capital expenditure on railways has seen tremendous growth in recent years. The data suggests that the average expenditure during 2014-19 has been significantly higher as compared to the period during 2009-14. The average expenditure during 2014-19 was around ₹99,178 crore, which was a 70% increase in average commissioning during 2009-14 (₹45,980 crore). Further, the data shows a continuous increase in the infrastructure capital expenditure in railways in FY19-20, FY20-21, FY21-22, and FY22-23.

The data regarding railway passenger and freight traffic, and Capex on infrastructure constitute the financial year data. The data for FY22-23 is till November 2022. The data presented in the tables and graphs is provided by the Ministry of Railways.

Indian Railways has been rapidly augmenting physical infrastructure with an increase in allocation of funds, delegation of powers at the field level and regular follow-up with state governments and relevant authorities. This has resulted in commissioning of doubling projects and reduced transit time and cost. Major physical infrastructure initiatives include Mumbai-Ahmedabad High Speed Rail (MAHSR) Project, Dedicated Freight Corridor (DFC) Project, GatiShakti Multi-Modal Cargo Terminal (GCT) and induction of semi-high-speed Vande Bharat Trainsets. Electrical/Electronic Interlocking System has been provided at 6,322 stations to enhance safety in train operations. Indian Railways also intends to develop a demonstrative project on Hyperloop Technology.

Indian Railways is rapidly developing digital infrastructure to improve passenger experience and enhance safety in train operations. Key digital initiatives include on-board infotainment and Global Positioning System (GPS) based passenger information system on semi-high-speed Vande Bharat Trainsets and envisaging centralized operation of points and signals through Electrical/Electronic Interlocking System. Indian Railways has also collaborated with IIT Madras for developing Hyperloop Technology by setting up Centre of Excellence for Hyperloop Technology.

Kisan Rail trains were introduced in FY21 to enable speedy movement of perishables from production or surplus regions to consumption or deficient regions. Up to 31 October 2022, Indian Railways have operated 2,359 Kisan Rail services, transporting approximately 7.91 lakh tonnes of perishables including fruits and vegetables.

In FY21, air traffic and passenger traffic handling saw a decline of 54% and 66% respectively due to Covid-19. However, in FY22 and FY23, there was a recovery in the domestic sector, with both passenger and cargo movement close to pre-Covid-19 levels. The Ministry of Civil Aviation supports this sector through schemes such as UDAN, which has considerably enhanced regional connectivity through the opening of airports in India’s hinterland.
Ports have been crucial to India's economy for ages. Recent governance reforms have helped to handle higher capacity in ports.

Ports handle around 90% of international trade cargo by volume and 79.9% by value. The capacity of major ports has increased from 871.5 Million Tonnes Per Annum (MTPA) to 1534.9 MTPA by March 2022. The government is working on improving port governance, addressing low-capacity utilisation, modernising berths with techno-efficient loading/unloading equipment, creating new channels for port connectivity, and digitising key EXIM processes for streamlining port compliances and reducing Turn Around Time for vessels.

India has a large endowment of rivers, canals, and other waterways with a total navigable length of around 14,850 kilometres. Inland water transport holds great untapped potential for the transportation of goods and passengers. The data shows navigable length of waterways for different states in India.

headings: Salient features of Inland Vessels Act 2021
explanations: Under the National Waterways Act 2016, 106 new waterways have been declared as National Waterways (NWs), taking the total number of NWs in the country to 111. Based on the outcome of techno-economic feasibility and Detailed Project Reports (DPRs), 26 NWs viable for cargo movement have been prioritised, out of which developmental activities have been initiated in the 14 most viable NWs. Further, to promote the use of inland waterways, waterway usage charges levied by the Inland Waterways Authority of India (IWAI) on vessels moving on NWs were waived in July 2020, initially for a period of three years. The cargo movement on National Waterways achieved an all-time high of 108.8 million tons during FY22, recording 30.1 per cent growth compared to the previous year.

The Inland Vessels Bill 2021, which replaced the over 100 year-old Inland Vessels Act, 1917 (Act No.1 of 1917), was passed by the Parliament in August 2021. This will usher in a new era for inland water transport sector and fulfil the vision to utilise the potential of multi-modal transport ecosystem while making the legislative framework user-friendly and promoting ease of doing business. The uniform application of rules and regulations will ensure seamless, quick, and cost-efficient trade and transportation by inland vessels using the inland waterways. Various sections of this Act as detailed in the box below have come into force in 2022.

The Inland Vessels Act 2021 aims to bring uniformity in the application of the law relating to inland waterways and navigation within the country. Some salient features of the Act include: State governments may declare by notification any inland water area as a “Zone”; any mechanically propelled vessel would have to obtain a certificate, which would indicate the zone in which the vessel is to be operated; a central database of inland vessels would be maintained by the government; the standards for qualification, training, training institutes, examination, and grant of certificate of competency would be prescribed by the Central Government; standards for prevention of environmental pollution; constitution of a Development Fund by the State Government to be utilised for meeting emergency preparedness, containment of pollution, removal of unidentified wrecks or obstruction, boosting development works of inland water navigation, etc. Overall, the new Act would lead to uniformity of rules across states ensuring unhindered and safe movement of vessels within and across states. This is likely to promote inland water transport as a potential mode for large-scale movement of cargo as well as passengers across the country owing to its relative cost effectiveness.

India's total installed power capacity of utilities and captive power plants have increased by 4.7% from 460.7 GW in 2021 to 482.2 GW in 2022, with utilities accounting for 399.5 GW of the capacity. Thermal sources of energy constitute 59.1% of the total installed capacity in utilities, followed by renewable energy resources with 27.5% and hydro with 11.7%.

India's total electricity generation, including that from captive plants, increased from 15.9 lakh GWh in FY21 to 17.2 lakh GWh in FY22, of which 14.8 lakh GWh was generated by utilities and 2.3 lakh GWh in captive plants. Maximum rise in electricity generation was recorded for renewable energy resources in utilities and for captive plants. India has put in place a target of achieving 50% cumulative installed capacity for generating electric power from non-fossil fuel-based energy resources by 2030.

The Indian government has been driving a vibrant renewable energy program aimed at achieving energy security and access, and reducing the carbon footprint of the national economy. Pradhan Mantri Kisan Urja Suraksha evam Utthaan Mahabhiyan (PM-KUSUM) aims to provide energy and water security to the farm sector and reduce its carbon footprint.

The Indian government is actively promoting the generation of renewable energy as a means to reduce carbon emissions. Various initiatives such as the Solar Park Scheme and the Hydropower Purchase Obligation have been introduced to encourage the private sector to invest in renewable energy generation. As of September 2022, the government has sanctioned the entire capacity of 40 GW for the development of 59 Solar Parks in 16 states. Indian Railways has also announced its intention to achieve net zero carbon emission by 2030 and has commissioned plants generating about 143 MW of solar power and about 103 MW of wind power.

The role of digital infrastructure in socio-economic development has assumed increased importance in recent years. The government's Digital India programme aims to transform India into a digitally empowered society and knowledge economy. The focus areas include the availability of high-speed internet, unique digital identity, enabling citizen participation in digital and financial space, shareable private space on a public cloud, and a safe and secure cyber-space.

The government's persistent efforts in promoting technological development have led to a significant increase in telecommunications services penetration. Today, the total telephone subscriber base in India stands at 117 crore, with more than 97% connected wirelessly. About 83.7 crore people have internet connections as of June 2022, and the overall tele-density in India stood at 84.8%. The government has helped widen the network bandwidth, allowing for telecom players to reach even the remotest corners of the country.

The data shows that Himachal Pradesh, Kerala, Punjab, Tamil Nadu, and Karnataka had a tele-density of above 100 per cent. However, there is disparity in tele-density between urban and rural areas. In rural areas, the tele-density continues to be at much lower levels compared to urban areas.

The YoY change in internet subscribers is greater in rural areas (for the majority of the states) than in urban areas, indicating a catch-up by the rural areas. This provided a cushion to the rural economy during the initial phase of the Covid-19 pandemic as many people went back to rural India for their livelihood.

The digital infrastructure created over the years ensured not just the continuous transmission of information but also added economic value when businesses went digital. The services like digital payments, e-governance, e-commerce, e-health, and e-education, acting as the backbone have boosted the overall economic growth of the country.

India has been able to contain the impact of the pandemic through structural reforms in several sectors, telecom being one of them. The telecommunication sector continued to provide seamless connectivity for the smooth functioning of critical activities and services such as ‘work from home’, ‘study from home’ etc. This was supported by the significant increase in affordable smartphones, which emerged as the key enabler of Digital India initiative with various new services and applications.

headings: Impact of Rural Growth on COVID-19 Pandemic
explanations: Digital India programme was launched in 2015 with the vision of developing digital infrastructure as a core utility for every citizen. The focus of this programme has been on bridging the gap between rural and urban internet penetration. This concrete focus on bridging the gap between rural and urban internet penetration has borne positive results. We have added more internet subscribers in rural areas in the last 3 years (2019-21) than in their urban counterparts (95.76 million vis-a-vis 92.81 million in rural and urban areas respectively).

BharatNet Project Scheme is a flagship government scheme aimed at providing high-speed broadband connectivity to rural areas of the country. It has been one of the key initiatives contributing to the growth of internet subscribers in rural areas. The success of this scheme has been a result of dedicated digital drives across rural areas through ambitious government schemes like the Telecom Development Plan, Aspirational District Scheme, initiatives in North-Eastern Region through Comprehensive Telecom Development Plan (CTDP) and initiatives towards areas affected by Left Wing Extremism (LWE).

There is a significant difference in the growth rates of internet subscribers in rural and urban areas across different LSAs. The steep transition from a negative gap in 2018 for most LSAs to above 50 per cent in positive territory (for a majority of LSAs) in 2019 reflects the demand side growth in digital services, which was backed by the availability of budget smartphones and affordable data usage. The difference has been positive since then.

The growth of internet subscribers in rural areas has been a major shock absorber during the COVID-19 pandemic when both businesses and consumer demand were impacted. When majority of the workforce reverse-migrated to rural areas in search of livelihoods, agriculture (3.4 per cent growth in FY20-21) as well as the world’s largest employment scheme MNREGA supported the domestic economy. The digital infrastructure created over the years in rural areas ensured transparent and timely payments to the beneficiaries directly into their account thus limiting their exposure to the virus. With affordability and accessibility to private education restricted, 12 per cent change in rural subscriptions and per cent change in urban subscriptions.

headings: Saturation of 4G Mobile Services in Uncovered Villages
Telecom Development Plan for North-Eastern Region
explanations: The government has been putting increased impetus into bringing rural and urban digital connectivity to the same level. Schemes like Production Linked Incentive (PLI) for telecom and networking products will promote domestic mobile manufacturing as well as network installation. The continuous proliferation of measures such as Bharat Net Project shall continue to improve accessibility, affordability, connectivity, and inclusivity pan-India.

A project for the saturation of 4G mobile services in uncovered villages across the country has been approved. The project will provide 4G mobile services in 24,680 uncovered villages in remote and difficult areas, and 6,279 villages having only 2G/3G connectivity shall be upgraded to 4G.

The government is implementing a Comprehensive Telecom Development Plan (CTDP) with a special focus on the states in the North-Eastern Region. Mobile connectivity on 2G is to be provided by setting up 2004 towers in the uncovered villages and along National Highways of Assam, Manipur, Mizoram, Nagaland, Tripura, Sikkim, and Arunachal Pradesh (National Highways only). Furthermore, to make available high-quality and high-speed internet access to the North-Eastern Region, Universal Service Obligation Fund (USOF) signed an Agreement with Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (BSNL) for the hiring of 10 Gigabits per second (Gbps) International Bandwidth for Internet Connectivity to Agartala from Bangladesh Submarine Cable Company Limited (BSCCL), Bangladesh.

The government’s initiative of the Comprehensive Telecom Development Plan for Islands has realised a comprehensive initiative to connect islands to the mainland. The Submarine OFC connectivity from Chennai to Andaman & Nicobar Islands (CANI) project was launched to connect Port Blair and seven other islands of Andaman & Nicobar Islands with Chennai through 2,313 km of underwater OFC.

The Indian government has launched several initiatives to promote the development of telecom infrastructure in the country. This includes the launch of several projects to improve submarine OFC connectivity and increase the availability of bandwidth. The government has also launched major reforms to promote the deployment of telegraph infrastructure and facilitate faster and easier deployment of telegraph infrastructure to enable speedy 5G rollout. Moreover, the Indian government is facilitating the rollout of satellite-based communication services with reforms that promote ease of doing business and streamline satellite-related clearance processes.

India has made significant progress in the deployment of 5G services, which could impact consumers directly through higher data transfer speeds and lower latency. Telecom Service Providers and start-ups in education, health, worker safety, smart agriculture etc., are now deploying 5G use cases across the country. Moreover, the Indian government has implemented several reforms, including the launch of the Indian Telegraph Right of Way (Amendment) Rules, 2022, to facilitate the speedy rollout of 5G services.

The National Frequency Allocation Plan 2022 (NFAP) provides a broad regulatory framework that identifies which frequency bands are available for cellular mobile services, Wi-fi, sound, and television broadcasting, radio navigation for aircraft and ships, and other wireless communications. NFAP will give guidance to the users of the spectrum to plan their networks in accordance with the relevant frequency and parameters provided therein. NFAP helps align spectrum usage with demands from emerging technologies in an efficient manner.

The Indian government launched the GatiShakti Sanchar portal in May 2022 to streamline the process of Right of Way (RoW) applications and permissions across the country. The portal has been developed keeping in view the vision areas of the National Broadband Mission to provide broadband infrastructure as a core utility to every citizen, governance and services on demand, and digital empowerment of the citizens of the country.

Radio continues to be one of the best media to reach all residents of the country, and the Indian government is focusing on its development to improve national digital connectivity. While telecom infrastructure development remains a key focus area, radio continues to contribute significantly to the dissemination of information across the country.

headings: Radio as a tool for outreach and social development
All India Radio as a public service broadcaster
Variety and popularity of radio programmes
explanations: Radio has persisted as a bulwark for outreach during the times of pandemic and beyond, and continues to be the most affordable and popular medium of mass communication in India. Its accessibility, wide coverage, variety of programmes, mobility and vernacularity have contributed to its popularity. In addition to the public broadcaster, private commercial radio stations (FM Radio) and Community Radio Stations (CRS) each serve as platforms for a variety of programmes. The growth in the number of private FM radio stations has been observed in recent years.

Prasar Bharati, India's autonomous public service broadcaster, has not only been witness to the history and landmark events of the country, but has also been the proverbial story-teller for all citizens across the country, standing by its motto ‘Bahujan Hitaya: Bahujan Sukhaya’, meaning 'for the happiness of many, for the welfare of many'. It broadcasts in 23 languages, 179 dialects from 479 stations across the country, reaching nearly 92 per cent of the area and 99.2 per cent of the total population of the country. It marked its silver jubilee on 23 November 2022, and has embraced technology, reflected in the fact that over 240 radio services of All India Radio are live-streamed on NewsOnAir App, Prasar Bharati’s official App.

Radio offers a variety of programmes that cater to different audiences in different contexts. For example, the popular ‘Mann ki Baat’ programme where the Prime Minister establishes a dialogue with the citizens on issues of day-to-day governance has completed its 96th episode on 25th December 2022, with more to follow this year. Private commercial radio stations and Community Radio Stations (CRS) also serve as platforms for a variety of programmes, catering to specific audiences and interests.
The number of private FM Radio stations has been increasing in recent years, as observed in the quarterly growth from 243 in the quarter ending December 2015 to 388 in quarter ending June 2022.

headings: Role of FM and CRS in Public Service during Pandemic
Growth Story of Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI)
explanations: Radio as mass media has delivered on their mandate of public service during pandemic by increasing outreach to even far-flung rural areas, targeting local and well-defined communities. Radio waves travelled without interruption for the larger public cause and functioned as a channel for empowerment, becoming a medium for information dissemination as well as virtual education.

Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI) has played a critical role in uplifting the economy and bringing it to the stature where it stands today. The journey of DPI has been remarkably memorable, dating to 2009, when Aadhaar was first launched. The three growth drivers that acted as catalysts for DPI growth were favourable demographics, vast expansion of the middle-class, and digital behaviour patterns. By leveraging these growth drivers, India has built a competitive digital economy that empowers every individual and business to transact paperless and cashless. Aadhaar established the authentication framework for verifying the identity of beneficiaries of welfare schemes.

'MyScheme' is an e-Marketplace for schemes where users can look for suitable schemes based on their eligibility. It helps reduce users' time and effort by doing away with the requirement of searching multiple websites of government departments and studying multiple scheme guidelines to check their eligibility. The scheme also acts as the single national platform for launching any government scheme. As on 16 January, 2023, more than 181 Central and State/UT government schemes across 14 diverse categories have been hosted on the portal.
Data sourced from quarterly Performance Indicator Reports by TRAI (Telecom Regulatory Authority of India)

headings: Unified Mobile Application for New-Age Governance (UMANG)
explanations: UMANG is a mobile application launched by the government that enables citizens to access e-Government services offered by the Central and State Government in various sectors such as agriculture, education, health, housing, employees, pensioners, and students’ welfare, the Public Distribution System, and others. Until 16 January 2023, UMANG catered to about 21,869 services (1,672 Central and State Govt. services and 20197 Bill Payment services) under 310+ departments of Central Government and departments of 34 States/UTs. Over 4.9 crore users are registered and benefiting from services on UMANG. Four hundred and eighty-nine DBT (Direct Benefit Transfer) schemes were made live on UMANG until September 2022. During the trying times of Covid-19, UMANG was instrumental in making available the services of EPFO for claims related to Covid-19. Around 4.9 lakh advance claims in EPFO have been raised via the UMANG Platform until September 2022.

ONDC is a unique initiative that aims to go beyond the current platform-centric digital commerce model where the buyer and seller can use the same platform or application for transactions. ONDC is a network-based open protocol that would connect all the buyers and sellers on the network thus bringing better visibility across the Business-to-Consumer (B2C) & Business-to-Business (B2B) landscape. In the ONDC framework, consumers can potentially discover any seller, product, or service by using any compatible application or platform. This will increase the freedom of choice for the consumers and will enable them to match demand with the nearest available supply, allowing them to choose their preferred local businesses. ONDC’s beta test in the city of Bengaluru is a major first step in operationalising a network approach to e-commerce as an alternative to a platform-centric approach. The open network system will make the e-Commerce landscape more inclusive, accessible, and experience-driven for all consumers and sellers, especially for small businesses that will exercise more freedom in business decision-making.

headings: Web 3.0 and Open Credit Enablement Network (OCEN)
explanations: The OpenForge platform is a government initiative to promote open collaborative software development of e-governance applications. As of 16th January 2023, it has 10,328 users and 2,205 projects.

With the aim of strengthening the AI ecosystem in the country, the government has launched a national AI portal. As of 16th January 2023, the portal has published 1724 articles, 829 news items, 276 videos, 127 research reports, and 120 government initiatives, all related to AI.

Launched in July 2022, Bhashini is a national language translation mission aimed at nurturing Indian language technologies and solutions as a public good. The Digital India Bhashini portal is a public digital platform with 260 open-source API-based AI models available for speech-to-text conversion, machine translation, and text-to-speech conversion in 11 Indian languages and English for various purposes. This initiative has the potential to bring internet access and other digital resources to millions of Indians in their own languages.

Web 3.0 is the next generation of web technologies that are changing the entire experience of the internet. The Open Credit Enablement Network (OCEN) is one of the standards that is being hailed as a major shift in how lending and borrowing will be conducted in the future. This initiative is aimed at democratising lending operations and ensuring small borrowers are able to avail themselves of the best credit terms.

India's digital public infrastructure is finding global resonance. The increasing adoption of digital services in areas like healthcare, agriculture, FinTech, education, and skilling during COVID-19 indicates its massive potential across economic sectors. Low-cost accessibility (Aadhaar), citizen-centric services like Unified Payments Interface (UPI), large-scale adoption and reach (DigiLocker, MyGov), and the successful vaccine journey through Co-Win are a few notable milestones in India's public digital infrastructure journey.

headings: UPI Transactions over the Calendar Years
explanations: Unified Payments Interface (UPI) is a system that empowers and knits multiple bank accounts into a single mobile application (of any participating bank), merging several banking features, seamless fund routing and merchant payments into one hood. It also caters to the “Peer to Peer” collection request, which can be scheduled and paid as per requirement and convenience. Introduced in 2016 to revolutionize the payment landscape through universal operability, single payment address, and low-cost mobile-first payment system, UPI has acted as a positive disruption towards enabling greater digital payments adoption in the country. UPI is a single mobile application for accessing different bank accounts. It can be accessed on all major platforms, such as Android and iOS.

The journey of UPI has been fascinating. The number of banks that became part of the real-time payment system increased from 35 in December 2017 to more than 380 in December 2022. Though pre-existing payment modes such as debit cards, credit cards, National Electronic Funds Transfer (NEFT) and Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) have grown over time, UPI has shown a quantum jump comparatively to become one of the preferred modes of payment. In FY19, UPI accounted for 17 per cent of the country's total 3,100 crore digital transactions. The next fiscal year saw UPI’s share rise to more than 27 per cent as it processed 1,250 crore transactions out of 4,600 crore digital transactions. In FY22, UPI accounted for 52 per cent of the total 8,840 crore financial digital transactions. On average, between FY19-22 (calendar year), growth in UPI-based transactions in value and volume terms have been 121 per cent and 115 per cent, respectively. Recently, in Dec 2022, UPI touched its highest-ever mark with 782 crore transactions worth ₹12.8 lakh crore.

From the above graph, it can be seen that the UPI transactions value and volume has been continuously increasing from 2017 until 2022. In FY19, UPI accounted for 17 per cent of the country's total 3,100 crore digital transactions. The next fiscal year saw UPI's share rise to more than 27 per cent as it processed 1,250 crore transactions out of 4,600 crore digital transactions. In FY22, UPI accounted for 52 per cent of the total 8,840 crore financial digital transactions.

UPI has acted as a positive disruption towards enabling greater digital payments adoption in the country. UPI has made digital payments more accessible to consumers and merchants alike as it is a single mobile application for accessing different bank accounts. The system is user-friendly and fast, and as a result, it has gained popularity amongst users. The introduction of UPI has made financial transactions more convenient, secure, and cost-effective for users. It has also made the collection request for Peer to Peer payments simpler and more efficient.

UPI has become a critical lifeline especially for small and micro merchants during COVID-19 pandemic. It has processed over 2,922 crore contactless merchants’ transactions with a total value of over ₹21.7 lakh crore in FY23 till December 2022. The successful deployment of UPI and its international arm NPCIL is being pushed by NPCI for acceptance in international markets such as Singapore, UAE, France, the Netherlands among others. Tech companies are increasingly leveraging the power of UPI to expand the digital ecosystem, which has led to a significant acceleration in the pace of financial inclusion. The journey of UPI is envisioned to help accelerate the process of financial inclusion and digital adoption in India by creating a more prosperous and inclusive ecosystem that can accommodate larger sections of the population in times to come.

GST, with its end-to-end digitisation of all processes, has improved governance and formalisation of the economy. The seamless generation of e-way bills and electronic toll collections have augmented better tax collections for the government. It has not just helped in curbing tax evasion but generated trust for small businesses through monitoring compliance.

The government has taken initiatives towards empowering individuals with control over their data to access essential services related to finance, health, education, and skills digitally. The Account Aggregator (AA) is a global techno-legal framework that enables individuals to share their financial data quickly and securely, with their consent, with any regulated third-party financial institution of their choice. The AA framework is currently live across over 110 crore of bank accounts.

headings: Reforms in Energy and Power Sector
explanations: The Indian start-up environment witnessed a turning point in FY15 due to reforms led by the government which changed the landscape of the ecosystem. Additionally, inherent advantages like demography, technological developments, entrepreneurial spirit, and market size have also contributed to its growth. The 'Stand-up India' scheme launched in January 2016 has led to the recognition of over 84,000 start-ups in India.

India aims to strengthen the up-and-coming drone industry under 'Drone Shakti', for which drone start-ups and Drone-as-a-Service (DrAAS) are being promoted. The airspace has now been opened up as a green zone for flying drones up to 400 feet, with a Production-Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme for drones and drone import policy. The private equity investments in the agri-tech space have also witnessed an increase of more than 50% per annum to aggregate approximately ₹6600 crore.

As the digital space widens to bring in newer services, appropriate regulations become paramount. Governments worldwide have adopted or are introducing legislation to provide a foundation for robust data governance complemented and advanced with the help of standard, open, and interoperable protocols that increase the choice of digital services available to a user, such as the Data Empowerment & Protection Architecture.

The targeted increase in investment is seen across all infrastructure sectors, with NIP providing a forward-looking roadmap of investible projects. PM GatiShakti aims to accelerate infrastructure development by integrating the seven engines of growth, including traditional infrastructure sectors like roads and railways, and untapped sectors like inland water transport and civil aviation. The focus is also on improving coordination among different stakeholders and ministries to increase efficiency and effectiveness of investments.

Reforms in the energy and power sector will help fast-track India's progress in the next 25 years due to high demand for energy from all sectors. The reforms focus on making electricity affordable, reliable, and sustainable, and the step towards cleaner sources of energy through solar and wind power.

headings: The importance of reliable power availability for India’s manufacturing sector
Challenges posed by new technologies and the government’s commitment towards maintaining pace with the digital landscape
Synergy between physical and digital infrastructure for India's growth story
explanations: The reliable availability of power is critical for India’s aspirations for the manufacturing sector to be fulfilled. It is important for the government and the private sector to work together to increase the share of renewables. This will ensure a gradual but calibrated energy transition, meeting the country’s sustainability targets and giving primacy to its national developmental requirements.

With the advent of new technologies, there are new regulatory challenges. Technology and innovation are, per se, neither constructive nor destructive. The government is committed to keeping pace with the digital landscape developments including those related to legislations and frameworks. While the digital journey started with Aadhaar as a medium for service delivery at the doorstep, UPI strengthened the digital payment infrastructure. With other initiatives like Co-WIN, e-RUPI, TReDS, Account Aggregators, ONDC, etc. at different stages of implementation, India has developed a unique and cogent digital story to tell.

In sum, the synergy between physical and digital infrastructure will be one of the defining features of India's future growth story. The government's commitment towards digital landscape developments and initiatives like Co-WIN, e-RUPI, TReDS, Account Aggregators, ONDC, etc. at different stages of implementation play a major role in this synergy between physical and digital infrastructure. There is much untapped potential in India's digital public infrastructure space.
